definition: A form of monochasium in which the lateral branches arisealternately on opposite sides of the false axis; -- called alsoscorpioid cyme. --Cin*cin"nal (#), a.
A thicket of canes. Ellicott.
In a running or hasty manner; carelessly.
One who caricatures.
The Angora goat. See Angora goat, under Angora.
A native of China; a Chinese.
An instrument for cutting into the fetal head, to facilitatedelivery.
Methyl alcohol, CH3OH; -- also, by extension, any one in thehomologous series of paraffine alcohols of which methyl alcohol isthe type.
A red nose. Shak.
Without a carpet.
A method of taking photographic pictures, on paper sensitizedwith iodide of silver; -- also called Talbotype, from the inventor,Mr. Fox. Talbot.
Made or contrived for getting small sums of money from theignorant or unwary; as, a catchpenny book; a catchpenny show.-- n.
Relating to, or having the properties of, a caustic curveformed by reflection. See Caustic, a. Nichol.
Of or pertaining to the thigh or leg, or to any of the partscalled crura; as, the crural arteries; crural arch; crural canal;crural ring.
The first word of any page of a book after the first, insertedat the right hand bottom corner of the preceding page for theassistance of the reader. It is seldom used in modern printing.
A blowing together, as of many instruments in a concert, or ofmany fires in a foundry. [R.]  Bacon.
A joint cause. Fotherby.

Any device in which an imperfectly conducting contact betweenpieces of metal or other conductors loosely resting against eachother is materially improved in conductivity by the influence ofHertzian waves; -- so called by Sir O. J. Lodge in 1894 on theassumption that the impact of the electic waves caused the looselyconnected parts to cohere, or weld together, a condition easilydestroyed by tapping. A common form of coherer as used in wirelesstelegraphy consists of a tube containing filings (usually a pinch ofnickel and silver filings in equal parts) between terminal wires orplugs (called conductor plugs).
See Chrysoberyl.
The dried meat of the cocoanut, from which cocoanut oil isexpressed. [Written also cobra, copperah, coppra.]
One who is compos mentis. [Colloq.]
Of, pertaining to, or derived from, the celandine. Cheidonicacid, a weak acid extracted fron the celandine (Chelidonium majus),as a white crystalline substance.
Controversial. [Obs.] Bp. Hall.
An offering made to the church at the interment of a dead body.Blackstone.

A name applied to various marine univalve shells; esp. to thoseof the genus Strombus, which are of large size. S. gigas is the largepink West Indian conch. The large king, queen, and cameo conchs areof the genus Cassis. See Cameo.
The act of certifying.
The native name of certain South American monkeys of the genusAteles, esp. A. paniscus. The black-faced coaita is Ateles ater. SeeIllustration in Appendix.
Rendering a criminal process civil. [Obs.]
Having the nerves spring from the midrib.
Frequent; numerous. [Obs.] Goodwin.
Of or pertaining to croup; resembling or indicating croup; as,a croupy cough.

A curve invented by Diocles, for the purpose of solving twocelebrated problems of the higher geometry; viz., to trisect a planeangle, and to construct two geometrical means between two givenstraight lines.
A judicial court of chancery, which in England and in theUnited States is distinctively a court with equity jurisdiction.
One of the Cystidea.
A continuous noise or murmur.The chide of streams. Thomson.

A constellation of the northern hemisphere, situated betweenCapheus and Perseus; -- so called in honor of the wife of Cepheus, afabuolous king of Ethiopia. Cassiopeia's Chair, a group of six stars,in Cassiopeia, somewhat resembling a chair.
With arms crossed.
In the manner of a child; in a trifling way; in a weak orfoolish manner.
A comfit; a confection. [Obs.]At supper eat a pippin roasted and sweetened with sugar of roses andcaraway confects. Harvey.
A salt of capric acid.
See Camass.
A scroll; a writing; a schedule. [Obs.]
To connect, in a series of links or ties; to chain. E. Darwin.
An apparatus for conveying and distributing heat, especially bymeans of hot water circulating in tubes.
The act, process, or result of carburizing.
Crabbed; difficult, or perplexing. "Persius is crabby, becauseancient." Marston.
A performer on the cornet or horn.
Of the nature of a cataract in the eye; affected with cataract.
Tending to counteract.
Work done by a cooper in making or repairing barrels, casks,etc.; the business of a cooper.
Of or pertaining to catechu or its derivatives. See catechin.
See Commandery.

False accusation of crime or offense, or a malicious and falserepresentation of the words or actions of another, with a view toinjure his good name.The calumniation of her principal counselors. Bacon.
Heretical.
To act as captain of; to lead. [R.]Men who captained or accompanied the exodus from existing forms.Lowell.
To brood; to incubate. [Obs.][Tortoises] covey a whole year before they hatch. Holland.
A slender prolongation of the receptacle as an axis between thecarpels, as in Geranium and many umbelliferous plants.
The Brazilian wax palm. See Wax palm.
A genus of bulbous-rooted plants found in many parts of Europe,including the meadow saffron.
An obstetrical instrument for performing cephalotripsy.
Having a plump, short face.
See Cerate.
A little can or cup. "And let me the canakin clink." Shak.
A tie consisting of a series of connected iron bars or rods.
See Sill., n. a foundation.
See Caramel.
An instrument for drawing lines through a point, or linesconverging to a center.
The act or practice of opening cysts; esp., the operation ofcutting into the bladder, as for the extraction of a calculus.
The state, characteristic, or quality of being circumstantial;particularity or minuteness of detail. "I will endeavor to describewith sufficient circumstantiality." De Quincey.
One who makes a compact.
To drink deeply or freely in compliment; to take in a carousal;to engage in drunken revels.He had been aboard, carousing to his mates. Shak.
One of the Cystidea.
A gratuitous loan.
Of or pertaining to the cerris.Chaplets green of cerrial oak. Dryden.
The light of a candle.Never went by candlelight to bed. Dryden.

The crested screamer of Brazil (Palamedea, or Chauna,chavaria), so called in imitation of its notes; -- called alsochauna, and faithful kamichi. It is often domesticated and is usefulin guarding other poultry. See Kamichi.
One who charters; esp. one who hires a ship for a voyage.

To imply as an attribute.The word "white" denotes all white things, as snow, paper, the foamof the sea, etc., and ipmlies, or as it was termed by the schoolmen,connotes, the attribute "whiteness." J. S. Mill.
Relating to, or having the character of, a cicatrix. Dunglison.
A pipe or duct used to convey hot air or steam.Subterranean caliducts have been introduced. Evelyn.
Absolutely; directly; expressly; positively; as, to affirmcategorically.
A panel deeply recessed in the ceiling of a vault, dome, orportico; a caisson.
A concert for two or more principal instruments, withorchestral accompaniment. Also adjectively; as, concertante parts.
Distinguished by opposite qualities. J. Goodwin.
A comedian. [Obs.] Steele.
To roll or wind together; to roll or twist one part on another.Then Satan first knew pain, And writhed him to and fro convolved.Milton.
Christlike. H. Bushnell.
See centare.

Suitable; adapted; fit; corresponding; congruous; conformable;in accord or agreement; obedient; willing.Action correspondent or repugnant unto the law. Hooker.As fast the correspondent passions rise. Thomson.I will be correspondent to command. Shak.
In a cheerful manner, gladly.
In a coarse manner; roughly; rudely; inelegantly; uncivilly;meanly.

A body of ore, usually of elongated form, extending downward ina vein. Raymond. Chimney board, a board or screen used to close afireplace; a fireboard.-- Chimney cap, a device to improve the draught of a chimney, bypresenting an exit aperture always to leeward.-- Chimney corner, the space between the sides of the fireplace andthe fire; hence, the fireside.-- Chimney hook, a hook for holding pats and kettles over a fire, --Chimney money, hearth money, a duty formerly paid in England for eachchimney.-- Chimney pot (Arch.), a cylinder of earthenware or sheet metalplaced at the top of a chimney which rises above the roof.-- Chimney swallow. (Zoöl.) (a) An American swift (Chæturepelasgica) which lives in chimneys. (b) In England, the commonswallow (Hirundo rustica).-- Chimney sweep, Chimney sweeper, one who cleans chimneys of soot;esp. a boy who climbs the flue, and brushes off the soot.
To surround with a rampart or wall. Johnson.
Slow; tardy; dilatory; causing delay.

To make remarks, observations, or criticism; especially, towrite notes on the works of an author, with a view to illustrate hismeaning, or to explain particular passages; to write annotations; --often followed by on or upon.A physician to comment on your malady. Shak.Critics . . . proceed to comment on him. Dryden.I must translate and comment. Pope.
To pour round; to spread round.His army circumfused on either wing. Milton.
One who chaffs.

Designating, pertaining to, or characterized by, that form ofpulse tracing, or sphygmogram, in which the descending portion of thecurve is marked by secondary elevations due to two or more expansionsof the artery in the same beat. -- Ca*tac"rotism (#), n.
Of or pertaining to Chaldes.-- n.

Descent of related families; distinction between the members ofa family according to their ages. Marks of cadency (Her.), bearingsindicating the position of the bearer as older or younger son, or asa descendant of an older or younger son. See Difference (Her.).
A coheir.
Of or pertaining to carcinology.
One who adheres to the constitution of the country.Bolingbroke.
One who, or that which, circulates.
Expense; cost. [Obs.] Chaucer.
A monster, in the shape, of a three-headed dog, guarding theentrance into the infernal regions, Hence: Any vigilant custodian orguardian, esp. if surly.
A very broad and heavy wooden collar which certain offenders inChina are compelled to wear as a punishment.
Full of scars. Craig.

A kind of pie or pudding made by lining a dish with slices ofbread, and filling it with bread soaked in milk, and baked. CharlotteRusse (, or Charlotte à la russe Etym: [F., lit., Russian charlotte](Cookery), a dish composed of custard or whipped cream, inclosed insponge cake.
To be of importance. [Obs.]Which to deny concerns more than avails. Shak.
The faculty or propensity which has to do with concentratingthe intellectual the intellectual powers. Combe.
The state of being contemporaneous.The lines of contemporaneity in the oölitic system. J. Philips.
That may be compacted.
Adorned with flowers (usually fleurs-de-lis) so divided thatthe tops appear on one side and the bottoms on the others; -- said ofany ordinary.
Conducive; tending.Conducent to the good success of this business. Abp. Laud.
The interrogating or questioning of a witness by the partyagainst whom he has been called and examined. See Examination.
A band of singers and dancers.The Grecian tragedy was at first nothing but a chorus of singers.Dryden.
Connivance. [Obs.]
A West Indian wood, used for making flutes and other musicalinstruments.
See Colophony.
An application to the eye, usually an eyewater.
Twisting.
To chirp, as a young bird.
A genus of ruminants, including the red deer and other alliedspecies.

Having a body; consisting of, or pertaining to, a material bodyor substance; material; -- opposed to spiritual or immaterial.His omnipotence That to corporeal substance could add Speed almostspiritual. Milton.Corporeal property, such as may be seen and handled (as opposed toincorporeal, which can not be seen or handled, and exists only incontemplation). Mozley & W.
Having a full crop or belly; satiated. Milton.
To act in harmony or conjunction; to form combined plans.The ministers of Denmark were appointed to concert with Talbot. Bp.Burnet
A sedgelike plant (Cyperus esculentus) producing edible tubers,native about the Mediterranean, now cultivated in many regions; theearth almond.
One who confesses to a priest. [Obs.] Bacon.
A name applied loosely to several plants of different genera,esp. the comfrey.
In a cleanly manner.
Of or pertaining to the cedar or its wood. [R.]
(Bot.) A leguminous herb (Onobrychis Caput-galli), having smallspiny-crested pods.

An exhibition in which a series of views in various parts ofthe world is seen reflected by mirrors through a series of lenses,with such illumination, etc., as will make the views most closelyrepresent reality.
To context. [Obs.] Boyle.
See Barwood.
Procrastination; a putting off till to-morrow. [Obs.]
Allied or pertaining to cinchona, or to the plants that produceit.
The quality of being commersurable. Sir T. Browne.
A grallatorial bird of Europe (Cursorius cursor), remarkablefor its speed in running. Sometimes, in a wider sense, applied torunning birds of the Ostrich family.
Of the nature of, or pertaining to, chorea; convulsive.
One who writes a commentary or comments; an expositor; anannotator.The commentator's professed object is to explain, to enforce, toillustrate doctrines claimed as true. Whewell.
The operation of making an opening in the gall bladder, as forthe removal of a gallstone.
Pertaining to a chorepiscopus or his change or authority.

Anything which serves to compress; as:(a) (Anat.) A muscle that compresses certain parts.(b) (Surg.) An instrument for compressing an artery (esp., thefemoral artery) or other part.(c) An apparatus for confining or flattening between glass plates anobject to be examined with the microscope; -- called alsocompressorium.(d) (Mach.) A machine for compressing gases; especially, an aircompressor.
One who performs a public religious rite; -- appliedparticularly to an officiating priest in the Roman Catholic Church,as distinguished from his assistants.
A body or collection of cousins; the whole number of personswho stand in the relation of cousins to a given person or persons.
A south American fresh water fish of the genus Serrasalmo ofmany species, remakable for its voracity. When numerous they attackman or beast, often with fatal results.
The state of quality of being calm; quietness; tranquillity;self-repose.The gentle calmness of the flood. Denham.Hes calmness was the repose of conscious power. E. Everett.
A dyestuff consisting of the dried bodies of females of theCoccus cacti, an insect native in Mexico, Central America, etc., andfound on several species of cactus, esp. Opuntia cochinellifera.
A foul vein, like chalcedony, in some precious stones.
A room for cookery; a kitchen; the galley or caboose of a ship.Sir W. Raleigh.
One who compares.
Belonging to the circle of the sciences, or to a cyclopedia; ofthe nature of a cyclopedia; hence, of great range, extent, or amount;as, a man of cyclopedic knowledge.
In a conscious manner; with knowledge of one's own mentaloperations or actions.
Worthy of condemnation; blamable; culpable.
Passing opportunities seized; snatches.It has been writ by catches with many intervals. Locke.
The lily of the valley.

A severe paroxysmal pain in the abdomen, due to spasm,obstruction, or distention of some one of the hollow viscera. Hepaticcolic, the severe pain produced by the passage of a gallstone fromthe liver or gall bladder through the bile duct.-- Intestinal colic, or Ordinary colic, pain due to distention ofthe intestines by gas.-- Lead colic, Painter's colic, a violent form of intestinal colic,associated with obstinate constipation, produced by chronic leadpoisoning.-- Renal colic, the severe pain produced by the passage of acalculus from the kidney through the ureter.-- Wind colic. See Intestinal colic, above.
Familiar talk; easy, unrestrained, unceremonious conversation.Friends' confabulations are comfortable at all times, as fire inwinter. Burton.
One belonging to, or living in, a cloister; a recluse.
A cranial development supposed to indicate a combativedisposition.
To infold; to embrace. [Obs.]Seemed to comply, Cloudlike, the daintie deitie. Herrick.

Tending to one point; approaching each other; convergent; as,converging lines. Whewell. Converging rays(Opt.), rays of light,which, proceeding from different points of an object, tend toward asingle point.-- Converging series (Math.), a series in which if an indefinitelygreat number of terms be taken, their sum will become indefinitelynear in value to a fixed quantity, which is called the sum of theseries; -- opposed to a diverging series.
To organic cohesion of different circled in a flower; adnation.

Of, pertaining to, or resembling, cheese; having the qualitiesof cheese; cheesy. Caseous degeneration, a morbid process, inscrofulous or consumptive persons, in which the products ofinflammation are converted into a cheesy substance which is neitherabsorbed nor organized.
The process of testing the bleaching power of any combinationof chlorine.
See Cozenage.

Legal or noral qualification, as of age, residence, character,etc., necessary for certain purposes, as for holding office, formarrying, for making contracts, will, etc.; legal power or right;competency. Capacity for heat, the power of absorbing heat.Substances differ in the amount of heat requisite to raise them agiven number of thermometric degrees, and this difference is themeasure of, or depends upon, whzt is called their capacity for heat.See Specific heat, under Heat.
A forest composed of stunted trees and thorny bushes, found inareas of small rainfall in Brazil.
One who conspires in a fraud.

That which drives or carries; as: (a) A piece whichcommunicates to an object in a lathe the motion of the face plate; alathe dog. (b) A spool holder or bobbin holder in a braiding machine.(c) A movable piece in magazine guns which transfers the cartridge toa position from which it can be thrust into the barrel. Carrierpigeon (Zoöl.), a variety of the domestic pigeon used to conveyletters from a distant point to to its home.-- Carrier shell (Zoöl.), a univalve shell of the genus Phorus; --so called because it fastens bits of stones and broken shells to itsown shell, to such an extent as almost to conceal it.-- Common carrier (Law.) See under Common, a.
One who advocates the practice of cremation.
Capable of being consumed; that may be destroyed, dissipated,wasted, or spent. "Consumable commodities." Locke.
To produce counter irritation in; to treat with one morbidprocess for the purpose of curing another.
A key; a glossary.
Charlatanry.
Negligence or fault, as distinguishable from dolus (deceit,fraud), which implies intent, culpa being imputable to defect ofintellect, dolus to defect of heart. Wharton.
A short passage connecting two sections, but not forming partof either; a short coda.
To form flesh; to become like flesh. Sir M. Hale.

The system of commercial blockade aiming to exclude Englandfrom commerce with the Continent instituted by the Berlin decree,which Napoleon I. issued from Berlin Nov. 21, 1806, declaring theBritish Isles to be in a state of blockade, and British subjects,property, and merchandise subject to capture, and excluding Britishships from all parts of Europe under French dominion. The retaliatorymeasures of England were followed by the Milan decree, issued byNapoleon from Milan Dec. 17, 1807, imposing further restrictions, anddeclaring every ship going to or from a port of England or hercolonies to be lawful prize.
A plant coif or skullcap. Same as Calotte. B. Jonson.
Of or pertaining to, or derived from, carmine. Carminic acid.Same as Carmine, 3.
A former gold coin of Germany worth nearly five dollars; also,a gold coin of Sweden worth nearly five dollars.
Controversy. [Obs.] Spenser.
Same as Catchup, and Ketchup.
Fragmental; made up of brokas, sandstone is a clastic rock.
One of the opium alkaloids; a white crystalline substance,C18H21NO3, similar to and regarded as a derivative of morphine, butmuch feebler in its action; -- called also codeia.
Under way and moving as nearly as possible toward the directionfrom which the wind blows; -- said of a sailing vessel.
Of or pertaining to a cynosure.
A wheel with cogs or teeth set at right angles to its plane; --called also a contrate wheel or face wheel.
Having or bearing cupeles; cupuliferous.
See Caoutchin.
A strainer. See Colander.

To grow in clusters or assemble in groups; to gather or unitein a cluster or clusters.His sunny hair Cluster'd about his temples, like a god's. Tennyson.The princes of the country clustering together. Foxe.
One who, or that which, covers.
To gather into a small round mass.
The quality of being concrete.
An apparatus to assist in locating the center of a cyclone.
Of or pertaining to California.-- n.

An inscription, monogram, or cipher, containing the place anddate of publication, printer's name, etc., formerly placed on thelast page of a book.The colophon, or final description, fell into disuse, and . . . thetitle page had become the principal direct means of identifying thebook. De Morgan.The book was uninjured from title page to colophon. Sir W. Scott.
Making warm; heating. [R.]
In a costive manner.
In a concise manner; briefly.
A provider; a purveyor; a caterer. [Obs.] Chaucer.
To throw together, or to throw. [Obs.] Bp. Montagu.

A carnivorous American Jurassic dinosaur allied to the EuropeanMegalosaurus. The animal was nearly twenty feet in length, and theskull bears a bony horn core on the united nasal bones. SeeIllustration in Appendix.
To strike together so as to produce a ringing metallic sound.The fierce Caretes . . . clanged their sounding arms. Prior.
Marked with closely set ribs or ridges.
A stream; (Geol.)
A light, loose dress or robe. [Also written camus.] [Obs.]All in a camis light of purple silk. Spenser.
The jaws, or the fleshy parts about them. See Chap. "Open yourchaps again." Shak.
A heater; one who, or that which, makes hot, as a stove, etc.
A cuckold maker. [R.] Jordan.
Closed while too cold to become thoroughly welded; -- said of aforging or casting.-- n.
A Chinese governor general; a tsung tu (which see).
A white amorphous substance, the insoluble part of cherry gum;-- called also meta-arabinic acid.
A burning or searing, as of morbid flesh, with a hot iron, orby application of a caustic that will burn, corrode, or destroyanimal tissue.
Cast or laid aside; as, cast-off clothes.
Pertaining to conversation; in the manner of one conversing;as, a conversational style. Thackeray.
Bearded or tufted with hairs. Gray.
A flatterer or sycophant. [Obs.] "Take heed of theseclawbacks." Latimer.
See Shad. [Obs.]
The quality of being commutable; interchangeableness.
A genus of plants (Briza); quaking grass.
Having much hair; hairy. [R.]
One who works at cabbling.
A burglar. [Slang]
A machine for cropping, as for shearing off bolts or rod iron,or for facing cloth.
That can not be checked or restrained.
One who plays on a crowd; a fiddler. [Obs.] "Some blindcrowder." Sir P. Sidney.
To make the noise, or utter the call, of a brooding hen. Ray.

A process of fecundation in which the pollen tube penetrates tothe embryosac through the tissue of the chalaza, instead of enteringthrough the micropyle. It was originally discovered by Treub inCasuarina, and has since been found to occur regularly in thefamilies Betulaceæ and Juglandaceæ. Partial chalazogamy is found inUlmus, the tube here penetrating the nucleus midway between thechalaza and micropyle. --Chal`a*zo*gam"ic (#), a.
Hooded; cowled.
One who exhibits moving pictures or who takes chronophotographsby the cinematograph. -- Cin`e*mat`o*graph"ic (#), a. --Cin`e*mat`o*graph"ic*al*ly (#), adv.
The act or process by which chyle is formed from food in animalbodies; chylification, -- a digestive process.
Bearing cirri, as many plants and animals.
Inclination; ascent or descent; a gradient. [R.]
The puffin.
Existing at, or dating from, birth; pertaining to one frombirth; born with one; connate; constitutinal; natural; as, acongenital deformity. See Connate.
In a cloudy manner; darkly; obscurely. Dryden.
A bell tower, esp. one built separate from a church.Many of the campaniles od Italy are lofty and magnificent atructures.Swift.
An act of condescension. [Obs.] Dr. H. More.
To fertilize, as the stigmas of a flower or plant, with thepollen from another individual of the  same species.
Cherry-colored; a light bright red; --- applied to textilefabrics, especially silk.
A coachman [Slang]
Having a head; -- applied chiefly to the Cephalata, a divisionof mollusks.

Lying down with the head raised, which distinguishes theposture of couchant from that of dormant, or sleeping; -- said of alion or other beast. Couchant and levant (Law), rising up and lyingdown; -- said of beasts, and indicating that they have been longenough on land, not belonging to their owner, to lie down and rise upto feed, -- such time being held to include a day and night at theleast. Blackstone.
The science or practice of instructing by questions andanswers.

Capable of being conceived, imagined, or understood. "Anyconceivable weight." Bp. Wilkins.It is not conceivable that it should be indeed that very person whoseshape and voice it assumed. Atterbury.-- Con*ceiv"a*ble*ness, n.-- Con*ceiv"a*bly, adv.
That branch of physics which treats of heat and electricity. R.Park.
Lying down; recumbent. [R.]
A lively dance (called also galliard), the steps of which wereregulated by the number five. [Obs.] Nares. Shak.
Plaited lengthwise and twisted in addition, as the bud of themorning-glory. Gray.
Capable of being commuted or interchanged.The predicate and subject are not commutable. Whately.
The head violinist or leader of the strings in an orchestra;the sub-leader of the orchestra; concert master.
The doctrine or theory that psychical phenomena are functionsor products of the brain only.
An East Indian Weight of 11/3 pounds.
The art or act of encamping; the making or laying out of acamp.

A brief compilation or composition, containing the principalheads, or general principles, of a larger work or system; anabridgment; an epitome; a compend; a condensed summary.A short system or compendium of a sience. I. Watts.
A disease or diseases, or adventitious circumstances orconditions, coexistent with and modifying a primary disease, but notnecessarily connected with it.
Of or pertaining to a chord.
Having the form of a cyme.
A white waxy solid obtained from Chinese wax, and by thedistillation of cerotin.
The American red squirrel (Sciurus Hudsonius); -- so calledfrom its cry.
A corporal's office.
Bulk; largeness. [Obs.] See Size.

An officer of the peace whose principal duty is to inquire,with the help of a jury, into the cause of any violent, sudden ormysterious death, or death in prison, usually on sight of the bodyand at the place where the death occurred. [In England formerly alsowritten and pronounced crowner.]
In the manner of a kitchen; in connection with a kitchen orcooking.
Having a crimped appearance; frizzly; as, the crimpy wool ofthe Saxony sheep.
Excessively. [Low]He's so consumedly pround of it. Thackeray.
Characterized by cunning or shrewdness; crafty. [R.]
To make the noise of the cuckoo. [Obs. or R.]Constant cuckoos cook on every side. The Silkworms (1599).
One who chirps, or is cheerful.
Mutually assisting or operating; helping. J. Philips.
Diseased or gangrenous condition of the mouth.
The aggregate of risks covered by the terms of a contract ofinsurance.
The doctrine that the geological changes in the earth's crusthave been caused by the sudden action of violent physical causes; --opposed to the doctrine of uniformism.
A circular frame on which cadgers carry hawks for sale.
In a causative manner.
A soluble product (proteose) formed in the gastric andpancreatic digestion of casein and caseinogen.
Having the nature, qualities, taste, form, consistency, orappearance of cheese.
Bearing or producing cells.
Having no cubs. Byron.
See Chebacco.
One engaged in a crusade; as, the crusaders of the Middle Ages.Azure-eyed and golden-haired, Forth the young crusaders fared.Longfellow.
The condition, character, or conduct of a cotquean. [Obs.] B.Jonson.
An associate in an act; a coworker. Drayton.
Belonging to a covenant. Specifically, belonging to the ScotchCovenanters.Be they covenanting traitors, Or the brood of false Argyle Aytoun.
A state of confusion.  Norris.
Frivolous or sophistical objection. [Obs.] Hooker.
a dry fruit or pod which is made up of several parts orcarpels, and opens to discharge the seeds, as, the capsule of thepoppy, the flax, the lily, etc.
To manage a canoe, or voyage in a canoe.
Doubled and twisted thread, made of coarse silk, and used fortassels, fringes, etc. McElrath.
A liquid measure containing about three quarts.
See Coalgoose.
Characterized by concinnity; neat; elegant. [R.]The most concinnous and most rotund of proffessors, M. Heyne. DeQuiency.
A nitrogenous substance closely resembling diastase, obtainedfrom bran, and possessing the power of converting starch intodextrin, sugar, and lactic acid. Watts.
, a. Etym: [L. conversus, p.p. of convertere. See Convert.]Turned about; reversed in order or relation; reciprocal; as, aconverse proposition.
Overlapping, as the elytra of certain beetles.
A mechanocal contrivance for exercesing the fingers of apianist.
The chief police officer of a large city. [East Indies]
Same as Comfit. [Obs.]
Having the power or quality of conservation.
Colliding; clashing. [Obs.]
An armor of bony plates, somewhat resembling a cuirass.

A plant of the Pink family (Cucubalus bacciferus), bearingberries regarded as poisonous. Bladder campion, a plant of the Pinkfamily (Cucubalus Behen or Silene inflata), having a much inflatedcalyx. See Behen.-- Rose campion, a garden plant (Lychnis coronaria) with handsomecrimsome crimson flowers.
To indicate, as by a symptom, some method of treatment contraryto that which the general tenor of the case would seem to require.Contraindicating symptoms must be observed. Harvey.
A wooden lever with a movable iron hook. hear the end; -- usedfor canting or turning over heavy logs, etc. [U. S.] Bartlett.

A group of fishes, characterized by cartilaginous fins andskeleton. It includes both ganoids (sturgeons, etc.) and selachians(sharks), but is now often restricted to the latter. [Written alsoChondropterygia.]
A flatterer or deceiver; a sharper.
A raccoon. See Raccoon.
Fitly; suitably. [Obs.] "Well and covenably." Chaucer.
Capable of being pressed together or forced into a narrowercompass, as an elastic or spongy substance.
Having the leaves or petals arranged in the form of a cross;cruciform.
The body. In cuerpo, without full dress, so that the shape ofthe Body is exposed; hence, naked or uncovered.Exposed in cuerpo to their rage. Hudibras.
Complexity. Sir M. Hale.
The pupa state of certain insects, esp. of butterflies, fromwhich the perfect insect emerges. See Pupa, and Aurelia (a).
To talk in a light and familiar manner; to converse withoutform or ceremony; to gossip. Shak.To chat a while on their adventures. Dryden.
The development of cartilage.

from Cleave, v. t. To show the cloven foot or hoof, to reveal adevilish character, or betray an evil purpose, notwithstandingdisguises, -- Satan being represented dramatically and symbolicallyas having cloven hoofs.
A genus of showy herbaceous or shrubby plant, biought fromSouth America; slipperwort. It has a yellow or purple flower, oftenspotted or striped, the shape of which suggests its name.

A sudden stroke; an unexpected device or stratagem; -- a termused in various ways to convey the idea of promptness and force. Coupde grace (ke gr Etym: [F.], the stroke of mercy with which anexecutioner ends by death the sufferings of the condemned; hence, adecisive, finishing stroke.-- Coup de main (ke m Etym: [F.] (Mil.), a sudden and unexpectedmovement or attack.-- Coup de soleil (k Etym: [F.] (Med.), a sunstroke. See Sunstroke.-- Coup d'état (k Etym: [F.] (Politics), a sudden, decisive exerciseof power whereby the existing government is subverted without theconsent of the people; an unexpected measure of state, more or lessviolent; a stroke of policy.-- Coup d'oeil (k. Etym: [F.] (a) A single view; a rapid glance ofthe eye; a comprehensive view of a scene; as much as can be seen atone view. (b) The general effect of a picture. (c) (Mil.) The facultyor the act of comprehending at a glance the weakness or strength of amilitary position, of a certain arrangement of troops, the mostadvantageous position for a battlefield, etc.
One of a breed of small silky-haired terriers related to, butsmaller than, the Skye terrier, having smaller and perfectly erectears.
A deadly alkaloid extracted from the curare poison and from theStrychnos toxifera. It is obtained in crystalline colorless salts.

Relating to or resembling croup; especially, attended with theformation of a deposit or membrance like that found in membranouscroup; as, croupous laryngitis. Croupous pneumonia, pneumoniaattended with deposition of fibrinous matter in the air vesicles ofthe lungs; ordinary acute pneumonia.
See Calk.
Capable of being committed; liable to be committed. [R.] Sir T.Browne.
Act of concurring; coincidence; concurrence.The consilience of inductions takes place when one class of factscoincides with an induction obtained from another different class.Whewell.
A shallow tray divided into compartments or "boxes" for holdingtype.
Relating to the growth of hair. [R.]
A genus of small, hardy trees, including the hawthorn, muchused for ornamental purposes.
A Latin adverb and preposition, signifying against, contrary,in opposition, etc., entering as a prefix into the composition ofmany English words. Cf. Counter, adv. & pref.
Inheritance; heritage.
Born together; produced at the same time. Craig.
A girder.
A solution of chloride of line.

An apparatus consisting of a slowly revolving disk, usuallyregulated by  clockwork, by means of wich the action of externalagents, as light and gravity, on growing plants may be regulated oreliminated.
A natural or artificial purgation of any passage, as of themouth, bowels, etc.

One of the highest classes to which the objects of knowledge orthought can be reduced, and by which they can be arranged in asystem; an ultimate or undecomposable conception; a predicament.The categories or predicaments -- the former a Greek word, the latterits literal translation in the Latin language -- were intended byAristotle and his followers as an enumeration of all things capableof being named; an enumeration by the summa genera i.e., the mostextensive classes into which things could be distributed. J. S. Mill.
A colorless oily hydrocarbon, C6H5.C3H7, obtained by thedistillation of cuminic acid; -- called also cumol.
Capable of being crumbed or broken into small pieces.
Work looped or linked after the manner of a chain; chain stitchwork.
See Canine, a.
A distinction of character; a characteristic. [Obs.] Bp. Hall.
To gain advantage over by arts, stratagem, or deception; todecieve; to delude; to get around.I circumvented whom I could not gain. Dryden.
Having a covering of bony plates, resembling a cuirass;- saidof certain fishes.

Am alkaloidal principle obtained from the celandine, and namedfrom the red color of its salts, It is a coloriess crystallinesubstance, and acts as an acrid narcotic poison. It is identical withsanguinarine.
The act or process of subjecting anything to the action ofchlorine; especially, a process for the extraction of gold byexposure of the auriferous material to chlorine gas.
One of two small sticks of wood, ivory, etc., used by theChinese and Japanese to convey food to the mouth.
A crock; a jar. [Obs.] Chauser.
An order of reptiles including the crocodiles, gavials,alligators, and many extinct kinds.
A woven fabric originally made of camel's hair, now chiefly ofgoat's hair and silk, or of wool and cotton. [Sometimes writtencamelot and camblet.]
The fore part of a horse's head.
See Collodion.
One of two things compared together.
The act or habit of chattering. [Colloq.]
Climatic. Dunglison.
To adjust by mutual adaptations. R. Owen.
A created or high-topped crown or head. "Like the copple-crownthe lapwing has." T. Randolph.-- Cop"ple-crowned`, a.
An adjustable gage, with double points for transferringmeasurements from one timber to another, as the breadth of a mortiseto the place where the tenon is to be made. Knight.
Suitable to be eaten; eatable; esculent.Some herbs are most comestible. Sir T. Elyot.
Pertaining to Cyrene, in Africa; Cyrenaic.
Capable of being compelled or constrained. Blackstone.
One who, or that which, crisps or curls; an instrument formaking little curls in the nap of cloth, as in chinchilla.

Specious; plausible; having an appearance of right or justice."Colorable pretense for infidility." Bp. Stillingfleet.-- Col"or*a*ble*ness, n.-- Col"or*a*bly, adv.Colorable and subtle crimes, that seldom are taken within the walk ofhuman justice. Hooker.
A train whose coaches are connected so as to have through itsentire length a continuous corridor, into which the compartmentsopen. [Eng.]
Capable of being convicted. [R.] Ash.
The act of connoting; a making known or designating somethingadditional; implication of something more than is asserted.

An order of reptiles, including the tortoises and turtles,perculiar in having a part of the vertebræ, ribs, and sternum unitedwith the dermal plates so as to form a firm shell. The jaws arecovered by a horny beak. See Reptilia; also, Illust. in Appendix.
A material for carpeting or floor covering, made of ground corkand caoutchouc or India rubber.
See under Cloud.
The series or division of flowerless plants, or those neverhaving true stamens and pistils, but propagated by spores of variouskinds.
Quality of being calcareous.

A coil of small resistance and large inductance, used in analternating-current circuit to impede or throttle the current, or tochange its phase; --called also reactance coil or reactor, theseterms being now preferred in engineering usage.
To give birth; to produce young.This queen Genissa childing died. Warner.It chanced within two days they childed both. Latimer.
Pertaining to, or derived from, cahinca, the native name of aspecies of Brazilian Chiococca, perhaps C. recemosa; as, cahincicacid.
To make a series of small, sharp, rapidly repeated explosionsor sounds, as salt in fire; to crackle; to snap.
In a consuming manner.
Having a curved form.
An extravagant or absurd report or story; a fabricatedsensational report or statement; esp. one set afloat in thenewspapers to hoax the public.
A curve, of the fourth degree, first made use of by the Greekgeometer, Nicomedes, who invented it for the purpose of trisecting anangle and duplicating the cube.

Operating jointly to the same end. Coöperative society, asociety established on the principle of a joint-stock association,for the production of commodities, or their purchase and distributionfor consumption, or for the borrowing and lending of capital amongits members.-- Coöperative store, a store established by a coöperative society,where the members make their purchases and share in the profits orlosses.
Of or pertaining to Cambria or Wales.
A racing stroke, in which the swimmer, lying flat on the waterwith face submerged, takes alternate overhand arm strokes whilemoving his legs up and down alternately from the knee.
Knit or woven together; close; firm. [Obs.]The coats, without, are context and callous. Derham.
Agglutinant.-- n.
About the pole; -- applied to stars that revolve around thepole without setting; as, circumpolar stars.

A colorless volatile liquid, CHCl3, having an ethereal odor anda sweetish taste, formed by treating alcohol with chlorine and analkali. It is a powerful solvent of wax, resin, etc., and isextensively used to produce anæsthesia in surgical operations; alsoexternally, to alleviate pain.
The Mexican chery (Prunus Capollin).

A species of divination, which was perforned by letting down amirror into water, for a sick person to look at his face in it. Ifhis countenance appeared distorted and ghastly, it was an ill omen;if fresh and healthy, it was favorable.
One who has care or custody, as of some public building; akeeper or superintendent.
To curdle. [Obs.]See how thy blood cruddles at this. Bea
The two canonical books of the Old Testament in whichimmediately follow 2 Kings.

The hollow crust or hoof of a horse's foot, below the coronet,in which is the coffin bone. Coffin bone, the foot bone of the horseand allied animals, inclosed within the hoof, and corresponding tothe third phalanx of the middle finger, or toe, of most mammals.-- Coffin joint, the joint next above the coffin bone.
Measurement of the heart, as by percussion or auscultation.
A biennial plant of the Parsley family (Carum Carui). The seedshave an aromatic smell, and a warm, pungent taste. They are used incookery and confectionery, and also in medicine as a carminative.
One of the round variety of bacteria, a vegetable organism,generally less than a thousandth of a millimeter in diameter.
Like a clock or like clockwork; mechanical.Their services are clocklike, to be set Blackward and vorward attheir lord's command. B. Jonson.
Of or pertaining to a cosmorama.
Shaped like a club; grasped like, or used as, a club. Skelton.
A genus of grasses bearing spikes of flowers resembling thecornucopia in form.
Having no lower jaw; hence, fleshless. [R.] "Yellow, chaplessskulls." Shak.
A continuous level range of brick or stones of the same heightthroughout the face or faces of a building. Gwilt.
Consisting of, or containing, cells.
Mild chloride of mercury, Hg
Forwards; towards the head or anterior extremity of the body;opposed to caudad.

Rudeness compounded of haughtiness and contempt; scornfulinsolence; despiteful treatment; disdain; contemptuousness in act orspeech; disgrace.The oppressor's wrong, the proud man's contumely. Shak.Nothing aggravates tyranny so much as contumely. Burke.
One who make charts or maps.
A confrère. [Obs.]  Weever.

A term used in the Middle Ages for Spanish leather (goatskintanned and dressed), and hence, any leather handsomely finished,colored, gilded, or the like.Buskins he wore of costliest cordwain. Spenser.
See Electron.
See Cudweed.
In confidence; in reliance on secrecy.
Coccygeal. [R.]
Congenial. [Obs.]
A case in which certain goods, as tea, opium, etc., aretransported; hence, the quantity which such a case contains.
Same as Crenate.

Calcium carbonate, or carbonate of lime. It is rhombohedral inits crystallization, and thus distinguished from aragonite. Itincludes common limestone, chalk, and marble. Called also calc-sparand calcareous spar.
A curate; a pardon.
White or pale, as the effect of fear, or as the naturalcomplexion.Thou cream-faced loon. Shak.
Grossness of mind.
A capoch or hood. [Obs.] Spenser.
See Cercopod.
To circumgyrate. [Obs.]
See Catechise.
The act of torturing; torture; torment. [Obs.] Bp. Hall.
To con (a ship). [Obs.]
The keyboard of an organ, pianoforte, or harmonium.

To stand in opposition; to exhibit difference, unlikeness, oropposition of qualities.The joints which divide the sandstone contrast finely with thedivisional planes which separate the basalt into pillars. Lyell.
The state of being a coheir.
A condition in which, from insufficient aCyanopathy.
See Coak, a kind of tenon.
A kind of cake filled with custard made of cream, eggs, etc.
To change into cutin.
A white, waxy substance, forming the essential part ofspermaceti.
A mixture of constituents, as of the blood; constitution;temperament.
One who complains or laments; one who finds fault; a murmurer.Beattie.Speechless complainer, I will learn thy thought. Shak.
Native sulphate of copper. Cf. Blue vitriol, under Blue.
Cockfighting. Ben Jonson.
Without wit; stupid. [Obs.]Think'st thou I am so shallow, so conceitless. To be seduced by thyflattery Shak.
Possessing congruity; suitable; agreeing; corresponding.The congruent and harmonious fitting of parts in a sentence. B.Jonson.Congruent figures (Geom.), concurring figures.
Having a sour, disagreeable countenance. Beau & Fl.
To ingraft by cleaving the stock and inserting a scion.Mortimer.
Full of clots, or clods. "Clotty matter." Harvey.
The monthly courses of women; menstrual discharges; menses.
One who raises coal out of the hold of a ship. [Eng.] Dickens.

An exceedingly faint roundish or somewhat oblong nebulous lightnear the ecliptic and opposite the sun, best seen during Septemberand October, when in the constellations Sagittarius and Pisces. Itscause is not yet understood. Called also Gegenschein.

The act of forming into a class or classes; a distibution intogroups, as classes, orders, families, etc., according to some commonrelations or affinities. Artificial classification. (Science) Seeunder Artifitial.
A disease in the feet of cattle; laminitis. Crabb.
The emblem of the increasing moon with horns directed upward,when used in a coat of arms; -- often used as a mark of cadency todistinguish a second son and his descendants.
A dovecote.
In drawing and line engraving, shading with lines that crossone another at an angle.
Made dense; condensed.Water . . . thickened or condensate. Peacham.
An ancient instrument resembling the harp.
The quality of being cubical.
Pertaining to a commune.
The line of junction or cohering face of two carpels, as in theparsnip, caraway, etc.
A kind of worsted lace or ribbon. "Caddises, cambrics, lawns."Shak.
The frontier of a country; confines. [Obs.] Shelton.
One of a number of processes by which an impression from anengraved plate is obtained in relief, to be used for printing on anordinary printing press.
One who makes barrels, hogsheads, casks, etc.
A joint heir; one of two or more heirs; one of several entitledto an inheritance.
One who, or that which, cremmates or consumes to ashes.
A partner in giving a lease.
A hairdresser.
An advocate of collectivism.-- a.
A girth. [R.] See Surcingle.
See Cadmean.

A genus of extinct mammals from the eocene tertiary of Europeand America. Its species varied in size between the tapir andrhinoceros, and were allied to those animals, but had short,plantigrade, five-toed feet, like the elephant.
An instrument or apparatus employed in the ancient mysteries toimitate thunder and lightning. T. Moore.
The fruit of a Brazilian tree (Attalea funifera of Martius.).
Having a crest of feathers or hair upon the head. "The crestedbird." Dryden.
A quill of the crow, or a very fine pen made from such a quill.

The act or process of centralizing, or the state of beingcentralized; the act or process of combining or reducing severalparts into a whole; as, the centralization of power in the generalgovernment; the centralization of commerce in a city.
A small boat, esp. one used on rivers or near the shore.
Resembling crape.
A subdivision of the Quaternary age immediately following theGlacial period; -- so named from beds near Lake Champlain.
A harsh grating or squeaking sound, or the act of making such asound.Start not at the creaking of the door. Longfellow.
To grow hard, stiff, or thick, from cold or other causes; tobecome solid; to freeze; to cease to flow; to run cold; to bechilled.
The sickness occasioned by intemperance; surfeit. Bailey.
To ascertain; to verify; to establish; to prove. F. P. Cobbe.
One who sets type and arranges it for use.
A cockney. [Obs.] Chaucer.
A bird, usually black, of the genus Corvus, having a strongconical beak, with projecting bristles. It has a harsh, croakingnote. See Caw.
A projecting piece of timber or iron near the bow of vessel, towhich the anchor is hoisted and secured.
The act or process of straining or filtering. [R.]
A sheath in the embryo of grasses, inclosing the caulicle.Gray.
Having a casement or casements.
An instrument of observation, the graduated limb of whichconsists of an entire circle.
A row of small bracts, at the base of the calyx, on theoutside.
A reckoning together. [R.] Porson.

The act or ceremony of consecrating; the state of beingconsecrated; dedication.Until the days of your consecration be at an end. Lev. viii. 33.Consecration makes not a place sacred, but only solemny declares itso. South.
Producing color.
Marked with closely set transverse furrows.
A benefice or prebend in a cathedral or collegiate church; aright to a place in chapter and to a portion of its revenues; thedignity or emoluments of a canon.
Of or pertaining to or used in chrism.
A trench guarded with a parapet, constructed by besiegers, tosecure themselves and check sallies of the besieged.
A seat in the porch of a church. Shak.
Brisk; lively; bold; self-complacent. [Scot.] Burns.
A woman hired for odd work or for single days.
A white, crystalline glucoside, of an irritating taste,extracted from the convallaria or lily of the valley.
A soft and moist substance applied externally to some part ofthe body; a poultice. Dunglison.
Cineration; reduction to ashes. [Obs.]
A member or molding of the cornice, the profile of which iswavelike in form.
See Calx.
In a current manner; generally; commonly; as, it is currentlybelieved.
The ringdove or wood pigeon.Scarce with cushat's homely song can vie. Sir W. Scott.
In a conjoint manner; untitedly; jointly; together. Sir T.Browne.
Pertaining to the bone, or carts, large, below the epihyal inthe hyoid arch.-- n.
The expressed juice of apples. It is used as a beverage, formaking vinegar, and for other purposes.
Ten millions; as, a crore of rupees (which is nearly$5,000,000). [East Indies] Malcolm.
Of or pertaining to a convent; monastic. "A conventual garb."Macaulay. Conventual church, a church attached or belonging to aconvent or monastery. Wordsworth.

To disentangle, cleanse, or adjust, with a comb; to lay smoothand straight with, or as with, a comb; as, to comb hair or wool. Seeunder Combing.Comb down his hair; look, look! it stands upright. Shak.
A white, crystalline substance, C12H13NO3, obtained as aproduct of the decomposition of narcotine. It has weak basicproperties, and is usually regarded as an alkaloid.
See Ch.
Capable of being controlled, checked, or restrained; amenableto command.Passion is the drunkeness of the mind, and, therefore, . . . notalways controllable by reason. South.
The art of representing dancing by signs, as music isrepresented by notes. Craig.

An Asiatic genus of small shrubs, often with shining leaves andshowy flowers. Camelia Japonica is much cultivated for ornament, andC. Sassanqua and C. Oleifera are grown in China for the oil which ispressed from their seeds. The tea plant is now referred to this genusunder the name of Camellia Thea.
Of or relating to cataphonics; catacoustic.
Lulled to sleep. [Obs.] Dr. H. More.

An expression, by word or act, of approbation, regard,confidence, civility, or admiration; a flattering speech orattention; a ceremonious greeting; as, to send one's compliments to afriend.Tedious waste of time, to sit and hear So many hollow compliments andlies. Milton.Many a compliment politely penned. Cowper.To make one a compliment, to show one respect; to praise one in aflattering way.Locke.-- To make one's compliments to, to offer formal courtesias to.-- To stand on compliment, to treat with ceremony.
See Camlet. [Obs.]
To make designs in art, according to conventional principles.Cf. Conventionalize, v. t., 2.
To join together. [Obs.] Glanvill.
Unmarried; single; as, a celibate state.
The root of a handsome erect herb (Leptandra, syn. Veronica,Virginica) common in most moist woods of North America , used as anactive cathartic and emetic; also, the plant itself.
Pertaining to, or resembling, a comet. Cheyne.
See Chasuble.
A variety of cabbage (Brassica oleracea), cultivated for itsseeds, which yield an oil valued for illuminating and lubricatingpurposes; summer rape.
A second quantity added to a given quantity to make equal to athird given quantity.
One who performs circumcision. Milton.
Having the side planks (af a boat) so arranged that the loweredge of each overlaps the upper edge of the plank next below it likeclapboards on a house. See Lapstreak.
The state of being congealed.  Dr. H.More.
The act of burning different things together. [Obs.]
A short ridge connecting two higher elevations or mountains;the pass over such a ridge.
The technical name for isocyanic acid. See under Isocyanic.
Having (such) a chest; -- in composition; as, broad-chested;narrow-chested.
The driver of a cab.
A liquid organic base, C10H13.NH2, derived from cymene.
Pertaining to the complexion, or to the care of it. Jer.Taylor.
A soft, earthy substance, of a white, grayish, or yellowishwhite color, consisting of calcium carbonate, and having the samecomposition as common limestone.
Conciliatory. Coleridge.
A genus of plants related to the clover, having their flowersarranged in little heads or tufts resembling coronets.
One who receives relief for a night in a parish to which hedoes not belong; a vagrant.
A thick plank on the inner part of a ship's side, used tosustuan the ends of beams.

A vacant living or benefice commended to a cleric (usually abishop) who enjoyed the revenue until a pastor was provided. A livingso held was said to be held in commendam. The practice was abolishedby law in 1836.There was [formerly] some sense for commendams. Selden.Partnership in commendam. See under Partnership.
Pertaining to, or derived from, the lichen, Iceland moss(Cetaria Islandica). Cetraric acid. See Cetrarin.
A man who attends at the counter of a shop to sell goods.[Eng.]
The chemical basis of cartilage, converted by long boiling inwater into a gelatinous body called chondrin.
Undue pretensions to skill; quackery; wheedling; empiricism.
The state or quality of being conversant; habit of familiarity;familiar acquaintance; intimacy. [R.]
The act of surrounding or encompassing. Sir T. Browne.
Corresponding; conformable; adapted. Shak.-- Cor`re*spon"sive*ly, adv.
A small cover; a lid. [Obs.] Sir T. Browne.
A variety of fluor spar, which, when heated, gives a beautifulemerald green light.
To commove; to disturb; to stir up. [R.]Society being more or less commoted and made uncomfortable.Hawthorne.
The act or art of engraving on copper or brass, especially ofengraving for printing.
A low outwork before a bastion or ravelin, consisting of twolines of rampart parallel to the faces of the bastion, and protectingthem from a breaching fire.
Same as Cow parsley.
See Platinichloric.
To delay. Bailey.
One who describes crystals, or the manner of their formation;one versed in crystallography.
Capable of being conquered or subdued. South.-- Con"quer*a*ble*ness, n.
A professor of canon law; one skilled in the knowledge andpractice of ecclesiastical law. South.
A kind of fresh-water bass of the genus Pomoxys, found in therivers of the Southern United States and Mississippi valley. Thereare several species. [Written also croppie.]
To pack in a crate or case for transportation; as, to crate asewing machine; to crate peaches.
Same as Chromatism.
An instrument which consists of links and is used in measuringland.
Shining brightly. Shak.
A place where merchants and others meet to transact business; abuilding appropriated for mercantile transactions. [Colloq. forExchange.]
One who contrives, devises, plans, or schemas. Swift.
Joint efficiency; coöperation. Glanvill.
Wrought by carving; ornamented by carvings; carved. [Poetic]A carven bowl well wrought of beechen tree. Bp. Hall.The carven cedarn doors. Tennyson.A screen of carven ivory. Mrs. Browning.
Containing, or resembling, a cyst or cysts; cystic; bladdery.
Serious injunction; solemn demand or entreaty. [Obs.] Milton.
A piece of meat, especially of veal or mutton, cut forbroiling.
Relating to a cause or causes; inplying or containing a causeor causes; expressing a cause; causative.Causal propositions are where two propositions are joined by causalwords. Watts.
See Cartulary.
A greenish blue pigment prepared in various ways, consistingessentially of cobalt stannate. Unlike other cobalt blues, it doesnot change color by gaslight.
See Card clothing, under 3d Card.
Of or pertaining to the cremaster; as, the cremasteric artery.

Consisting of a hundred degrees; graduated into a hundreddivisions or equal parts. Spesifically: of or pertaining thecentigrade thermometer; as, 10° centigrade (or 10° C.). Centigradethermometer, a thermometer having the zero or 0 at the pointindicating the freezing state of water, and the distance between thatand the point indicating the boiling state of water divided into onehundred degrees. It is called also the Celsius thermometer, fromAnders Celsius, the originator of this scale.
One who keeps the entrance to an edifice, public or private; adoorkeeper; a janitor, male or female.
A female servant or maid who dresses provisions and assists thecook.
Cutting a cask into two pieces lengthwise, to enable it to passa narrow place, the two parts being afterward united and rehooped.
Anything separated or selected from a mass.
Rounded; arched. [Obs.]She came . . . into the compassed window. Shak.
A hypochondriacal condition verging upon insanity, occurring inthose whose brains have been unduly taxed; -- called also brain fag.
Turning on pivots at the top and bottom; -- said of a door.
Divination by written paper or by cards.
Conterminous.
The kiling of another in self-defense upon a sudden andunpremeditated encounter. See Chaud-Medley.
Relative to exchange; interchangeable; reciprocal.-- Com*mut"a*tive"ly, adv.Rich traders, from their success, are presumed . . . to havecultivated an habitual regard to commutative justice. Burke.
An invitation to take charge of or serve a church as itspastor.
Of or pertaining to a whale.
According to custom; customary; usual. [R.]
A climate. [Obs.] Shak.
Having crinkles; wavy; wrinkly.
To call before a judge or judicature; to summon; to convene.[Obs.] Shak.
Of or pertaining to the Craspedota.
Combined with carbon in the manner of a carburet or carbide.
A space in the galley; a part of the hatches. Ham. Nav. Encyc.
A division of annelids in which the gills arise from or nearthe head. See Tubicola.
Divided into small alternating squares of two tinctures; --said of the field or of an armorial bearing. [Written also checquy,cheguy.]
One who, or that which, circumscribes.
Pertaining to clairvoyance; discerning objects while in amesmeric state which are not present to the senses.
Complex, complicated. [Obs.] "Complexed significations." Sir T.Browne.
A soft and delicate woolen, or woolen and silk, fabric, forladies' dresses. [Written also chally.]
Capable of being congealed. --Con*geal"a*ble*ness, n.
Pertaining to, or connected with, conchology.
The act or process of forming cartilage. Wright.
The art of modeling in wax.
To arrange in a clump or clumps; to cluster; to group.Blackmore.
See Comb.
A stone Curbstone broker.See under Broker.
To break into crumbs or small pieces with the fingers; as, tocrumb bread. [Written also crum.]
Having curved teeth.
Used in sexual union; as, the copulatory organs of insects.
In a courageous manner.
A genus of marine univalve shells; the gondola.
A controller; a public officer whose duty it is to examinecertify accounts.
To cry as cats in rutting time; to make a harsh, offensivenoise. Coleridge.
A curacy.
in a convincing manner; in a manner to compel assent.
To share. [Obs.]For, of all miserias, I hold that chief Wretched to be, when nonecoparts our grief. Webster (1661).
The process of shortening an operation.
With contemplation; in a contemplative manner.
A twist; a whimsey or whim. [Colloq.]
Communicable by contact, by a virus, or by a bodily exhalation;catching; as, a contagious disease.

A follower of the Rev. Richard Cameron, a Scotch Covenanter ofthe time of Charies II.Cameron and others refused to accept the "indulgence" offered thePresbyterian clergy, insisted on the Solemn league and Covenant, andin 1680 declared Charles II deposed for tyranny, breach of faith,etc. Cameron was killed at the battle of Airdmoss, but his followersbecame a denomination (afterwards called Reformed Presbyterians) whorefused to recognize laws or institutions which they believedcontrary to the kingdom of Christ, but who now avail themselves ofpolitical rights.
A thick oily liquid, C10H13.OH, of a strong taste anddisagreeable odor, obtained from oil of caraway (Carum carui).
A fly that preys on fruit.
That may be complained of. [R.] Feltham.
An alloy of lead and tin, of which the Chinese make teacanisters.
That may be created.
See Carack.
A keel.(a) That part of a papilionaceous flower, consisting of two petals,commonly united, which incloses the organs of fructification.(b) A longitudinal ridge or projection like the keel of a boat.

The decoration of a fluted shaft of a column or of a pilasterwith reeds, or rounded moldings, which seem to be laid in the hollowsof the fluting. These are limited in length to about one third of theheight of the shaft.
The quality of being charitable; the exercise of charity.
imp. & p. p. of Cry.
A person with a large head; a numskull; a dunce. [Low] Knowles.
The hedge sparrow.
, Resembling a cone; conoidal.
A species of agalloch, or aloes wood, of a dusky or mottledcolor, of a light, friable texture, and less fragrant than calambac;-- used by cabinetmakers.
Bent without angles; crooked; curved; as, a curve line; a curvesurface.
The doctrine of consubstantiation.
Abounding in cresses.The cressy islets white in flower. Tennyson.
Any instrument by which electricity can be measured incoulombs.
Flattened lengthwise. Compessed air engine, an engine operatedby the elastic force of compressed air.
A gung of slaves. Same as Coffle.
An appearance of Christ, as to his disciples after thecrucifixion.
An umbelliferous biennial plant (Daucus Carota), of manyvarieties.
Capability of being controlled; controllableness.
To console; to comfort. [Obs.] Shak.
A complex; an aggregate of parts; a complication.
See Clake.
A peculiar rounded body lying near the nucleus of a cell. It isregarded as the dynamic element by means of which the machinery ofcell division is organized.
See Cantabile.

A dramatic composition, or representation of a bright andamusing character, based upon the foibles of individuals, the mannersof society, or the ludicrous events or accidents of life; a play inwhich mirth predominates and the termination of the plot is happy; --opposed to tragedy.With all the vivacity if comedy. Macaulay.Are come to play a pleasant comedy. Shak.
To put a stop to; to bring to an end.But he, her fears to cease Sent down the meek-eyed peace. Milton.Cease, then, this impious rage. Milton
The garment for the legs and feet and for the body below thewaist, worn in Europe throughout the Middle Ages; applied also to thearmor for the same parts, when fixible, as of chain mail.
Trippant in opposite directions. See Trippant.
The act of pouring or spreading round; the state of beingspread round. Swift.
See Cirriferous.
To dawn together; to contract; to force to contract itself; toconstrict; to cause to shrink. [R.]Strong liquors . . . intoxicate, constringe, harden the fibers, andcoagulate the fluids. Arbuthnot.
Having the flowers gathered into a head.
The upper robe worn by a bishop, to which lawn sleeves areusually attached. Hook.

The science of the world or universe; or a treatise relating tothe structure and parts of the system of creation, the elements ofbodies, the modifications of material things, the laws of motion, andthe order and course of nature.
The science which treats of the laws of distribution of livingorganisms over the earth's surface as to latitude, altitude,locality, etc.Its distribution or chorology. Huxley.
See under Oval.
A boy kept for unnatural purposes.
Relating to the comitia, or popular assembles of the Romans forelecting officers and passing laws. Middleton.
A competitress.
A knot, boss, or mass of hair, natural or artificial, worn by awoman at the back of the head.A curl that had strayed from her chignon. H. James.
The conjugal state; sexual intercourse. [R.] Milton.
One who conjectures. Hobbes.
One who continues; one who has the power of perseverance orpersistence. "Indulgent continuers in sin." Hammond.I would my horse had the speed of your tongue, and so good acontinuer. Shak.
A change-speed gear in which the gears are changed by slidingendwise.
Resembling the beak of a crow; as, the coronoid process of thejaw, or of the ulna.

A staff used in cudgel play, shorter than the quarterstaff, andwielded with one hand; hence, any heavy stick used as a weapon.He getteth him a grievous crabtree cudgel and . . . falls to ratingof them as if they were dogs. Bunyan.Cudgel play, a fight or sportive contest with cudgels.-- To cross the cudgels, to forbear or give up the contest; -- aphrase borrowed from the practice of cudgel players, who lay onecudgel over another when the contest is ended.-- To take up cudgels for, to engage in a contest in behalf of (someone or something).
Pertaining to, containing, or composed of, carbon.
Bringing to a close; decisive; conclusive. [Obs.]Arguments highly consequential and concludent to my purpose. Sir M.Hale.
The seed of one or more leguminous plants of the genusDolichos; also, the plant itself. Many varieties are cultivated inthe southern part of the United States.
Partnership in inheritance; joint heirship; joint right ofsucession to an inheritance.
The state or quality of being cold.
Large in quantity or amount; plentiful; abundant; fruitful.Kindly pours its copious treasures forth. Thomson.Hail, Son of God, Savior of men! thy name Shall be the copious matterof my song. Milton.
Having the quality of being viscous or adhesive; soft andsticky; glutinous; damp and adhesive, as if covered with a coldperspiration.
A member of the Congress of the United States, esp. of theHouse of Representatives.
Shaped like a lattice; cancellate. Gray.
See Chiaroscuro.
Having ridges or bunches of flesh, like collops.With that red, gaunt, and colloped neck astrain. R. Browning.
Of the callosum.
Having no compass. Knowles.
See Chicory.
A thing to be believed; an article of faith; -- distinguishedfrom agendum, a practical duty.The great articles and credenda of Christianity. South.
Producing or having shells.
Worn or burdened with care; as, careworn look or face.
One who holds a living in commendam.
The highest or covering course of masonry in a wall, often withsloping edges to carry off water; -- sometimes called capping. Gwill.
A hollow in the side of a hill, where game usually lies. "Fleetfoot on the correi." Sir W. Scott.
Corivalry. [R.]By the corrivalship of Shager his false friend. Sir T. Herbert.
Mixed; confounded. [Obs.] Baret.
Like or belonging to the cuckoos (Cuculidæ).
A utensil to hold a chamber vessel, for the use of the sick andinfirm. It is usually in the form of a box, with a seat and tightcover.
Bearing Children; (Fig.) productive; fruitful. [R.] Shak.
A work divided into a hundred parts. [R.] Burton.
A game at cards, a modification of seven-up, or all fours.
A mild cathartic oil, expressed or extracted from the seeds ofthe Ricinus communis, or Palma Christi. When fresh the oil isinodorus and insipid. Castor-oil plant. Same as Palma Christi.
Proceeding in a circle; circular. [Obs.] "With motioncirculine". Dr. H. More.
An usher to a riding master.
Conicalness.
One who describes or writes about comets.
Costly. [Obs.] Chaucer.

A bird of the family Ampelidæ -- so called from its monotonousnote. The Bohemion chatterer (Ampelis garrulus) inhabits the arcticregions of both continents. In America the cedar bird is a morecommon species. See Bohemian chatterer, and Cedar bird.
Common; ordinary; trite; as, a commonplace person, orobservation.
Of or pertaining to cetology.

The standard unit of quantity in electrical measurements. It isthe quantity of electricity conveyed in one second by the currentproduced by an electro-motive force of one volt acting in a circuithaving a resistance of one ohm, or the quantitty transferred by oneampère in one second. Formerly called weber.
The water buffalo. [Phil. Islands]
The acquiring of property by other means than by inheritance;acquisition. Blackstone.
A joint legatee.
Flying around.The circumvolant troubles of humanity. G. Macdonald.
To fit with a crupper; to place a crupper upon; as, to cruppera horse.
To unite. [Obs.]
Of or pertaining to Castalia, a mythical fountain ofinspiration on Mt. Parnassus sacred to the Muses. Milton.
See Carom.
The small table by the side of the altar or communion table, onwhich the bread and wine are placed before being consecrated.
See Capitulum.
A condiment made from the sap of the bitter cassava (Manihotutilissima) deprived of its poisonous qualities, concentrated byboiling, and flavored with aromatics. See Pepper pot.
A coin. See Sequin. Shak.
An English dry measure, being, at London, 36 bushels heaped up,or its equivalent weight, and more than twice as much at Newcastle.Now used exlusively for coal and coke.
See Harmotome, and Staurotide.
Dying together or at the same time. [R.] Sir G. Buck.
Want of courage to face danger; extreme timidity;pusillanimity; base fear of danger or hurt; lack of spirit.The cowardice of doing wrong. Milton.Moderation was despised as cowardice. Macualay.
An English gold coin of the value of twenty or twenty-threeshillings. It was first struck in the reign of Charles I.Told down the crowns and Caroluses. Macawlay.
The mucous membrane which covers the external surface of theball of the eye and the inner surface of the lids; the conjunctivalmembrance.
Relating to the long axis of the body.
A caster of accounts; a reckoner; a bookkeeper; -- usedconteptuously.
See Crimson. [Obs.]
A district, or part of a province. See Sircar. [India]
Crying earnestly, beseeching clamorousky. "Clamant children."Thomson.
Contrived for the purpose of making a show, or gainingapplause; deceptive; unreal.
See Castanets.
In a compact manner.
Having the quality of entering into composition; compounded.[R.]
A hydrous borate of lime occurring in transparent colorless orwhite crystals, also massive, in Southern California.
Healing the distemper of cows.
To judge. [Obs.] Shak.
See Chalice.
Having the appearance and manners of a rustic; rude.As being one who took no pride, And was a deal too countrified.Lloyd.

A large bird, of the genus Casuarius, found in the east Indies.It is smaller and stouter than the ostrich. Its head is armed with akind of helmet of horny substance, consisting of plates overlappingeach other, and it has a group of long sharp spines on each wingwhich are used as defensive organs. It is a shy bird, and runs withgreat rapidity. Other species inhabit New Guinea, Australia, etc.
Having joint or equal signification; synonymous. [R.] Spelman.
Connecting, or adapted to connect; involving connection.Connection tissue (Anat.) See Conjunctive tissue, under Conjunctive.
Pertaining to the earth; earthy; as, chthonic religions.[The] chthonic character of the wife of Zeus. Max Müller.
To print surreptitiously a work belonging to another. E.Phillips.
To hold fast; to grasp something firmly; to seize or grasp oneanother.
In a cynical manner.
To move in a canter.
In a consistent manner.
Pertaining to, or furnishing, a contribution.
The Arabian gazelle (Gazella Arabica), found from persia toNorth Africa.
See Creosote.
The distribution of religious books, tracts, etc., bycolporteurs.
A blue-flowered liliaceous plant (Camassia esculenta) ofnorthwestern America, the bulbs of which are collected for food bythe Indians. [Written also camas, cammas, and quamash.]
A broad ice sheet resting on a plain or plateau and spreadingoutward from a central névé, or region of accumulation.
Circumscribing or tending to circumscribe; marcing the limitsor form of.
The Song of Songs or Song of Solomon, one of the books of theOld Testament.
See Chipmunk.
One versed in the study of the Coleoptera.
A shot in which the ball struck with the cue comes in contactwith two or more balls on the table; a hitting of two or more ballswith the player's ball. In England it is called cannon.
Changeableness.
Turned in a direction which is not the usual one; -- said of ananimal turned to the sinister which is usually turned to the dexter,or the like.
That branch of Zoölogy which treats of the Crustacea;malacostracology; carcinology.
A spasmodic trembling of the upper eyelid.
See Catechu.
The act or process of carbonizing.
A treatise on crime or the criminal population.-- Crim`i*nol"o*gist (-j, n.
Same as Colter.
Having a narrow, projecting chest, caused by forward curvatureof the vertebral column.
Defn:

Of or pertaining to the confederated colonies collectively, inthe time of the Revolutionary War; as, Continental money.The army before Boston was designated as the Continental army, incontradistinction to that under General Gage, which was called the"Ministerial army." W. Irving.Continental Congress. See under Congress.-- Continental system (Hist.), the blockade of Great Britain orderedby Napoleon by the decree of Berlin, Nov. 21, 1806; the object beingto strike a blow at the maritime and commercial supremacy of GreatBritain, by cutting her off from all intercourse with the continentof Europe.
A thin, twilled, woolen cloth, used for men's garments.[Written also kerseymere.]
Same as Cantalever.
Communicating. [R.] Coleridge.
The Hebrew plural of Cherub.. Cf. Seraphim.
Growing together; cohering, as in the organic cohesion ofsimilar parts; uniting.
To wear clothes. [Poetic]Care no more to clothe eat. Shak.
See Coal.
Of or pertaining to a concession. -- n.; pl. -ries.
Having the qualities of a crab; crablike.
Selected from a number; picked out; choice.Seven hundred chosen men left-handed. Judg. xx. 16.
Congenital; connate; inborn. See Congenital. [Obs.]Many conclusions, of moral and intellectual truths, seem . . . to becongenite with us. Sir M. Hale.
The larval form of a trematode worm having the shape of atadpole, with its body terminated by a tail-like appendage.
See Chantry. [Obs.] Chaucer.
A variety of feldspar found in crystals in the county ofChester, Pennsylvania.
Inclining or nodding downward; pendulous; drooping; -- said ofa bud, flower, fruit, or the capsule of a moss.
A large kettle or boiler of copper, brass, or iron. [Writtenalso cauldron.] "Caldrons of boiling oil." Prescott.
An instrument with a screw or a steel spiral for drawing corksfrom bottles. Corkscrew starts, a spiral staircase around a solidnewel.
Capability of being controlled.
A bill brought by a defendant, in an equity or chancery suit,against the plaintiff, respecting the matter in question in thatsuit. Bouvier.
To give additional security to or for. Burke.
A chapel within the jurisdiction of a church; a subordinateecclesiastical foundation.
A song or canto [Obs.]Write loyal cantons of contemned love. Shak.
Having eyes like a cat; hence, able to see in the dark.
To bear or carry round. [Obs.] Bacon.
Made by baking, or exposing to heat, as a brick.
A powerful alkaloid, C17H21NO4, obtained from the leaves ofcoca. It is a bitter, white, crystalline substance, and is remarkablefor producing local insensibility to pain.
One of the cells which, in the Coelenterata, develop intocnidæ.
Of or pertaining to the conjunctiva.
Ornamentation with crockets. Ruskin.
Famous. [Obs.] Speed.
Sick from excess in eating or drinking. [Obs.] "Cropsickdrunkards." Tate.-- Crop"sick`ness, n. [Obs.] Whitlock.
Against the affirmative side; in opposition; on the negativeside; -- The antithesis of pro, and usually in connection with it.See Pro.
Salted codfish hardened by pressure. Kane.

To restrain within limits; to restrict; to limit; to bound; toshut up; to inclose; to keep close.Now let not nature's hand Keep the wild flood confined! let orderdie! Shak.He is to confine himself to the compass of numbers and the slavery ofrhyme. Dryden.To be confined, to be in childbed.
Cell production or development; cytogenesis.
A kind of mineral coal of a black color, sufficiently hard andsolid to be cut and polished. It burns readily, with a clear, yellowflame, and on this account has been used as a substitute for candles.
Like the carp (Cyprinus).-- n.
A Hebrew measure of capacity; a homer. [Written also core.]

The light spongy pulp of the fruit of the bitter cucumber(Citrullus, or Cucumis, colocynthis), an Asiatic plant allied to thewatermelon; coloquintida. It comes in white balls, is intenselybitter, and a powerful cathartic. Called also bitter apple, bittercucumber, bitter gourd.
A strong broth of meat, strained and made clear for invalids;also, a savory jelly. [Obs.]When I am exellent at caudles And cullises . . . you shall be welcometo me. Beau. & Fl.
A house occupied by a club.
Var. of Karakul, a kind of fur.
A kind of divination by means of the dough of the cakes offeredin the ancient sacrifices, and the meal strewed over the victims.
A concave surface, or the space bounded by it; the state ofbeing concave.
The process of forming a cicatrix, or the state of beingcicatrized.
Drawing inference. [R.] Milton.
Having a cheek; -- used in composition. "Rose-cheeked Adonis."Shak.
A division of passerine birds in which the vocal muscles arebut little developed, so that they lack the power of singing.
Unnatural; contrary to nature. [R.]Some artists . . . have given to Sir Walter Scott a pile of foreheadwhich is unpleassing and cataphysical. De Quincey.
To make coarse or vulgar; as, to coarsen one's character. [R.]Graham.
A coat with short flaps.
Capable of being circumstantiated. [Obs.] Jer Taylor.
Shaped like a pruning knife; cultrate.
To make a loud or shrill noise. [Obs.] Golding.
Heart-shaped; as, a cordate leaf.
Capable of being coagulated. Boyle.

A mineral occuring in silky fibers of a lavender blue color. Itis related to hornblende and is essentially a silicate of iron andsoda; -- called also blue asbestus. A silicified form, in which thefibers penetrating quartz are changed to oxide of iron, is the yellowbrown tiger-eye of the jewelers.

A small musical imstrument on the principle of the accordion.It is a small elastic box, or bellows, having free reeds on theinside, and keys and handles on the outside of each of the twohexagonal heads.

Any species of Phalacrocorax, a genus of sea birds having a sacunder the beak; the shag. Cormorants devour fish voraciously, andhave become the emblem of gluttony. They are generally black, andhence are called sea ravens, and coalgeese. [Written also corvorant.]
An African ruminant; the giraffe. See Giraffe.
A little cushion.

Pertaining to, or composed of, corpuscles, or small particles.Corpuscular philosophy, that which attempts to account for thephenomena of nature, by the motion, figure, rest, position, etc., ofthe minute particles of matter.-- Corpuscular theory (Opt.), the theory enunciated by Sir IsaacNewton, that light consists in the emission and rapid progression ofminute particles or corpuscles. The theory is now generally rejected,and supplanted by the undulatory theory.
The coronet of a horse.
An inflammantion of the cellular or areolar tissue, esp. ofthat lying immediately beneath the skin.
In a compliant manner.
One who undertakes to confute.  Milton.
A placing among the stars; a catalogue of stars.The catasterisms of Eratosthenes. Whewell.
A sort of cotton so short and fine thet it can not be spun,used in the East Indies to line palanquins, to make mattresses, etc.
Chubby. [R.] H. Brooke.
The common chamber into which the intestinal, urinary, andgenerative canals discharge in birds, reptiles, amphibians, and manyfishes.
One who, or that which, confirms, establishes, or ratifies; onewho corroborates. Shak.

To adhere closely; to stick; to hold fast, especially bytwining round or embracing; as, the tendril of a vine clings to itssupport; -- usually followed by to or together.And what hath life for thee That thou shouldst cling to it thus Mrs.Hemans.
