A tree (Anacardium occidentale) of the same family which thesumac. It is native in tropical America, but is now naturalized inall tropical countries. Its fruit, a kidney-shaped nut, grows at theextremity of an edible, pear-shaped hypocarp, about three incheslong. Casbew nut, the large, kidney-shaped fruit of the cashew, whichis edible after the caustic oil has been expelled from the shell byroasting the nut.
According to the order or series of causes; by tracing effectsto causes.
To sing or recite after the manner of a chant, or to a tunecalled a chant.
A knight or cavalier; hence, a gentleman.
A state of being compact.
A group of passerine birds, including the creepers andnuthatches.
One who, or that which, crushes. Crusher gauge, an instrumentfor measuring the explosive force of gunpowder, etc., by its effectin compressing a piece of metal.
One who caters.The little fowls in the air have God for Their provider and caterer.Shelton.
A little hoof.

A beautiful crystalline compound, SiC, consisting of carbon andsilicon in combination; carbon silicide. It is made by heating carbonand sand together in an electric furnace. The commercial article isdark-colored and iridescent. It is harder than emery, and is used asan abrasive.
OF or pertaining to cheese; as, caseic acid.

A solution of pyroxylin (soluble gun cotton) in ethercontaining a varying proportion of alcohol. It is strongly adhesive,and is used by surgeons as a containing for wounds; but its chiefapplication is as a vehicle for the sensitive film in photography.Collodion process (Photog.), a process in which a film of sensitizedcollodion is used in preparing the plate for taking a picture.-- Styptic collodion, collodion containing an astringent, as tannin.
Pertaining, or adapted, to the cithara.
One who combats. Sherwood.
A walk or other exercise taken for one's health orconstitution. [Colloq.] Thackeray.The men trudged diurnal constitutionals along the different roads.Compton Reade.
In the manner of a convalescent; with increasing strength orvigor.
A kind of large. thin muffin or cake, light and spongy, andcooked on a griddle or spider.
A red coloring matter. extracted from the Bignonia Chica, usedby some tribes of South American Indians to stain the skin.
A partner in a lease taen.
A dove. "Culver in the falcon's fist." Spenser.
A small inclosed pond used for gathering and greening oysters.
A coin. See Carline.
Smutty.
One of a series of substances C10H16, resembling camphor,regarded as modified terpenes.

The morsel of execration; a species of ordeal consisting in theeating of a piece of bread consecrated by imprecation. If thesuspected person ate it freely, he was pronounced innocent; but if itstuck in his throat, it was considered as a proof of his guilt.Burril.
A hook or drag; a grapnel.
The outer membrane of seeds of plants.
A reveling; a rioting. [Obs.] Bp. Hall.
Defn:
Abounding in bark; resembling bark; barky.
Something rising in a conical shape; specifically, a hillrising to a point.A low cape, and upon it a copple not very high. Hakluyt.
With consideration or deliberation.
Inflammation of a capsule, as that of the crystalline lens.
A meal made from hulled cotton seeds after the oil has beenexpressed.
Of pertaining to crinoids; consisting of, or containing,crinoids.

A powerful and very poisonous vegetable alkaloid found in thehemlock (Conium maculatum) and extracted as a colorless oil, C8H17N,of strong repulsive odor and acrid taste. It is regarded as aderivative of piperidine and likewise of one of the collidines. Itoccasions a gradual paralysis of the motor nerves. Called alsoconiine, coneine, conia, etc. See Conium, 2.
One who keeps treasures in a coffer. [R.]
Without a companion.
Built of, or in, the clouds; airy; unsubstantial; imaginary.Cowper.So vanished my cloud-built palace. Goldsmith.
To rotate about. [R.]
Georgia; -- a nickname. See Cracker, n. 5.
Custom, habit; usage. [R.]To observe this consuetude or law. Barnes.
One of the canine teeth; -- so called from having but one pointor cusp on the crown. See Tooth.
Any merely ornamental adjunct of a woman's dress, as a bunch ofribbon, lace, etc.
In a contradictory manner. Sharp.
The act or process of curling the hair. [Obs.] burton.
Wavy or undulating like camlet; veined. Sir T. Herbert.
The science which treats of climates and investigates theirphenomena and causes. Brande & C.
Same as Zedoary. [Obs.] Chaucer.
The state or quality of being centric; centricalness.
A block in which two or more trains are permitted to travel,under restrictions imposed by a caution card or the like.
The waist or bodice of a lady's dress; as. a low corsage.

A name applied to various species of edible fishes of the genusSerranus, and related genera, inhabiting the Meditarranean, the coastof California, etc. In California, some of them are also called rockbass and kelp salmon.
A fabulous cow of enormous size, whose food was patient wives,and which was therefore in very lean condition.
A black submetallic mineral consisting of oxide of chromium andiron; -- called also chromic iron.
Avarice. [Obs.] Spenser.

The quality or state of being comely.Comeliness is a disposing fair Of things and actions in fit time andplace. Sir J. Davies.Strength, comeliness of shape, or amplest merit. Milton.Comeliness signifies something less forcible than beauty, lesselegant than grace, and less light than prettiness. Johnson.
A light wine, of several kinds, originally made in the provinceof Champagne, in France.
A small black spot or mark remaining in the cavity of thecorner tooth of a horse after the large spot or mark has becomeobliterated.
See Contradance.He had introduced the English country-dance to the knowledge of theDutch ladies. Macualay.
Like a bed; -- applied to several processes on the inner sideof the sphenoid bone.

The use of many words to express an idea that might beexpressed by few; indirect or roundabout language; a periphrese.the plain Billingagate way of calling names . . . would saveabundance of time lost by circumlocution. Swift.Circumlocution office, a term of riducle for a governmental officewhere business is delayed by passing through the hands of differentofficials.
An artificial, yellow, crystalline dye, C6H5N2.C6H3(NH2)2.Also, one of a group of dyestuffs resembling chrysoïdine proper.
To seal or ratify with another or others. Shak.
A day (December 28) observed by mass or festival incommemoration of the children slain by Herod at Bethlehem; -- calledalso Holy Innocent's Day.
Belonging to exchanges in commerce; of exchange. [R.]
Made of, pertaining to, or resembling, canvas or coarse cloth;as, a canvas tent.
Of or pertaining to the Cestoidea.-- n.
Pertaining to conception.
Of or pertaining to catechumens; as, catechumenicalinstructions.
The quality of being clever; skill; dexterity; adroitness.

The recess, seat, or inclosed place, where a priest sits tohear confessions; often a small structure furnished with a seat forthe priest and with a window or aperture so that the penitent who isoutside may whisper into the priest's ear without being seen by himor heard by others.
An eating house. "A subterranean cookshop." Macaulay.
A costermonger.
The act or process of turning to flesh, or to a substanceresembling flesh.
That which is cast or brought forth prematurely; an abortion.Sir T. Browne.
Climatic.
The art of hunting with dogs.
Pertaining to the art of making sweetmeats. [Obs.] Beaumont.
A toad. [Obs.]
A costly cloth, of uncertain material, used in the Middle Ages.[Obs.] [Written also checklaton, chekelatoun.]His robe was of ciclatoun, That coste many a Jane. Chaucer.
A salt of cholic acid; as, sodium cholate.

A vessel; vessels of any kind; -- generally used in acollective sense.The evolutions of the numerous tiny craft moving over the lake. Prof.Wilson.Small crafts, small vessels, as sloops, schooners, ets.
Concave. Abp. potter.-- Con*ca"vous*ly, adv.
A goveror or warden of a castle.
One who cheers; one who, or that which, gladdens. "Thou cheererof our days." Wotton. "Prime cheerer, light." Thomson.
Caries.
Cavo-rilievo.
One who believes in the contagious character of certaindiseases, as of yellow fever.
One of the patches of villi found in some forms of placenta.
Marked with the sign of the cross. [Obs.] Crouched friar. SeeCrutched friar, under Crutched.
By the act of nature; originally; from birth. Sir M. Hale.
That which produces coagulation.
In a careful manner.
A disciple of Comte; a positivist.
An oil obtained by distillation of peat, and containing variousmembers of the pyridine series.
A bird belonging to Cuculus, Coccyzus, and several alliedgenera, of many species.
An ornamental hook, or brooch worn by a lady at her waist, andhaving a short chain or chains attached for a watch, keys, trinkets,etc. Also used adjectively; as, a chatelaine chain.
By chance. [Obs.]
A large, slender, harmless snake of the southern United States(Masticophis flagelliformis).
Pertaining to, or derived from, cumin, or from oil of caraway;as, cuminic acid. Cuminic acid (Chem.), white crystalline substance,C3H7.C6H4.CO2H, obtained from oil of caraway.
A colloquial expression, not employed in formal discourse orwriting.
See Corrundum.
Joint signature. [R.] Colgrave.
Belonging to, or resembling, a suborder of composite plants ofwhich the chicory (Cichorium) is the type.

A subdivision in the upper part of the Devonian system inAmerica, so named from the Chemung River, along which the rocks arewell developed. It includes the Portage and Chemung groups or epochs.See the Diagram under Geology.
Having furrowed edges, as if turned in a lathe.
Having a clear physical or mental vision; having a clearunderstanding.
An assemblage; a collection; harmonious union. [Obs.]That person of his [George Herbert], which afforded so unusual acontesseration of elegancies. Oley.
A device consisting of a short rope with flat hooks at eachend, for hoisting casks or barrels by the ends of the staves.
The use of cannon. Burke.
A genus of small dipterous files, including several veryinjurious species, as the Hessian fly. See Hessian fly.
Act of kicking.
Clumsy; awkward. [Obs.]Rough-hewn, cloutery verses. E. Phillips.
In the manner of a carouser.
A small house; a cot; a hut.
A leaf converted into a fruit or a constituent portion of afruit; a carpel.
See Comfrey.
The second day of February, on which is celebrated the feast ofthe Purification of the Virgin Mary; -- so called because the candlesfor the altar or other sacred uses are blessed on that day.
That part of a speech, usually the exordium, in which theorator sets forth the subject matter to be discussed.
Terminated with crescent; -- said of a cross the ends of whichare so terminated.
Capable of being committed.
A speaking or conversing together; conference; mutualdiscourse. Bailey.
Having the form or appearance of a calyx.

Capable of being credited or believed; worthy of belief;entiled to confidence; trustworthy.Things are made credible either by the known condition and quality ofthe utterer or by the manifest likelihood of truth in themselves.Hooker.A very diligent and observing person, and likewise very sober andcredible. Dampier.
Contrarily; oppositely. Shak.
To shoot out; to sprout.I have known barley chit in seven hours after it had been thrownforth. Mortimer.
To restrain desire; to live in continence or chastity.But if they can not contain, let them marry. 1 Cor. vii. 9.
A claw. [Obs.]
See Cheer.
Like a colt; wanton; frisky.He was all coltish, full of ragery. Chaucer.-- Colt"ish*ly, adv.-- Colt"ish*ness, n.
A region of country having covers; a hunting country.
Capability of being condensed.
Agreeing. Concurring figure (Geom.), one which, being laid onanother, exactly meets every part of it, or one which correspondendswith another in all its parts.
A mean or inferior poet, perhaps from his habit of wanderingaround as a stroller; an itinerant poet. Also, a name given to thecyclic poets. See under Cyclic, a. [Obs.] B. Jonson.
A vessel for heating water. [Obs.] Johnson.
Short; brittle; as, crup cake. Todd.
Capable of conceiving. Sir T. Browne

To form by an exercise of ingenuity; to devise; to invent; todesign; to plan.What more likely to contrive this admirable frame of the universethan infinite wisdom. Tillotson.neither do thou imagine that I shall contrive aught against his life.Hawthorne.
A grass with leaves having edges furnished with very minutehooked prickles, which form a cutting edge; one or more species ofLeersia.
Same as Hydrochloric.
Craniotomy; -- usually applied to bisection of the fetal headwith a saw.
One who uses chicanery. Locke.
Clogging, or having power to clog.
Numerical loss caused by death, wounds, discharge, ordesertion. Casualty ward, A ward in a hospital devoted to thetreatment of injuries received by accident.
, v. t. To cut across or through; to intersect.

To conceive; to imagine. [Archaic]The strong, by conceiting themselves weak, are therebly rendered asinactive . . . as if they really were so. South.One of two bad ways you must conceit me, Either a coward or aflatterer. Shak.
Cirrose.
Befitting or indicating a coxcomb; like a coxcomb; foppish;conceited.-- Cox*comb"ic*al*ly, adv.Studded all over in coxcombical fashion with little brass nails. W.Irving.
Of or pertaining to the Chætognatha.
A young cock.
Cluniac.
A fillet or band placed around the shaft of a column as if tostrengthen it. [Written also cimia.]
The name by which a person is addressed; an appellative.
To clothe. [Obs.] Holland.
A variety of cellulose, occuring as a fine transparent membranecovering the aerial organs of plants, and forming an essentialingredient of cork; by oxidation it passes to suberic acid.
Agreeing; correspondent; harmonious; consonant.Were every one employed in points concordant to their natures,professions, and arts, commonwealths would rise up of themselves. SirT. Browne
A large, highly esteemed, edible fish of India (Latescalcarifer); -- also called begti.
To tread or trample under foot. [Obs.] Bp. Montagu --Con`cul*ca"tion (, n. [Obs.]
To make crooked. [Obs.]

A groove in any cylinder; specif., a groove around the cylinderof an elongated bullet for small arms to contain a lubricant, oraround the rotating band of a gun projectile to lessen the resistanceoffered to the rifling. Also, a groove around the base of acartridge, where the extractor takes hold. --Can"ne*lured (#), a.
Mercury telluride, an iron-black metallic mineral, found inColorado.
According to rites and ceremonies; as, a person ceremoniallyunclean.
Having the quality or power of conducting; as, the conductivetissue of a pistil.The ovarian walls . . . are seen to be distinctly conductive. Goodale(Gray's Bot. ).
To vary or shift suddenly; as, the wind chops about.

To make a prolonged sharp grating or ssqueaking sound, as bythe friction of hard substances; as, shoes creak.The creaking locusts with my voice conspire. Dryden.Doors upon their hinges creaked. Tennyson.
A rounded tooth on the edge of a leaf.
The quality of being combustible.
The ground adjoining a church, in which the dead are buried; acemetery.Like graves in the holy churchyard. Shak.
See Culrage.

Having a bluish effect. Cf. Warm, 8. Cold abscess. See underAbscess.-- Cold blast See under Blast, n., 2. Cold blood. See under Blood,n., 8.-- Cold chill, an ague fit. Wright.-- Cold chisel, a chisel of peculiar strength and hardness, forcutting cold metal. Weale.-- Cold cream. See under Cream.-- Cold slaw. See Cole slaw.-- In cold blood, without excitement or passion; deliberately.He was slain in cold blood after thefight was over. Sir W. Scott.To give one the cold shoulder, to treat one with neglect.

Quadrupeds of the Bovine family; sometimes, also, including alldomestic quadrupeds, as sheep, goats, horses, mules, asses, andswine. Belted cattle, Black cattle. See under Belted, Black.-- Cattle guard, a trench under a railroad track and alongside acrossing (as of a public highway). It is intended to prevent cattlefrom getting upon the track.-- cattle louse (Zoöl.), any species of louse infecting cattle.There are several species. The Hæmatatopinus eurysternus and H.vituli are common species which suck blood; Trichodectes scalariseats the hair.-- Cattle plague, the rinderpest; called also Russian cattle plague.-- Cattle range, or Cattle run, an open space through which cattlemay run or range. [U. S.] Bartlett.-- Cattle show, an exhibition of domestic animals with prizes forthe encouragement of stock breeding; -- usually accompanied with theexhibition of other agricultural and domestic products and ofimplements.
Resembling, or analogous to, the cerebrum or brain.
To approach or meet in a common center; to consolidate; as,population tends to concentrate in cities.
A writ given by statute to recover lands when the tenant hasfor two years failed to perform the conditions of his tenure.
The act of running about; also, rambling language. [Obs.]Barrow.

A substance composed essentially of gun cotton and camphor, andwhen pure resembling ivory in texture and color, but variouslycolored to imitate coral, tortoise shell, amber, malachite, etc. Itis used in the manufacture of jewelry and many small articles, ascombs, brushes, collars, and cuffs; -- originaly called xylonite.
A colored photographic picture taken upon paper made sensitivewith potassium bichromate or some other salt of chromium.
One who swears or is sworn with others; one bound by oath withothers; a compurgator. Burrill.
In the East Indies, an inclosure containing a house,outbuildings, etc.
A friend to colonization, esp. (U. S. Hist) to the colonizationof Africa by emigrants from the colored population of the UnitedStates.
With consent; in a compliant manner. Jer. Taylor.
The crawfish. [Prov. Eng.]
Eroding, or eating into, limestone.
Pertaining to the shin bone. Cnemial crest, a crestlikeprominence on the proximal end of the tibia of birds and somereptiles.
One of the Crinoidea.
In company with others; unitedly; concurrently. Bp. pearson.
Converging to a center; -- applied to lines drawn so as to meetin a point or center.
Pertaining to contexture or arrangement of parts; producingcontexture; interwoven. Dr. John Smith (1666).
Growing upward, as distinguished from a laterral growth; --applied to the growth of corals. Dana.

Of, pertaining to, or derived from, cacodyl. Cacodylic acid, awhite, crystalline, deliquescent substance, (CH3)2AsO.OH, obtained bythe oxidation of cacodyl, and having the properties of an exceedinglystable acid; -- also called alkargen.
State or condition of a creator.

A monument in the form of a cross, or surmounted bu a cross,set up in a public place; as, a market cross; a boundary cross;Charing Cross in London.Dun-Edin's Cross, a pillared stone, Rose on a turret octagon. Sir W.Scott.
The upper margin of a hoof; a coronet.
A triangular protection from the intrados of an arch, or froman inner curve of tracery.
A mineral occuring in thin-bladed crystals and crystallineaggregates, of a sky-blue color. It is a silicate of aluminium.[Written also kyanite.]
Comradeship and loyalty.
An instrument for measuring minute intervals of time; used indetermining the velocity of projectiles, the duration of short-livedluminous phenomena, etc.
The water rat. Walton.

A gentianaceous plant not fully identified. The name is usuallygiven to the Erytheræa Centaurium and the Chlora perfoliata ofEurope, but is also extended to the whole genus Sabbatia, and even tothe unrelated Centaurea.
A large species of African baboon (Cynocephalus porcarius); --called also ursine baboon.
Engraved by a voltaic battary.

To contend emulously; to seek or strive for the same thing,position, or reward for which another is striving; to contend inrivalry, as for a prize or in business; as, tradesmen compete withone another.The rival statesmen, with eyes fixed on America, were all the whilecompeting for European alliances. Bancroft.
A colonist. [Obs.] Holland
Corymbose.
Having a large fist. Howell.
A white, fatty, crystalline substance, tasteless and odorless,found in animal and plant products and tissue, and especially innerve tissue, in the bile, and in gallstones.

One of a warlike, pastoral people, skillful as horsemen,inhabiting different parts of the Russian empire and furnishingvaluable contingents of irregular cavalry to its armies, those ofLittle Russia and those of the Don forming the principal divisions.
The gathering and examination of sheets preparatory to binding.
Corrupt or guilty assent to wrongdoing, not involving actualparticipation in, but knowledge of, and failure to prevent or opposeit.
Of or pertaining to constables; consisting of constables.
Pertaining to crustalogy.
Belonging to the confervae.
Ulceration of bone; a process in which bone disintegrates andis carried away piecemeal, as distinguished from necrosis, in whichit dies in masses.
A waxy substance obtained from the bark of the sugar cane, andcrystallizing in delicate white laminæ.

A list or enumeration of names, or articles arrangedmethodically, often in alphabetical order; as, a catalogue of thestudents of a college, or of books, or of the stars. Card catalogue,a catalogue, as of books, having each item entered on a separatecard, and the cards arranged in cases by subjects, or authors, oralphabetically.-- Catalogue raisonné Etym: [F.], a catalogue of books, etc.,classed according to their subjects. Syn.-- List; roll; index; schedule; enumeration; inventory. See List.
The coalfish. See 3d Cuddy.
One who is skilled in, or given to, casuistry.The judment of any casuist or learned divine concerning the state ofa man's soul, is not sufficient to give him confidence. South.
One who consecrates; one who performs the rites by which aperson or thing is devoted or dedicated to sacred purposes. [Writtenalso consecrater.]
See Cruse, a small bottle.
See Crawfish.

A progressive wasting away of the body; esp., that form ofwasting, attendant upon pulmonary phthisis and associated with cough,spitting of blood, hectic fever, etc.; pulmonary phthisis; -- calledalso pulmonary consumption. Consumption of the bowels (Med.),inflammation and ulceration of the intestines from tuberculardisease.
Having the petals and stamens adnate to the calyx; -- appliedto a subclass of dicotyledonous plants in the system of the Frenchbotanist Candolle.
Composed of, or adorned with, gold and ivory.
A hydroid of the family ampanularidæ, characterized by havingthe polyps or zooids inclosed in bell-shaped calicles or hydrothecæ.
A fruit resembling a lemon, but larger, and pleasantlyaromatic. The thick rind, when candied, is the citron of commerce.
A pisonous resin extracted from hemp (Cannabis sativa, varietyIndica). The narcotic effects of hasheesh are due to this resin.
Dimness; cloudiness. [R.] Sir T. Browne.
An epoch at the close of the American lower Silurian system.The rocks are well developed near Cincinnati, Ohio. The groupincludes the Hudson River and Lorraine shales of New york.
To mix; to mingle, to temper. [Obs.] Shak.
The living together of a man and woman in supposed sexualrelationship.That the duty of cohabitation is released by the cruelty of one ofthe parties is admitted. Lord Stowell.
Five-spotted. [R.] Shak.

(a) The keynote of the normal or "natural" scale, which hasneither flats nor sharps in its signature; also, the third note ofthe relative minor scale of the same (b) C after the clef is the markof common time, in which each measure is a semibreve (four fourths orcrotchets); for alla breve time it is written (c) The "C clef," amodification of the letter C, placed on any line of the staff, abowsthat line to be middle C.
A horse, not of pure breed, but having only one eighth or onesixteenth impure blood in his veins. Darwin.
An old woman. [Scot. & Prov. Eng.]
Resistance; opposition; a stand against.Making counterstand to Robert Guiscard. Longfellow.
To make a shop, sharp, cheerful, as of small birds or crickets.
See Conine.
Capable of being contradicting.
One who holds a benefice in commendam; a commendatary.Chalmers.
Incapable of cure; incurable.With patience undergo A cureless ill, since fate will have it so.Dryden.
A church bell.
A small nodule or cystic tumor, common on the nose, etc., whichon pressure allows the escape of a yellow wormlike mass of retainedoily secretion, with a black head (dirt).
Lying round; borderong on every side. T. Fuller.
The right of pasturing on a common; the right of using anythingin common with others.The claim of comonage . . . in most of the forests. Burke.
A roof having a rounded form, hemispherical or nearly so; also,a celing having the same form. When on a large scale it is usuallycalled dome.
Same as Casein.
Of the same color throughout.
Circumspectly.
A sight covering; a scarf. See Simar.Her body shaded with a light cymar. Dryden.
Any plant of the genus Rudbeckia; -- so called from the cone-shaped disk of the flower head. Also, any plant of the related generaRatibida and Brauneria, the latter usually known as purpleconeflower.
One who converses with another; a convenser. [R.]
A dovecote; a pigeon house. Sir T. Browne.
A disease of horses, on which the mouth is so furred that theafflicted animal can not eat.
A colorless liquid resembling phenol or carbolic acid,homologous with pyrocatechin, and obtained from beechwood tar and gumguaiacum. [Written also creasol.]
To cover with, or as with, a canopy. "A bank with ivycanopied." Milton.
A yellow oil liquid, extracted from the shell of the cashewnut.
Worthy of being commended or praised; laudable; praiseworthy.Order and decent ceremonies in the church are not only comely butcommendable. Bacon.-- Com*mend"a*ble*ness, n.-- Com*mend"a*bly, adv.
The first rudiments of an embryo in generation. Dr. H. More.
A crafty fox. [Obs.] Chaucer.
A bar or set of bars with skewers for holding paying-offbobbins, as in the roving machine, throstle, and mule.
Of or pertaining to calculation; involving calculation.Long habits of calculative dealings. Burke.
One who, or that which, calcines.
Cheerful; sprightly; lively; merry. "The canty dame."Wordsworth [Scot. & Prov. Eng.]Contented with little, and canty with mair. Burns.
Unlawful support, countenance, or encouragement; as, to giveaid and comfort to the enemy.
A king; a chief; the title of the emperor of Russia. [Writtenalso tzar.]

An act of endearment; any act or expression of affection; anembracing, or touching, with tenderness.Wooed her with his soft caresses. Langfellow.He exerted himself to win by indulgence and caresses the hearts ofall who were under his command. Macaulay.
A faculty in animals of developing and preserving the heatnesessary to life, that is, the animal heat.
Pertaining to, or produced by, chemosmosis. [R.]
Giddy; rash. Milton.

A piece of apparatus used for reversing the direction of anelectrical current; an attachment to certain electrical machines, bymeans of which alternating currents are made to be continuous or tohave the same direction.

Of, pertaining to, or derived from, the citron or lemon; as,citric acid. Citric acid (Chem.), an organic acid, C3H4OH.(CO2H)3,extracted from lemons, currants, gooseberies, etc., as a whitecrystalline substance, having a pleasant sour taste.
A South American wild cat (Felis colocolo), of the size of theocelot.
To treat or prepare with a chloride, as a plate with chlorideof silver, for the purposes of photography. R. Hunt.
Following as a matter of course. Blount.
Scholarship. [Obs.]
Capable of being caught. [R.]
The act or art of using a canoe.
A fish; the goldsinny.
Under the protection of a husband; married. Burrill.
The fielder in the games of cricket and lacrosse who supports"point."
Covetous; niggardly. Bp. Berkeley. "Closefisted contractors."Hawthorne.
An outcry or shout of many together. [R.]Before his funeral conclamation. May (Lucan).
On this side of the Atlantic Ocean; -- used of the eastern orthe western side, according to the standpoint of the writer. Story.
The theory, principles, or authority of constitutionalgovernment; attachment or adherene to a constitution orconstitutional government. Carlyle.
Capable of being converted or reversed. Hammond.
A floret in an aggregate flower. [Obs.] Martyn.
To grow cloudy; to become obscure with clouds; -- often usedwith up.Worthies, away! The scene begins to cloud. Shak.
A slow rising of the floor of a gallery, occasioned by thepressure of incumbent strata upon the pillars or sides; a gradualmovement of mining ground.

Relating to the center; situated in or near the center ormiddle; containing the center; of or pertaining to the parts near thecenter; equidistant or equally accessible from certain points.Central force (Math.), a force acting upon a body towards or awayfrom a fixed or movable center.-- Center sun (Astron.), a name given to a hypothetical body aboutwhich Mädler supposed the solar system together with all the stars inthe Milky Way, to be revolving. A point near Alcyone in the Pleiadeswas supposed to possess characteristics of the position of such abody.
The Celsius thermometer or scale, so called from AndersCelsius, a Swedish astronomer, who invented it. It is the same as thecentigrade thermometer or scale.
See Calipers.
According to chemical principles; by chemical process oroperation.
Of or pertaining to a client.A dependent and cliental relation. Burke.I sat down in the cliental chair. Dickens.
The separation of a leaf or floral organ into two more parts.
Bearing a crosier.
Calling for notice; compelling attention; notorious; heinous;as, a crying evil.Too much fondness for meditative retirement is not the crying sin ofour modern Christianity. I. Taylor.
The science which treats of cartilages. Dunglison.
Destitute of any distinguishing quality; without character orforce.
See Capelin.
A thick solid-rubber tire, as for a bicycle, with a hollowgroove running lengthwise on the inside.
Operating with force; compelling; forcing; constraininig;resulting from, or enforced by, compulsion. [R.]To recover of us, by strong hand And terms compulsatory, thoseforesaid lands. Shak.

One who, or that which, crimps; as: (a) A curved board or frameover which the upper of a boot or shoe is stretched to the requiredshape. (b) A device for giving hair a wavy apperance. (c) A machinefor crimping or ruffling textile fabrics.

A preparation made from the seeds of the chocolate tree, andused in making, a beverage; also the beverage made from cocoa orcocoa shells. Cocoa shells, the husks which separate from the cacaoseeds in preparing them for use.

Formerly an allowance of two pounds in every three hundredweight after the tare and tret are subtracted; now used only in ageneral sense, of small deductions from the original weight. [Writtenalso clough.] McCulloch.
Adapted or designed to confute.  Bp. Warburton
A constellation. See Auriga, and Wagones.
An oily hydrocarbon, C16H32, of the ethylene series, obtainedfrom spermaceti.
A movement in dancing, as across or to the right or left.
Going round in a circuit; roundabout; indirect; as, acircuitous road; a circuitous manner of accompalishing an end.-- Cir*cu"i*tous*ly, adv.-- Cir*cu"i*tous*ness, n.
A Linnæan genus of free-flowering composite plants, mostly fromSouth Africa. Several species are cultivated for ornament.

Full of, or containing, cream; resembling cream, in nature,appearance, or taste; creamlike; unctuous. "Creamy bowis." Collins."Lines of creamy spray." Tennyson. "Your creamy words but cozen."Beau & Fl.
A strong inclined frame, usually of wrought-iron bars, in frontof a locomotive engine, for catching or throwing off obstructions ona railway, as cattle; the pilot. [U.S.]
To form a counterbore in, by boring, turning, or drilling; toenlarge, as a hole, by means of a counterbore.
The bean or seed of the castor-oil plant (Ricinus communis, orPalma Christi.)
See Cognizant. [Obs.]
A kind of carriage like a gig, orig. of wicker-work.
Manner of acting; behavior; bearing.A graceful comportment of their bodies. Cowley.Her serious and devout comportment. Addison.
Resembling cholera.
Criminality. [R.]
A telescope arranged and used to determine errors ofcollimation, both vertical and horizontal. Nichol.
Having a temper not easily excited; free from passion.-- Cool"-head`ed*ness, n.
In a clear manner.
The clavicle.
A cicatrix.

A conversational game, in which questions and answers are madeso as to involve ludicrous combinations of ideas. Pepys. To be atcross-purposes, to misunderstand or to act counter to one anotherwithout intending it; -- said of persons.
A common councilman. [Obs.]
A South American short-tailed monkey (Pithecia (or Brachyurus)melanocephala). [Written also cacajo.]
Of or pertaining to a choir or chorus; singing, sung, oradapted to be sung, in chorus or harmony. Choral service, a serviceof song.
A carucate. [Obs.] Burrill.
The act or state of suffering persecution for religious faith.Our duty to contend even to confessorship. J. H. Newman.
Belonging or going to, or resembling, a conventicle. [Obs.]Conventicling schools . . . set up and taught secretly by fanatics.South.
The conductor, chief, or leader of the dramatic chorus; hence,the chief or leader of a party or interest.That noted corypheus [Dr. John Owen] of the Independent faction.South.
Seized and appropriated by the government to the public use;forfeited.Lest that your goods too soon be confiscate. Shak.
To stereotype or electrotype.
Office or duty of a custodian.
A disputant. [Obs.]
See Counterfesance. [Obs.]
A large, Old World, ground cuckoo of the genus Centropus, ofseveral species.
The anterior, and in man the larger, division of the brain; theseat of the reasoning faculties and the will. See Brain.
Fastened with copper bolts, as the planks of ships, etc.; as, acopper-fastened ship.
Applied to those nerve fibers which go from the spinal cord tothe brain and so transfer sensations (centripetal impressions) fromthe exterior inwards.
Same as Conine.
Rib-bearing, as the dorsal vertebræ.
See under Rocket.

A law, or rule of doctrine or discipline, enacted by a counciland confirmed by the pope or the sovereign; a decision, regulation,code, or constitution made by ecclesiastical authority.Various canons which were made in councils held in the second centry.Hock.
Ravenous; voracious.Cormorant, devouring time. Shak.
One of a pair of horses employed to draw a coach; hence (Fig.),a comrade. Shak.
An adventure in which two or more persons are partakers.
Having the planks meet flush at the seams, instead of lappingas in a clinker-built vessel.
Corroborated. [Obs.] Bacon.
A limbless amphibian belonging to the order Cæciliæ orOphimorpha. See Ophiomorpha. [Written also coecilian.]
Of or pertaining to culture.
Giving a title or claim to credit or confidence; accrediting.Their credential letters on both sides. Camden.
In the manner of a coward. Spenser.
Same as Cabiric.
A coming together; sexual intercourse; copulation. Grew.
Any structure having the appearance of a cord, esp. a tendon ora nerve. See under Spermatic, Spinal, Umbilical, Vocal.
Surrounding; inclosing or being on all sides; encompassing."The circumambient heaven." J. Armstrong.
Conclusive. [R.]

Changed into, or contained in, a coagulum or a curdlike mass;curdled. Coagulated proteid (Physiol. Chem.), one of a class ofbodies formed in the coagulation of a albuminous substance by heat,acids, or other agents.
A dramatic sketch; a brief comedy.

A large ruminant used in Asia and Africa for carrying burdensand for riding. The camel is remarkable for its ability to go a longtime without drinking. Its hoofs are small, and situated at theextremities of the toes, and the weight of the animal rests on thecallous. The dromedary (Camelus dromedarius) has one bunch on theback, while the Bactrian camel (C. Bactrianus) has two. The llama,alpaca, and vicuña, of South America, belong to a related genus(Auchenia).
A form of seacoast cannon; a long, chambered gun designed forthrowing shot or shells with heavy charges of powder, at high anglesof elevation.
Any mechanical engraving process depending upon chemicalaction; specif., a process of zinc etching not employing photography.-- Chem`i*graph"ic (#), a.
A brilliant star in the constellation Auriga.
Tea; -- the Chinese (Mandarin) name, used generally in earlyworks of travel, and now for a kind of rolled tea used in CentralAsia.
A small, inclosed field, adjoining a house; a small farm.A few small crofts of stone-encumbered ground. Wordsworth.
Like or belonging to the swifts (Cypselidæ.)
To act as a clown; -- with it [Obs.]Beclowns it properly indeed. B. Jonson.

A deep red color tinged with blue; also, red color in general.Theugh jour be as scarlet, they shall be as white as snow; thoughthey be red like crimson, they shall be as wool. Is. i. 18.A maid jet rosed over with the virgin crimson of modesty. Shak.
One who classifies.

Style of address or salutation; an appellation. "Metaphoricalcompellations." Milton.He useth this endearing compellation, "My little children." Bp.Beveridge.The peculiar compellation of the kings in France is by "Sire," whichis nothing else but father. Sir W. Temple.
The art of moving the hands in oratory or in pantomime; gesture[Obs.]
Costing nothing.
Like a chandler; in a petty way. [Obs.] Milton.
Joseph Hall (1574 -- 1656), Bishop of Norwich, a divine eminentas a moralist.
Having the same form. [R.]
Hundred-headed.
See Corriestep.

The final process or decree (following beatifacation) by whichthe name of a deceased person is placed in the catalogue (canon) ofsaints and commended to perpetual veneration and invocation.Canonization of saints was not known to the Christian church titltoward the middle of the tenth century. Hoock.
Having the power or quality of shaking or agitating. Johnson.
A conic section.
That consults. Consulting physician (Med.), a physician whoconsults with the attending practitioner regarding any case ofdisease.
The fine filiform process of a cnidoblast.
A measure of area, the hundredth part of an are; one squaremeter, or about 1
See Bilirubin.
Passing or held by collation; -- said of livings of which thebishop and the patron are the same person.
The state of being on an equality, as in rank or power.
A hard or thickened spot or protuberance; a hardening andthickening of the skin or bark of a part, eps. as a result ofcontinued pressure or friction.
Running; flowing. Cursive hand,a running handwriting.
See Cod, and Buffalo cod, under Buffalo.
A pain about the heart. [Obs.] Chaucer.
Showing the full face, but nothing of the neck; -- said of thehead of a beast in armorial bearing. [Written also caboshed.]
Wood to which a tenant is entitled for making and repairingcarts and other instruments of husbandry.
A large herbaceos plant (Cynara Cardunculus) related to theartichoke; -- used in cookery and as a sald.
Carotid; as, the carotic arteries.
See Cymene.
Under cover, authority or protection; as, a feme covert, amarried woman who is considered as being under the protection andcontrol of her husband. Covert way, (Fort.) See Covered way, underCovered.
A garden plant (Chrysanthemum Balsamita) having a strongbalsamic smell, and nearly allied to tansy. It is used as a pot herband salad plant and in flavoring ale and beer. Called also alecost.
Having a flesh color.
A secret society of Irish Fenians founded in Philadelphia in1881.
The complex radical, CO.OH, regarded as the essential andcharacteristic constituent which all oxygen acids of carbon (asformic, acetic, benzoic acids, etc.) have in common; -- called alsooxatyl.
To strike or drive back or in an opposite direction; to stop bya blow or impulse in front. Dryden.
In a supercilious, disdainful, or haughty manner; arroganty.Junius.
In a congruous manner.
A voltaic battery, having a large surface of plate, andproducing powerful heating effects.
Relating to chirology.
Like or becoming a cousin.
See Camlet.

Having the tinctures exchanged mutually; thus, if the field isdivided palewise, or and azure, and cross is borne counterchanged,that part of the cross which comes on the azure side will be or, andthat on the or side will be azure.
A space left unroofed over the court of a Roman dwelling,through which the rain fell into the impluvium or cistern.
Supplied with clients. [R.]The least cliented pettifiggers. R. Carew.
That can not be changed; constant; as, a changeless purpose.-- Change"less*ness, n.
To cover round, as woth a garment; to invest. [Obs.]Circumvested with much prejudice. Sir H. Wotton.

Pertaining to, derived from, or containing, cobalt; -- saidespecially of those compounds in which cobalt has higher valence; as,cobaltic oxide. Luteo-cobaltic compounds (Chem.), an extensive seriesof complex yellow compounds of ammonia and cobaltic salts.-- Roseo-cobaltic compounds (Chem.), an extensive series of complexred compounds of cobalt and ammonia. Modifications of these are thepurpureo-cobaltic compounds.
See Cadency.
To include in a circular space; to bound. [Obs.] Sir T. Browne.
A small loop or bow of ribbon used in making hats, boas, etc.
A prickly plant of the genus Carlina (C. vulgaris), found inEurope and Asia.

A genus of iridaceous plants, with pretty blossoms risingseparately from the bulb or corm. C. vernus is one of the earliest ofspring-blooming flowers; C. sativus produces the saffron, andblossoms in the autumn.
Producing, or converting into, chyle; having the power to formchyle.
Blameworthiness. [Obs.]Banished out of the realme . . . without culpe. E. Hall.
The title of the eldest son of the czar of Russia.
A disease characterized by severe nervous symptoms, dependentupon the presence of the constituents of the bile in the blood.
An edible species of mushroom (Agaricus campestris). Fairy ringchampignon, the Marasmius oreades, which has a strong flavor but isedible.
The wolverence; -- also applied, but erroneously, to the Canadalynx, and sometimes to the American badger. See Wolverene.
Of or pertaining to a city. Shak. City council. See underCouncil.-- City court, The municipal court of a city. [U. S.] -- City ward,a watchman, or the collective watchmen, of a city. [Obs.] Fairfax.
A salesman in a shop; a shopman; -- used contemtuously. [Slang]

The small, spicy berry of a species of pepper (Piper Cubeba; inmed., Cubeba officinalis), native in Java and Borneo, but nowcultivated in various tropical countries. The dried unripe fruit ismuch used in medicine as a stimulant and purgative.

One of the generic names of the gigantic ray (Manta birostris),known as devilfish and sea devil. It is common on the coasts of SouthCarolina, Florida, and farther south. Some of them grow to enormoussize, becoming twenty feet of more across the body, and weighing morethan a ton.
A piece of ground terminating in a point or acute angle. [Obs.]

A system of electric traction, esp. for light railways, inwhich the actuating current passes along a wire or rail laid in anunderground conduit, from which the current is "picked up" by a plowor other device fixed to the car or electric locomotive.  HenceConduit railway.
One of the short ropes or iron cramps used to brace in theshrouds toward the masts so a to give freer sweep to the yards.
; according to the canons.
A rope or wire on which clothes are hung to dry.
A knife or cutter, attached to the beam of a plow to cut thesward, in advance of the plowshare and moldboard. [Written alsocoulter.]
Capable of being classed.
One who shoots with a crossbow. See Arbalest.
The act ofworking together; united labor.
Producing cymes.
Lustful. [Obs.] Shak.
A description or record of past time; history. [Obs.] Bp. Hall.
To reduce to a code, as laws.
One who rents and tills a small farm or helding; as, thecrofters of Scotland.
Polishing rouge; a reddish brown oxide of iron, used inpolishing glass, and also as a pigment; -- called also crocus Martis.

To form or become covered with cream; to become thick likecream; to assume the appearance of cream; hence, to grow stiff orformal; to mantle.There are a sort of men whose visages Do cream and mantle like astanding pool. Shak.
Repeated potations; social or exessive indulgence inintoxicating drinks; revelry.Thence from cups to civil broils. Milton.
To choose or elect in concert with another. [R.]Each of the hundred was to coöpt three others. Jowett (Thysyd. ).
Relating to custody or guardianship.
Bearing or producing little cells.
A wall raised behind another, to supply its place when breachedor destroyed. [R.] Cf. Contramure. Knolles.
The use or application of a caustic; cautery. Ferrand.
Contributing, or tending to contribute. Fuller.
Belonging to the Coelentra.-- n.
Free from, or with little, charge.
Pertaining to confervae; consisting of, or resembling, theconfervae.Yon exiguous pool's confervous scum. O. W. Holmes.
Having the power of contracting into wrinkles. Johnson.
All-powerful; omnipotent. [R] "God cunctipotent." Neale (Trans.Rhythm of St. Bernard).
Without craft or cunning.Helpless, craftless, and innocent people. Jer. Taylor.
To sum or collect together. [Obs.] Bp. King.
A lepidop terous insect with partially transparent wings, ofthe family Ægeriadæ, of which the currant and peach-tree borers areexamples.
A plant which prduces cardamoms, esp. Elettaria Cardamomum andseveral of Amommum.
To act in opposition to; to hinder, defeat, or frustrate, bycontrary agency or influence; as, to counteract the effect ofmedicines; to counteract good advice.
The seat of a coachman.
The private orchestra or band of a prince or of a church.
A large genus of composite plants, related to the thistles andincluding the cornflower or bluebottle (Centaurea Cyanus) and thestar thistle (C. Calcitrapa).
A division of Bryozoa, in which the cells have circularapertures.
See Cozily.
A subdivision of the cretaceous formation of western NorthAmerica, especially developed in Colorado and the upper Missouriregion.
See Colstaff.
A flowing round on all sides; an inclosing with a fluid.
Like or pertaining to the Mosquito family (Culicidæ). -- n.
A prefix meaning contrary, opposite, in opposition; as,counteract, counterbalance, countercheck. See Counter, adv. & a.
Pertaining to, consisting, of resembling, turf; turfy.A cespitous or turfy plant has many stems from the same root, usuallyforming a close, thick carpet of matting. Martyn.
Of or pertaining to a contralto, or to the part in music calledcontralto; as, a contralto voice.
Having a bill shaped like the colter of a plow, or like aknife, as the heron, stork, etc.
In a continuous maner; without interruption.-- Con*tin"u*ous*ness, n.
A superior kind of violin, formerly made at Cremona, in Italy.
A stroke or blow in return. Spenser.
A small, flat, sweetened cake of various kinds.
EAsily crumbled; friable; brittle. "The crumbly soil."Hawthorne.
See Centring.
Acquainted with manners and deportment; behaved. [Obs.]Till she be better conversationed, . . . I'll keep As far from her asthe gallows. Beau. & Fl.
An insect that turns about nimbly; the mole cricket; -- calledalso fan cricket. Johnson.
a position in which an army finds itself with no way of exitbut to the front.
A small foxlike mammal (Cynalopex corsac), found in CentralAsia. [Written also corsac.]
A branching perennial plant (Cichorium Intybus) with brightblue flowers, growing wild in Europe, Asia, and America; alsocultivated for its roots and as a salad plant; succory; wild endive.See Endive.
A bar of iron sharpened at one end, and used as a lever.
To turn in flight; -- said of a hawk. [Obs.] Nares.He makes his stoop; but wanting breath, is forced To cancelier.Massinger.
The wood louse. [Prov. Eng.]
The peculiar fruit of fennel, carrott, parsnip, and the like,consisting of a pair of carpels pendent from a supporting axis.
pret. of Chese. [Obs.] Chaucer.
Same as Carnelian.
Adjointing the shore.
Strengthening; supporting; corroborating. Bacon.-- n.
Consecrator.
A piece for one or more solo instruments with orchestra; --more concise than the concerto.
Yielding; bending; pliant; submissive. "The compliant boughs."Milton.

In the terminology of the United States Weather Bureau, anunusual fall in temperature, to or below the freezing point,exceeding 16º in twenty-four hours or 20º in thirty-six hours,independent of the diurnal range.
To curl or friz, as the hair. [Obs.] Cotgrave.
To sing; esp. to sing joyfully; to warble.And carol of love's high praise. Spenser.The gray linnets carol from the hill. Beattie.
The wiew or doctrins of the ultramontane party in the LatinChurch. Gladstone.
Of, pertaining to, or resembling, a cotyledon.
One who confutes or disproves.
Hairiness. [R.]
Having the form of a shallow bowl; -- said of a corolla.
See Cheetah.
Chinese conduct, art, decoration, or the like; also, a specimenof Chinese manners, art, decoration, etc.
One who makes calendars. [R.]

From Copy, v. Copying ink. See under Ink.-- Copying paper, thin unsized paper used for taking copies ofletters, etc., in a copying press.-- Copying press, a machine for taking by pressure, an exact copy ofletters, etc., written in copying ink.
One whose occupation is to make cabinets or other choicearticles of household furniture, as tables, bedsteads, bureaus, etc.
To bring together by colligation; to sum up in a singleproposition.He had discovered and colligated a multitude of the most wonderful .. . phenomena. Tundall.
A small box, can, or chest to keep tea in.
A morbid condition of the system resulting from excessive useof chloral.
See Colombier.
A comblike structure on the metatarsus of the hind legs ofcertain spiders (Ciniflonidæ), used to curl certain fibers in theconstruction of their webs.
A Jacobite who favored the restoration of James II, oncondition of a general amnesty and of guarantees for the security ofthe civil and ecclesiastical constitution of the realm.
A cop of thread.
Having the quality of preserving from loss, decay, or injury.
One who castigates or corrects.
Capable of being compared; worthy of comparison.There is no blessing of life comparable to the enjoyment of adiscreet and virtuous friend. Addison.-- Com"pa*ra*ble*ness, n.-- Com"pa*ra*bly, adv.
In a chary manner; carefully; cautiously; frugally.
Belonging to, or consisting of, bark or rind; resembling barkor rind; external; outer; superficial; as, the cortical substance ofthe kidney.
Act of inclosing on all sides. [R.]
A trope, by which a speaker assumes that his hearer is apartner in his sentiments, and says we, instead of I or you. Beattie.
Pertaining to, or affected by, chlorosis.
Of the nature of a chancre; having chancre.
A captain, leader, or commander; a chief; the head of a troop,army, or clan.

An extraordinary assembly of the parkiament or estates of therealm, held without the king's writ, -- as the assembly whichrestored Charles II. to the throne, and that which declared thethrone to be abdicated by James II.Our gratitude is due . . . to the Long Parliament, to the Convention,and to William of Orange. Macaulay.
One who lodges temporarily in a hut or camp.
Joint establishment. Bp. Watson.
With coequality.
Capable of being convened or assembled.
A woman who carries a canteen for soldiers; a vivandière.
A stitch in which the looping of the thread or threads forms achain on the under side of the work; the loop stitch, asdistinguished from the lock stitch. See Stitch.
Continuously.
A chronicle. L. Addison.
The Mexican name for turquoise. See Turquoise.
The act of consigning or sending property to an agent orcorrespondent in another place, as for care, sale, etc.
A chorister boy. [Obs.] Chaucer.
Crystallized cawk, in which the crystals are small.
A processive wasting or melting away of the solid parts of theanimal system with copious excretions of liquids by one or morepassages. [Obs.]
To concur; to agree. [Burlesque]
A making thick or viscous; thickness; inspissation. [R.] Dr. H.More.
See Sentry. [Obs.] Gray.
Encumbrance. [Obs.]Extol not riches then, the toil of fools, The wise man's cumbrance,if not snare. Milton.

A woman who holds a canonry in a conventual chapter. Regularcanoness, one bound by the poverty, and observing a strict rule oflife.-- Secular canoness, one allowed to hold private property, and boundonly by vows of chastity and obedience so long as she chose to remainin the chapter.
Capable of being compassed or accomplished. Burke.
The quality of being changeable; fickleness; inconstancy;mutability.
Scissors. [Obs.] Swift.
Same as Correspondence, 3.The correspondencies of types and antitypes . . . may be veryreasonable confirmations. S. Clarke.
The art of measuring crystals.
See Circumflexion.
Connate or coalescent at the base so as to produce a broadfoliaceous body through the center of which the stem passes; --applied to leaves, as the leaves of the boneset.
Participation of the same essence. Johnson.
One who is jointly concerned with one or more persons inbusiness, etc.; a partner; an associate; a partaker; a sharer.the associates and copartners of our loss. Milton.
See Calumba.
A kind of boat of various forms, used in the IndianArchipelago.
The typical pentadactyloid limb of the higher vertebrates.
A colorless oil obtained from hemp dy distillation, andpossessing its intoxicating properties.
Pasteboard for paper boxes; also, a pasteboard box. Cartonpierre (, a species of papier-maché, imitating stone or bronzesculpture. Knight.
Pertaining to the circumference; encompassing; encircling;circuitous. Parkhurst.
A kind of buttress of masonry to strengthen a revetment wall.
A quoit. [Obs.] Carew.
A California fish (Hemilepidotus spinosus), allied to thesculpin.
See Clnquant.
A duel; the decision of a case by a duel.

The quality or state of being coarse; roughness; melegance;vulgarity; grossness; as, coarseness of food, texture, manners, orlanguage. "The coarseness of the sackcloth." Dr. H. More.Pardon the coarseness of the illustration. L'Estrange.A coarseness and vulgarity in all the proceedings. Burke.
The position of a candidate; state of being a candidate;candidateship.
A colter. See Colter.
The state or quality of being correct; as, the correctness ofopinions or of manners; correctness of taste; correctness in writingor speaking; the correctness of a text or copy.
A sweet wine from Portugal; -- so called from the district ofCarcavelhos. [Written also Calcavellos or Carcavelhos.]
A squinting eye. Forby.
One who examines the sheets of a book that has just beenprinted, to ascertain whether they are correctly printed, paged, etc.[Eng.]

To join together; to unite.The English army, that divided was Into two parties, is now conjoinedin one. Shak.If either of you know any inward impediment why you should not beconjoined. Shak.Let that which he learns next be nearly conjoined with what he knowsalready. Locke.
Shining around or about.
One of the Cetacea.
A long cannon of the 16th century, usually an 18-pounder withserpent-shaped handles.Trump, and drum, and roaring culverin. Mac
See Cozy. Dickens.
The adaptation or adjustment of parts to each other, as of abroken bone or dislocated joint.
The quality of being commutable.
That which blasts a blossom as a canker does. [Obs.]O me! you juggler! you canker blossom! You thief of Love! Shak.
Of or pertaining to Chili.-- n.
To frisk or frolic like a colt; to act licentiously orwantonly. [Obs.]They shook off their bridles and began to colt. Spenser.
A small tube, usually curved, applied to a trumpet, horn, etc.,to change its pitch or key.

A large South American rodent (Hydrochærus capybara) Living onthe margins of lakes and rivers. It is the largest extant rodent,being about three feet long, and half that in height. It somewhatresembles the Guinea pig, to which it is related; -- called alsocabiai and water hog.
Closely crowded together; densly clustered; as, conglomerateflowers. Gray.
One who believes in the law of universal causation.
One who cabals.A close caballer and tongue-valiant lord. Dryden.
A ctenoidean.
The transmission of a disease from one person to another, bydirect or indirect contact.
One of the French Protestant insurgents who rebelled againstLouis XIV, after the revocation of the edict of Nates; -- so calledfrom the peasant's smock (camise) which they wore.
Sexual lust; morbid carnal passion.Concupiscence like a pestilence walketh in darkness. Horne.
Same as Conjoined.
Relating to, or containing, a census.He caused the whole realm to be described in a censual roll. Sir R.Baker.
Having a conscience. [R.] "Soft-conscienced men." Shak.
Pertaining to, or characterized by, clairaudience.
Contrary to nature. [R.] Harvey.

A formal allegation or charge against a party made or presentedto the appropriate court or officer, as for a wrong done or a crimecommitted (in the latter case, generally under oath); an information;accusation; the initial bill in proceedings in equity.
To restrain. [Obs.] Bailey.
The substance which, added to the material of a cell wall,makes it waterproof, as in cork.
The association of a number of persons for their benefit.
In a calm manner.The gentle stream which calmly flows. Denham.
The celebration of the hundredth anniversary of any event; acentenary. [U. S.]
Wattles, or hurdles, made with stakes interwoven with osiers,to cover lodgments. [Obs.]
With embraces. [Obs.] Gascoigne.
To feel sorrow, pain, or regret for; to pity.Then must we those, who groan, beneath the weight Of age, disease, orwant, commiserate. Denham.We should commiserate our mutual ignorance. Locke.
See under Buoy, n.
The cry of cats; a harsh, disagreeable noise or cry like thecry of cats. Shak.
One who cringes meanly; a fawner.
The axis deer of India.
A stalk of Indian corn.
A believer in Christian Science; one who practices itsteachings.
The state of being complex; complexity. A. Smith.
To gather or throw into a heap; to heap together; toaccumulate.Shoals of shells, bedded and cumulated heap upon heap. Woodward.
Confirmation. [Obs.]
A potter. [Obs.] Wyclif.
To perform the canary dance; to move nimbly; to caper. [Obs.]But to jig of a tune at the tongue's end, canary to it with yourfeet. Shak.Ca*na"ry bird`. (Zoöl.)
A Welshman.
A kind of trumpet, whose note is clear and shrill.He sounds his imperial clarion along the whole line of battle. E.Everett.
The state or condition of a cousin; also, the collective bodyof cousins; kinsfolk.
The condition of increased irritability of a nerve in theregion of the cathode or negative electrode, on the passage of acurrent of electricity through it.
The quality of being courtly; elegance or dignity of manners.

A short, heavy, curving sword, used in the navy. See Curtal ax.Cutlass fish, (Zoöl.), a peculiar, long, thin, marine fish (Trichiruslepturus) of the southern United States and West Indies; -- calledalso saber fish, silver eel, and, improperly, swordfish.
See Gamboge.
Divination by means of apperances in the air.
Rapidity of motion; quickness; swiftness.Time, with all its celerity, moves slowly to him whose wholeemployment is to watch its flight. Johnson.
To embrace. [Obs.] "They coll and kiss him." Latimer.
A joint herald.
A soldier armed with a carbine.
To bless according to a prescribed form, or to unite with inpublicly returning thanks in church, as after deliverance from thedangers of childbirth; as, the churching of women.
In a becoming manner. Ascham.
In a manner that corrupts.
Preserved; pickled. [Obs.] Burton.
A collection of particles or bodies into one mass; a heap; anaggregation.
A kind of breechloading, center-fire rifle, or improved needlegun.
A collection of small projectiles, inclosed in a case orcanister.
A friar of a mendicant order (the Order of Our Lady of MountCarmel) established on Mount Carmel, in Syria, in the twelfthcentury; a White Friar.
A cramp iron or cramp ring; a chape, as of a scabbard. [Writtenalso crampit and crampette.]
That art or operation of measuring the inclination of strata.
A form of the prefix com-, signifying with, together, inconjunction, joint. It is used before vowels and some consonants. SeeCom-.
A secret name; a name by which a person is known only to theinitiated.
Moving in a circle; turning round. Hawthorne.

A kind of short cannon, formerly in use, designed to throw alarge projectile with small velocity, used for the purpose ofbreaking or smashing in, rather than piercing, the object aimed at,as the side of a ship. It has no trunnions, but is supported on itscarriage by a bolt passing through a loop on its under side.
A genus of dipterous insects, including the gnat and mosquito.
The large lobe of the hind brain in front of and above themedulla; the little brain. It controls combined muscular action. SeeBrain.
Dead body; carrion. [Obs.] Chaucer.
Same as Anthodium.
In a complete manner; fully.
Of, pertaining to, or resembling, a large family of plants ofwhich the sedge is the type.
A wading bird of the genus Numenius, remarkable for its long,slender, curved bill.
The state of being convex; the exterior surface of a convexbody; roundness.A smooth, uniform convexity and rotundity of a globe. Bentley.
A bird of Europe (Fringilla coelebs), having a variety of verysweet songs, and highly valued as a cage bird; -- called also copperfinch.
The resistance of a horse, that interrupts his cadence and themeasure of his manege, occasioned by a bad horseman, or the badtemper of the horse.
One who, or that which, consumes; as, the consumer of food.
Bearing or producing berries; bacciferous; as, cocciferroustrees or plants.
To agree; to be suitable. [Obs.] Shak.
A friar who acted as porter at the gate of a monastery. Sir W.Scott.
A complex derivative of cyanogen, regarded as an acid, andknown chiefly in its salts; -- called also hydromellonic acid.
One versed in, or who studies, climatology.
Copper.
The principal grounds of a college or school, between thebuildings or within the main inclosure; as, the college campus.
Without faith in Christ; unchristian. Tennyson.
Resembling, or pertaining to, the Crotalidae, or Rattlesnakefamily.
Hoisted as high as the tackle will admit; brought closetogether, as the two blocks of a tackle in hoisting.
Cocklebur.

Pertaining to, or used in, conversation, esp. common andfamiliar conversation; conversational; hence, unstudied; informal;as, colloquial intercourse; colloquial phrases; a colloquial style.-- Col*lo"qui*al*ly, adv.His [Johnson's] colloquial talents were, indeed, of the highestorder. Macaulay.

One of the orders of myriapods, including the centipeds. Theyhave a single pair of elongated legs attached laterally to eachsegment; well developed jaws; and a pair of thoracic legs convertedinto poison fangs. They are insectivorous, very active, and somespecies grow to the length of a foot.

A violent storm, often of vast extent, characterized by highwinds rotating about a calm center of low atmospheric pressure. Thiscenter moves onward, often with a velocity of twenty or thirty milesan hour.
Coexistent. Locke.
In a cubical method.
A solid bulb-shaped root, as of the crocus. See Bulb.
Strife; contention. [Obs.] Bailey.
The foghting of hawks with each other.
A compartment. [Obs.] T. Warton.
To strut; to swagger; to look big, pert, or menacing. Addison.
That tie of consanguinity which exists between personsdescended from the same mother; -- used in distinction from agnation.
A troublesome grass, growing as a weed in grain fields; --called also chess. See Chess.
Belonging to a camp. Sir T. Browne.
An instrument to guid the hands and fingers of pupils inplaying on the piano, etc.
One who has served in an army in several campaigns; an oldsoldier; a veteran.
The process of chasing on metals; also, the work thus chased.Weale.
Trousers or breeches of corduroy. Corduroy road, a roadwayformed of logs laid side by side across it, as in marshy places; --so called from its rough or ribbed surface, resembling corduroy.[U.S.]

To draw together; to render narrower or smaller; to bind; tocramp; to contract or ause to shrink.Such things as constrict the fibers. Arbuthnot.Membranous organs inclosing a cavity which their contractionconstrict. Todd & Bowman.
Chiding; reproof; reproach. [Obs.]Angry, passionate correption being rather apt to provoke, than toamend. Hammond.
An allowance of meat, drink, or clothing due from an abbey orother religious house for the sustenance of such of the king'sservants as he may designate to receive it. [Written also corrody.]
To quality. [R.]The benefice he is capacified and designed for. Barrow.
The common soft tissue which unites the polyps of a compoundhydroid. See Hydroidea.
On this side of the mountains. See under Ultramontane.
To concrete into lumps; to clot. [Obs.] "Clottered blood."Chapman.

A manger or open frame for hay; a crib; a rack. [Obs.]Begin from first where He encradled was, In simple cratch, wrapt in awad of hay. Spenser.Cratch cradle, a representation of the figure of the cratch, madeupon the fingers with a string; cat's cradle; -- called also scratchcradle.

A member of the solar system which usually moves in anelongated orbit, approaching very near to the sun in its perihelion,and receding to a very great distance from it at its aphelion. Acomet commonly consists of three parts: the nucleus, the envelope, orcoma, and the tail; but one or more of these parts is frequentlywanting. See Illustration in Appendix.
Capable of being crystallized; that may be formed intocrystals.
Dried dung of cattle used as fuel. [Prov. Eng.] Waterland.
A colorless gas, CH3Cl, of a sweet odor, easily condensed to aliquid; -- called also methyl chloride.
A species of Ranunculus (R. bulbosus); -- called alsobutterflower, buttercup, kingcup, goldcup. Shak.
Serving to fill out or to complete; as, complementary numbers.Complementary colors. See under Color.-- Complementary angles (Math.), two angles whose sum is 90°.
A woman who leads or directs; a directress.
A contraction for Violoncello.
A narrow street. [Prov. Eng.]
A corselet. [Obs.] Hakluyt.
The yellow, waxlike secretion from the glands of the externalear; the earwax.
The extant copies of the first or earliest printed books, or ofsuch as were printed in the 15th century.

One who cuts purses for the sake of stealing them or theircontents (an act common when men wore purses fastened by a string totheir girdles); one who steals from the person; a pickpocketTo have an open ear, a quick eye, and a nimble hand, is necessary fora cutpurse. Shak.
A club usually located in the suburbs or vicinity of a city ortown and devoted mainly to outdoor sports.
Development of cells in animal and vegetable organisms. SeeGemmation, Budding, Karyokinesis; also Cell development, under Cell.
State of being curled; curliness.
A blue, fluorescent, oily base (regarded as a derivative ofpyridine), obtained from conine.
To make colloquial and familiar; as, to colloquialize one'sstyle of writing.
Having the ovules and seeds so curved, or bent down uponthemselves, that the ends of the embryo are brought close together.
Cowardice. [Obs.]

An ancient Spanish land tenure similar to the English knight'sfee; hence, in Spain and countries settled by the Spanish, a landmeasure of varying size. In Cuba it is about 33 acres; in Porto Rico,about 194 acres; in the Southwestern United States, about 108 acres.
In hair dressing, a loose, low coil at the back of the head,like the knot on the head of the bust of Clytie by G. F. Watts.
Relating to a church; unduly fond of church forms. [Colloq.]
A kind of wig. [Obs.] Lamb.
A hydrous sulphate of copper and lead, found in some parts ofCaledonia or Scotland.
A wooden tool used in graining leather. Knight.
A kind of weak cider made by steeping the refuse pomace inwater.Ciderkin is made for common drinking, and supplies the place of smallbeer. Mortimer.
To grumble or mutter like a froward child. [Obs.] E. Phillips.
To grow cordial; to feel or express cordiality. [R.]
Same as Couch.
A game of cards derived from conquian, played by two or moreplayers with one or two full packs of cards.
Cream; -- a term used esp. in cookery, names of liqueurs, etc.
In a coy manner; with reserve.
A piece of oak bolted perpendicularly on the side of a vessel,to aid in drawing down and securing the clew of the mainsail.
A lively Polish dance, in 2-4 time.
Making Christ the center, about whom all things are grouped, asin religion or history; tending toward Christ, as the central objectof thought or emotion. J. W. Chadwick.
The office of a chancellor; the time during which one ischancellor.
Candidacy.

The state of having a body; the state of being corporeal;materiality.The one attributed corporeity to God. Bp. Stillingfleet.Those who deny light to be matter, do not therefore deny itscorporeity. Coleridge.
The black grime or soot of coal. [Obs.] Burton.
Defensive armor for the thighs. [ Written also cuisse, andquish.]
The uppermost cover of a bed or of any piece of furniture.Lay her in lilies and in violets . . . And odored sheets and arrascoverlets. Spenser.
Hollow-seeded; having the ventral face of the seedlike carpelsincurved at the ends, as in coriander seed.
Similarity of origin; affinity. [Obs.]  Dr. H. More.
A boast. See Crack, n. [Obs.] Spenser.
A native or natives of Ceylon descended from its primitiveinhabitants; also (sing.),
The papal chamberlain; the cardinal who presides over thepope's household. He has at times possessed great power. [Writtenalso camerlengo and camarlengo.]
A diminutive of the bendlet, containing one half its area orone quarter the area of the bend. When a single cottise is used aloneit is often called a cost. See also Couple-close.
Quality of being customable; conformity to custom. [Obs.]
To give a rural appearance to; to cause to appear rustic. Lamb.
Looking around everi way; cautious; careful of consequences;watchful of danger. "Circumspective eyes." Pope.
One who consigns. See Consignor.
A bony prominence; particularly, an eminence at the end of abone bearing a rounded articular surface; -- sometimes applied alsoto a concave articular surface.
Hot furnished with a cushion.Rows of long, cushionless benches, supplying the place of pews.Hawthorne.
Moving or moved by cirri, or hairlike appendages.
A colorless crystalline alkaloid obtained in small quantitiesfrom opium.
Furnished with, protected by, or built like, a casemate.Campbell.
The surface formed by cutting away the arris, or angle, formedby two faces of a piece of timber, stone, etc.
To bestow horns upon; to make a cuckold of; to cuckold. [Obs.]Burton.
To have reciprocal or mutual relations; to be mutually related.Doctrine and worship correlate as theory and practice. Tylor.
Ascending and descending fresh streams from and to the sea, asthe salmon; anadromous. [R.]
Destitute of claws.

An inflammatory affection of any mucous membrane, in whichthere are congestion, swelling, and an altertion in the quantity andquality of mucus secreted; as catarrh of the stomach; catarrh of thebladder.

Disposition to please or oblige; obliging compliance with thewishes of others; a deportment indicative of a desire to please;courtesy; civility.These [ladies] . . . are by the just complaisance and gallantry ofour nation the most powerful part of our people. Addison.They strive with their own hearts and keep them down, In complaisanceto all the fools in town. Young.
See under Tenant.
Relating to concupiscence. [Obs.] Johnson.
To draw or press into wrinkles or folds to crush together; torumple; as, to crumple paper.They crumpled it into all shapes, and diligently scanned everywrinkle that could be made. Addison.
A cotton stuff showing a fine cord on one side and a satinysurface on the other.
An iron or pope thimble or grommet worked into or attached tothe edges and corners of a sail; -- usually in the plural. Thecringles are used for making fast the bowline bridles, earings, etc.
A codifier; a maker of codes. [R.]
An instrument for constructing triangles in marine surveying,etc.

A system or method of connecting and operating two inductionmotors so that the primary circuit of one is connected to thesecondary circuit of the other, the primary circuit of the latterbeing connected to the source of supply; also, a system of electrictraction in which motors so connected are employed. The cascadesystem is also called tandem, or concatenated, system; the connectiona cascade, tandem, or concatenated, connection, or a concatenation;and the control of the motors so obtained a tandem, or concatenation,control. In the cascade system of traction the cascade connection isused for starting and for low speeds up to half speed. For full speedthe short-circuited motor is cut loose from the other motor and iseither left idle or (commonly) connected direct to the line.
A grove of small growth; a thicket of brushwood; a wood cut atcertain times for fuel or other purposes. See Copse.The rate of coppice lands will fall, upon the discovery of coalmines. Locke.
Producing a blue or sky color. [R.]
One who compels or constrains.
The quality of being capital; preeminence. [R.]
To pollute; to defile. [Obs.] Cockeram.
To turn to ice; to freeze. [Obs.] Sir T. Browne.
a neglect of a tenant to perform services, or make payment, fortwo years.
A mode of harrowing crosswise, or transversely to the ridges.Crabb.
A variant of Chieftain. [Obs.] Chaucer.
A high, steep rock; a precipice. Cliff swallow (Zoöl.), a NorthAmerican swallow (Petrochelidon lunifrons), which builds its nestagainst cliffs; the eaves swallow.
To link together; to unite in a series or chain, as thingsdepending on one another.This all things friendly will concatenate. Dr. H. More
Corruptible. [Obs.]
A maker of cider. [Obs.] Mortimer.
A horse; hence, a support or frame. Cheval glass, a mirrorswinging in a frame, and large enough to reflect the full leghtfigure.
A contrivance; a new-fangled device; -- used scornfully.[Colloq. or Dial.] -- Con*trap"tious (#), a.
Conditionally. [Obs.]
Circular motion in a direction contrary to some other circularmotion.
Of or pertaining to the crow; crowlike.
The native carbonate of lead.
Capable of existing in harmony; congruous; suitable; notrepugnant; -- usually followed by with.Our poets have joined together such qualities as are by nature themost compatible. Broome.
See Cipher.
1 Having corners or angles.
The compiler of a concordance.
An indented or zigzaged line of intrenchment.
Characterized by exessive brevity; short; rudely concise; as,curt limits; a curt answer.The curt, yet comprehensive reply. W. Irving.
Of or pertaining to Cracow in Poland.
The state or quality of being columnar.
One of the corneas of a compound eye in the invertebrates.Carpenter.
Pertaining to a choriamb.-- n.
An open internal courtyard inclosed by the walls of a largedwelling house or other large and stately building.
The capybara. See Capybara.
The state of being a cub. [Jocose] "From cubhood to old age."W. B. Dawkins.
To castrate, as a fowl.
Same as Conchometry.
Covered with minute cracks in the glaze; -- said of some kindsof porcelain and fine earthenware.
One of the two principal orders of myriapods. They havenumerous segments, each bearing two pairs of small, slender legs,which are attached ventrallly, near together.
The act business of forming chart's or maps.
A curvet. Peacham.
A shallow porus cup, used in refining precious metals, commonlymade of bone ashes (phosphate of lime). [Written also coppel.] Cupeldust, powder used in purifying metals.
A term applied to the action of nerve force in the spinalcenter. Marshall Hall.
The dissection of cartilages.
The exact opposite.The German prose offers the counterpole to the French style. DeQuincey.
The son of Erebus and Nox, whose office it was to ferry thesouls of the dead over the Styx, a river of the infernal regions.Shak.
A rubbing together; friction. [Obs.] Bacon.
Resembling a cow.With cowlike udders and with oxlike eyes. Pope.
A series of muscular contractions due to sudden stretching ofthe muscle, -- a sign of certain neuropathies.
Coincidence, as that of lines or figures laid over one another.
The process of chenge into a stony or calcareous substance bythe deposition of lime salt; -- normally, as in the formation of boneand teeth; abnormally, as in calcareous degeneration of tissue.
Shaped like one half of a bivalve shell; shell-shaped.
Soft leather made of kid skin. Fig.: Used as a symbol offlexibility. [Obs.]Here's wit of cheveril, that stretches from an inch narrow to an ellbroad. Shak.
Expelling wind from the body; warning; antispasmodic."Carmenative hot seeds." Dunglison.
One who, or that which, crawls; a creeper; a reptile.
Bell-shaped.
To play the thief; to steal. [Cant]But as I am Crack, I will convey, crossbite, and cheat uponSimplicius. Marston.
The flowing of different streams into one. [Obs.] Burton.
See Clientele, n., 2.
Blue; cerulean. [Obs.] Dyer.
A slow unwieldy trading vessel. [Obs.] [Written also crayer,cray, and craie.] Shak.
See Neurine.
One who plays upon a reed or pipe. [Obs.] Blount.
A scoop or ring with either a blunt or a cutting edge, forremoving substances from the walls of a cavity, as from the eye, ear,or womb.
One who makes or deals in cutlery, or knives and other cuttinginstruments.
A South American rodent (Myopotamus coypus), allied to thebeaver. It produces a valuable fur called nutria. [Written alsocoypou.]
A plant of the genus Arum (A. maculatum); the European wake-robin.
Crosiered.
A genus of living Brachiopoda; -- so called from its fanciedresemblance to the cranium or skull.
State of lying down for repose. [R.]
Having cogs or teeth projecting parallel to the axis, insteadof radiating from it. [R.] Contrate wheel. See Crown wheel.
Of or pertaining to Cantabria on the Bay of Biscay in Spain.
The state or quality of being consecutive.
One of the peculiar stinging, cells found in Coelenterata; anematocyst; a lasso cell.
A peculiar mucilaginous substance extracted from the seeds ofthe quince (Cydonia vulgaris), and regarded as a variety of amylose.
See Chlorometry.
In violation of law; wickedly.
Having the quality of cementating or uniting firmly.
A reed stop in an organ.
According to estimate made by comparison; relatively; notpositively or absolutely.With but comparatively few exceptions. Prescott.
(Mus.) Gradually diminishing in rapidity and loudness.
Pertaining to the ribs or the sides of the body; as, costalnerves.
Acute discernment.

An unctuous preparation for external application, of aconsistence intermediate between that of an ointment and a plaster,so that it can be spread upon cloth without the use of heat, but doesnot melt when applied to the skin.
The act of flying round. [R.]
An ancient term for embroidery, esp. applied to the earliestform of lace, or to that early embroidery on linen and the like, fromwhich the manufacture of lace was developed.

The spiritual head of the Armenian church, who resides atEtchmiadzin, Russia, and has ecclesiastical jurisdiction over, andconsecrates the holy oil for, the Armenians of Russia, Turkey, andPersia, including the Patriarchs of Constantinople, Jerusalem, andSis.
A member of an exceeding austere religious order, founded atChartreuse in France by St. Bruno, in the year 1086.
To part; to open; to crack; to separate; as parts of bodies;as, the ground cleaves by frost.The Mount of Olives shall cleave in the midst. Zech. xiv. 4.
The quality or state of being compassionate.
In a constructive manner; by construction or inference.A neutral must have notice of a blockade, either actually by a formalinformation, or constructively by notice to his government. Kent.
See Iolite.
Of or pertaining to chalcedony.
That part of the rampart and parapet which is between twobastions or two gates. See Illustrations of Ravelin and Bastion.
Conciseness in writing. Bp. Horsley.
Inclined to flow or run together. --Con*flux"i*ble*ness, n.
A var. spelling of Coin, Quoin, a corner, wedge; -- chieflyused in the phrase coign of vantage, a position advantageous foraction or observation.
In a familiar manner.
A vessel carried on a pole between two persons, for conveyanceof water. Johnson.
The rounded or pointed top of a grinding mill spindle, forminga pivot on which the stone is balanced.
