Barriers with loopholes, formerly erected on the deck of avessel to shelter the men in a close engagement with an enemy'sboarders; -- called also close quarters. [Obs.]
A creatress. [R.]
The state or office of a coadjutor; joint assistance. Pope.
Same as Corallian.
A disease incident to trees, causing the bark to rot and falloff.
the boilers in the galley for cooking; as, a ship's coppers.
To brace in opposite directions; as, to counterbrace the yards,i. e., to brace the head yards one way and the after yards another.
See Crimson.
Timorous; fearful; cowardly. [R.] Shak.
Shaped like the head. Craing.
Complimentary. [R.] Boswell.
See Charge, n., 17.
A surgeon. [Obs.]
The largest kind of bass viol. See Violone.
A style of interweaving giving to fabrics a channeled or flutedeffect; also, a fabric woven so as to have this effect; a rep.
A hinge having one strap perpendicular and the other straphorizontal giving it the form of an Egyptian or T cross.
An order of birds, including the swans, ducks, geese,flamingoes and screamers.
Having the quality of contracting, binding, or compressing.Thomson.

Agreement or concurrence for some end or purpose; conspiracy.[R.]As soon as it was day, certain Jews made a conspiration. Udall.In our natural body every part has a nacassary sympathy with everyother, and all together form, by their harmonious onspiration, ahealthy whole. Sir W. Hamilton.
Of, pertaining to, or derived from, the brain. Cerebric acid(Physiol. Chem.), a name formerly sometimes given to cerebrin.
Pertaining to the cuticle, or external coat of the skin;epidermal.
See Cozen.
A mobile liquid, CO.N.C6H5, of pungent odor. It is the phenylsalt of isocyanic acid.
Capable of cleaving or being divided.
Existence from eternity equally with another eternal being;equal eternity.
See Cotton flannel.
Colonelcy. Swift.
A trammel, or hook to support a pot over a fire. Knight.
Like a cancer; having the qualities or virulence of a cancer;affected with cancer. "cancerous vices" G. Eliot.[1913 Webster]
A large family of dicotyledonous plants, having their flowersarranged in dense heads of many small florets and their anthersunited in a tube. The daisy, dandelion, and asters, are examples.
A white crystalline substance, C27H55.OH, obtained from Chinesewax, and regarded as an alcohol of the marsh gas series; -- calledalso cerotic alcohol, ceryl alcohol.
A fortune teller; one who pretends to reveal mysteries. [Obs.]Hudibras.
Cathedral. [R.]
One who ciphers.
Mild in temper and disposition; merciful; compassionate. Shak.-- Clem"ent*ly, adv.
One who instructs by question and answer, especially inreligions matters.
Concord; agreement. [Obs.] Aschlam.

Of or pertaining to Calippus, an Athenian astronomer. Calippicperiod, a period of seventy-six years, proposed by Calippus, as animprovement on the Metonic cycle, since the 6940 days of the Metoniccycle exceeded 19 years by about a quarter of a day, and exceeded 235lunations by something more.
Without a crown.
The process of breaking up the flat masses into which wroughtiron is first hammered, in order that the pieces may be reheated andwrought into bar iron.
The hooded snake (Naia tripudians), a highly venomous serpentinhabiting India.
To shut the eyes to; to overlook; to pretend not to see. [R. &Obs.] "Divorces were not connived only, but with eye open allowed."Milton.
To shade by means of crosshatching.
The unoin or articulation of bones to form a joint.
A cancer. By some medical writers, the term is applied to anindolent tumor. See Cancer. Dunglison.

A euphorbiaceous West Indian shrub (Croton Eleutheria); also,its aromatic bark. Cascarilla bark (or Cascarila) (Med.), the bark ofCroton Eleutheria. It has an aromatic odor and a warm, spicy, bittertaste, and when burnt emits a musky odor. It is used as a gentletonic, and sometimes, for the sake of its fragrance, mixed withsmoking tobacco, when it is said to occasion vertigo andintoxication.
Without a comb or crest; as, a combless ceck.

A feudal prerogative of the lord of the soil entitling him tolodging and food at his tenant's house. Burrill.Sometimes he contrived, in deflance of the law, to live by coshering,that is to say, by quartering himself on the old tentants of hisfamily, who, wretched as was their own condition, could not refuse aportion of their pittance to one whom they still regarded as theirrightful lord. Macaulay.
Pertaining to whetstones; like or suitable for whetstones.
To take leave with the customary civilities; to bow orcourtesy.
Having a cramp or square piece at the end; -- said of a crossso furnished.
That which is contained; the extent; the substance. [Obs.]The containment of a rich man's estate. Fuller.
A colonel. [Obs.] Spenser.
A talebearer. [R.] Shak.
Helmet-shaped; -- applied to a corolla having a broad, helmet-shaped upper petal, as in aconite.
Determined by, or pertaining to, consultation; deliberate;consultative.He that remains in the grace of God sins not by any deliberative,consultive, knowing act. Jer. Taylor.
Like a cushion; soft; pliable.A flat and cushiony noce. Dickens.
To fold and sew down the edge of with a coarse zigzag stitch.
Without chaff.
Falling. [R.] "Cadent tears." Shak.
The whole collection; the entire quantity or number; -- usuallyin the phrase the whole caboodle. [Slang, U.S.] Bartlett.
Basso continuo, or continued bass.
One who converses much, or who excels in conversation. Byron.
Like a curmudgeon; niggardly; churlish; as, a curmudgeonlyfellow.

An elementary substance; a metal which combined with oxygenforms lime. It is of a pale yellow color, tenacious, and malleable.It is a member of the alkaline earth group of elements. Atomic weight40. Symbol Ca.
Colored. [Obs.] Ray.
A sloping plain, esp. one with the upper end at the crest of acliff; a hill or ridge with one face steep and the opposite facegently sloping. [Southwestern U. S.]
A powerful vegetable alkaloid, C17H19NO5, extracted from theColchicum autumnale, or meadow saffron, as a white or yellowishamorphous powder, with a harsh, bitter taste; -- called alsocolchicia.
A mineral, found in crystals, of a yellow to green or browncolor, and consisting of aluminia and glucina. It is very hard, andis often used as a gem.
A soft solid made by incorporating a medicinal substance orsubstances with sugar, sirup, or honey.
Shaped like a plipper, as one petal of the lady's-slipper;calceolate.
Same as Carl, 3. Carling Sunday, a Sunday in Lent when carlsare eaten. In some parts of England, Passion Sunday. See Carl, 4.
The act or art of coloring; the state of being colored. Bacon.The females . . . resemble each other in their general type ofcoloration. Darwin.

An apparatus in which the image of an external object orobjects is, by means of lenses. thrown upon a sensitized plate orsurface placed at the back or an extensible darkened box or chambervariously modifled; -- commonly called simply the camera.
A tenor clarinet; -- called also basset horn, and sometimesconfounded with the English horn, which is a tenor oboe.
An accomplice. [Obs.]To quell the rebels and their complices. Shak.
The act or operation of cutting, to relieve the structure instrangulated hernia. [Frequently written kelotomy.]
A strait, or narrow sea, between two portions of lands; as, theBritish Channel.
To plant or establish a colony or colonies in; to people withcolonists; to migrate to and settle in. Bacon.They that would thus colonize the stars with inhabitants. Howell.
See under Calcite.

Inlaid between partitions: -- said of enamel when the lineswhich divide the different patches of fields are composed of a kindof metal wire secured to the ground; as distinguished from champlevéenamel, in which the ground is engraved or scooped out to receive theenamel. S. Wells Williams.
To examine or question, as a witness who has been called andexamined by the opposite party. "The opportunity to cross-examine thewitnesses." Kent.
Of or pertaining to cement, as of a tooth; as, cemental tubes.R. Owen.
A powerfully narcotic and intoxicating gum resin which exudesfrom the flower heads, seeds, etc., of Indian hemp.
The board used in the game of chess, having eight rows ofalternate light and dark squares, eight in each row. SeeCheckerboard.
With coincidence.
An oval figure on monuments, and in papyri, containing the nameof a sovereign.
A small gutter; a furrow; a groove.
A testicle. [Obs.] Chaucer.
A projecting ornament in carved stone. Specifically, a finial.[Obs.]
To grant; to allow; to assent to; to admit. [Obs.]Interpreters . . . will not consent it to be a true story. Milton.

Shortened or reduced; -- said of the distance of a planet fromthe sun or earth, as measured in the plane of the ecliptic, or thedistance from the sun or earth to that point where a perpendicular,let fall from the planet upon the plane of the ecliptic, meets theecliptic. Curtate cycloid. (Math.) See Cycloid.
The manners of a courtier; courtliness. [Obs.] B. Jonson.
See Cæsarism.
Same as Prison base.
Of or pertaining to pottery; relating to the art of makingearthenware; as, ceramic products; ceramic ornaments for ceilings.
See Crosier.
In a manner becoming the principles of the Christian religion.Sufferings . . . patiently and Christianly borne. Sharp.

The act of collimating; the adjustment of the line of thesights, as the axial line of the telescope of an instrument, into itsproper position relative to the other parts of the instrument. Errorof collimation, the deviation of the line collimation of anastronomical instrument from the position it ought to have withrespect to the axis of motion of the instrument.-- Line of collimation, the axial line of the telescope of anastronomical or geodetic instrument, or the line which passes throughthe optical center of the object glass and the intersection of thecross wires at its focus.
The gall bladder.
Well-propotioned; symmetrical. [Poetic] Shak.

A vertical cleated drum or cylinder, revolving on an uprightspindle, and surmounted by a drumhead with sockets for bars orlevers. It is much used, especially on shipboard, for moving orraising heavy weights or exerting great power by traction upon a ropeor cable, passing around the drum. It is operated either by steampower or by a number of men walking around the capstan, each pushingon the end of a lever fixed in its socket. [Sometimes spelt Capstern,but improperly.] Capstan bar, one of the long bars or levers by whichthe capstan is worked; a handspike..-- To pawl the capstan, to drop the pawls so that they will catch inthe notches of the pawl ring, and prevent the capstan from turningback.-- To rig the capstan, to prepare the for use, by putting the barsin the sockets.-- To surge the capstan, to slack the tension of the rope or cablewound around it.
The East Indian name for the large spiral shell of severalspecies of sea conch much used in making bangles, esp. Turbinellapyrum. Called also chank chell.
Calyculate.
Tending to tear or pull up. [Obs.]The ends of the fragment . . . will not yield to the convellentforce. Todd & Bowman.
A flattish or convex flower cluster, of the centrifugal ordeterminate type, differing from a corymb chiefly in the order of theopening of the blossoms.
A kind of lichen, of the genus Cladonia.
To destroy the effect of a charm upon.

A native of the Caribbee islands or the coaste of the Caribbeansea; esp., one of a tribe of Indians inhabiting a region of SouthAmerica, north of the Amazon, and formerly most of the West Indiaislands.
Same as Calcite.

A complete charge for a firearm, contained in, or held togetherby, a case, capsule, or shell of metal, pasteboard, or othermaterial. Ball cartridge, a cartridge containing a projectile.-- Blank cartrige, a cartridge without a projectile, -- Center-firecartridge, a cartridge in which the fulminate occupies an axialposition usually in the center of the base of the capsule, instead ofbeing contained in its rim. In the Prussian needle gun the fulminateis applied to the middle of the base of the bullet. Rim-firecartridge, a cartridge in which the fulminate is contained in a rimsurrounding its base.-- Cartridge bag, a bag of woolen cloth, to hold a charge for acannon.-- Cartridge belt, a belt having pocket for cartridges.-- Cartridge box, a case, usually of leather, attached to a belt orstrap, for holding cartridges.-- Cartridge paper. (a) A thick stout paper for inclosingcartridges. (b) A rough tinted paper used for covering walls, andalso for making drawings upon.
Tending to conserve; preservative.
Of, pertaining to, or resembling, a cataphract.
An instrument, intended to represent the revolution of a cometround the sun. Hutton.
To arrange (types) in a composing stick in order for printing;to set (type).
A claw. See Chela. [Obs.]
A public room where coffee and other refreshments may beobtained.
An instrument for measuring shells, or the angle of theirspire.
A salad made of sliced cabbage.
To make like heaven. [Obs.] Sir T. Browne.
A fault or error to be corrected.
The group of Thysanura which includes Lepisma and allied forms;the bristletails. See Bristletail, and Lepisma.
To break or fly off in small pieces.
Capable of being coerced.-- Co*er"ci*ble*ness, n.
A custodian. [Scot.] Sir W. Scott.
Equal share. [Obs.]Myself will bear . . . coportion of your pack. Spenser.
(Zoöl.) One of the Ctenophora.

One who creates, produces, or constitutes. Specifically, theSupreme Being.To sin's rebuke and my Creater's praise. Shak.The poets and artists of Greece, who are at the same time itsprophets, the creators of its divinities, and the revealers of itstheological beliefs. Caird.
Same as Craps.
A peculiar perforated organ of certain spiders (Ciniflonidæ),used for spinning a special kind of silk.
One of the claque employed to applaud at a theater.
One who catechises.
The actual, substantial presence of the body of Christ with thebread and wine of the sacrament of the Lord's Supper; impanation; --opposed to transubstantiation.
A social gathering; usually, one for dancing.
Furnished with tendrils.
A deposit of coralliferous limestone forming a portion of themiddle division of the oölite; -- called also coral-rag.
A collective term for the Welsh race; -- so called bythemselves . [Written also Cymri, Cwmry, Kymry, etc.]
Topollute. [Obs.] Skelton.
An earth of a deep brown color, containing more vegetable thanmineral matter; an earthy variety of lignite, or brown coal.
One who commutes; especially, one who commutes in traveling.
A kind of fish. Same as Cod.
Having a charge in each of the four corners; -- said of a crosson a shield, and also of the shield itself.
To cause to unite, or to regard as united, in one commonsubstance or nature. [R.]His soul must be consubstantiated with reason. Jer. Taylor.
To cut in pieces; to cut out from. [Obs.] [Written alsocantile.]
To attend in public places as a guide and protector; tomatronize.Fortunately Lady Bell Finley, whom I had promised to chaperon, sentto excuse herself. Hannah More.
To collect, as into a cupboard; to hoard. [R.] Shak.
To cause (a vessel) to lean over so that she floats on oneside, leaving the other side out of water and accessible for repairsbelow the water line; to case to be off the keel.
To wait or watch for; to be on guard against. [Obs.] Chaucer.
A singer or composer of chorals.
Teaching what is useful. "A chrestomathic school." Southey.
Acting in competition; competing; rival.
Containing, pertaining to, or of the nature of, coprolites.
Having the form of a circle; round. "Monthly changes in hercircled orb." Shak.
An explosive consisting essentially of nitroglycerin, woodmeal, and some nitrate, as that of sodium.
dealing with (a person or problem) directly; taking the bull bythe horns.Syn. -- braving, coping with, grappling, tackling.[WordNet 1.5 +PJC]
Community of limits; contiguity. [R.] Bailey.
Containing copper; as, cupriferous silver.
Corrosive. [R.] Bp. King.
A capillary blood vessel. [Obs.] Sir T. Browne.
Concretionary.
A toll for passage through a forest. [Obs.] Cowell.

Rising or swelling into a spherical or rounded form; regularlyprotuberant or bulging; -- said of a spherical surface or curved linewhen viewed from without, in opposition to concave.Drops of water naturally form themselves into figures with a convexsurface. Whewell.Double convex, convex on both sides; convexo-convex.
Agreeing in mind; accordant.The consentient judgment of the church. Bp. Pearson.
To cover with clapboards; as, to clapboard the sides of ahouse. [U. S.] Bartlett.
The English form of the Spanish word Cañon.
Relating to the chair or office of a teacher. [Obs.]

The combination of a combustible with a supporter ofcombustion, producing heat, and sometimes both light and heat.Combustion results is common cases from the mutual chemical actionand reaction of the combustible and the oxygen of the atmosphere,whereby a new compound is formed. Ure.Supporter of combustion (Chem.), a gas as oxygen, the combination ofwhich with a combustible, as coal, constitutes combustion.
See Caboose.
Capable of being contested; debatable.

A chamber, or instrument having a chamber. Specifically: Thecamera obscura when used in photography. See Camera, and Cameraobscura. Bellows camera. See under Bellows.-- In camera (Law), in a judge's chamber, that is, privately; as, ajudge hears testimony which is not fit for the open court in camera.-- Panoramic, or Pantascopic, camera, a photographic camera in whichthe lens and sensitized plate revolve so as to expose adjacent partsof the plate successively to the light, which reaches it through anarrow vertical slit; -- used in photographing broad landscapes.Abney.
One who compiles; esp., one who makes books by compilation.
Long-toed boots or shoes formerly worn in many parts of Europe;-- so called from Cracow, in Poland, where they were first worn inthe fourteenth century. Fairholt.
Of or pertaining to Cuba or its inhabitants.-- n.
A list of servants in a household; -- called also chequer roll.
A turkish fabric of silk and cotton, with gold threadinterwoven.
Having the quality of consolidating broken bones.
One of two corresponding copies of an instrument; a duplicate.
See Scimiter.
Shouting together for joy; rejoicing together. [R.] Neale.
Contrivance; invention; arrangement; design; plan. [Obs.]Consider the admirable contrivement and artifice of this greatfabric. Glanvill.Active to meet their contrivements. Sir G. Buck.
To confederate. [Obs.] Sir T. North.
One who makes a confession. [Obs.] Bp. Hall.
Hundredfold.
To struggle or contend, as with an opposing force; to fight.To combat with a blind man I disdain. Milton.After the fall of the republic, the Romans combated only for thechoice of masters. Gibbon.
An ornamental bordering or framelike decoration around thesides and top of a door, window, or fireplace. The top piece iscalled the traverse and the side pieces the ascendants.
A curved sheath or breasting for a revolving cylinder or roll.
A mild kind caustic used to reduce warts and otherexcrescences. Dunglison.
A curve generated by a point in the plane of a circle when thecircle is rolled along a straight line, keeping always in the sameplane.
A state of profound insensibility from which it is difficult orimpossible to rouse a person. See Carus.
A fortune teller.
To render useless or void; to annul; to reject; to send away.[Obs.] Sir W. Raleing.
Condition of being circumjacent, or of bordering ou every side.

To address with expressions of sympathetic pleasure on accountof some happy event affecting the person addressed; to wish joy to.It is the king's most sweet pleasure and affection to congratulatethe princess at her pavilion. Shak.To congratulate one's self, to rejoice; to feel satisfaction; toconsider one's self happy or fortunate.
A plant of several species of the Mint family, cultivated forits bright-colored or variegated leaves.

Eating or feeding on flesh. The term is applied: (a) to animalswhich naturally seek flesh for food, as the tiger, dog, etc.; (b) toplants which are supposed to absorb animal food; (c) to substanceswhich destroy animal tissue, as caustics.
The practice of concubinage. [Obs.] Strype.
A salt of cyanuric acid.
An annual variety of Brassica oleracea, or cabbage of which thecluster of young flower stalks and buds is eaten as a vegetable.
At great cost; expensively. [Obs.]
Of or pertaining to the papal curia; as, the curial etiquetteof the Vatican. -- n.
See Cleavers.
Compatible; suitable; consistent. [Obs.] Sir M. Hale.
See Cæsural.
Good form; style. [Slang]
Of or pertaining to a corolla.
One who confounds.
A state of being complicate or intricate. Mitford.
Materialism. Cudworth.
See Center.

A meeting, especially a preliminary meeting, of personsbelonging to a party, to nominate candidates for public office, or toselect delegates to a nominating convention, or to confer regardingmeasures of party policy; a political primary meeting.This day learned that the caucus club meets, at certain times, in thegarret of Tom Dawes, the adjutant of the Boston regiment. JohnAdams's Diary [Feb. , 1763].
Same as Coerulignone.
A granule of chlorophyll; -- also called chloroleucite.
To express sympathetic sorrow; to grieve in sympathy; --followed by with.Your friends would have cause to rejoice, rather than condole withyou. Sir W. Temple.
Slipper-ahaped. See Calceiform.
Darkened. See Colly, v. t.

A piece of timber or an iron barrel traversed with iron-pointedspikes or spears, five or six feet long, used to defend a passage,stop a breach, or impede the advance of cavalry, etc.Obstructions of chain, boom, and cheval-de-frise. W. Irving.
Crowded together. Gray.
In union; conjointly; unitedly; together. Sir W. Hamilton.
A mound of earth in which potatoes and other vegetables arestored for protection against frost; -- called also burrow and pie.[Prov. Eng.]
Of, pertaining to, or derived from, camphor. Camphoric acid, awhite crystallizable substance, C10H16O4, obtained from the oxidationof camphor.

A bent portion of an axle, or shaft, or an arm keyed at rightangles to the end of a shaft, by which motion is imparted to orreceived from it; also used to change circular into reciprocatingmotion, or reciprocating into circular motion. See Bell crank.
A wax candle used in religous rites.
The state of being curvilinear or of being bounded by curvedlines.
An open level tract of country; especially "Campagna di Roma."The extensive undulating plain which surrounds Rome.
A garment resembling a long frock coat worn by the clergy ofcertain churches when officiating, and by others as the usually outergarment.
Conditional. [Obs.]Barak's answer is faithful, though conditionate. Bp. Hall.
Enlarged gradually at the end, as the antennæ of certaininsects.

A game of cards, played by two or four persons, in which thereis a crib. (See Crib, 11.) It is characterized by a great variety ofchances.A man's fancy would be summed up in cribbage. John Hall.Cribbage board, a board with holes and pegs, used by cribbage playersto score their game.
Pertaining to, or obtained from, coffee. Caffeic acid, an acidobtained from coffee tannin, as a yellow crystalline substance,C9H8O4.
A place where the business of canning fruit, meat, etc., iscarried on. [U. S.]
One who cringes.
To pardon; to overlook the offense of; esp., to forgive for aviolation of the marriage law; -- said of either the husband or thewife.
Chasteness.
A species of fern with fronds (Asplenium Ceterach).
One who crams; esp., one who prepares a pupil hastily for anexxamination, or a pupil who is thus prepared. Dickens.
An order of marine Crustacea, mostly of small size.
The process of forming an artificial tip or part of a lip, byusing for the purpose a piece of healthy tissue taken from someneighboring part.
One who consents.
A genus of trees growing naturally on the Andes in Peru andadjacent countries, but now cultivated in the East Indies, producinga medicinal bark of great value.
See Calumbin.
Of the same color; of uniform color. [R.] "Concolor animals."Sir T. Browne.

With a constantly increasing volume of voice; with graduallyincreasing strength and fullness of tone; -- a direction for theperformance of music, indicated by the mark, or by writing the wordon the score.

Belonging to a close or termination; decisive; convincing;putting an end to debate or question; leading to, or involving, aconclusion or decision.Secret reasons . . . equally conclusive for us as they were for them.Rogers.Conclusive evidence (Law), that of which, from its nature, the lawallows no contradiction or explanation.-- Conclusive presumption (Law), an inference which the law makes soperemptorily that it will not allow it to be overthrown by anycontrary proof, however strong.
Abatement of a morbid process, as a fever and return to anormal condition. [Obs.]
A quoin.See you yound coigne of the Capitol yon corner stone Shak.
One whose business is to draw up conveyances of property, asdeeds, mortgages, leases, etc. Burrill.
A white wax, made by bleaching and purifying ozocerite, andused as a substitute for beeswax.
Filled with white flakes; mothery; -- said vinegar whencontaining mother. [Prov. Eng.] Halliwell.

The outer vestment worn by the priest in saying Mass,consisting, in the Roman Catholic Church, of a broad, flat, backpiece, and a narrower front piece, the two connected over theshoulders only. The back has usually a large cross, the front anupright bar or pillar, designed to be emblematical of Christ'ssufferings. In the Greek Church the chasuble is a large round mantle.[Written also chasible, and chesible.]
Contradictory; inconsistent; opposing. [R.] Milton.
To place fitly together; to adapt; to clear. [Obs.] Holland.
One who adheres to what he thinks the classical canons of art.Ruskin.
Closemouthed; silent. "Close-tongued treason." Shak.
The ring which turns inward and condenses the flame of a lamp.Knight.
A mucilagenous secretion of certain birds found as thecharacteristic ingredient of edible bird's-nests.
Of or pertaining to the chromosphere.
To sell wine or victuals. [Obs.] Warburfon.
A secretary or clerk. [Obs.] Chaucer.
Having the skeleton in the state of cartilage, the bonescontaining little or no calcareous matter; said of certain fishes, asthe sturgeon and the sharks.
Quality of being ceremonial.
A religious or either sex devoted to prayer and meditation,rather than to active works of charity.

A contrivance for producing manifold copies of writing ordrawing. The writing or drawing is done with a style carrying a smallwheel at the end which makes minute punctures in the paper, thusconverting it into a stencil. Copies are transferred with an inkedroller.
To stoop by bending the knees; to crouch; to squat; hence, toquail; to sink through fear.Our dame sits cowering o'er a kitchen fire. Dryden.Like falcons, cowering on the nest. Goldsmith.
Contiguous; touching. [Obs.] Holland.
A member of a council, especially of the common council of acity; a councilor.
In the game of croquet, to drive away an opponent's ball, afterputting one's own in contact with it, by striking one's own ball withthe mallet.
Attendance of a chaperon on a lady in public; protectionafforded by a chaperon.
The quality of being candid.
Tending to conciliate; pacific; mollifying; propitiating.The only alternative, therefore, was to have recourse to theconciliatory policy. Prescott.
Capable of, or fit for, being cultivated; capable or becomingcultured. London Spectator.
To weigh against; to counterbalance.
Confused, disturbed. [Obs.]  Chaucer.
One who studies, or is versed in, conchology.
Suffering or enduring together. [Obs.] Sir G. Buck.
A lichen (Lecanora tartarea), from which the powder isobtained.

To hide or withdraw from observation; to cover; to cover orkeep from sight; to prevent the discovery of; to withhold knowledgeof.It is the glory of God to conceal a thing. Prov. xxv. 2.Declare ye among the nations, . . . publish and conceal not. Jer. 1.2.He which finds him shall deserve our thanks, . . . He that concealshim, death. Shak.
the old imp. of chide. See Chide.
A tube or duct for conducting heat; a caliduct.
See Cannel coal.
A chromolithograph.
A field where corn is or has been growing; -- in England, afield of wheat, rye, barley, or oats; in America, a field of Indiancorn.

The land with which a prebend or other ecclesiastical office isendowed. [Obs.]The prebendaries over and above their reserved rents have a corps.Bacon.Army corps, or (French) Corps d'armée (k, a body containing two ormore divisions of a large army, organized as a complete army initself.-- Corps de logis (ke l Etym: [F., body of the house], the principalmass of a building, considered apart from its wings.-- Corps diplomatique (k Etym: [F., diplomatic body], the body ofministers or envoys accredited to a government.
Having power to compel; exercising or applying compulsion.Religion is . . . inconsistent with all compulsive motives. Sharp.

Reciprocal relation; corresponding similarity or parallelism ofrelation or law; capacity of being converted into, or of giving placeto, one another, under certain conditions; as, the correlation offorces, or of zymotic diseases. Correlation of energy, the relationto one another of different forms of energy; -- usually having somereference to the principle of conservation of energy. SeeConservation of energy, under Conservation.-- Correlation of forces, the relation between the forces whichmatter, endowed with various forms of energy, may exert.
The extreme end of the chancel or choir; properly the round orpolygonal part.
A peculiar kind of reproductive cell found in certain fungi,and often containing zoöspores.
Hollow relief; sculpture in relief within a sinking made forthe purpose, so no part of it projects beyond the plain surfacearound.
Expressing blame; censuring; reprehensory; inculpating.Adjectives . . . commonly used by Latian authors in a culpatorysense. Walpole.
To ravish; to debauch. Burton.
A match or contest of gamecocks.
A thrashing floor. Hos. ix. 1.
To cuckold. Dryden.
Pieces of timber at a masthead, to which are attached the uppershrouds. At the head of lower masts in large vessels, they support asemicircular platform called the "top."
To roll or turn round; to cause to perform a rotary or circularmotion. Ray.
A surname.
One who subscribed and defended the "Solemn League andCovenant." See Covenant.
The unit for estimating the weight of a
One who compliments; one given to complimenting; a flatterer.
A member of a corporation, esp. one of the original members.
Full of creases. Tennyson.
The quality of being compressible; compressibility.
The active medicinal principle of colocynth; a bitter, yellow,crystalline substance, regarded as a glucoside.
Having a crooked beak, as the crossbill.
A light covered carriage, having four wheels and seats for fouror more persons, usually drawn by one horse.
A genus of freshwater leeches, furnished with a proboscis. Theyfeed upon mollusks and worms.
Of or pertaining to collecting.The first twenty-five [years] must have been wasted for collectionalpurposes. H. A. Merewether.
See Chine, n., 3.
Acuteness; cunning. [Colloq.]
See Copra.
A stanchion or post of wood or iron, with two arms forsupporting a boom, spare yards, etc.; -- called also crane andcrutch. Totten.
Composed of three three-stranded ropes, or hawsers, twistedtogether to form a cable.
The act of buying the whole quantity of any commodity. [R.]Bacon.
A pipe for carrying off waste water, etc., from a sink orcesspool. Knight.
A genus of harmless serpents.
Vegetable coloring matter other than green; chromule.

The era in use in all Christian countries, which was intendedto commence with the birth of Christ. The era as now established wasfirst used by Dionysius Exiguus (died about 540), who placed thebirth of Christ on the 25th of December in the year of Rome 754,which year he counted as 1 a. d. This date for Christ's birth is nowgenerally thought to be about four years too late.
The quality of being chary.
The territorial disrict legally assigned to a chapel.
The absence or suppression of the essential organs (stamens andpistil) in a flower.
A black variety of diamond, found in Brazil, and used fordiamond drills. It occurs in irregular or rounded fragments, rarelydistinctly crystallized, with a texture varying from compact toporous.
Relating to escheat, forfeiture, or confiscation.
A cenotaph. [R.]Lord Cobham honored him with a cenotaphy. Macaulay.
A genus of trees, intermediate in character between the palmsand the pines. The pith of the trunk of some species furnishes avaluable kind of sago.
One of the classes of the arthropods, including lobsters andcrabs; -- so called from the crustlike shell with which they arecovered.
One proficient in craniology; a phrenologist.
Divination by dropping melted wax in water.
An Andalusian dance in three-four time, resembing the bolero.[Sometimes in English spelled cachuca (.]The orchestra plays the cachucha. Logfellow.
Short; compendious. [Obs.] Bailey.
Capable of being computed, numbered, or reckoned.Not easily computable by arithmetic. Sir M. Hale.
Capable of being constrained; liable to constraint, or torestraint. Hooker.
To treat or anæsthetize with cocaine. -- Co*ca`in*i*za"tion(#), n.
Corrodibility. "Corrosibility . . . answers corrosiveness."Boyle.
A south American bird of several species and genera, resemblingboth the eagles and the vultures. The caracaras act as scavengers,and are also called carrion buzzards.
The science of exchanges, a branch of political economy.
One versed in cetology.
Entitled to, or admitting, the benefit of clergy; as, aclergyable felony. Blackstone.
An american bird (Pipilo erythrophthalmus) of the Finch family,so called from its note; -- called also towhee bunting and groundrobin.
Like curd; full of curd; coagulated. "A curdy mass." Arbuthnot.
A cutting off; a division; a schism; a faction. South.
An embrace; dalliance. [Obs.] Halliwell.
The dress prescribed by canon to be worn by a clergyman whenoficiating. Sometimes, any distinctive professional dress. Fullcanonicals, the complete costume of an officiating clergyman orecclesiastic.
See under Dome.
producing coral; coraligerous; coralliferous. Humble.
Pica type; -- so called by French printers.
Fault-finding; censorious caviling. See Captious.-- Carp"ing*ly, adv.
A machine for measuring at any moment velocity of rotation, asof a wheel of a steam engine. Knight.
Bearing a tuft of soft hairs or down, as the seeds of milkweed.Gray.
Of or pertaining to the roebuck.
imp. of Cleave. [Obs.]

A piece of metal bent in the form of an oxbow, with the twoends perforated to receive a pin, used on the end of the tongue of aplow, wagen, etc., to attach it to a draft chain, whiffletree, etc.;-- called also clavel, clevy.
A particular leap of a horse, when he raises both his fore legsat once, equally advanced, and, as his fore legs are falling, raiseshis hind legs, so that all his legs are in the air at once.
Cut off smoothly, as distinguished from erased; -- usedespecially for the head or limb of an animal. See Erased.
A plant with the joints of the stem, and sometimes other parts,covered with a viscid secretion to which small insects adhere. Thespecies of Silene are examples of the catchfly.
One of a body of light troops, cavalry or infantry, trained forrapid movements.
A claw. [Holland.
Inflammatory swelling of the conjunctival tissue surroundingthe cornea. --Che*mot"ic (#), a.
Commensality. [Obs.]Daniel . . . declined pagan commensation. Sir T. Browne.
The quality of being coagulable; capacity of being coagulated.Ure.

One born of European parents in the American colonies of Franceor Spain or in the States which were once such colonies, esp. aperson of French or Spanish descent, who is a native inhabitant ofLouisiana, or one of the States adjoining, bordering on the Gulf ofof Mexico.
To determine calculation; to reckon; to count.Two days, as we compute the days of heaven. Milton.What's done we partly may compute, But know not what's resisted.Burns.
A garland carried before the bier of a maiden. [Obs.]Yet here she is allowed her virgin crants, Her maaiden strewments.Shak.

The quality or power of conducting, or of receiving andtransmitting, as, the conductivity of a nerve. Thermal conductivity(Physics), the quantity of heat that passes in unit time through unitarea of plate whose thickness is unity, when its opposite facesdiffer in temperature by one degree. J. D. Everett.-- Thermometic conductivity (Physics), the thermal conductivity whenthe unit of heat employed is the heat required to raise unit volumeof the substance one degree.
An obscure ecclesiastical council; a conciliable. Milman.
The layer of bone investing the root and neck of a tooth; --called also cementum. Hydraulic cement. See under Hydraulic.
Capable of being numbered.
Like, or pertaining to, the family Cyathophyllidæ.
Of or pertaining to the ancient Celtiberia (a district in Spainlying between the Ebro and the Tagus) or its inhabitants theCeltiberi (Celts of the river Iberus).-- n.
A Hebrew dry measure, containing a little over two (2.37)pints. W. H. Ward. 2 Kings vi. 25.
A member or inhabitant of a colony.
A game at cards, played by two or more persons, usually fortwenty-one points. Great cassino, the ten of diamonds.-- Little cassino, the two of spades.
Of kin blood; related. [R.] Johnson.
Having or bearing chalazas.
The act of commensurating; the state of being commensurate.All fitness lies in a particular commensuration, or proportion of onething to another. South.
The  tendency of fluids to run together. [R.] Boyle.

Not deviating or varying from uninformity; not interrupted; notjoined or articulated. Continuous brake (Railroad), a brake which isattached to each car a train, and can be caused to operate in all thecars simultaneously from a point on any car or on the engine.-- Continuous impost. See Impost.
A salt of chromic acid.
Capable of being conveyed or transferred. Burke.
A circuiter. Pope.

An annual church festival (December 25) and in some States alegal holiday, in memory of the birth of Christ, often celebrated bya particular church service, and also by special gifts, greetings,and hospitality. Christmas box. (a) A box in which presents aredeposited at Christmas. (b) A present or small gratuity given toyoung people and servants at Christmas; a Christmas gift.-- Christmas carol, a carol sung at, or suitable for, Christmas.-- Christmas day. Same as Christmas.-- Christmas eve, the evening before Christmas.-- Christmas fern (Bot.), an evergreen North American fern (Aspidiumacrostichoides), which is much used for decoration in winter.-- Christmas flower, Christmas rose, the black hellebore, apoisonous plant of the buttercup family, which in Southern Europeoften produces beautiful roselike flowers midwinter.-- Christmas tree, a small evergreen tree, set up indoors, to bedecorated with bonbons, presents, etc., and illuminated on Christmaseve.
One who treats diseases of the hands and feet; especially, onewho removes corns and bunions.
See Gambrel, n., 2. Wright.
See Scion.The cion overruleth the stock; and the stock is but passive, andgiveth aliment, but no motion, to the graft. Bacon.
Cementing together; uniting closely; causing to adhere;promoting healing, as of a wound or a broken bone, by adhesion of theparts.
The pintail duck.
With compunction.
The salmon of the Columbia River or California. See Quinnat.
a genus of poisonous umbelliferous plants, of which the waterhemlock or cowbane is best known.
One whose occupation is to tend cows.
One who denies the reality of spiritual existences; amaterialist.Some corporealists pretended . . . to make a world without a God. Bp.Berkeley.
Cupel dust. [Obs.]Powder of steel, or copple dust. Bacon.
Criminal; involving great crime or grave charges; very wicked;heinous. [Obs.] Holland.-- Crim"i*nous*ly, adv..-- Crim"i*nous*ness,n. [Obs.]

Set right, or made straight; hence, conformable to truth,rectitude, or propriety, or to a just standard; nnot faulty orimperfect; free from error; as, correct behavior; correct views.Always use the most correct editions. Felton.
A large size of paper for drawings. See under Paper.
A cavalry raid; hence, a military expedition. [Obs.] Chaucer.
Imitation of, or resemblance to, the style or action Cicero; aCiceronian phrase or expression. "Great study in Ciceronianism, thechief abuse of Oxford." Sir P. Sidney.
A machine for raising or lowering heavy weights.
A proposition collected from the agreement of other previouspropositions; any conclusion which results from reason or argument;inference.
Provisions; food; viands; especially, luxurious food;delicacies; dainties. Shak.Cates for which Apicius could not pay. Shurchill.Choicest cates and the fiagon's best spilth. R. Browning.
A New Zealand plover (Anarhynchus frontalis), remarkable forhaving the end of the beak abruptly bent to the right.

A dwarf umbelliferous plant, somewhat resembling fennel(Cuminum Cyminum), cultivated for its seeds, which have a bitterish,warm taste, with an aromatic flavor, and are used like those of aniseand caraway. [Written also cummin.]Rank-smelling rue, and cumin good for eyes. Spenser.Black cumin (Bot.), a plant (Nigella sativa) with pungent seeds, usedby the Afghans, etc.
A fossil echinus of the genus Cannulus; -- so called from itssupposed resemblance to a cap.
Coagulated. [Obs.]His cruel wounds with crudy blood congealed. Spenser.
Relating to, or affected with, headache.-- n.
The nucleus of the cytula or parent cell. Hæckel.
That part of a legal instrument, as a commission, indictment,etc., which shows where, when, and by what authority, it taken,found, or executed. Bouvier. Wharton.
By counteraction.
The act or process of characterizing.
A woman whose husband is unfaithful to her. [Obs.]
The science of Mollusca, and of the shells which they form;malacology.
Relating to, or consisting of, circumlocutions; periphrastic;circuitous.
A fermented liquor made in Cayenne from the grated root of themanioc, and resembling perry. Dunglison.
To perform the action of biting and grinding with the teeth; toruminate; to meditate.old politicians chew wisdom past. Pope.
Having the texture and color of new wax; like wax; waxy.
To chew loudly and greedily; to champ. [Prov. Eng. & Colloq. U.S.] Halliwell.
Coadunation. [R.] Sir M. Hale.
Office if a chamberlain.
Formed by, or resulting from, consultation; advisory. Bancroft.
A brass wind instrument, like the trumpet, furnished withvalves moved by small pistons or sliding rods; a cornopean; a cornet.
Criminal; wicked; contrary to law, right, or dury. [Obs.] Shak.
A shrubby euphorbiaceous plant of the genus Manihot, withfleshy rootstocks yielding an edible starch; -- called also manioc.
To toss up the head frequently, as a horse to avoid therestraint of the bridle.
The Anointed; an appellation given to Jesus, the Savior. It issynonymous with the Hebrew Messiah.
The edge of a cask, etc; a chine. See Chine, n., 3. [Writtenalso hime.]
The act of catechising.
To live in, or as in, a cabin; to lodge.I'll make you . . . cabin in a cave. Shak.
The state or conduct of a cicisbeo.
Pertaining to hemp; hempen. [R.]
Same as Chive.
A remedy for all diseases, o
Wolfram, an ore of tungsten. Simmonds.
Of or pertaining to an acid more generally called pepsin-hydrochloric acid.
A place where copper is wrought or manufactured. Woodward.
Capable of being created. [Obs.] I. Watts.
One who inserts in a category or list; one who classifies.Emerson.
Same as Castleguard.
To enroll; to enlist. [Obs.] E. Hall.
To tend to one point; to incline and approach nearer together;as, lines converge.The mountains converge into a single ridge. Jefferson.
A hard brittle cake or biscuit. Spenser.
A mild, eruptive disease, generally attacking children only;varicella.
See Cheval.
A scientific study of children, undertaken for the purpose ofdiscovering the laws of development of the body and the mind frombirth to manhood.
Of the same age; beginning to exist at the same time;contemporaneous.-- Co`e*ta"ne*ous*ly, adv.And all [members of the body] are coetaneous. Bentley.
Of or pertaining to carpology.
See Caraway.
See Lumpfish. [Scot.]
See Corf.
Properly the citron, a variety of Citrus medica, with largefruits, not acid, and having a high perfume.
A claim made by a person as an offset to a claim made on him.
Coolness; coldness; a chill.Death is the chillness that precedes the dawn. Longfellow.

A shark of the genus Cestracion, and of related genera. Theposterior teeth form a pavement of bony plates for crushingshellfish. Most of the species are extinct. The Port Jackson sharkand a similar one found in California are living examples.
A white amorphous substance, regarded as a polymericmodification of isocyanic acid.
A plant or weed that grows in rivers; a species of ofEquisetum; also, the yellow frog lily (Nuphar luteum).
Containing or implying calumny; false, malicious, and injuriousto reputation; slanderous; as, calumnious reports.Virtue itself 'scapes not calumnious strokes. Shak.
An American bird (Galeoscoptes Carolinensis), allied to themocking bird, and like it capable of imitating the notes of otherbirds, but less perfectly. Its note resembles at times the mewing ofa cat.
Same as Chondrigen.

A disease frequently induced by remaining for some time in anatmosphere of high pressure, as in caissons, diving bells, etc. It ischaracterized by neuralgic pains and paralytic symptoms. It isvariously explained, most probably as due to congestion of internalorgans with subsequent stasis of the blood.
Monitory. [Obs.]Only commemorative and commonitive. Bp. Hall.
Engaging in a plot to commit a crime; conspiring. [Obs.] Shak.
A cryptocrystalline, translucent variety of quartz, havingusually a whitish color, and a luster nearly like wax. [Written alsocalcedony.]
The name of several evergreen trees. The wood is remarkable forits durability and fragrant odor.

Defn:Now abideth faith, hope, charity, three; but the greatest of these ischarity. 1. Cor. xiii. 13.They, at least, are little to be envied, in whose hearts the greatcharities . . . lie dead. Ruskin.With malice towards none, with charity for all. Lincoln.
See Colliery.
A soft, white or colored silk fabric, of a gauzy texture andwavy appearance, used for ladies' scarfs, shawls, bonnet trimmings,etc.; -- called also Oriental crape. De Colange.
Resembling chaos; confused.
The state of being culpable.
Compounded of chlorine and iodine; containing chlorine andiodine.
ToShe cuddles low beneath the brake; Nor would she stay, nor dares shefly. Prior.
To treat, or cause to combine, with chlorine.
The act or process by which a substance in solidifying assumesthe form and sructure of a crystal, or becomes crystallized.
A covered pot im which coffee is prepared,
Giving way; yielding. [Obs.] -- Ces`si*bil"i*ty, n. [Obs.] SirK. Digby.
See Collaborator.
To break in pieces violently; to dash together with noise andviolence. [R.]He shakt his head, and crasht his teeth for ire. Fairfax.
Commonwealth.Such a prince, So kind a father of the commonweal. Shak.
Pertaining to, or characterized by, cacography; badly writtenor spelled.

The relation of person by blood, is distinction from affinityor relation by marriage; blood relationship; as, linealconsanguinity; collateral consanguinity.Invoking aid by the ties of consanguinity. Prescott.
Clad in a cope.
A colorless, liquid, combustible hydrocarbon, CH3.C6H4.C3H7, ofpleasant odor, obtained from oil of cumin, oil of caraway, carvacrol,camphor, etc.; -- called also paracymene, and formerly camphogen.
Expressive of sympathetic joy; as, a congratulatory letter.
The noise or call of a brooding hen.
The chippy.
The ninth month of the Jewish ecclesiastical year, answering toa part of November with a part of December.

A town in the county of Warwick, England. To send to Coventry,to exclude from society; to shut out from social intercourse, as forungentlemanly conduct.-- Coventry blue, blue thread of a superior dye, made at Coventry,England, and used for embroidery.
A piece; a fragment; a corner. Dryden.

To cheat; to defrand; to beguile; to deceive, usually by smallarts, or in a pitiful way.He had cozened the world by fine phrases. Macualay.Children may be cozened into a knowledge of the letters. Locke.Goring loved no man so well but that he would cozen him, and exposehim to public mirth for having been cozened. Clarendon.
Having a movable joint or finger closing againts a precedingjoint or a projecting part of it, so that the whole may be ised forgrasping, as the claw of a crab; pincherlike.
See Clinch.
Dehiscing or opening by a transverse fissure extending around(a capsule or pod). See Illust. of Pyxidium.
In the manner of cannibal. "An he had been cannibally given."Shak.
One who belongs to a convention or assembly.
One of the Cetacea, or collectively, the Cetacea.
A fixed state.
Serving to couple, unite, or connect; as, a copulativeconjunction like "and".
Growing in, or full of, clusters; like clusters. Johnson.

Belonging to a certain order which is composed of the Ionicorder grafted upon the Corinthian. It is called also the Roman or theItalic order, and is one of the five orders recognized by the Italianwriters of the sixteenth century. See Capital.
To manufacture counterfeit money.They cannot touch me for coining. Shak.
Any solid concretion, formed in any part of the body, but mostfrequent in the organs that act as reservoirs, and in the passagesconnected with them; as, biliary calculi; urinary calculi, etc.
The temple or temporal fossa. Also used adjectively.

A kind of food. See citation, below.Caring or carl are gray steeped in water and fried the next day inbutter or fat. They are eaten on the second Sunday before Easter,formerly called Carl Sunday. Robinson's Whitby Glossary (1875).

Of or pertaining to a congress, especially, to the Congress ofthe United States; as, congressional debates.Congressional and official labor. E. Everett.Congressional District, one of the divisions into which a State isperiodically divided (according to population), each of which isentitled to elect a Representative to the Congress of the UnitedStates.
Curt; brief; laconic.Essays and curtal aphorisms. Milton.Curtal dog. See Curtail dog.
Weary; mournful.  Shak.
A copper coin of Italy and Spain equivalent to a centime.
A joint trustee.
Any disease of the tonsils, throat, or windpipe, attended withinflammation, swelling, and difficulty of breathing and swallowing.
The art or practice of foretelling events, or of telling thefortunes or the disposition of persons by inspecting the hand;palmistry.
State of being a client.
Divination by means of a suspended sieve.
Affected with caries; decaying; as, a carious tooth.
A hairlike envelope.The nucleus and chevelure of nebulous star. Sir. W. Hershel.
A curvet; a leap. See Capriole.The cabrioles which his charger exhibited. Sir W. Scott.
A priest hearing, or sitting to hear, confession. [R.] Boucher
To have discourse; to consult; to compare views; to deliberate.Festus, when he had conferred with the council, answered. Acts xxv.12.You shall hear us confer of this. Shak.
Catholic. [Obs.]
Cover with, or as with, a hood. [Obs.] Sir T. Browne.
The act or process of uniting by chemical affinity, by whichsubstances unite with each other in definite proportions by weight toform distinct compounds.

One who has convulsions; esp., one of a body of fanatics inFrance, early in the eighteenth century, who went into convulsionsunder the influence of religious emotion; as, the Convulsionists ofSt. Médard.
Pertaining to, or troubled with, colic; as, a colicky disorder.
State of being a church. South.
Relating to the chapter of a cathedral; capitular. "Capitularyacts." Warton.
Ending in a point.
In a connotative manner; expressing connotation.
Having a changeable, varying luster, or color, like that of achangeable silk, or oa a cat's eye in the dark.
She who creates. Spenser.
An officer of the peace having power as a conservator of thepublic peace, and bound to exeute the warrants of judicial offiers.Bouvier.
A controverser. [Obs.]
One professing a certain faith. Bp. Montagu.
The opening and crying of hounds at first finding the scent oftheir game.

Cayenne pepper. Cayenne pepper. (a) (Bot.) A species ofcapsicum (C. frutescens) with small and intensely pungent fruit. (b)A very pungent spice made by drying and grinding the fruits or seedsof several species of the genus Capsicum, esp. C. annuum and C.Frutescens; -- Called also red pepper. It is used chiefly as acondiment.

A one-celled, dry, indehiscent fruit, with a thin membranouspericarp, adhering closely to the seed, so that fruit and seed areincorporated in one body, forming a single grain, as of wheat,barley, etc.
One who hawks about fruit, green vegetables, fish, etc.
An opaque or milk-white chalcedony, a variety of quartz; also,a similar variety of opal.
Of, pertaining to, or of the nature of, colic. Swift.
relating to conjugation. Ellis.
Colorado; -- a nickname alluding to the fact that it wasadmitted to the Union in the centennial year, 1876.
A schoolfellow; a fellow-student. [R.]
A report of an officer or agent.
The shank bone, or great bone above the fetlock, in the foreand hind legs of the horse and allied animals, corresponding to themiddle metacarpal or metatarsal bone of most mammals. See Horse.
To suppress or omit; to strike out, as matter in type. Canceledfigures (Print), figures cast with a line across the face., as foruse in arithmetics.

A transverse bar or piece, as a bar across a door, or as theiron bar or stock which passes through the shank of an anchor toinsure its turning fluke down. Russell. Crossbar shot, a projectilewhich folds into a sphere for loading, but on leaving the gun expandsto a cross with a quarter ball at the end of each arm; -- used innaval actions for cutting the enemy's rigging.
Crossness; coarseness; thickness; density. Bacon.
Capable of being conceived; conceivable. Sir M. Hale.
Adapted one to another; as, coadapted pulp and tooth. R. Owen.
To cause to shrink or draw together; to contract; to curl. [R.]Wiseman.
A copier; a transcriber; an imitator; a plagiarist.
In a a corresponding manner; conformably; suitably.
Of or pertaining to a chloride; containing a chloride.
To lament; to bewail. [Obs.]They might the grievance inwardly complain. Daniel.By chaste Lucrece's soul that late complain'd Her wrongs to us. Shak.
Horned; having horns; as, cornigerous animals. [Obs.] Sir T.Browne.
A large gallinaceous bird of the American genera Crax, Ourax,etc., of the family Cracidæ.
A friction clutch with conical bearing surfaces.
By compulsion.
To convert into, or add to, a forest. Howell.
One who, or that which, climbs:(a) (Bot.) A plant that climbs.(b) (Zoöl.) A bird that climbs, as a woodpecker or a parrot.
A plane figure of a thousand angles and sides. Barlow.
A kind of inn, in the East, where caravans rest at night, beinga large, rude, unfurnished building, surrounding a court. [Writtenalso caravanserai and caravansera.]
Of or pertaining to Canaan or the Canaanites.
Formation of, or conversion into, cartilage.

A molding, shaft of a column, or any other member of convex,rounded section, made to resemble the spiral twist of a rope; --called also cable molding. Bower cable, the cable belonging to thebower anchor.-- Cable road, a railway on which the cars are moved by acontinuously running endless rope operated by a stationary motor.-- Cable's length, the length of a ship's cable. Cables in themerchant service vary in length from 100 to 140 fathoms or more; butas a maritime measure, a cable's length is either 120 fathoms (720feet), or about 100 fathoms (600 feet, an approximation to one tenthof a nautical mile).-- Cable tier. (a) That part of a vessel where the cables arestowed. (b) A coil of a cable.-- Sheet cable, the cable belonging to the sheet anchor.-- Stream cable, a hawser or rope, smaller than the bower cables, tomoor a ship in a place sheltered from wind and heavy seas.-- Submarine cable. See Telegraph.-- To pay out the cable, To veer out the cable, to slacken it, thatit may run out of the ship; to let more cable run out of the hawsehole.-- To serve the cable, to bind it round with ropes, canvas, etc., toprevent its being, worn or galled in the hawse, et.-- To slip the cable, to let go the end on board and let it all runout and go overboard, as when there is not time to weigh anchor.Hence, in sailor's use, to die.
Confined in, or as in, a cage; like a cage or prison. "Thecaged cloister." Shak.

The arrangement and union of the constituent parts of a thing;a weaving together of parts; structural character of a thing; system;constitution; texture.That wonderful contexture of all created beings. Dryden.He was not of any delicate contexture; his limbs rather sturdy thandainty. Sir H. Wotton.
Showing contrariety; repugnant; perverse. [Archaic] Milton.She flew contrarious in the face of God. Mrs. Browning.
Blindness. [R.] Sir T. Browne.
Relating to, or resembling, a cup; also improperly used forcalycular, calyculate.
To incorporate. [Obs.] Stow.
The act of confronting; the state of being face to face.
Same as Capellet.
A small ruminant of the family Tragulidæ a allied to the muskdeer. It inhabits Africa and the East Indies. See Kanchil.
The lowest course of stones in a building.
Confutation. [Obs.]  Milton.
Energy wasted by hysteresis or eddy currents in the core of anarmature, transformer, etc.
In a corresponding manner; conformably.
An indication or symptom which forbids the method of treatmentusual in such cases.
Disposed to cavil; finding fault without good reason. SeeCaptious.His depreciatory and caviling criticism. Lewis.
Calling to mind; giving admonition. [Obs.] Foxe.
See Kestrel.
A utensil with a bottom perforated with little holes forstraining liquids, mashed vegetable pulp, etc.; a strainer ofwickerwork, perfprated metal, or the like.
A small hornlike part or process.
The quality of being catholic; universality; catholicity.
The act of commiserating; sorrow for the wants, afflictions, ordistresses of another; pity; compassion.And pluck commiseration of his state From brassy bosoms and roughhearts of flint. Shak.
A mineral substance or petrifaction, in the form of coral.
To notify of a proceeding in court. Abbot
A roundabout or indirect course; indirectness. [Obs.] S.Richardson.
A white crystalline substance, C3H7NSO2, containing sulphur,occuring as a constituent of certain rare urinary calculi, andoccasionally found as a sediment in urine.
The mendole; a small worthless Mediterranean fish consideredpoisonous by the ancients. See Mendole.
An official administering a prefecture of China; a prefect,supervising the civil business of the hsiens or districts comprisedin his fu (which see).
The state of being a cully.Less frequent instances of eminent cullyism. Spectator.
A purse. [Obs.] Dr. H. More.
An ancient wind instrument, resembling the bassoon in tone.
To make a short, shrill, cheerful sound; to chirp. See Chirrup."Cheruping birds." Drayton.
Divided into a hundred parts.
A kind of sauce much used in India, containing garlic, pepper,ginger, and other strong spices.
A variety of the mineral domeykite, or copper arsenide, fromthe Condurra mine in Cornwall, England.
See Camis. [Obs.]
One who makes or practices contortions.
Capable of being collated. Coleridge.
Tendency to fall; the feebleness of old age; senility. [R.][A] jumble of youth and caducity. Chesterfield.
A man that wears the horns; a cuckold. [R.] Shak.
In Spain and Portugal, one who supports the constitution.
A dry measure of four bushels, or half a quarter. [Written alsocomb.]
Pertaining to the sending of two messages in oppositedirections at the same time.
A cuirass. [Obs.] Spenser.
Sophistical.
See Calorificient.
A chorus leader; esp. one who provided at his own expense andunder his own supervision one of the choruses for the musicalcontents at Athens.
One who considers. [Obs.] Sir T. Browne.
Same as Crape.
A place or ground set apart for the burial of the dead; agraveyard; a churchyard; a necropolis.
South Dakota; -- a nickname.
Joined together or touching.
A kind of food used by the natives of Western Africa, made ofmillet flour with flesh, and leaves of the baobab; -- called alsolalo.
A short, thick, heavy piece of wood. Morton. Chump end, thethick end; as, the chump end of a joint of meat. Dickens.

An open country abounding in sheepcotes, as in the Cotswoldhills, in Gloucestershire, England. Cotswold sheep, a long-wooledbreed of sheep, formerly common in the counties of Gloucester,Hereford, and Worcester, Eng.; -- so called from the Cotswold Hills.The breed is now chiefly amalgamated with others.
A medicinal confection made of freshly gathered vegetablesubstances mixed with finely powdered refined sugar. See Confection.
Somewhat cinereous; of a color somewhat resembling that of woodashes.
The buckthorn (Rhamnus Purshiana) of the Pacific coast of theUnited States, which yields cascara sagrada.
A worm or grub that makes for itself a case. See Caddice.
Relating to, or resembling, bark; corticose.
See Coranach.
The quality of being of particular value or worth; nicely;excellence.
Not wearing a coat; also, not possessing a coat.
To converge to one point or focus, as light or rays.
Pertaining to the calcaneum; as, calcaneal arteries.
A calligrapher
The sine of the complement of an arc or angle. See Illust. ofFunctions.
To make as pliable as kid leather. [Obs.] Br. Montagu.
A genus of orchidaceous plants including the lady's slipper.
Clottered. [Obs.] Chaucer.
Corrected; disciplined; refined; purified; toned down. Sir. W.Scott.Of such a finished chastened purity. Tennyson.
One who joins or promotes a coalition; one who advocatescoalition.

A resinous substance flowing spontaneously from trees ofZanzibar, Madagascar, and South America (Trachylobium Hornemannianum,T. verrocosum, and Hymenæa Courbaril), and dug from earth whereforests have stood in Africa; -- used chiefly in making varnishes. Ur
Peevishness; malignity; frowardness; crabbedness; surliness.[Obs.] Shak.
An orthopterus insect of the genus Blatta, and allied genera.
An associate; an accomplice. [Archaic] "Wicked consociates."Bp. Hall.
Same as Conoidal.
A suborder of Arachnoidea, including the European tarantula andthe wolf spiders (Lycosidae) and their allies, which capture theirprey by rapidly running and jumping. See Wolf spider.
A traveling tinker; also a tramp or sturdy beggar. [Prov. Eng.]
Cannon, collectively; artillery.The ringing of bells and roaring of cannonry proclaimed his coursethrough the country. W. Irving.
The tendency to associate in cliques; the spirit of cliques.
Glittering in flashes; flashing. Howell.
In a condescending manner. Atterbury.
A sleeve covering the arm from the elbow to the hand. Crabb.

Containing the substance oe general principles of a subject orwork in a narrow compass; abridged; summarized.More compendious and exeditious ways. Woodward.Three things be required in the oration of a man having authority --that it be compendious, sententious, and delectable. Sir T. Elyot.
Given to crotchets; subject to whims; as, a crotchety man.
In a coactive manner.
To cheat, trick, defraud; -- followed by of, or out of; as, tochouse one out of his money. [Colloq.]The undertaker of the afore-cited poesy hath choused your highness.Landor.
The act of going round; circumlocution. [R.]
Having the quality of taining or vitiating; tending to producecorruption.It should be endued with some corruptive quality for so speedy adissolution of the meat. Ray.

A device or contrivance which serves to couple or connectadjacent parts or objects; as, a belt coupling, which connects theends of a belt; a car coupling, which connects the cars in a train; ashaft coupling, which connects the ends of shafts. Box coupling,Chain coupling. See under Box, Chain.-- Coupling box, a coupling shaped like a journal box, for clampingtogether the ends of two shafts, so that they may revolve together.-- Coupling pin, a pin or bolt used in coupling or joining togetherrailroad cars, etc.
A pun.
Complexioned. [Low, New Eng.]
Having the form of a goat.
A commendation; eulogy. [R.] "Commendatories to our affection."Sharp.
To plot; to plan; to combine for.Angry clouds conspire your overthrow. Bp. Hall.
In a coaxing manner; by coaxing.
One who clatters.
To plead orally; to argue a matter in court; to recite a count.Burrill.
Relating to, or resembling, coma; drowsy; lethargic; as,comatose sleep; comatose fever.
Having a very small knoblike termination, or collected intominute capitula.
Familiar talk or conversation. [Colloq.]
The division of Thysanura which includes Podura, and alliedforms.
Having the characteristics of a cretin. "Cretinousstupefaction." Ruskin.
By constraint or compulsion; in a constrained manner. Hooker.
Jerked beef; beef cut into long strips and dried in the windand sun. Darwin.
The state of being cohesible. Good.
Having a high crown, or a point or peak at top. [Obs.]A copatain hat made on a Flemish block. Gascoigne.
The quality of being conscientious; a scrupulous regard to thedictates of conscience.
Tranquil; peaceful; calm. [Poet.] "A still and calmy day"Spenser.
A caustic curve or caustic surface.
Low, worthless people; the rabble. [Scot.] Jamieson.
A parisan of Charles X. Of France, or of Dod Carlos of Spain.
Readiness to believe on slight evidence; credulity.Beyond all credulity is the credulousness of atheists. S. Clarke.
The projection in rear of the breech of a cannon, usually aknob or breeching loop connected with the gun by a neck. In oldwriters it included all in rear of the base ring.
A patching together; patchwork. [Obs.] Bailey.
A bed blanket. [Obs.] Chaucer.
A white, crystallizable, bitter substance extracted from oil ofcascarilla.
Wanting a syllable at the end, or terminating in an imperfectfoot; as, a catalectic verse.
the state of being copartners in any undertaking. [R.]
To change from solid to fluid; to make or become liquid; tomelt. [Obs.]The ore of it is colliquated by the violence of the fire. Boyle.[Ice] will colliquate in water or warm oil. Sir T. Browne.
A Chilian burrowing rodent of the genus Spalacopus.

To engage in continuous thought; to think.He that calleth a thing into his mind, whether by impression orrecordation, cogitateth and considereth, and he that employeth thefaculty of his fancy also cogitateth. Bacon.

The hands, claws, or talons, in the act of grasping firmly; --often figuratively, for power, rapacity, or cruelty; as, to fall intothe clutches of an adversary.I must have . . . little care of myself, if I ever more come near theclutches of such a giant. Bp. Stillingfleet.

An American feline quadruped (Felis concolor), resembling theAfrican panther in size and habits. Its color is tawny, withoutspots; hence writers often called it the American lion. Called alsopuma, panther, mountain lion, and catamount. See Puma.
See Dermis.
One entire round in a circle or a spire; as, a cycle or set ofleaves. Gray.
A south American carrion buzzard (Milvago chimango). SeeCaracara.
See cantharis.
The leader or driver of the camels in caravan.
Quality of being cunning; craft.
Belonging to the Cheiroptera, or Bat family.
A writing on wax. Knight.
To make sharp or pointed. [Obs.]

Equal in rank or order; not subordinate.Whether there was one Supreme Governor of the world, or manycoördinate powers presiding over each country. Law.Conjunctions joint sentences and coördinate terms. Rev. R. Morris.Coördinate adjectives, adjectives disconnected as regards aneanother, but referring equally to the same subject.-- Coördinate conjunctions, conjunctions joining independentpropositions. Rev. R. Morris.
A twist or bend; a turn; a whimsey. [Colloq.] Hudibras.

A more or less solid article of confectionery made by boilingsugar or molasses to the desired consistency, and than crystallizing,molding, or working in the required shape. It is often flavored orcolored, and sometimes contains fruit, nuts, etc.
A thing of the same genus, species, or kind; a thing allied innature, character, or action.
A court or inclosure attached to a house.
Of or pertaining to case; as, a casal ending.
To mix or mingle together; to blend.The commixed impressions of all the colors do stir up and beget asensation of white. Sir I. Newton.To commix With winds that sailors rail at. Shak.
A goldsmith's crucible or melting pot.
The act of heaping together; a heap. See Accumulation.
A skin disease, common in India, in which there is perpetualitching and eruption, esp. of the groin, breast, armpits, and face.
Having a crackling sound; crackling; rattling. Crepitant rale(Med.), a peculiar crackling sound audible with inspiration inpneumonia and other lung disease.
See Crus.
Having an azure color. Pennant.
The composition of a cento; the act or practice of composing acento or centos.
That part of a bit which is put in a horse's mouth.
A name given to any one of several yellow or scarlet dyestuffsof artificial production and complex structure. In general they arediazo and sulphonic acid derivatives of benzene and naphthol.
A chanting; recitation or reading with musical modulations.

Enrolled; written; registered. Conscript fathers (Rom. Antiq.),the senators of ancient Rome. When certain new senators were firstenrolled with the "fathers" the body was called Patres et Conscripti;afterward all were called Patres conscripti.
One who condemns or censures.
A speciec of armadillo of the genus Xenurus (X. unicinctus andX. hispidus); the tatouay. [Written also Kabassou.]
One who connives.

The scales or bracts on the receptacle, which subtend eachflower in the heads of many Compositæ, as the sunflower. Gray. Chaffcutter, a machine for cutting, up straw, etc., into "chaff" for theuse of cattle.
The astringent fruit of a species of wild cherry (PrunusVirginiana); also, the bush or tree which bears such fruit.
Something, as a symptom, indicating that the usual mode oftreatment is not to be followed. Burke.
A vegetable alkaloid found with conine in the poison hemlock(Conium maculatum). It is a white crystalline substance, C8H17NO,easily convertible into conine.
Having a crevice or crevices; as, a creviced structure forstoring ears of corn.Trickling through the creviced rock. J. Cunningham.
A species of grebe (Podiceps crisratus); the crested grebe.
Of or pertaining to a chorus.I remember a choric ode in the Hecuba. Coleridge.
See Cramp, n., 2.
A prefecture or district of the second rank in China, or thechief city of such a district; -- often part of the name of a city,as in Foochow.
See Krems.
Relationship; kinship. [Obs.] Wyclif.
One guilty of champerty; one who purchases a suit, or the rightof suing, and carries it on at his own expense, in order to obtain ashare of the gain.
One who condoles.
One who puts a certain construction upon some writing orinstrument, as the Constitutions of the United States; as, a strictconstructionist; a broad constructionist.
A stricture or narrowing, as of a canal, cavity, or orifice.
Having a hard exterior, or a short, rough manner, though kindat heart; snappish; peevish; surly.Thou crusty batch of nature, what's the news Shak.
Distinction by contrast.That there are such things as sins of infirmity in contradistinctionto those of presumption is not to be questioned. South.
A dark brown substance of vegetable origin, allied to curare,and used by the natives of New Granada as an arrow poison.
Pertaining to consultation; having the privilege or right ofconference. "A consultative . . . power." Abp. Bramhall.
To starve; to famish. [Obs.] B. Jonson.
To operate on with a catheter. Dunglison.
Like, or related to, the confervae. Loudon.
Corresponding relation.
See Calipash.
A tenant in common, or a joint tenant.
Illuminating power, as of a lamp, or gas flame, reckoned interms of the light of a standard candle.
A contrivance for producing manifold copies of a writing ordrawing.
Bearing corymbs of flowers or fruit.
The artifices, intrigues, and plottings, at courts.
The state of being unmarried; single life, esp. that of abachelor, or of one bound by vows not to marry. "The celibacy of theclergy." Hallom.
A horizontal row of corbels, with the panels or filling betweenthem; also, less properly used to include the stringcourse on them.
Croupy.
A long, light, open vehicle, with benches or seats runninglengthwise.
The quality of being concise.

Singing, esp. as a chant is sung. Chanting falcon (Zoöl.), anAfrican falcon (Melierax canorus or musicus). The male has the habit,remarkable in a bird of prey, of singing to his mate, while she isincubating.
One who engages in a conspiracy; a plotter. 2 Sam. xv. 31.
To combine wtih carbon or a carbon compound; -- said esp. of aprocess for conferring a higher degree of illuminating power oncombustible gases by mingling them with a vapor of valatilehydrocarbons.
An integrating anemometer.
An oceanic fish of large size (Elacate canada); the crabeater;-- called also bonito, cubbyyew, coalfish, and sergeant fish.
A large swan. B. Jonson.
Increasing; growing. [R.]Unseen, yet crescive in his faculty. Shak.
Capable of being condensed; as, a gas condensible to a liquidby cold.
Relating to capital letters.
One who ackowledged the right of the plaintiff or cognizee in afine; the defendant. Blackstone.
An obligation to perform certain services, as the repair ofroads, for the lord or sovereign.
A substance, analogous to benzil, obtained from oil of caraway.
Having the gout in the hand, or subject to that disease. Sir.T. Browne.
Glandular scrofulous swellings in the neck.
An assembly of the clergy, by their representatives, to consulton ecclesiastical affairs.

Free from agitation; calm; sedate; quiet; tranquil; self-possessed.The Mantuan there in sober triumph sate, Composed his posture, andhis look sedate. Pope.-- Com*pos"ed*ly (, adv.-- Com*pos"ed*ness, n.
The act or process of reducing, by depression of temperature orincrease of pressure, etc., to another and denser form, as gas to thecondition of a liquid or steam to water.

Composed of clots or clods; having the quality or form of aclot; sticky; slimy; foul. "The clotted glebe." J. Philips.When lust . . . Lets in defilement to the inward parts, The soulgrows clotted by contagion. Milton.
Like or pertaining to the Clamatores.
Anything which clogs. Dr. H. More.
The state or quality of being crustaceous or having a crustlikeshell.
Resembling cotton. [R.] Evelyn.

A peculiar East Indian mammal (Galleopithecus volans), havingalong the sides, connecting the fore and hind limbs, a parachutelikemembrane, by means of which it is able to make long leaps, like theflying squirrel; -- called also flying lemur.
An order of Entomastraca, including many minute Crustacea, bothfreshwater and marine.
Incrusted; covered with, or containing, crust; as, old, crustedport wine.
To insert in a category or list; to class; to catalogue.
Same as Gambrel.
To have corrosive action; to be subject to corrosion. Corrodinglead, lead sufficiently pure to be used in making white lead by aprocess of corroding.
In corymbs.
Belonging to, or like, the genus Coryphæna. See Dolphin.

A plant (Celosia cristata), of many varieties, cultivated forits broad, fantastic spikes of brilliant flowers; -- sometimes calledgarden cockscomb. Also the Pedicularis, or lousewort, the RhinanthusCrista-galli, and the Onobrychis Crista-galli.
A steelyard for weighting grain.
The common name of the kerria Japonica or Japan globeflower, ayellow-flowered, perennial, rosaceous plant, seen in old-fashionedgardens.

Highly carbonized iron, the direct product of the blastfurnace; -- used for making castings, and for conversion into wroughtiron and steel. It can not be welded or forged, is brittle, andsometimes very hard. Besides carbon, it contains sulphur, phosphorus,silica, etc.
The state of being craggy.
Incorrect or bad writing or spelling. Walpole.
Freedom from doubt; assurance; certainty. J. H. Newman.
Pertaining to, or employed in, cremation.
A stick or club employed in the game of ball called cat ortipcat. Massinger.
In a convex form; as, a body convexly shaped.
A house where chops, etc., are sold; an eating house.The freedom of a chophouse. W. Irving.
Hollow; affording a passage through its interior length forwire, thread, etc.; as, a cannulated (suture) needle. [Written alsocanulated.]
Having a castle or castles; supporting a castle; as, a castledheight or crag.
To make sorrowful. [Obs.] Bacon.
Somewhat sour or cross.The wips of the most crabbish Satyristes. Decker.
Circular; illogical. [Obs. & .] "Cross and circulary speeches."Hooker.
A chimney cap; a cowl
Having the gills around the margin of the body, as certainlimpets.
An apparatus by which a number of copies of written matter,maps, plans, etc., can be made; -- called also hectograph.
A large pear, shaped like a flattened top, used chiefly forcooking. Johnson.
A nucleated cell having an envelope or cell wall, as a redblood corpuscle or an epithelial cell; a cell concerned in growth.
The head; also, a knoblike protuberance or capitulum.
Of or pertaining to the cochlea.
The act or process of making mathematical computations or ofestimating results.
A base fellow; a rogue; a cheat. [Obs.] B. Jonson.
The state of being a clergyman.
Coolish; cool. [Obs.] Spenser.
Agreement; accord; consent.That traditional consensus of society which we call public opinion.Tylor.

An order of marine mammals, including the whales. Like ordinarymammals they breathe by means of lungs, and bring forth living youngwhich they suckle for some time. The anterior limbs are changed topaddles; the tail flukes are horizontal. There are two livingsuborders: (a) The Mysticete or whalebone whales, having no trueteeth after birth, but with a series of plates of whalebone [seeBaleen.] hanging down from the upper jaw on each side, thus making astrainer, through which they receive the small animals upon whichthey feed. (b) The Denticete, including the dolphins and sperm whale,which have teeth. Another suborder (Zeuglodontia) is extinct. TheSirenia were formerly included in the Cetacea, but are now made aseparate order.
A song. Shak.

Designating, or pertaining to, gods or spirits of theunderworld; esp., relating to the underworld gods of the Greeks,whose worship is widely considered as more primitive in form thanthat of the Olympian gods. The characteristics of chthonian worshipare propitiatory and magical rites and generalized or euphemisticnames of the deities, which are supposed to have been primarilyghosts.
Converted into horn; horny.
The cougar. Applied also, in some parts of the United States,to the lynx.
Boorish; rude. C. Bronté.
The backing or steaming of clams on heated stones, betweenlayers of seaweed; hence, a picnic party, gathered on such anoccasion.
A tasteless and odorless crystalline substance, extracted fromcloves, polymeric with common camphor.
A species of Dorstenia (D. Contrayerva), a South Americanplant, the aromatic root of which is sometimes used in medicine as agentle stimulant and tonic.
A hood-shaped bandage for the head, the shoulder, or the stumpof an amputated limb.
Not susceptible of corruption or decay; incorruptible. Dryden.
The quality of being corruptible; the possibility or liabilityof being corrupted; corruptibleness. Burke.
Having gaps or a chasm. [R.]
A binary compound of carbon with some other element or radical,in which the carbon plays the part of a negative; -- formerly termedcarburet.
A deeption; a cheat. [Obs.]
To criticise or pass judgment upon. [Obs.] Pope.

An order of Mammallia including the lion, tiger, wolf bear,seal, etc. They are adapted by their structure to feed upon flesh,though some of them, as the bears, also eat vegetable food. The teethare large and sharp, suitable for cutting flesh, and the jawspowerful.
One who cheapens.
A clinic.
A Mexican prickly poppy (Argemone platyceras), which hasmigrated into California.
Without a creed. Carlyle.
