A standard of judging; any approved or established rule ortest, by which facts, principles opinions, and conduct are tried informing a correct judgment respecting them.Of the diseases of the mind there is no criterion. Donne.Inferences founded on such enduring criteria. Sir G. C. Lewis.
A mouse (Arvicala agrestis), called also meadow mouse, whichoften does great damage in fields and gardens, by feeding on rootsand seeds.
Compulsatory. [R.] Shak.
Confusing; having a tendency to confusion.  Bp. Hall.
Apt to conceive; fruitful. [Obs.] Shak.
Joint estate. Smolett.
A short narrative or tale, esp. one dealing with surprising ormarvelous events.
One who commends or praises.
One who makes or writes comments; a commentator; an annotator.
The European starling. [Local, Eng.]
Strict adherence to the forms or principles of some churchorganization; sectarianism.
Of or pertaining to cawk; like cawk.

One well versed in any subject; a skillful or knowing person; acritical judge of any art, particulary of one of the fine arts.The connoisseur is "one who knows," as opposed to the dilettant, whoonly "thinks he knows." Fairholt.
The act or operation of crushing the head of a fetus in thewomb in order to effect delivery.
The frill to the breast of a shirt, which when ironed outresembled the small entrails. See Chitterlings. [Obs.] Gascoigne.
A stiff compact pasteboard of various qualities, for makingcards, etc., often having a polished surface.
A kind of pleasure carriage; a coach. [Obs.]To mount two-wheeled caroches. Butler.
A coarse, composite weed, having a rough or prickly fruit; oneof several species of the genus Xanthium; -- called also clotbur.
In a cautious manner.
The state of being convertible; convertibility.
Relatives by the mother's side. Wharton.

The fleshy hinder part of the leg below the knee. Calf's-footjelly, jelly made from the feet of calves. The gelatinous matter ofthe feet is extracted by boiling, and is flavored with sugar,essences, etc.
Capable of being sailed round. Ray.
One of a class of compounds formed from certain polybasicalcohols (and especially glycerin) by the substitution of chlorinefor one or more hydroxyl groups.
A Mohammedan rosary, consisting of ninety-nine beads. Byron.
Having the form a calyptra, or extinguisher.
Concubinage. [Obs.] Johnson.
Covered, or furnished with, cedars.
To cumber. [Obs.] Spenser.
An operation for opening the colon
Accompanying; conjoined; attending.It has pleased our wise Creator to annex to several objects, as alsoto several of our thoughts, a concomitant pleasure. Locke.
An instrument for drawing curved lines.
Pertaining to the cornea.
Lying down, with their heads in opposite directions; -- said ofanimals borne in a coat of arms.
Shifting the sword from one side of an adversary's sword to theother.
Having elevations or depressions in form like one half of abivalve shell; -- applied principally to a surface produced byfracture.
Combustibility.
Belonging to the Carangidæ, a family of fishes allied to themackerels, and including the caranx, American bluefish, and the pilotfish.
To close with glutinous matter. [Obs.] Mortimer.
The science of exchange, weight, measures, etc.
Agreement of words with one another, in gender, number, person,or case.
See Kauri.
A cavity.
A simple gland, glandular cavity, or tube; a follicle; as, thecryps of Lieberk.
To make stony or calcareous by the deposit or secretion ofsalts of lime.
In a comprehensive manner; with great extent of scope.
A female cook. [R.]
A creel or osier basket.
Living or having their nests in common, as certain birds.
To make a cuckold of, as a husband, by seducing his wife, or byher becoming an adulteress. Shak.

To search thoroughly; to engage in solicitation by traversing adistrict; as, to canvass for subscriptions or for votes; to canvassfor a book, a publisher, or in behalf of a charity; -- commonlyfollowed by for.
An instrument for measuring the size of skulls.
A writ or process commanding the officer to take the body ofthe person named in it, that is, to arrest him; -- also called writof capias.
The art or occupation of working upon wooden furniturerequiring nice workmanship; also, such furniture.

A series of links united; a series or order of things dependingon each other, as if linked together; a chain, a succession.The stoics affirmed a fatal, unchangeable concatenation of causes,reaching even to the illicit acts of man's will. South.A concatenation of explosions. W. Irving.
A myriapod of the order Chilopoda.
Capable of being brought before the mind as a throught or idea;conceivable; thinkable.Creation is cogitable by us only as a putting forth of divine power.Sir W. Hamilton.
A massive mineral, greenish in color, and opal-like inappearance. It is essentially a hydrous silicate of iron.
A contradicter.
The practice of magic; enchantment. Motley.
Joint efficacy.
Same as Chloroplastid.
A bracket to support a balcony, a cornice, or the like.
Of, pertaining to, or derived from, copper; containing copper;-- said of those compounds of copper in which this element is presentin its highest proportion.
Covetous; penurious; stingy; closefisted.-- Close"hand`ed*ness, n.
To call together; to summon to meet; to assemble by summons.There remained no resource but the dreadful one of convoking aparliament. palfrey.
A red clay from the Upper Missouri region, used by the Indiansfor their pipes.
A bringing together. [Obs.] Bp. Richardson.
Clearness; brightness; splendor.Floods, in whose more than crystal clarity, Innumerable virgin gracesrow. Beaumont.

A small evergreen tree (Theobroma Cacao) of South America andthe West Indies. Its fruit contains an edible pulp, inclosing seedsabout the size of an almond, from which cocoa, chocolate, and bromaare prepared.
The inner planking of a vessel. Camp ceiling. See under Camp.-- Ceiling boards, Thin narrow boards used to ceil with.
Belonging to, or obtained from, cinchona. Mayne.
A state of union; mass.
See Quinodine.
Marked by, or causing, complacence. [Obs.] "Complacentiallove." Baxter.
One of several that jointly sign a written instrument, as atreaty. Fallows.
A trible of North American Indians (Southern Appalachian)allied to the Choctaws. They formerly occupied the northern part ofAlabama and Mississippi, but now live in the Indian Territory.
The corsak.
An order of fishes, formerly proposed by Agassiz, for thosewith thin, smooth scales, destitute of marginal spines, as theherring and salmon. The group is now regarded as artificial.
One afflicted with cretinism.

An ament; a species of inflorescence, consisting of a slenderaxis with many unisexual apetalous flowers along its sides, as in thewillow and poplar, and (as to the staminate flowers) in the chestnut,oak, hickory, etc.-- so called from its resemblance to a cat's tail. See Illust. ofAment.
Pertaining to, or derived from camphor. [R.]
Having hollow horns.
One of a tribe of North American Indians now living in thestate of Washington, noted for the custom of flattening their skulls.Chinooks also called Flathead Indians.
A surplice, in England and America usually one shorter and lessfull than the ordinary surplice and with short sleeves, or sometimesnone.
A foot consisting of four syllables, of which the first andlast are long, and the other short (- ~ ~ -); that is, a choreus, ortrochee, and an iambus united.
A person of convivial habits.
One of the royalist insurgents in western France (Brittany,etc.), during and after the French revolution.
A piece of defensive or ornamental armor (with or without avizor) for the head and neck; a helmet.His casque overshadowed with brilliant plumes. Prescott.
A word coined by Lewis Carroll (Charles L. Dodgson), andusually explained as a combination of chuckle and snort. [Humorous]
Pertaining to crustaceology.
To believe; to credit. [Obs.]That part which is so creeded by the people. Milton.
The office, rank, or commission of a colonel.
Coöperating; acting together to produce an effect.Co`ef*fi"cient*ly, adv.
A short, light musket or rifle, esp. one used by mountedsoldiers or cavalry.
Pertaining to, or containing, columbium or niobium; niobic.Columbic acid (Chem.), a weak acid derived from columbic or niobicoxide, Nb2O5; -- called also niobic acid.
First or foremost; chief; principal. [Archaic] "Our chiefestcourtier." Shak.The chiefest among ten thousand. Canticles v. 10.
The operation of forming a new canthus, when one has beendestroyed by injury or disease.
A capping or crowning molding in classic architecture.
The whole top of the head of a bird from the base of the billto the nape of the neck.
Caontaining cant or affectation; whining; singing. [R.]
A dish for holding compotes, fruit, etc.
According to merit.
The quality of being cheesy.
A cross in the shape of the ankh.
Having the nature of chitin; consisting of, or containing,chitin.
Joint signification. [R.]
See Catafalque.
See Calker.
A companion. Shak.
A musical instrument; a kind of dulcimer. [Obs.]
To correct. [Obs.]When your worship's plassed to correctify a lady. Beau & Fl.
To combine or unite. [Obs.] "Co-uned together." Feltham.
A bird (Crex crex or C. pratensis) which frequents grainfields; the European crake or land rail; -- called also corn bird.
See Kinematics.
To trace or copy with a cymograph.
A cock, so called from the clearness or loundness of his voicein crowing.
A genus of delicate branching corals, made up of minute cells,belonging to the Bryozoa.
Attentive to all the circustances of a case or the probableconsequences of an action; cautious; prudent; wary.
A genus of nut-bearing trees or shrubs including the chestnutand chinquapin.
Cloud-gatherer; -- an epithet applied to Zeus. [Poetic.] Pope.
A feast for the benefit of the parish clerk. [Eng.] T. Warton.
The quality of being connubial; something characteristics ofthe conjugal state; an expression of connubial tenderness.Some connubialities which had begun to pass between Mr. and Mrs. B.Dickens.
Able to exist with another thing; consistent. [R.]Chillingworth.
A state of being consumptive, or a tendency to a consumption.
Mellow earth; mold. [Obs.] Bacon.

A game in which questions are asked for the purpose of enablingthe questioners to discover a word or thing previously selected bytwo persons who answer the questions; -- so called because theplayers take sides in two "clumps" or groups, the "clump" whichguesses the word winning the game.
Wine produced on the island of Capri, commonly a light, dry,white wine.
A cheat; a sharper; a deceiver. [Obs.] Minsheu.
Allied in origin or cause; congeneric; as, congenerousdiseases. [Obs.]  Sir T. Browne.
See Cilia.
A Cretan
A room or rooms under a building, and usually below the surfaceof the ground, where provisions and other stores are kept.
Having or wearing a cincture or gridle.
Spurge. [Obs.]
Charged with another bearing of the same figure, and of thecolor of the field, so large that only a narrow border of the firstbearing remains visible; -- said of any heraldic bearing. CompareVoided.
Stiff, like leather or parchment.
Having cirri along the margin of a part or organ.
A capital [Obs.] See Chapital. Ex. xxxvi. 38.
Having a cotyledon; tufted; as, the cotyledonary placenta ofthe cow.
The title of the empress of Russia.
A neck guard of chain mall, hanging from the bascinet or otherheadpiece.
To have compassion for; to pity; to commiserate; to sympathizewith.Compassionates my pains, and pities me. Addison.
A "country" or suffragan bishop, appointed in the ancientchurch by a diocesan bishop to exercise episcopal jurisdiction in arural district.
Vigilance un guarding against evil from every quarter; caution.[Travel] forces circumspectness on those abroad, who at home arenursed in security. Sir H. Wotton.
To overwhelm by argument; to refute conclusively; to prove orshow to be false or defective; to overcome; to silence.
A vessel used to hold wine, oil, or water for the service ofthe altar. Cruet stand, a frame for holding cruets; a caster.
Relating to the kitchen, or to the art of cookery; used inkitchens; as, a culinary vessel; the culinary art.
Broken paper; the outside quires of a ream.
An instrument for measuring degress of blueness.
Costly; expensive. [Obs.]The fineness of the gold and chargeful fashion. Shak.
A conoisseur. Mason.
See Choreus.
To exalt to the office of a cardinal. Sheldon.
The curve formed by a rope or chain of uniform density andperfect flexibility, hanging freely between two points of suspension,not in the same vertical line.
State of being comfortable or comforting manner.Speak ye comfortably to Jerusalem. Is. xl. 2.

A plume-shaped fossil, supposed to be a seaweed, characteristicof the lower Devonian rocks; as, the cauda galli grit. Gauda galliepoch (Geol.), an epoch at the begining of the Devonian age ineastern America, so named from the characteristic gritty sandstonemarked with impressions of cauda galli. See the Diagram underGeology.
A cipher writing. Same as Cryptograph.
A singer in a choir; a chorister. [R.]
An instrument or utensil for supporting a candle.
The science which pertains to the production of crystals.
To form into a cake, or mass.
A genus of flowering plants, of many species, mostly climbers,having feathery styles, which greatly enlarge in the fruit; -- calledalso virgin's bower.
The quality or power of being compatible or congruous;congruity; as, a compatibility of tempers; a compatibility ofproperties.
A loose and flowing outer garment, worn by the ancient Greeks;a kind of cloak.
Conscious. [R.] Bacon.
The quality of being caustic; causticity.
Murmuring; grumbling; -- sometimes applied to the rumblingproduced by a slight attack of the gripes. [Scot.] Burns.
The condition of a woman during marriage, because she isconsidered under the cover, influence, power, and protection of herhusband, and therefore called a feme covert, or femme couverte.
A shrub (Covillea mexicana) found in desert regions fromColorado to California and southward through Mexico. It has yellowflowers and very resinous foliage with a strong odor of creosote.
A keyed stringed instrument, now superseded by the pianoforte.See Clarichord.
A salt of carbazotic or picric acid; a picrate.

The regular form which a substance tends to assume insolidifying, through the inherent power of cohesive attraction. It isbounded by plane surfaces, symmetrically arranged, and each speciesof crystal has fixed axial ratios. See Crystallization.
To migrate together. [R.]
A halting or limping. [R.] Tatler.
To goad, drive, hunt, throw, or pitch. [Slang, Eng.] Dickens.
An iron plate or magnet placed near the compass on iron vesselsto neutralize the effect of the ship's attraction on the needle.
One of the speakers in a dialogue. Derham.
Any unbranched, slender, green plant of the fresh-water algae.The word is frequently used in a wider sense.
Capable of being claimed.
Production of heat, esp. animal heat.
A forked piece of wood, or a small spring clamp, used forfastening clothes on a line.
Full of complaint. [Obs.]
A consignee. [Obs.] Jenkins.
To triturate; to pulverize. [R.]
(Crystalloq.) A solid related to a tetrahedron, and containedunder twelve equal triangles.
A covering for the head. [Obs.] Chaucer.
Of the form of a cube.
One skilled in calligraphy; a good penman.
Same as Checky.
Diagonal. [Colloq.]
Of some other color than white; specifically applied to negroesor persons having negro blood; as, a colored man; the colored people.
A musical instrument, formerly in use, in form of a spinet; --called also manichord and clavichord.
The quality of being courageous; courage.
A cultivator of saffron; a dealer in saffron. [Obs.] Holinshed.
That may be confirmed.
Learned; erudite; clercial. [Obs.] Chaucer.
One whose occupation is to manufacture copper utensils; aworker in copper.
An American tree of the genus Populus or polar, having theseeds covered with abundant cottonlike hairs; esp., the P. moniliferaand P. angustifolia of the Western United States.
A joint accusation.
A border of greensward left round the margin of a plowed field.Ray.
The torpedo, or electric ray, the touch of which gives anelectric shock. See Electric fish, and Torpedo.
Manner of acting; behavior; conduct; deportment. [Obs.]I knew them well, and marked their rude comport. Dryden.
A convert. [Obs.] Shak.
To force; to compel; to drive. [Obs.]The faith and service of Christ ought to be voluntary and notcoacted. Foxe.
Quality of being conducible.
In a concrete manner.
The act or practice of justifying or confirming a man'sveracity by the oath of others; -- called also wager of law. SeePurgation; also Wager of law, under Wager.

One of thirty regions or zones, parallel to the equator, intowhich the surface of the earth from the equator to the pole wasdivided, according to the successive increase of the length of themidsummer day.
The lordship of a castle; the extent of land and jurisdictionappertaining to a castle.
See Key, a ledge.
A disease in the West Indies. It is a kind of ulcer on thesoles of the feet, with very hard edges. See Yaws. Dunglison.
A jail. See Calaboose.
In a chirping manner.
Fluor spar. See Kand.
Of or pertaining to the Celts; as, Celtic people, tribes,literature, tongue. [Written also Keltic.]
(kroitn. See Kreutzer.
The act of reforming anything; clearance. [R.]
Rubblework faced with stone. Knight.
Conducive; tending; contributing. Bacon.All his laws are in themselves conducible to the temporal interest ofthem that observe them. Bentley.
A gull in the plumage of its first year.
A fissure or fracture on the side opposite to that whichreceived the blow, or at some distance from it. Coxe.
The description or natural history of cetaceous animals.
The act of placing; the state of being placed with somethingelse; disposition in place; arrangement.The choice and collocation of words. Sir W. Jones.
Having a spongy or porous stracture; made up of cancelli;cancellated; as, the cancellous texture of parts of many bones.
A glucoside extracted from the cambium layer of coniferoustrees as a white crystalline substance.
Having processes resembling small horns.

To exchange; to put or substitute something else in place of,as a smaller penalty, obligation, or payment, for a greater, or asingle thing for an aggregate; hence; to lessen; to diminish; as, tocommute a sentence of death to one of imprisonment for life; tocommute tithes; to commute charges for fares.The sounds water and fire, being once annexed to those two elements,it was certainly more natural to call beings participating of thefirst "watery", and the last "fiery", than to commute the terms, andcall them by the reverse. J. HarrisThe utmost that could be obtained was that her sentence should becommuted from burning to beheading. Macaulay.
Capable of being countermanded; revocable. Bacon.
Conformity. [R.]  Marston.
To yield or surrender; to give up; to resign; as, to cede afortress, a province, or country, to another nation, by treaty.The people must cede to the government some of their natural rights.Jay.
A swaying in a contrary direction; an opposing influence.[Obs.]A countersway of restraint, curbing their wild exorbitance. Milton.
Resembling Christ in character, actions, etc.-- Christ"like`ness, n.
A cloth with a cotton wart, and a woof of very fine wool, orwool and silk.
So near the sun as to be obscured or eclipsed by his light, asthe moon or planets when not more than eight degrees and a half fromthe sun. [Obs.]Planets that are oft combust. Milton.
by creeping slowly; in the manner of a reptile; insidiously;cunningly.How slily and creepingly did he address himself to our first parents.South.
Full of chinks or fissures; gaping; opening in narrow clefts.Dryden.
Hollowness; concavity.
A mineral consisting principally of sulphate of iron; whitecopperas; -- so called because found in the province of Coquimbo,Chili.
Union, as in one body or mass; unity. Jer. Taylor.The coadunation of all the civilized provinces. Coleridge.

A colorless, inflammable, poisonous gas, C2N2, with a peach-blossom odor, so called from its tendency to form blue compounds;obtained by heating ammonium oxalate, mercuric cyanide, etc. It isobtained in combination, forming an alkaline cyanide when nitrogen ora nitrogenous compound is strongly ignited with carbon and soda orpotash. It conducts itself like a member of the halogen group ofelements, and shows a tendency to form complex compounds. The name isalso applied to the univalent radical, CN (the half molecule ofcyanogen proper), which was one of the first compound radicalsrecognized.
A perennial herb (Tussilago Farfara), whose leaves androotstock are sometimes employed in medicine. Butterbur coltsfoot(Bot.), a European plant (Petasites vulgaris).
A plant having long hard, crooked roots, the Ononis spinosa; --called also rest-harrow. The Scandix Pecten-Veneris is also calledcammock.
Capable of combinding; consistent with. [R.] M. Arnold.-- Com*bin"a*ble*ness, n.
To cheer; to enliven; as, to chirk one up. [Colloq. New Eng. ]
Rate by the hundred; percentage.
Catalogue.

A process which consists in surrounding a solid body with thepowder of other substances, and heating the whole to a degree notsufficient to cause fusion, the physical properties of the body beingchanged by chemical combination with powder; thus iron becomes steelby cementation with charcoal, and green glass becomes porcelain bycementation with sand.
The power possessed by the fibers of living muscle ofcontracting or shortening.
A minute, thin-walled vessel; particularly one of the smallestblood vessels connecting arteries and veins, but used also for thesmallest lymphatic and biliary vessels.
The machinery of a clock, or machinary resembling that of aclock; machinery which produced regularity of movement.
A female chanter or singer. Milton.
One who belong to a council; one who gives an opinion. [Obs.]I will in three months be an expert counsilist. Milton.
A whitish marble, from Rome, containiing pale greenish zones.It consists of calcium carbonate, with zones and cloudings of talc.
Of or pertaining to the clergy; clerical; clerkily; learned.[Obs.] Milton.
The illumination given by a standard candle at a distance ofone meter; -- used as a unit of illumination, except in GreatBritain.
Of or pertaining to a charism.

To arch over; to build in a hollow concave form; to make in theform of a cove.The mosques and other buildings of the Arabians are rounded intodomes and coved roofs. H. Swinburne.Coved ceiling, a ceiling, the part of which next the wail isconstructed in a cove.-- Coved vault, a vault composed of four coves meeting in a centralpoint, and therefore the reverse of a groined vault.
The act of shutting up or confining; confinement. [R.] Geddes.

To separate, select, or pick out; to choose and gather orcollect; as, to cuil flowers.From his herd he culls, For slaughter, from the fairest of his bulls.Dryden.Whitest honey in fairy gardens culled. Tennyson.
The doctrine that land and capital should be owned by societycollectively or as a whole; communism. W. G. Summer.
Stupid; dull; doltish.
Having the qualities of a cuckold; mean-spirited; sneaking.Shak.
1. The act of covering with carpets.
One of the same country, and having like interests and feeling.The distrust with which they felt themselves to be regarded by theircompatriots in America. Palfrey.

One who couples; that which couples, as a link, ring, orshackle, to connect cars. Coupler of an organ, a contrivance by whichany two or more of the ranks of keys, or keys and pedals, areconnected so as to act together when the organ is played.

A word of warning denoting that the king is in danger; such amenace of a player's king by an adversary's move as would, if it wereany other piece, expose it to immediate capture. A king so menaced issaid to be in check, and must be made safe at the next move.
One of the fine lines of a letter, esp. one of the fine crossstrokes at the top and bottom of letters. [Spelt also seriph.]Savage.
A genus of small, bivalve, freshwater Crustacea, belonging tothe Ostracoda; also, a member of this genus.
In a conjugal manner; matrimonially; connubially.
A cycadaceous plant of Florida and the West Indies, the Zamiaintegrifolia, from the stems of which a kind of sago is prepared.
See Corroboree.
One of a class of organic bases, C8H11N, usually pungent oilyliquids, belonging to the pyridine series, and obtained from boneoil, coal tar, naphtha, and certain alkaloids.
Same as Pantheism. [R.]
The state or quality of being cozy.
A wall made of clay mixed with straw.
To change into various colors. [R.]
Styrene (which was formerly called cinnamene because obtainedfrom cinnamic acid). See Styrene.
Full of crags, or steep, brokenInto its cragged rents descend. J. Baillie.
A bar or timber connecting two knightheads or two bitts.
A body of about five or six hundred soldiers; the tenth part ofa legion.
The charasteristics, manners, or dialect, of a cockney.
Brought together; contributed; done by contributions. [Obs.]Bailey.
The power of convincing, or the quality of being convincing.
Containing cobalt.
A state of being united togheter as in a clan; an associationunder a chieftain.
To convoke; to call together. [Obs.] May (Lucan).
Of or pertaining to a canton or cantons; of the nature of acanton.
An arcograph.
An order of sponges in which the skeleton consists of hornyfibers. It includes all the commercial sponges.
See Cazique.
A fossil shell, curved like a ram's horn; an obsolete name foran ammonite.
One who codifies.
Presenting a combination of a cube and an octahedron.
To adopt the character or belief of a Christian; to becomeChristian.The pagans began to Christianize. Latham.

Manifecting or expressing contempt or disdain; scornful;haughty; insolent; disdainful.A proud, contemptious behavior. Hammond.Savage invectiveand contemptuous sarcasm. Macaulay.Rome . . . entertained the most contemptuous opinion of the Jews.Atterbury.
See Chawdron. [Obs.]
Property; -- often used by Chaucer in contrast with rent, orincome."For loss of catel may recovered be, But loss of tyme shendeth us,"quod he. Chaucer.

To make matter of controversy; to dispute or oppose byreasoning; to contend against in words or writings; to contest; todebate.Some controverted points had decided according to the sense of thebest jurists. Macaulay.
Of or pertaining to calculi.
A conjunction or concentration of rays in one point. Bacom
One who practices cerography.
That part of the baths and gymnasia in which bathers andwrestlers anointed themselves.
The rough, shaggy part of oak bark.
A weed that binds stalks of corn, as Convolvulus arvensis,Polygonum Convolvulus. [Prov. Eng.]
A tenure of lands by knight's service; that is, by thecondition of a knight's performing service on horseback, or ofperforming some noble or military service to his lord.
A kind of confectionery or cake. [Obs.] Nares.
The wooden mold in which cheese is pressed. Simmonds.
A lamentation for the dead; a dirge. [Written also coranich,corrinoch, coronach, cronach, etc.] [Scot.]
One who consults, or asks counsel or information.
In a corpulent manner.
See Cæcum.
Adorned with cowslips. "Cowslipped lawns." Keats.
Blockhead; dunce; -- so called because the handle of a citternusually ended with a carved head. Marsion
The art of ringing bells, or a treatise on the art.

A plastid containing chlorophyll, developed only in cellsexposed to the light. Chloroplasts are minute flattened granules,usually occurring in great numbers in the cytoplasm near the cellwall, and consist of a colorless ground substance saturated withchlorophyll pigments. Under light of varying intensity they exhibitphototactic movements. In animals chloroplasts occur only in certainlow forms.
An inflammation of the large intestine, esp. of its mucousmembrane; colonitis.
A virtuoso.
Variant of Clasp [Obs.] Chaucer.
The state of being curdy.
Consisting of, or resembling, chalk; containing chalk; as, achalky cliff; a chalky taste.
Communion; sympathetic intercourse or conversation betweenfriends.For days of happy commune dead. Tennyson.
Pertaining to the concha, or external ear; as, the conchalcartilage.
To yield or make concession.I wished you to concede to America, at a time when she prayedconcession at our feet. Burke.
A kind of net to catch woodcock. [Obs.] Nares. Cockshut time orlight, evening twilight; nightfall; -- so called in allusion to thetome at which the cockshut used to be spread. [Obs.] Shak. B. Jonson.
Implying concession; as, a concessive conjunction. Lowth.
The interlacing osseous plates constituting the elastic poroustissue of certain parts of the bones, esp. in their articularextremities.
A tribe of Indians of the Dakota stock, living in Montana; --also called Upsarokas.
A pale sea-green color; also, porcelain or fine pottery of thistint.
The word which unites the subject and predicate.

The act or process of disintegrating a substance, or renderingit friable by the action of heat, esp. by the expulsion of somevolatile matter, as when carbonic and acid is expelled from carbonateof calcium in the burning of limestone in order to make lime.
Commixture; mingling. [R.]An exact commixtion of the ingredients. Boyle.
Producing, or attended with, convulsions or spasms;characterized by convulsions; convulsionary.An irregular, convulsive movement may be necessary to throw off anirregular, convulsive disease. Burke.
A public place of instruction in any special branch, esp. musicand the arts. [See Conservatory, 3].
Neatly. [Obs.] Sherwood.
One of the bones of the tarsus which in man, forms the greatbone of the heel; -- called also fibulare.
See Collie.
A genus of trilobites characteristic of the Silurian age.
A struggling; a contention. [Obs.]Colluctation with old hags and hobgoblins. Dr. H. More.
A fluoride of sodium and aluminum, found in Greenland, in whitecleavable masses; -- used as a source of soda and alumina.
Rude; churlish; violent. Longfellow.
Having club-shaped antennæ. See Antennæ -- n.
United closely; confederated; chemically united.
A perennial alliaceous plant (Allium fistulosum), sometimescalled Welsh onion. Its fistular leaves areused in cookery.

A nonphosphorized, nitrogenous substance, obtained from brainand nerve tissue by extraction with boiling alcohol. It is uncertainwhether it exists as such in nerve tissue, or is a product of thedecomposition of some more complex substance.
Tending confirm or establish. Sherwood.-- Con*firm"a*tive*ly, adv.
To salute mutually. [Obs.]

Of or pertaining to a college; as, collegiate studies; acollegiate society. Johnson. Collegiate church. (a) A church which,although not a bishop's seat, resembles a cathedral in having acollege, or chapter of canons (and, in the Church of England, adean), as Westminster Abbey. (b) An association of churches,possessing common revenues and administered under the joint pastorateof several ministers; as, the Reformed (Dutch) Collegiate Church ofNew York.
The hollow at the flexure of the arm.
See Clevis.
An opacity of the crystalline lens, or of its capsule, whichprevents the passage of the rays of light and impairs or destroys thesight.
A hot iron for searing or cauterizing. Minsheu.
Straight threads obtained by unraveling old linen cloth; --used for surgical dressings.
Having the food yolk placed at the center of the ovum,segmentation being either regular or unequal. Balfour.
Resembling clods; gross; low; stupid; boorish. Hawthorne.-- Clod"dish*ness, n.
A lamb reared without the aid of the dam. Hence: A pet, ingeneral.
To take a counter proof of, or a copy in reverse, by taking animpression directly from the face of an original. See Counter proof,under Counter.
Same as Chronologist.

A pencil of carbon used in producing electric light. Crayonboard, cardboard with a surface prepared for crayon drawing.-- Crayon drawing, the act or art of drawing with crayons; a drawingmade with crayons.
The state of a community which permits promiscuous sexualintercourse among its members; -- as in certain primitive tribes orcommunistic societies. [Written also cenogamy.]
Of or pertaining to the coccyx; as, the coccygeal vertebræ.Coccygeal glands (Zoöl.) , glands situated at the base of the tail ofbirds. They secrete the oil with which the plumage is dressed.
Ropes or cords, collectively; hence, anything made of rope orcord, as those parts of the rigging of a ship which consist of ropes.
In the form of a cone.
A species of inferior carpet imported from the Levant.McElrath.
Containing, or capable of forming, chromogen; as, chromogenicbacteria.
A part of a turtle which is next to the upper shell. Itcontains a fatty and gelatinous substance of a dull greenish tinge,much esteemed as a delicacy in preparations of turtle.
One of the somites (arthromeres) which make up the head ofarthropods. Packard.
In a cabalistic manner.
Same as Chalaza.
Worsted yarn,, slackly twisted, used for embroidery.
The galeated curassow. See Curassow.
An artificial cavity made in the teeth of horses that haveoutgrown their natural mark, to disguise their age.
See under Cartridge.
propositions with the same terms, but opposed to each otherboth in quality and quantity.
Holy bark; the bark of the California buckthorn (RhamnusPurshianus), used as a mild cathartic or laxative.
Any ornamental vessel used as a spittoon; hence, to avoid thecommon term, a spittoon of any sort.
To broil. [Obs.] "We had a calf's head carboned". Pepys.

The action or effect of corrosive agents, or the process ofcorrosive change; as, the rusting of iron is a variety of corrosion.Corrosion is a particular species of dissolution of bodies, either byan acid or a saline menstruum. John Quincy.
Any position giving the enemy such advantage that the troopsoccupying it must either surrender or be cut to pieces. Farrow.
Furnished with, or bearing, campanes, or bells.
Pertaining to communalism.
The quality or state of being circular; a circular form.
Curved; rounded. [Obs.]Her neck is short, her shoulders courb. Gower.
The Lake herring (Coregonus Artedi), valuable food fish of theGreat Lakes of North America. The name is also applied to C. Hoyi, arelated species of Lake Michigan.
A comprehensive division of the Vertebrata, including all thosethat have a skull.
A lotion of linseed oil and lime water, used as an applicationto burns and scalds; -- first used at the Carron iron works inScotland.
A kind of linen cloth made in Egypt, and so named from itsresemblance to cambric.
A joint defendant. Blackstone.
In a consonant, consistent, or congruous manner; agreeably.
A tribe of wading birds including the stork, heron, crane, etc.
Turnip-rooted celery, a from of celery with a large globularroot, which is used for food.
A small or private assembly, especially of an ecclesiasticalnature. [Obs.] Bacon.
See 2d Calk, v. t.
A descendant of Cush, the son of Ham and grandson of Noah.
Clownishly; surlily.
Having coral; covered with coral.
Relating to a compurgator or to compurgation. "Theircompurgatorial oath." Milman.
A waxy substance extracted by alcohol or ether from cork;sometimes applied also to the portion of beeswax which is soluble inalcohol. Watts.
Affected wit; a conceit. Chesterfield.
A kind of buggy having a body with low sides, and side springs.
Bearing hair; hairy. [R.]

The official chair or throne of a bishop, or of any person inhigh authority. Ex cathedra Etym: [L., from the chair], in theexercise of one's office; with authority.The Vatican Council declares that the Pope, is infallible "when hespeaks ex cathedra." Addis & Arnold's Cath. Dict.
To distinguish by a contrast of opposite qualities.These are our complex ideas of soul and body, as contradistinguished.Locke.
The tumid upper lip of certain mammals, as of a camel.
The state of being an accomplice; participation in guilt.

A small and beautiful species of orchid, having a flowervariegated with purple, pink, and yellow. It grows in cold and wetlocalities in the northern part of the United States. The Calypsoborealis is the only orchid which reaches 68º N.
One who has charge of money; a cash keeper; the officer who hascharge of the payments and receipts (moneys, checks, notes), of abank or a mercantile company.
A cord by which a person in a carriage or horse car may signalto the driver.
Pertaining to the Citigradæ.-- n.
Regard for the church.
The genus Ranunculus, of many species; some are common weeds,others are flowering plants of considerable beauty.
A Crawford peach; a well-known freestone peach, wich yellowflesh, first raised by Mr. William Crawford, of New Jersey.
Having the hair of a different tincture from the rest of thebody; as, a charge crined of a red tincture.
Acting under contract; settled by express agreement; as,conventionary tenants. [Obs.] R. Carew.
To present and institute in a benefice, when the personpresenting is both the patron and the ordinary; -- followed by to.
One who cherishes.The cherisher of my flesh and blood. Shak.
Contrary; opposed; antagonistic; inconsistent; contradictory.[R.]The struggles of contrariant factions. Coleridge.
A valatile alkaloid extracted from Capsicum annuum or fromcapsicin.
A treatise on colors

The root of an American shrub (Chiococca racemosa), found asfar north as Florida Keys, from which cahincic acid is obtained;also, the root of the South American Chiococca anguifuga, acelebrated antidote for snake poison.
Raised into a pile; collected into a crowd; heaped. [R.] Bacon.
An East Indian resin, of a pellucid white color, from whichsmall ornaments and toys are sometimes made.
Strong, stiff, or hard, like a horn; resembling horn.Up stood the cornu reed. Milton.
Of or belonging to a cantor. Cantoral staff, the official staffor baton of a cantor or precentor, with which time is marked for thesingers.
One who rejects, discards, or dismisses; as, a cashierer ofmonarchs. [R.] Burke.
One who carries the keys of any place.
One who conjures; one who calls, entreats, or charges in asolemn manner.
One of the two main arteries of the neck, by which blood isconveyed from the aorta to the head.
Same as Capoch.
Erroneous doctrine; heresy; heterodoxy. [R.]Heterodoxy, or what Luther calls cacodoxy. R. Turnbull.
A device, usually of iron bent at the ends, used to holdtogether blocks of stone, timbers, etc.; a cramp iron.
One who commemorates.
A white crystalline substance, C9H6N.OH, of acid propertiesderived from one of the amido cinnamic acids.
A reflecting telescope, part of which is made to rotateeccentrically, so as to produce a ringlike image of a star, insteadof a point; -- used in studying the scintillation of the stars.
In a comfortable or comforting manner.
A breaking asunder; disruption.
Suitable for membership in a club; sociable. [Humorous.] G. W.Curtis.
A member of a committee.
A connected series of military operations forming a distinctstage in a war; the time during which an army keeps the field.Wilhelm.

The outline of a horizontal section of the ground, or of worksof fortification. Contour feathers (Zoöl.), those feathers that formthe general covering of a bird.-- Contour of ground (Surv.), the outline of the surface of groundwith respect to its undulation, etc.-- Contour line (Topographical Suv.), the line in which a horizontalplane intersects a portion of ground, or the corresponding line in amap or chart.
Any crinoid of the genus Antedon or allied genera.
Having long filaments; resembling a hair; slender. SeeCapillary.
Chatty; talkative; sociable; familiar. [Eng.]
Pleasing the mind or senses in a high degree; delighting;fascinating; attractive.How charming is divine philosophy. Milton.
See Cadie.
By compulsion; by force.
Composed in a melodious and singing style.
A morbid condition caused by an overwhelming shock or extremefear and marked by rigidity of the muscles. -- Cat`a*plec"tic (#), a.

A body politic or corporate, formed and authorized by law toact as a single person, and endowed by law with the capacity ofsuccession; a society having the capacity of transacting business asan individual.
Conglutinant.
One who, or that which, constructs or frames.
An electro-positive substance, which in electro-decompositionis evolved at the cathode; -- opposed to anion. Faraday.
Pertaining to the Cyclops; characteristic of the Cyclops; huge;gigantic; vast and rough; massive; as, Cyclopean labors; Cyclopeanarchitecture.
A name given to various lichens gathered for dyeing. [Scot.]
Containing, or abounding in, creeks; characterized by creeks;like a creek; winding. "The creeky shore." Spenser.
A military adventurer of the fourteenth and fifteenthcenturies, who sold his services, and those of his followers, to anyparty in any contest.

A solid of the form described by the revolution of a right-angled triangle about one of the sides adjacent to the right angle; -- called also a right cone. More generally, any solid having avertical point and bounded by a surface which is described by astraight line always passing through that vertical point; a solidhaving a circle for its base and tapering to a point or vertex.
Capable of being corroded; corrosible. Sir T. Browne.
Good spirits; a state of moderate joy or gayety; alacrity.
Serving to confirm; corroborative.A fact confirmatory of the conclusion. I. Taylor.
See Chasuble.
Having the character of a cosmopolite. [R.] Hackluyt.
One of the Cheiroptera.
A garment for women, consisting of chemise and drawers unitedin one. [U. S.]
See Carcass.

A colorless or yellowish oil, C10H15N, of a leathery odor,occuring in coal tar, Dippel's oil, tobacco smoke, etc., regarded asan organic base, homologous with pyridine. Also, one of a series ofmetameric compounds of which coridine is a type. [Written alsocorindine.]
To declare war with certain ceremonies. [Obs.] Holland.
See Catcall.
Coincident.
In a circumspect manner; cautiously; warily.
To daub, smear, or spread, as with mud, etc. [Prov. Eng.]Halliwell.
A group of nudibranchiate Mollusca having on the backpapilliform or branched organs serving as gills.
To wind itself cylindrically or spirally; to form a coil; towind; -- often with about or around.You can see his flery serpents . . . Coiting, playing in the water.Longfellow.
Dimness or obscurity of sight, dependent upon a speck on thecornea; also, the speck itself.
Containing, or partaking of the nature of, copper; like copper;as, a copperish taste.
The process of determining the solid or cubic contents of abody.
Given to light, familiar talk; talkative. Lady M. W. Montagu.
Literally, suffering with another; a sensation of sorrowexcited by the distress or misfortunes of another; pity;commiseration.Womanly igenuity set to work by womanly compassion. Macaulay.
In a chivalrous manner; gallantly; magnanimously.
Any violent catastrophe, involving sudden and extensive changesof the earth's surface.
Silent. [R.] "The guests sit conticent." Thackeray.
Conservation, as from injury, defilement, or irregular use.[An act was] passed in 1866, for vesting in the Conservators of theRiver Thames the conservancy of the Thames and Isis. Mozley & W.
The act of ravishing; violation; defilement. Bp. Hall.
An underground gallery excavated to intercept and destroy themining of an enemy.

Amazement or horror that confounds the faculties, andincapacitates for refletion; terror, combined with amaxement; dismay.The chiefs around, In silence wrapped, in onsternation downed. Attendthe stern reply. Pope.
The faculty which enables one to construct, as in mechanical,artistic, or literary matters.
See Chinquapin.
The state of a woman bringing forth a child, or being in labor;parturition.
A kind of coarse serge.
The condition or character of a cosmopolite; disregard ofnational or local peculiarities and prejudices.
A vessel with a sharp bow, built and rigged for fast sailing.-- Clip"per-built` (, a.
To clip with scissors. [Obs.] Beau. & Fl.
To transfer (as sheets of partly dried pulp) from the wireclotch mold to a felt blanket, for further drying.
Of or pertaining to Chaldea.-- n.
The pastoral staff of a bishop (also of an archbishop, beingthe symbol of his office as a shepherd of the flock of God.

To soil, stain, or corrupt by contact; to tarnish; to sully; totaint; to pollute; to defile.Shall we now Contaminate our figures with base bribes Shak.I would neither have simplicity imposed upon, nor virtuecontaminated. Goldsmith.
A genus of bulbous plants, of the order Amaryllidace,cultivated as greenhouse plants on account of their beauty.

A writ issuing out of chancery, or a superior court, to call upthe records of a inferior court, or remove a cause there depending,in order that the party may have more sure and speedy justice, orthat errors and irreguarities may be corrected. It is obtained uponcomplaint of a party that he has not received justice, or can nothave an impartial trial in the inferior court.
Expression of sympathy with another in sorrow or grief.Their congratulations and their condolences. Steele.A special mission of condolence. Macaulay.
A white crystallized substance, C12H8NH, derived from anilineand other amines.
A small job; in the pl., the regular or daily light work of ahousehold or farm, either within or without doors. [U. S.]
Lime-yielding; calciferous
To unite in one mass or body; to incorporate. [Archaic.] Jer.Taylor.
Concave or hollow on both sides; double concave.
A set or circle of persons who meet familiarly, as for social,literary, or other purposes; a clique. "The queen of your coterie."Thackeray.
Bred, or educated, at court; polished; courtly.

Having coincidence; occupying the same place; contemporaneous;concurrent; -- followed by with.Christianity teaches nothing but what is perfectly suitable to, andcoincident with, the ruling principles of a virtuous and well-inclined man. South.
The thick shell or sheild which cover the back of the tortoise,or turtle, the crab, and other crustaceous animals.
The act or process of capitalizing.
In a coördinate manner.

To be anxious or solictous; to be concerned; to have regard orinterest; -- sometimes followed by an objective of measure.I would not care a pin, if the other three were in. Shak.Master, carest thou not that we perish Mark. iv. 38.To care for. (a) To have under watchful attention; to take care of.(b) To have regard or affection for; to like or love.He cared not for the affection of the house. Tennyson.
Consistent; agreeable; suitable; accordant to; harmonious;concurrent.A good law and consentaneous to reason. Howell.-- Con`sen*ta"ne*ous*ly, adv.-- Con`sen*ta"ne*ous*ness, n.
See Protoplasm.
Chalky; cretaceous. [Obs.] Ash.
Pertaining to a plastic force as operative in the formation ofthe world independently of God; world-forming. "Cosmoplastic andhylozoic atheisms." Gudworth.
An apple-green mineral, a hydrous arseniate of nickel, cobalt,and magnesia; -- so named from the Sierra Cabrera, Spain.
Capable of being confiscated; liable to forfeiture.
A mass formed by concretion. [Obs.] Johnson.
One who champs, or bites.
An ornamental finish on the top of a wall or ridge of a roof.
The Indian four-horned antelope; the chikara.

One who has the cure souls; originally, any clergyman, but nowusually limited to one who assist a rector or vicar Hook.All this the good old man performed alone, He spared no pains, forcurate he had none. Dryden.
The state of being concupiscible. [Obs.]
See Quinone.
Cherubic; angelic. [Obs.] Shak.
To eat away by degrees; to corrode. [Obs.] Sandys.
As black as coal; jet black; very black. Dryden.
The state of a cuckold; cuckolds, collectively. Addison.
Being or dwelling around the earth. "Circumterraneous demouns."H. Hallywell.
A vacuum tube in which the exhaustion is carried to a very highdegree, with the production of a distinct class of effects; -- socalled from W. Crookes who introduced it.
A small cañon; a narrow valley or glen; also, but lessfrequently, an open valley. [Local, Western U. S.]
To vote in opposition ti; to balance or overcome by viting; tooutvote. Dr. J. Scott.
Wildy; vainly; fancifully.
A cake made of the meal of Indian corn, wrapped in a coveringof husks or paper, and baked under the embers. [U.S.] Bartlett.
A kind of large ship formerly used by the Spaniards andPortuguese in the East India trade; a galleon. [Spelt also carrack.]The bigger whale like some huge carrack law. Waller.
By cartography.

Short for Composition; -- used, esp. in England, colloq. invarious trade applications; as :(a) A mortar made of sand and cement.(b) A carver's mixture of resin, whiting, and glue, used  instead ofplaster of Paris for ornamenting walls and cornices.(c) A composition for billiard balls.(d) A preparation of which printer's rollers are made.(e) A preparation used in currying leather.(f) Composition paid by a debtor.
To oppose or check by some obstacle; to check by a returncheck.
A poisonous alkaloid extracted from corroval, and characterizedby its immediate action in paralyzing the heart.
having the quality of contradistinction; distinguishing bycontrast.-- Con`tra*dis*tinc"tive, n.

The condition of being of equal in intensity; -- applied torelations; as, 3 : 6 and 6 : 12 are relations of cointension.Cointension . . . is chosen indicate the equality of relations inrespect of the contrast between their terms. H. Spencer.
One of the nine honorable ordinaries, consisting of two broadbands of the width of the bar, issuing, respectively from the dexterand sinister bases of the field and conjoined at its center.
Pertaining to, or situated near, the calcar of the brain.
Loud or immoderate laughter; -- often a symptom of hystericalor maniacal affections.Hideous grimaces . . . attended this unusual cachinnation. Sir W.Scott.
Fair or elegant penmanship.
A classic idiom or expression; a classicalism. C. Kingsley.
To seize or take possession of by force, surprise, orstratagem; to overcome and hold; to secure by effort.Her heart is like some fortress that has been captured. W. Ivring.
The blue coloring matter of flowers; -- called also anthokyanand anthocyanin.
One of the attendants of a prince or noble, permanently chargedwith the performance of this office for his master. "I was the king'scupbearer." Neh. i. 11.
A narrow circle of persons associated by common interests orfor the accomplishment of a common purpose; -- generally used in abad sense.
In a manner or to a degree not trifling or unimportant;greatly; much.The breeds . . . differ considerably from each other. Darwin.
See Cottised.
The condition or quality of being convertible; capability ofbeing exchanged; convertibleness.The mutual convertibility of land into money, and of money into land.Burke.
Inflammation of the bladder.
One who supports or frequents conventicles. Dryden.
One who, or that which, contributes; specifically, one whowrites articles for a newspaper or magazine.

A branching, nut-bearing tree or shrub (Castanea pumila) ofNorth America, from six to twenty feet high, allied to the chestnut.Also, its small, sweet, edible nat. [Written also chincapin andchinkapin.] Chinquapin oak, a small shrubby oak (Quercus prinoides)of the Atlantic States, with edible acorns.-- Western Chinquapin, an evergreen shrub or tree (Castanopeschrysophylla) of the Pacific coast. In California it is a shrub; inOregon a tree 30 to 125 feet high.
Pertaining to, or having, convulsions; convulsionary. [R.]Lamb.
Same as Cothurn.
Divination by means of the ascent or motion of smoke.
The red oxide of copper; red copper; an important ore ofcopper, occurring massive and in isometric crystals.
Nicolite.
Pertaining to the catamenia, or menstrual discharges.

Having the characteristics of Circe, daughter of Sol andPerseis, a mythological enchantress, who first charmed her victimsand then changed them to the forms of beasts; pleasing, but noxious;as, a Circean draught.
The upper stratum of fuller's earth.
The cephalata.
Capable of bending or yielding; apt to yield; compliant.Another compliable mind. Milton.The Jews . . . had made their religion compliable, and accemodated totheir passions. Jortin.
The head.
A sort of salt, finely granulated, formed out of the bittern orleach brine.
Overalls of sheepskin or leather, usually open at the back,worn, esp. by cowboys, to protect the legs from thorny bushes, as inthe chaparral; -- called also chapareras or colloq. chaps. [Sp.Amer.]
A coarse or stupid fellow. Shak.
An adventurer; -- a term of contempt for a Northern man seekingprivate gain or political advancement in the southern part of theUnited States after the Civil War (1865). [U. S.]
An isocyanide of a hydrocarbon radical. The carbamines areliquids, usually colorless, and of unendurable odor.
One who, or that which, cleans.
Glowing; luminous; incandescent.
To accompany for protection, either by sea or land; to attendfor protection; to escort; as, a frigate convoys a merchantman.I know ye skillful to convoy The total freight of hope and joy.Emerson.
A small traveling case or bandbox; formerly, a chest.A capcase for your linen and your plate. Beau. & Fl.
One skilled in drawing cartoons.
See Cognizor.
Capable of being controverted; disputable; admitting ofquestion.-- Con`tro*ver"ti*bly, adv.
A tavern; a house where liquors are retailed. [Obs. as anEnglish word.]
A cake yeast made by filtering the cells from the liquid inwhich they are grown, subjecting to heavy pressure, and mixing withstarch or flour.
A thin stuff made of the finest wool or silk, or of wool andsilk.
A tailor who botches his work. [Obs.] Shak.
Relating to cyanosis; affected with cyanosis; as, a cyanoticpatient; having the hue caused by cyanosis; as, a cyanitic skin.
A town or village, or part of a town or village, assigned to abody of troops for quarters; temporary shelter or place of rest foran army; quarters.
A watchman; an officer of customs or police. [India]
See Choose. [Obs.]
Equally eternal.-- Co`e*ter"nal*ly, adv.Hail, holy Light, offspring of Heaven first born! Or of the Eternalcoeternal beam. Milton.

The act by which the title to property, esp. real estate, istransferred; transfer of ownership; an instrument in writing (as adeed or mortgage), by which the title to property is conveyed fromone person to another.[He] found the conveyances in law to be so firm, that in justice hemust decree the land to the earl. Clarendon.
See Aurocyanide.
The chub sucker.
To make close. [R.]

A diminutive of the chevron, containing one fourth of itssurface. Couple-closes are generally borne one on each side of achevron, and the blazoning may then be either a chevron between twocouple-closes or chevron cottised.
Gravel or pebbles. Halliwell.
By way of concession.
The chick-pea. Holland.
One who guesses or conjectures. [Obs.]A great conjector at other men by their writings. Milton.

One of two great circles intersecting at right angles in thepoles of the equator. One of them passes through the equinoctialpoints, and hence is denominated the equinoctial colure; the otherintersects the equator at the distance of 90º from the former, and iscalled the solstitial colure.Thrice the equinoctial line He circled; four times crossed the car ofnight From pole to pole, traversing each colure. Milton.
A flat, open country.Fair champaign, with less rivers interveined. Milton.Through Apline vale or champaign wide. Wordsworth.
A little horn. [Obs.] Sir T. Browne.
The office of a collector of customs or of taxes.
Having concealed or rudimentary gills.
A cup or bowl; especially, the cup used in the sacrament of theLord's Supper.
One who boasts; a braggart. [Obs.] Old Play.
A vender of paints, etc. Simmonds.
Pertaining to the temple; temporal.
A chinese reed instrument, with tubes, blown by the mouth.
Producing wax.
Gout in the hand.
The act of prevailing over another by arts, address, or fraud;deception; fraud; imposture; delusion.A school in which he learns sly circumvention. Cowper.
Rising to a point or head; conical; pointed; crested. Wiseman.
To utter loud sounds or outcries; to vociferate; to complain;to make importunate demands.The obscure bird Clamored the livelong night. Shak.
Of or pertaining to the Cabiri, or to their mystical worship.[Written also Cabiritic.]

An irregular and arbitrary imposition or tax leved on thepeople of a town or country.These sums, . . . and the forced contributions paid by lucklesspeasants, enabled him to keep his straggling troops together. Motley.
See Colocynth. Shak.
In a coquettish manner.
The edible nut of a forest tree (Castanea vesce) of Europe andAmerica. Commonly two or more of the nuts grow in a prickly bur.
One who contravenes.
See Buffalo fly, under Buffalo.
A cross, set upon three steps; -- more properly called crosscalvary.
From head to foot; at all points. "He was armed cap-a-pie."Prescott.
Furnished with a child. [Obs.]
By consequence; by natural or logical sequence or connection.
A wheel with cogs or teeth; a gear wheel. See Illust. ofGearing.
That class of Mollusca which includes the bivalve shells; theLamellibranchiata. See Mollusca.
Inclosed in a cyst.
Clemency. [Obs.] Spenser.
A one-horse carriage with two seats and a calash top.
See Carack.
See Chasse, n., above.
Deep sorrow and penitence for sin; contrition.
Of or pertaining to the neck; as, the cervical vertebræ.
To convert to Calvinism.

An inversion of the order of words or phrases, when repeated orsubsequently referred to in a sentence; thus,If e'er to bless thy sons My voice or hands deny, These hands letuseful skill forsake, This voice in silence die. Dwight.
To carry through; to succeed in; as, you can't come any trickshere. [Slang] To come it, to succeed in a trick of any sort. [Slang]
Like a carrot in color or in taste; -- an epithet given toreddish yellow hair, etc.
A steward or butler of a monastery or chapter; one who hascharge of procuring and keeping the provisions.
See Copartner. [Obs.]

A binary compound of chlorine with another element or radical;as, chloride of sodium (common salt). Chloride of ammonium, salammoniac.-- Chloride of lime, bleaching powder; a grayish white substance,CaOClcalcium hypochlorite. See Hypochlorous acid, under Hypochlorous.-- Mercuric chloride, corrosive sublimate.
See Cafila.
One who makes it his business to marry beggars to each other.Swift.
Of or relating to, or like, cockneys.
The varicose dilatation of the spermatic vein.
Painting in shades of one color; monochrome. Mollett.
A well known public school and charitable foundation in thebuilding once used as a Carthusian monastery (Chartreuse) in London.
A chicken; -- used as a diminutive or pet name, especially incalling fowls.
A general term for a fossil fruit, nut, or seed.

Relating to the center of gravity, or to the process of findingit. Centrobaric method (Math.), a process invented for the purpose ofmeasuring the area or the volume generated by the rotation of a lineor surface about a fixed axis, depending upon the principle thatevery figure formed by the revolution of a line or surface about suchan axis has for measure the product of the line or surface by thelength of the path of its center of gravity; -- sometimes calledtheorem of Pappus, also, incorrectly, Guldinus's properties. SeeBarycentric calculus, under Calculus.
The pineal gland.
Extreme depression or sudden failing o
A genus of fossil ganoid fishes found in the old red sandstoneor Devonian formation. The head is large, and protected by a broadshield-shaped helmet prolonged behind into two lateral points.
One who conceives.
Exchange; reciprocation.
The name firat given in England to the red wines of M
A tall, coarse grass (Imperata arundinacea) of the PhilippineIslands and adjacent countries, used for thatching.
A genus of perennial plants (Calamintha) of the Mint family,esp. the C. Nepela and C. Acinos, which are called also basil thyme.
Privacy or secrecy. [R.]
The tree (Dipteryx odorata) which bears the tonka bean; also,the bean itself.
To assume as a bearing; as, he charges three roses or; to addto or represent on; as, he charges his shield with three roses or.
A book in which is kept a register of money received or paidout.
Of or pertaining to a cemetery. "Cemeterial cells." [R.] Sir T.Browne.
A small rent paid to the lord paramount. [Obs.] Swift.

A citrous fruit produced by a cross between the sweet orangeand the trifoliate orange (Citrus trifoliata). It is more acid andhas a more pronounced aroma than the orange; the tree is hardier.There are several varieties.
Perverse; contentious; ugly; malicious. [Colloq.] --Can*tan"ker*ous*ly, adv.-- Can*tan"ker*ous*ness, n.The cantankerous old maiden aunt. Theckeray.
An order of marine sponges, containing calcareous spicules. SeePorifera.
The technical name for urea.
Taken prisoner; made captive; insnared; charmed.Women have been captivate ere now. Shak.

An apparattus for showing the position of the earth, at anygiven time, with respect to the fixed stars. It consist of a hollowglass globe, on which are depicted the stars and constellations, andwithin which is a terrestrial globe.
See Counterfoil.
Content; easy in mind; satisfied; quiet; willing.-- Con*tent"ed*ly, adv.-- Con*tent"ed*ness, n.
A red crystallizable tasteless substance, extracted from thecarrot.
That does not cloy. Shak.
The coarse tow of flax and hemp. McElrath.
Crawly; having or producing a sensation like that caused byinsects creeping on the skin. [Colloq.]One's whole blood grew curdling and creepy. R. Browning.
Corrodible. Bailey.
Smeared with blood. [Obs.] Glanwill.
A comprehensive group equivalent to the true Coelenterata,i.e., exclusive of the sponges. They are so named from presence ofstinging cells (cnidae) in the tissues. See Coelenterata.
An order of flying, dromTinamou.

Transmission through, or by means of, a conductor; also,conductivity.[The] communication [of heat] from one body to another when they arein contact, or through a homogenous body from particle to particle,constitutes conduction. Amer. Cyc.

To cut off the end or tail, or any part, of; to shorten; toabridge; to diminish; to reduce.I, that am curtailed of this fair proportion. Shak.Our incomes have been curtailed; his salary has been doubled.Macualay.
One who treats of the origin of the universe; one versed incosmogony.
A transmission arrangement in which the longitudinal crankshaft drives the rear wheels through a clutch, change-speed gear,countershaft, and two parallel side chains, in order.

To act against with equal force, power, or effect; to thwart orovercome by such action; to furnish an equivalent to or for; tocounterbalance; to compensate.Upon balancing the account, the profit at last will hardlycountervail the inconveniences that go allong with it. L'Estrange.
In a civil manner; as regards civil rights and privileges;politely; courteously; in a well bred manner.
A large, globular glass bottle, esp. one of green glass,inclosed in basket work or in a box, for protection; -- used commonlyfor carrying corrosive liquids; as sulphuric acid, etc.
See Cottise.
See Con, to direct a ship.
the mapping or description of a region or district.The chorography of their provinces. Sir T. Browne.
A joint ally. Kent.
Having no claim.
The name of several caryophyllaseous weeds, especiallyStellaria media, the seeds and flower buds of which are a favoritefood of small birds.
A tool of which the hemp for lines and twines, used bysailmakers, is finished.
To modify or temper; to allay; to qualify; to moderate; tosoften. [Obs.]The antidotes . . . have allayed its bitterness and contempered itsmalignancy. Johnson.
Case. [Obs.] Chaucer.

A box or chest. Specifically: (a) A bronze receptacle, round oroval, frequently decorated with engravings on the sides and cover,and with feet, handles, etc., of decorative castings. (b) A cineraryurn. See Illustration in Appendix.
An instrument for measuring charts or maps.
To move sidewise, as a crab. [Jocular]. Southey.
Bordering; conterminous; -- followed by with.
Pertaining to cryptography; cryptographical. Boyle.
Relating to a crust.
The last stone in a horizontal course, if of a less size thanthe others, or a piece of brick finishing a course. Gwilt.
As white as cream.

A large and valuable fish of the Mackerel family, of the genusScomberomorus. Two species are found in the West Indies and lesscommonly on the Atlantic coast of the United States, -- the commoncero (Scomberomorus caballa), called also kingfish, and spotted, orking, cero (S. regalis).
A cornemuse. [Obs.]
Opposed to or against nature; unnatural. [R.] Bp. Rust.
A glucoside occurring in jalap (the root of a convolvulaceousplant), and extracted as a colorless, tasteless, gummy mass ofpowerful purgative properties.
An algebraic curve, so called from its resemblance to a heart.
With conformity or in conformity; suitably; agreeably.
Cowardly.The Lady Powis . . . patted him with her fan, and called him acowhearted fellow. R. North.
Secretly; occultly.
An order of mammalia, including the bats, having four toes ofeach of the anterior limbs elongated and connected by a web, so thatthey can be used like wings in flying. See Bat.
p. a. & vb. n. of Cure. Curing house, a building in whichanything is cured; especially, in the West Indies, a building inwhich sugar is drained and dried.
The science of the useful arts, esp. agriculture, manufactures,and commerce. [R.]
A rival; a corrival.
Bound about, or wound, with cords.
The pole flounder.
Same as Clearstory.
The quality of being canonical; canonicity. Bp. Burnet.
In a conscientious manner; as a matter of conscience; hence;faithfully; accurately; completely.
Pertaining to; regarding; having relation to; respecting; asregards.I have accepted thee concerning this thing. Gen. xix. 21.The Lord hath spoken good concerning Israel. Num. x. 29.
A genus of poisonous African serpents, with a horny scale overeach eye; the horned viper.
Of or pertaining to Castile, in Spain.
A combination of a cube and octahedron, esp. one in which theoctahedral faces meet at the middle of the cubic edges.
Having a calyx or cup; cupshaped. "Chaliced flowers." Shak.
See Caddice.
consisting of, or containing, calcareous and argillaceousearths.
A fight in which centaurs take part, -- a common theme forrelief sculpture, as in the Parthenon metopes.
A lynx (Felis, or Lynx, caracal.) It is a native of Africa andAsia. Its ears are black externally, and tipped with long blackhairs.
Moving about slightly. [R.] H. Bushnell.
A species of Cardamine (C. pratensis), or lady's smock. Itsleaves are used in salads. Also, the ragged robin (Lychnis Flos-cuculi).
Wrinkled; crumpled; furrowed; contracted into ridges andfurrows.
A citizen; an inhabitant of a city; a pert townsman; -- usedcontemptuously. "Insulted as a cit". JohnsonWhich past endurance sting the tender cit. Emerson.

Adapted to cool and refresh; allaying heat. "The coolingbrook." Goldsmith. Cooling card, something that dashes hopes. [Obs.]-- Cooling time (Law), such a lapse of time as ought, taking all thecircumstances of the case in view, to produce a subsiding of passionpreviously provoked. Wharton.
Having a part cut off or away; having the corners rounded orcut away. Cutaway coat, a coat whose skirts are cut away in front soas not to meet at the bottom.
The disposition and tendency to preserve what is established;opposition to change; the habit of mind; or conduct, of aconservative.
Closely united.

Of or pertaining to capric acid or its derivatives. Capricacid, C9H9.CO2H, Caprylic acid, C7H15.CO2H, and Caproic acid,C5H11.CO2H, are fatty acids occurring in small quantities in butter,cocoanut oil, etc., united with glycerin; they are colorless oils, orwhite crystalline solids, of an unpleasant odor like that of goats orsweat.

The liver of the common cod and allied species. Cod-liver oil,an oil obtained fron the liver of the codfish, and used extensivelyin medicine as a means of supplying the body with fat in cases ofmalnutrition.
Of or pertaining to the calendar or a calendar.
Convex on botConvex, a.
Existing at the same time with another.-- n.
Curling or tending to curl; having curls; full of ripples;crinkled.
A plant of various species, chiefly cruciferous. The leaveshave a moderately pungent taste, and are used as a salad andantiscorbutic.
That which causes coagulation. Hixley.
To bring to the same nature as something else; to adapt. [Obs.]Dr. J. Scott.
Having the form of coral; branching like coral.
The state of being collateral.
The state or condition of a catechumen or the time during whichone is a catechumen.
A muscle which contracts the skin of the forehead intowrinkles.
Of superior excellence; having qualities to be boasted of.[Colloq.]One of our crack speakers in the Commons. Dickens.
In clusters.
The illumination produced by a British standard candle at adistance of one foot; --used as a unit of illumination.
Made of cast iron. Hence, Fig.: like cast iron; hardy;unyielding.
A contraction of cousin. Shak.
At a small price; at a low value; in a common or inferiormanner.

Literally, leaf green; a green granular matter formed in thecells of the leaves (and other parts exposed to light) of plants, towhich they owe their green color, and through which all ordinaryassimilation of plant food takes place. Similar chlorophyll granuleshave been found in the tissues of the lower animals. [Written alsochlorophyl.]
Same as Conferee.
To tilt up one end of so as to make almost vertical; as, tocockbill the yards as a sign of mourning. To cockbill the anchor, tosuspend it from the cathead preparatory to letting it go. SeeAcockbill.
Work formed of clay in whole or in part, and baked; as, vases,urns, etc. Knight.
Containing a cell or cells.
In a compendious manner.Compendiously exressed by the word chaos. Bentley.
A compound of chloral and formic amide used to produce sleep.
In a contemptuous manner; with scorn or disdain; despitefully.The apostles and most eminent Christians were poor, and usedcontemptuously. Jer. Taylor.
A weight of one hundred pounds avoirdupois; -- called in manyparts of the United States a Hundredweight.
A girdle; particularly that of Aphrodite (or Venus) which gavethe wearer the power of exciting love.
One who carries hawks on a cadge.
The quality or condition of being cylindrical.
Of or pertaining to the Cetacea.

Pertaining to, or serving to constitute, the character; showingthe character, or distinctive qualities or traits, of a person orthing; peculiar; distinctive.Characteristic clearness of temper. Macaulay.
One who plays at cricket.
Pertaining to, or derived from, cyanic and uric acids.
A painter who cares for and studies light and shade rather thancolor.
A cylindrical roll of tobacco; as, a carotte of perique.
A weed with a sterm of many joints (Illecebrum verticillatum);also, the Polygonum aviculare or knotgrass.
resembling the chorion; as, the choroid plexuses of theventricles of the brain, and the choroid coat of the eyeball.-- n.
See Arcograph.
A favorite soup in Scotland, made from a capon highly seasoned,and boiled with leeks and prunes.
The science which treats of the cerebrum or brain.
Having a corolla or corollas; like a corolla.
Broken glass for remelting.
Bearing a club or a key.
A tuft of hair turned up or awry (usually over the forehead),as if licked by a cow.
Living or being at the same time; contemporary.
To write comments or notes upon; to make comments. [R.]Commentate upon it, and return it enriched. Lamb.
The center of mass, inertia, or gravity of a body or system ofbodies.
A city woman [R.]

A term applied to various columnlike parts; as, the columnella,or epipterygoid bone, in the skull of many lizards; the columella ofthe ear, the bony or cartilaginous rod connecting the tympanicmembrane with the internal ear.

The root of a plant (Jateorrhiza Calumba, and probably Cocculuspalmatus), indigenous in Mozambique. It has an unpleasantly bittertaste, and is used as a tonic and antiseptic. [Written also colombo,columbo, and calombo.] American calumba, the Frasera Carolinensis,also called American gentian. Its root has been used in medicine asbitter tonic in place of calumba.
An allowance in weighing. See Cloff.
A flat-floored fishing boat with a lug sail, and a drop rudderextending from two to four feet below the keel. It was originallyused on the stormy coast of Yorkshire, England.
Serving to consummate; completing. "The final, the consummativeprocedure of philosophy." Sir W. Hamilton.
Contending; disposed to contend. B. Jonson.
See Crossroad.
A large, deep, hollow place in the earth; a large cave.
In a cogent manner; forcibly; convincigly; conclusively. Locke.
To make or become white, or candied. [R.]
The coloring principle of turmeric, or curcuma root, extractedas an orange yellow crystalline substance, C14H14O4, with a greenfluorescence.
A combination of cardiograph and shygmograph.
The quality of being conceivable; conceivableness. Cudworth.
Pertaining to a bone of the shoulder girdle in most birds,reptiles, and amphibians, which is reduced to a process of thescapula in most mammals.
A somewhat stoun and thick fabric of cotton.
In a concrete manner.
A lever mounted on a tripod for lifting stones, leveling uprailroad ties, etc. Knight.
A vibrant or whirring noise such as that made by some insects,as the cockchafer, or by some birds, as the nightjar, the partridge,etc.
Inclosed in a cyst. See Cysted.
The saturation of defecated beet juice with carbonic acid gas.Knight.
Bells. [R.]
To encompass with a wall. Shak.
Of or pertaining to Canada.-- n.
Encountering, or coming together. Sir T. Browne.
A muskmelon of several varieties, having when mature, ayellowish skin, and flesh of a reddish orange color. [Written alsocantaleup.]

An order of insects having the anterior pair of wings (elytra)hard and horny, and serving as coverings for the posterior pair,which are membranous, and folded transversely under the others whennot in use. The mouth parts form two pairs of jaws (mandibles andmaxillæ) adapted for chewing. Most of the Coleoptera are known asbeetles and weevils.
In a captious manner.
A movable sideboard or buffet, on which plate and otherarticles of luxury were displayed on special ocasions. [Obs.]A way with the joint stools, remove the court-cupboard, look to theplate. Shak.
In or with the body; bodily; as, to be corporally present.Sharp.
Connection. See Connection.

A genus of euphorbiaceous plants belonging to tropicalcountries. Croton oil (Med.), a viscid, acrid, brownish yellow oilobtained from the seeds of Croton Tiglium, a small tree of the EastIndies. It is a most powerful drastic cathartic, and is usedexternally as a pustulant.
Resembling paper or parchment; of paper-like texture; papery.
Of or relating to hair; as, a crinitory covering. T. Hook.
See Note under Cyclops, 1.
A coalitionist.
Burnt sugar; a brown or black porous substance obtained byheating sugar. It is soluble in water, and is used for coloringspirits, gravies, etc.
A beetle of the genus Melolontha (esp. M. vulgaris) and alliedgenera; -- called also May bug, chafer, or dorbeetle.
A prefix signifying with, together, etc. See Com-.
A species of leopard (Cynælurus jubatus) tamed and used forhunting in India. The woolly cheetah of South Africa is C. laneus.[Written also chetah.]

Pertaining to, or obtained from, chlorine; -- said of thosecompounds of chlorine in which this element has a valence of five, orthe next to its highest; as, chloric acid, HClO3. Chloric ether(Chem.), ethylene dichloride. See Dutch liquid, under Dutch.
The act of aiming at, or directing in a line with, a fixedobject. [R.] Johnson.
A dish made of fresh fish or clams, biscuit, onions, etc.,stewed together.

A large class of Echinodermata, including numerous extinctfamilies and genera, but comparatively few living ones. Most of thefossil species, like some that are recent, were attached by a jointedstem. See Blastoidea, Cystoidea, Comatula.
A treatise on Christ; that department of theology which treatsof the personality, attributes, or life of Christ.
A time note, with a stem, having one fourth the value of asemibreve, one half that of a minim, and twice that of a quaver; aquarter note.
That which cores; an instrument for coring fruit; as, an applecorer.
A radical, C16H33, not yet isolated, but supposed to exist in aseries of compounds homologous with the ethyl compounds, and derivedfrom spermaceti.
Of or pertaining to a cæsura. Cæsural pause, a pause made at acæsura.

One of a breed of small or medium-sized spaniels kept forhunting or retrieving game or for household pets. They usually weighfrom eighteen to twenty-eight pounds. They have the head of fairlength, with square muzzle, the ears long and set low, the legs shortor of medium length, and the coat fine and silky, wavy but not curly.Various colors are bred, as black, liver, red, black and white, blackand tan, etc.
Becoming to a Christian.A virtuous and a Christianlike conclusion. Shak.
In a commercial manner.
Same as Isorcin.
To con, as a ship.

A rich aromatic oil, C15H24, extracted from oil of red cedar,and regarded as a polymeric terpene; also any one of a class ofsimilar substances, as the essential oils of cloves, cubebs, juniper,etc., of which cedrene proper is the type. [Written also cedren.]
Having columns.Troas and Ilion's columned citadel. Tennyson.
Discontented; dissatisfied. [R.] Shak.
The act or practice of eating human flesh by mankind. Hence;Murderous cruelty; barbarity. Berke.
A highly volatile liquid, condensed by cold and pressure fromthe first products of the distillation of petroleum; -- used forproducing low temperatures.
Of the nature of compunction; caused by conscience; attendedwith, or causing, compunction.That no compunctious vistings of nature Shake my fell purpose. Shak.
One who, or that which, convinces; one who wins over by proof.
Same as Kauri.
Of, pertaining to, or resembling, the family of plants of whichthe bindweed and the morning-glory are common examples.
Implying an attribute. See Connote. Connotative term, one whichdenotes a subject and implies an attribute. J. S. Mill.
An Indian pony. [Northw. U. S.]
A cobblestone. [Obs.]
Concupiscence.
A summary. [Obs.]
Of or pertaining to a cotyledon or cotyledons; having a seedlobe.
To form with the manners or character of a cockney. [Colloq.]
Quite full; choke-full.
The art of making edged tools or cutlery. [Obs.] Milton.
The thick, curdy precipitate formed by the coagulation ofalbuminous matter; any mass of coagulated matter, as a clot of bloot.
Fitted to be a companion; fit for good fellowship; agreeable;sociable. "Each companionable guest." Mallett. "Companionable wit."Clarendon.-- Com*pan"ion*a*ble*ness, n.-- Com*pan"ion*a*bly, adv.
Behavior or manners of a clown; clownery. [Obs.] B. Jonson.
A little cigar; a little fine tobacco rolled in paper forsmoking.
Rosin.
A churl; a boor; a peasant or countryman. [Obs.] Shak.
Any preternatural labor, in whiche the boly of the child liesacross the pelvis of the mother, so that the shoulder, arm, or trunkis the part first presented at the mouth of the uterus.
See Aurochloride.
A general name for coloring matter of plants other thanchlorophyll, especially that of petals.
A coroner. [Prov. Eng. or Scot.]
The quality of being courteous; politeness; courtesy.
The act of comprising or comprehending; a compendium orepitome.A comprisal . . . and sum of all wickedness. Barrow.
Compatibility; consistency; fitness; agreement.
Full to the brim; quite full; chock-full.
Having the power or form of a citation; as, letters citatory.
Of or pertaining to a goat; as, caprine gambols.
One who curses.
to chasten. [Obs.] Chaucer.
The negative electrode or pole of a voltaic battery. Faraday.
A joint or coadjutant bishop. Ayliffe.
To burn; to reduce to ashes by the action of fire, eitherdirectly or in an oven or retort; to incremate or incinerate; as, tocremate a corpse, instead of burying it.
An arthropod.
Starch made from Indian corn, esp. a fine white flour used forpuddings, etc.
One who conserves.
A corruption or corrupt state of art. [R.]
One skilled in or given to controversy; a controversialist.How unfriendly is the controvertist to the discernment of the critic!Campbell.
An order of ganoid fishes, having cycloid scales. The bowfin(Amia calva) is a living example.
Harlotry.
