A substance that may bee set on fire, or which is liable totake fire and burn.All such combustibles as are cheap enough for common use go under thename of fuel. Ure.
Capable of being contaminated.
Welsh.-- n.
Act of completing or perfecting; completion. [Obs.] Dryden.
A genus of hemipterous insects of which the bedbug is the bestknown example. See Bedbug.
To attempt to attract the notice, admiration, or love of; totreat with a show of tenderness or regard, with a view to deceive anddisappoint.You are coquetting a maid of honor. Swift.
Of or pertaining to cantharides or made of cantharides; as,cantharidal plaster.
A white wine made near Chablis, a town in France.
One who bandies words or is very argunentative. [Jocular] Shak.
Same as Cockaleekie.
A coronet or little crown of a seed; the downy tuft on seeds.See Pappus. Martyn.
Chandlery. [Obs.] "Torches from the chandry." B. Jonson.
Having short clauses or sentences; brief; concise.
Affected by contagion.
In a choleric manner; angrily.
To flog with a cowhide.
Containing calumny; slanderous. Montagu.
An agreement or understanding between the chief Europeanpowers, the United States, and Japan in 1900 to take only jointaction in the Chinese aspect of the Eastern Question.
Traffic; bargaining. [Obs.] Spenser.
A group of fishes, established by Agassiz, characterized byhaving scales with a pectinated margin, as in the perch. The group isnow generally regarded as artificial.
A hollow cylindrical piece carried by a revolving shaft, onwhich it may, however, revolve independently.
Same as Callet. [Obs.]A callat of boundless tongue. Shak.
Domination of the head in animal life as expressed in thephysical structure; localization of important organs or parts in ornear the head, in animal development. Dana.
That diagonal or lateral axis in a monoclinic crystal whichmakes an oblique angle witch the vertical axis. See Crystallization.-- a.
A kind of sweet cake cut in strips and curled or twisted, andfried crisp in boiling fat. [Also written kruller.]
The quality of being conclusive; decisiveness.

Condition in regard to worldly estate; state of property;situation; surroundings.When men are easy in their circumstances, they are naturally enemiesto innovations. Addison.Not a circumstance, of no account. [Colloq.] -- Under thecircumstances, taking all things into consideration.
A throw in which the wrestler turns his left side to hisopponent, places his left leg across both legs of his opponent, andpulls him forward over his hip; hence, an unexpected defeat orrepulse.
The hypothetical radical, (C6H5.C2H2)2C, of cinnamic compounds.[Formerly written also cinnamule.]
Perceiving together.
Anything made so as to form alternate squares lke those of acheckerboard.
Encompassed with a coma, or bushy appearance, like hair; hairy.
A doubling together or folding; a duplication. [R.]
Full of thought; thoughtful. [R.] Leigh Hunt.

A genus of leafles trees or shrubs, with drooping branchlets ofa rushlike appearance, mostly natives of Australia. Some of them arelarge, producing hard and heavy timber of excellent quality, calledbeefwood from its color.
One who is, or who has been, in the house of correction. [Obs.]Shak.
Brittle; crisp. Wright.
A jackdaw. [Prov. Eng.]
The state or quality of being childish; simplicity;harmlessness; weakness of intellect.
See Coplanar.
A pin of a large size, formerly used attaching a woman'sheaddress to a cork mold. [Obs.] Swift.
That crushes; overwhelming. "The blow must be quick andcrushing." Macualay.

Built of logs, etc., laid horizontally, with the endsdovetailed together at the corners, as in a log house; in marinework, often surrounding a central space filled with stones; as, acobwork dock or breakwater.
Pertaining to the Cyclops; Cyclopean.
In a crusty or surly manner; morosely.
An order of free-swimming marine worms, of which the genusSagitta is the type. They have groups of curved spines on each sideof the head.
A starfish.

Pertaining to, or obtained from, chromium; -- said of thecompounds of chromium in which it has its higher valence. Chromicacid, an acid, H2CrO4, analogous to sulphuric acid, not readilyobtained in the free state, but forming well known salts, many ofwhich are colored pigments, as chrome yellow, chrome red, etc.-- Chromic anhydride, a brilliant red crystalline substance, CrO3,regarded as the anhydride of chromic acid. It is one of the mostpowerful oxidizers known.
Marked or measured by crotchets; having musical notation.Harmar (1587).
A violent shock or agitation. [Obs.] Bp. Hall.
A species of raspberry (Rubus Chamæmerous) growing in thenorthern regions, and bearing edible, amber-colored fruit.
The state or quality of being corrigible; corrigibility.
Holding lime or other earthy salts; as, the calcigerous cellsof the teeth.
Having no chain; not restrained or fettered. "The chainlessmind." Byron.
The frontlet, or head armor, of a horse. [Written alsochampfrain and chamfrain.]
from Cleave.
The stamping of pigs of tin, by the proper officer, with thearms of the duchy of Cornwall.
See Urodela.
Existence at the same time with another; -- contemporaryexistence.Without the help, or so much as the coexistence, of any condition.Jer. Taylor.
The incision of a capsule, esp. of that of the crystallinelens, as in a cataract operation.
Of or pertaining to concubinage.
Bread cut in various forms, and fried lightly in butter or oil,to garnish hashes, etc.
A thin, loosewoven cotton cloth, such as is used in pressingcheese curds.
Tending to corrupt; full of corruption. [Obs.] "Corruptfulbribes." Spenser.
As much as a cup will hold.
Having a coarse grain or texture, as wood; hence, wanting inrefinement.
A few measures added beyond the natural termination of acomposition.
A coin. See Crusado.
One who has capital; one who has money for investment, or moneyinvested; esp. a person of large property, which is employed inbusiness.The expenditure of the capitalist. Burke.
The act of taming. [Obs.] Ray.

The right of taking a profit in the land of another, in commoneither with the owner or with other persons; -- so called from thecommunity of interest which arises between the claimant of the rightand the owner of the soil, or between the claimants and othercommoners entitled to the same right. Common appendant, a rightbelonging to the owners or occupiers of arable land to put commonablebeasts upon the waste land in the manor where they dwell.-- Common appurtenant, a similar right applying to lands in othermanors, or extending to other beasts, besides those which aregenerally commonable, as hogs.-- Common because of vicinage or neighborhood, the right of theinhabitants of each of two townships, lying contiguous to each other,which have usually intercommoned with one another, to let theirbeasts stray into the other's fields.-- Common in gross or at large, a common annexed to a man's person,being granted to him and his heirs by deed; or it may be claimed byprescriptive right, as by a parson of a church or other corporationsole. Blackstone.-- Common of estovers, the right of taking wood from another'sestate.-- Common of pasture, the right of feeding beasts on the land ofanother. Burill.-- Common of piscary, the right of fishing in waters belonging toanother.-- Common of turbary, the right of digging turf upon the ground ofanother.
A Latin preposition, sometimes used as a prefix in Englishwords, and signifying on this side.
See Camomile.
Tissue which is capable of being stained by dyes.
A kind of annelid larva with a circle of cilia around the head.
The play in whist where partners trump each a different suit,and lead to each other for that purpose; -- called also seesaw.
Reckoning; computation. [Obs.] Howell.
Probability.
A segment forming a side piece in the head of a cask. Knight.
A metronome. Box chronometer. See under Box.-- Pocket chronometer, a chronometer in the form of a large watch.-- To rate a chronometer. See Rate, v. t.

One of the anterior pair of mouth organs, terminated by apincherlike claw, in scorpions and allied Arachnida. They arehomologous with the falcers of spiders, and probably with themandibles of insects.
A river fish; the chub. Sir T. Browne.

An instrument which by means of a prism of a peculiar form, oran arrangement of mirrors, causes an apparent image of an externalobject or objects to appear as if projected upon a plane surface, asof paper or canvas, so that the outlines may conveniently traced. Itis generally used with the microscope.
Dreamland.
The nucleus of a cell; the germinal or active spot of acellule, through or in which cell development takes place.

Raised pieces of wood of iron around a hatchway, skylight, orother opening in the deck, to prevent water from running bellow; esp.the fore-and-aft pieces of a hatchway frame as distinguished from thetransverse head ledges. [Written also combings.]
Having the lower chap or jaw drooping, -- an indication ofhumiliation and dejection; crestfallen; discouraged. See Chopfallen.
Condemning; containing or imposing condemnation or censure; as,a condemnatory sentence or decree.
A ball of minced meat, fowl, rice, or other ingredients, highlyseasoned, and fried.
Impregnated with salts of iron; having a taste like iron; as,chalybeate springs.
One who corrupts; one who vitiates or taints; as, a corrupterof morals.
Mandatory; as, commandatory authority. [Obs.]
The state of being a cuckold; the practice of making cuckolds.
The public executioner at Rome, who executed persons of thelowest rank; hence, an executioner or hangman.
To go side by side with; hence, to pass by; to outrun and getbefore; as, a dog cotes a hare. [Obs.] Drayton.We coted them on the way, and hither are they coming. Shak.
A poisonous umbelliferous plant; in England, the Cicuta virosa;in the United States, the Cicuta maculata and the Archemora rigida.See Water hemlock.
A white crystalline sugar, metameric with glucose, obtainedfrom the coloring matter of saffron. [Written also crokose.]
Growing white. [Obs.]
One who has commited a crime; especially, one who is foundguilty by verdict, confession, or proof; a malefactor; a felon.
Resembling a crab; pertaining to the Cancroidea, one of thefamilies of crabs, including the genus Cancer.
See Chrysoprase. Rev. xxi. 20.
One who neglects, for two years, to perform the service bywhich he holds lands, so that he incurs the danger of the writ ofcessavit. See Cessavit. Cowell.
A cushionlike band of vascular tissue at the upper border ofthe wall of the hoof of the horse and allied animals. It takes animportant part in the secretion of the horny walls.
Of or pertaining to the cranium.
A mineral consisting principally of silicate of iron, andcrystallizing in hexagonal prisms with perfect basal cleavage; -- sonamed from the Swedish mineralogist Cronstedt.
A tooth of a wool comb. [Written also combrouch.]
A blain, sore, or inflammatory swelling, produced by exposureof the feet or hands to cold, and attended by itching, pain, andsometimes ulceration.
A leap in which the horse pulls up his hind legs toward hisbelly.
To lay down in a chart; to map; to delineate; as, to chart acoast.

Any species of the genus Cicada. They are large hemipterousinsects, with nearly transparent wings. The male makes a shrill soundby pecular organs in the under side of the abdomen, consisting of apair of stretched membranes, acted upon by powerful muscles. A notedAmerican species (C. septendecim) is called the seventeen yearlocust. Another common species is the dogday cicada.
A combining form meaning a grain, granular, granular cartilage,cartilaginous; as, the chondrocranium, the cartilaginous skull of thelower vertebrates and of embryos.
A bag in which rennet is kept.
Abounding in cobwebs, or any fine web; resembling a cobweb.
Pertaining to, derived from, or resembling, the dogwood (Cornusflorida).
Red poppy. See Cop-rose.
A word which expresses or suggests a cause.
f Catch.
Of or pertaining to the Herring family.
An obsolete name for the cornet-à-piston.

Pertaining to, or contained in, a cyst; esp., pertaining to, orcontained in, either the urinary bladder or the gall bladder. Cysticduct, the duct from the gall bladder which unites with the hepatic toform the common bile duct.-- Cystic worm (Zoöl.), a larval tape worm, as the cysticercus andechinococcus.
Folded together, or upon itself, with the fold runninglengthwise.
See Inclandescence.
See Book scorpion, under Book.
Of or pertaining to Circassia, in Asia.-- n.
Deserving of censure; blamable; culpable; reprehensible; as, acensurable person, or censurable conduct.-- Cen"sur*a*bleness, n.-- Cen"sur*a*bly, adv.
Pertaining to, or divided into, centuries or hundreds. [R.]Holland.
Of the same blood; related by birth. Sir T. Browne.

A kind of chair formerly used for punishing scolds, and alsodishonest tradesmen, by fastening them in it, usually in front oftheir doors, to be pelted and hooted at by the mob, but sometimes tobe taken to the water and ducked; -- called also a castigatory, atumbrel, and a trebuchet; and often, but not so correctly, a duckingstool. Sir. W. Scott.
Disturbed; troubled; solicitous; as, to be much concerned forthe safety of a friend.
Belonging to, or associated in, the same province. [Obs.] -- n.
See Connective.
The quality of being cleared.Imputed by his friends to the clearedness, by his foes to thesearedness, of his conscience. T. Fuller.

Of, pertaining to, or derived from, spermaceti. Cetylic alcohol(Chem.), a white, waxy, crystalline solid, obtained from spermaceti,and regarded as homologous with ordinary, or ethyl, alcohol; ethal; -- called also cetyl alcohol.
This act of defiling; defilement; pollution. Bp. Hall.
One who, or that which, combines.
A female champion. Fairfax.
The covering of a flower. See Flower.
Sky-colored; blue; azure. Cowper.Blue, blue, as if that sky let fallA flower from its cerulean wall. Bryant.
A subordinate portion or a subdivision of a sentence containinga subject and its predicate.
To shake; to agitate. [Obs.] Harvey.-- Con`quas*sa"tion, n. [Obs.]
Of or pertaining to constitutional complexion.A moral rather than a complexional timidity. Burke.
A genus of plants of many species, producing capsules or dryberries of various forms, which have an exceedingly pungent, bitingtaste, and when ground form the red of Cayenne pepper of commerce.
The act of staying or residing in a place. [Obs.] Bp. Hall.
To make celestial. [R.]
The quality of being contemptible; contemptibleness. Speed.
Of or pertaining to the Cycloganoidei.
One of the Catarrhina, a division of Quadrumana, including theOld World monkeys and apes which have the nostrils close together andturned downward. See Monkey.
Of or pertaining to Chile.
A woman who corrects.
The property or quality of being centrifugal. R. W. Emerson.
Scholarlike. [Obs.] Shak.
Of or pertaining to the Cimbri.-- n.
The act of commiting, or the state of being committed;commitment.
A large, white, South American duck, of the genus Cascoroba,resembling a swan.
The curate of a chapel; a chaplain. [Obs.] Fuller.
See Canon Bone.
An assessment equal to a fourth part of the revenue. [India] J.Mill.
A form of marriage among the Romans, in which an offering ofbread was made, in presence of the high priest and at least tenwitnesses.
A granular variety of pyroxene, green or white in color.
A certain surface of the third degree, described by a movingstraight line; -- used to illustrate the motions of a rigid body andalso the forces acting on the body.
One of the Gorgoniacea; -- so called because the fleshy partsurrounds a solid axis, like a bark.
Threatening or denouncing punishment; as, comminatory terms. B.Jonson.
Depressed; flattened. [Obs.]Though my nose be cammoused. B. Jonson
The state of being complete.
A young cod; also, a hake.
A colorless oily liquid, CCl3.CHO, of a pungent odor and harshtaste, obtained by the action of chlorine upon ordinary or ethylalcohol.
Holding or held by custom; as, customary tenants; customaryservice or estate.
A highly refined sugar in impalpable powder, esp. suited toconfectioners' uses.
Same as Phrenitis.
A dagger or short sword used by the Malays, commonly having aserpentine blade. [Written also crease and kris.]From a Malayan creese to a sailor's jackknife. Julian Hawthorne.
Canicula. Addison.
One of the seeds or large beans of a tropical vine (Entadascandens) used for making purses, scent bottles, etc.
A body of constituents, as the body of citizens or voters in arepresentative district.
Having the form of a cylinder.
A West Indian tree (Turpinia occidentalis) of the familyStaphyleaceæ.
like or related to snakes of the genus Coluber.

To confine in a coop; hence, to shut up or confine in a narrowcompass; to cramp; -- usually followed by up, sometimes by in.The Trojans coopet within their walls so long. Dryden.The contempt of all other knowledge . . . coops the understanding upwithin narrow bounds. Locke.
The quality of being confident.

A bitter American herb of the Bloodwort family, with the leavesall radical, and the small yellow or white flowers in a long spike(Aletris farinosa and A. aurea). Called sometimes star grass,blackroot, blazing star, and unicorn root.
See Contortion.
The Holy Spirit, -- reffering to his office of comfortingbelievers.But the Comforter, which is the Holy Ghost, whom the Father will sendin my name, he shall teach you all things. John xiv. 26.
Act of considering; consideration. [Obs.] Shak.
Full of change; mutable; inconstant; fickle; uncertain. Pope.His course had been changeful. Motley.-- Change"ful*ly, adv.-- Change"ful*ness, n.
One of the order of Coleoptera.
imp. of Come.
The center of a circle that circumscribes a triangle.
Covered with growing clover.Flocks thick nibbling through the clovered vale. Thomson.
Conversion into, or formation of, horn; a becoming like horn.
The thorax of an insect.
Entrails. [Obs.] [Written also chaudron, chauldron.] Shak.
An old spelling of Camphor.
A horn, or anything shaped like or resembling a horn.
St. Vitus's dance; a disease attended with convulsivetwitchings and other involuntary movements of the muscles or limbs.
A genus of hardy perennial flowering plants, of the orderScrophulariaceaæ., natives of North America; -- called alsosnakehead, turtlehead, shellflower, etc.

The cow blackbird (Molothrus ater), an American starling. Likethe European cuckoo, it builds no nest, but lays its eggs in thenests of other birds; -- so called because frequently associated withcattle.
A maker of, or writer for, a cyclopedia.
Ending in a point.
A picture obtained by the collodion process; a melanotype orambrotype.
Hazardous. [Obs.] Spenser.
See Carapace.
An order of fishes, including the sturgeons; -- so namedbecause the skeleton is cartilaginous.
The office of a commander.
An order of the Entomostraca.
Frequency. [Obs.] Bailey.

An ancient instrument of music with six strings; a kind ofviolin, being the oldest known stringed instrument played with a bow.[Written also croud, crowth, cruth, and crwth.]A lackey that . . . can warble upon a crowd a little. B. Jonson.
The office of chief justice.Jay selected the chief-justiceship as most in accordance with histastes. The Century.
The skull of an animal; especially, that part of the skull,either cartilaginous or bony, which immediately incloses the brain;the brain case or brainpan. See Skull.
The process of cohobating. Grew.
To make or to become catholic or Roman Catholic.
Glued together; united, as by some adhesive substance.

To rest upon as a troublesome or useless weight or load; to beburdensome or oppressive to; to hinder or embarrass in attaining anobject, to obstruct or occupy uselessly; to embarrass; to trouble.Why asks he what avails him not in fight, And would but cumber andretard his flight Dryden.Martha was cumbered about much serving. Luke x. 40.Cut it down; why cumbereth it the ground Luke xiii. 7.The multiplying variety of arguments, especially frivolous ones, . .. but cumbers the memory. Locke.
Cowardly; fainthearted; spiritless. "His craven heart." Shak.The poor craven bridegroom said never a word. Sir. W. Scott.In craven fear of the sarcasm of Dorset. Macualay.
Act of controverting; controversy. [Obs.] Hooker.
An alloy of gold, silver, and copper, of which an inferiorquality of jewerly is made.
The hundredth part of a stere, equal to .353 cubic feet.

Mineral coal charred, or depriver of its bitumen, sulphur, orother volatile matter by roasting in a kiln or oven, or bydistillation, as in gas works. It is lagerly used where [Written alsocoak.] Gas coke, the coke formed in gas retorts, as distinguishedfrom that made in ovens.
Belonging to, or of the nature of, a conspiration.
A genus of gigantic American Jurassic dinosaurs, having largecavities in the bodies of the dorsal vertebræ.

An important edible fish (Gadus morrhua), Taken in immensenumbers on the northern coasts of Europe and America. It isespecially abundant and large on the Grand Bank of Newfoundland. Itis salted and dried in large quantities.

A ceasing of discontinuance, as of action, whether termporaryor final; a stop; as, a cessation of the war.The temporary cessation of the papal iniquities. Motley.The day was yearly observed for a festival by cessation from labor.Sir J. Hayward.Cessation of arms (Mil.), an armistice, or truce, agreed to by thecommanders of armies, to give time for a capitulation, or for otherpurposes.
Secretly; in private; insidiously.
A large, long-legged South American bird (Dicholophuscristatus) which preys upon snakes, etc. See Seriema.
The hide or skin of a calf; or leather made of the skin.
Defensive armor used for the whole body and often for thehorse, also, esp. the linked mail or scale armor of some easternnations.
Unlearned. [Obs.] E. Waterhouse.
A passage cut through the glacis to facilitate sallies by thebesieged. Wilhelm.
To be entitled to anything; to deduce a right or title; to havea claim.We must know how the first ruler, from whom any one claims, came byhis authority. Locke.
Passable by carriages; that can be conveyed in carriages. [R.]Ruskin.
Joint inheritance.
A wheedling to delude; words used in cajoling; flattery."Infamous cajoleries." Evelyn.
See Chiefage. [Obs.]
The exterior portion of the earth, formerly universallysupposed to inclose a molten interior.
A growing together; the collection or mass formed byconcretion, or natural union. [Obs.]The concrement of a pebble or flint. Sir M. Hale
To make pointed or sharp.
A military officer who commanded a minor division of the Romanarmy; a captain of a century.A centurion of the hand called the Italian band. Acts x. 1.
Same as Clamjamphrie. [Scot.] Sir W. Scott.
A body of followers; -- applied to the lawless or brigand bandsin Italy and Sicily.
Funnel-shaped; -- applied particularly to a hollow muscleattached to the ball of the eye in many reptiles and mammals.
Pertaining to a rude kind of hieroglyphics, in which a thing isrepresented by its picture instead of by a symbol.

A composition (usually in symphonic form with three movements)in which one instrument (or two or three) stands out in bold reliefagainst the orchestra, or accompaniment, so as to display itsqualities or the performer's skill.
An upper loft; a garret; the highest room in a building.Dryden. Swift.
A quarter of a crown. [Obs.]The bunch of them were not worth a cardecu. Sir W. Scott.
A nun of the order of St.Clare.
Crinitory. Craig.
Of or belonging to Mercury's caduceus, or wand.
Divination by means of a crystal or other transparent body,especially a beryl.
Pertaining to, or resembling, the genus Coryphodon.
Same as Confiture. [Obs.]
Having sexual lust; libidinous; lustful; lecherous; salacious.Johnson.
An exaggerated estimate of the importance of giving full assentto any particular formula of the Christian faith. Shaff.
Beebread.
Having columns; as, columnated temples.
In a caustic manner.
See Chili.

A keeper; a custodian; a superintendent. [Obs.] Custosrotulorum (r Etym: [LL., keeper of the rolls] (Eng. Law), theprincipal justice of the peace in a county, who is also keeper of therolls and records of the sessions of the peace.
In a conventional manner.
To cause to give out a slight, sharp, tinkling, sound, as bystriking metallic or other sonorous bodies together.And let me the canakin clink. Shak.
One who sails round. W. Guthrie.
The dorsal ridge of a bird's bill.
Like a chub; plump, short, and thick. "Chubby faces." I.Taylor.
That may be compounded.
The common rape or cole.
See Cittern.
A green substance, supposed to be the cause of the green colorof the blood in some species of worms. Ray Lankester.
Without compunction.
See Larvalla.
Expressing a collection or aggregate of individuals, by asingular form; as, a collective name or noun, like assembly, army,juri, etc.
In a limited manner.
One who as has charge of the work of a companionship.
The practice or principles of cavaliers. Sir. W. Scott.
One who controverts; a controversial writer; acontroversialist.Some controverters in divinity are like swaggerers in a tavern. B.Jonson.
A chanter.
Open or spongy, as some porous bones.
The state of being central; tendency towards a center.Meantime there is a great centrality, a centripetence equal to thecentrifugence. R. W. Emerson.
The state of being contemplative; thoughtfulness.
A plant of Sierra Leone which yields a wholesome, creamy juice.
To agree. [bs.] Shak.

The act of condescending; voluntary descent from one's rank ordignity in intercourse with an inferior; courtesy toward inferiors.It forbids pride . . . and commands humility, modesty, andcondescension to others. Tillotson.Such a dignity and condescension . . . as are suitable to a superiornature. Addison.
A kind of sofa for two person. A tête-a-tête.
Having an impaired intellect; whimsical; crazy. Pope.
A small bird, the blackcap titmouse (Parus atricapillus), ofNorth America; -- named from its note.
Made of, or having the apperance of, calico; -- often appliedto an animal, as a horse or cat, on whose body are large patches of acolor strikingly different from its main color. [Colloq. U. S.]
To mark or pronounce with a circumflex. Walker.
Of or pertaining to critics or criticism; critical. [Obs.]"Critic learning." Pope.
Cheerful or mirthful, as after good eating or drinking; also,wanton. [Scot. & Prov. Eng.]

The act or business of transporting from one place to another.Carrying place, a carry; a portage.-- Carrying trade, the business of transporting goods, etc., fromone place or country to another by water or land; freighting.We are rivals with them in . . . the carrying trade. Jay.
The framework or skeleton upon which a regiment is to beformed; the officers of a regiment forming the staff. [Written alsocader.]
Having crannies, chinks, or fissures; as, a crannied wall.Tennyson.

A peculiar bitter orange-brown substance, with strong,penetrating odor, found in two sacs between the anus and externalgenitals of the beaver; castor; -- used in medicine as anantispasmodic, and by perfumers.
The stonecrop (Sedum acre).
The place where provisions are deposited. [Obs.]
To ease the body by stool; to go to stool. Pope.
The quality or state of being capable; capability;adequateness; competency.
Lamed; lame; disabled; impeded. "The crippled crone."Longfellow.
An ecclesiastical body or judicat
A carack. [Obs.] Chaucer.
The occupation or work of a carpenter; the act of workingintimber; carpentry.
A mile traveled by a single car, taken as a unit ofcomputation, as in computing the average travel of each car of asystem during a given period.
An advocate or defender of convocation.
To have or indulge inordinate desire.Which [money] while some coveted after, they have erred from thefaith. 1 Tim. vi. 10.
See 4th Carol.
In a charitable manner.
See Custodian.
One of the jointed antenniform appendage of the posteriorsomites of cartain insects. Packard.
One who confesses his sins and faults. [Obs.]
In the form of a cross; across; transversely. Longfellow.
In a canny manner. [N. of Eng. & Scot.]
Pertaining to, or secreting, cerumen; as, the ceruminousglands.
With the corner in front; diagonally; not square.
Capable of being poured or spread round. "Circumfusile gold."Pope.
A one-seeded, one-called, indehiscent fruit; an achene with thecalyx tube adherent.
A large genus of plants belonging to the Sedge family, andincluding the species called galingale, several bulrushes, and theEgyptian papyrus.
In the manner of crystallography.
Crustaceology.
A concretion or coagulation; esp. a soft, slimy, coagulatedmass, as of blood; a coagulum. "Clots of pory gore." Addison.Doth bake the egg into clots as if it began to poach. Bacon.
Stoppage; cessation (of labor).
Serving to coagulate; produced by coagulation; as, coagulatoryeffects. Boyle.
See Cross, n. [Obs.] Chaucer.
The act or motion of crawling;

The principles of a political party in England (1838-48), whichcontended for universal suffrage, the vote by ballot, annualparliaments, equal electoral districts, and other radical reforms, asset forth in a document called the People's Charter.
Consecrated; devoted; dedicated; sacred.They were assembled in that consecrate place. Bacon.
Satiety. [Obs.] Shak.
A warp having more than two threads passing through each dentor split of the reed.
Congenitally united; growing from one base, or united at theirbases; united into one body; as, connate leaves or athers. SeeIllust. of Connate-perfoliate.
One who censures. Sha.

A yellow coal-tar dyestuff which probably consists chiefly ofrosolic acid. See Aurin, and Rosolic acid under Rosolic. Redcorallin, a red dyestuff which is obtained by treating aurin orrosolic acid with ammonia; -- called also pæonin.-- Yellow corallin. See Aurin.
Having a clubfoot.
Something used to conceal infamy. [Obs.] Dryden.
Having no culture.
Having the tail cropped.
A female citizen. [R.]
Pertaining to Catiline, the Roman conspirator; resemblingCatiline's conspiracy.

A plan of distributing surplus by giving to each policy theexcess of premiums and interest earned thereon over the expenses ofmanagement, cost of insurance, and the policy value at the date ofcomputation. This excess is called the contribution of the policy.
one who contradicts. Swift.
Like a fish of the genus Cottus.-- n.
That part of a bird, or the feathers, surrounding the cloacalopening; the under tail coverts.
An artificial red dye from which the Congo group received itsname. It is also widely used either in aqueous solution or as testpaper (Congo paper) for the detection of free acid, which turns itblue.

The name of a group of minerals, usually of a green color andmicaceous to granular in structure. They are hydrous silicates ofalumina, iron, and magnesia. Chlorite slate, a schistose or slatyrock consisting of alumina, iron, and magnesia.
Any one of the spaces in the Milky Way which are very black,owing to the nearly complete absence of stars; esp., the large spacenear the Southern Cross sometimes called the Black Magellanic Cloud.
The bones of the cranium; more especially, the bones of thedomelike upper portion.
A blank paper, with a person's signature, etc., at the bottom,given to another person, with permission to superscribe whatconditions he pleases. Hence: Unconditional terms; unlimitedauthority.
The act of circumnavigating, or sailing round. Arbuthnot.
A sort of bar or movable nut, attached to the finger board of aguitar or other  fretted instrument for the purpose of raisinguniformly the pitch of all the strings.
Of or pertaining to chyme.
A state of permanent rigidity or contraction of the muscles,generally of the flexor muscles.
A salt of caproic acid.
A portable bag for travelers; -- so called because originallymade of carpet.
A sugarlike body obtained by the decomposition of thenitrogenous non-phosphorized principles of the brain.

A clog, or patten, having a very thick sole, or in some casesraised upon a stilt to a height of a foot or more. [Variously speltchioppine, chopin, etc.]Your ladyship is nearer to heaven than when I saw you last, by thealtitude of a chopine. Shak.
In a curt manner.
A description of apparent spots on the disk of the sun, or onplanets.
A stick, cane, or cudgel, made of the wood of the carb tree.
A Cretan practice; iying; a falsehood.
A coverlet for a bed, -- originally stitched or woven insquares or figures.On which a tissue counterpane was cast. Drayton.
One of the small chips or slices into which beets are cut insugar making.

To call to remembrance by a special act or observance; tocelebrate with honor and solemnity; to honor, as a person or event,by some act of respect of affection, intended to preserve theremembrance of the person or event; as, to commemorate the sufferingsand dying love of our Savior by the sacrament of the Lord's Supper;to commemorate the Declaration of Independence by the observance ofthe Fourth of July.We are called upon to commemorate a revolution. Atterbury.
Cheering; enlivening.He takes his chirping pint, he cracks his jokes. Pope.
The state of being curved.
A cunette. 3. (Spectrometry) (Analytical chemistry)
A tribe of perching birds, including those which have a strongconical bill, as the finches.
Ordinarily residing; inhabiting.All freeholders within the precinct . . . and all persons commoranttherein. Blackstone.
A division of Mollusca having slender, cirriform appendagesnear the mouth; the Scaphopoda.
The act of accusing; accusation; charge; complaint.The criminations and recriminations of the adverse parties. Macaulay.
A gastropod shell belonging to the family Cerithiïdæ; -- socalled from its hornlike form.
A condition of endemic or inherited idiocy, accompanied byphysical degeneracy and deformity (usually with goiter), frequent incertain mountain valleys, esp. of the Alps.
The refrain of a famous song of the French Revolution.
A kind of griddlecake of unleavened bread, used among thenatives of India. [Anglo-Indian]
See Crassament.
A kind of spider monkey (Ateles chameck), having the thumbsrudimentary and without a nail.
The office of commissioner. Sir W. Scott.
A numerous and widely distributed genus of perennial herbaceousplants of the order Cypreaceæ; the sedges.
Could; was able; knew or known; understood. [Obs.]Above all other one Daniel He loveth, for he couth well Divine, thatnone other couth; To him were all thing couth, As he had it of God'sgrace. Gower.
n antagonist; a contestant. [Obs.]In all notable changes and revolutions the contendents have beenstill made a prey to the third party. L'Estrange.
The act or habit of talking idly or rapidly, or of makinginarticulate sounds; the sounds so made; noise made by the collisionof the teeth; chatter.
Of, pertaining to, or resembling, a family of plants of whichthe cucumber, melon, and gourd are common examples.
A small round dish with a handle, usually of porcelain.

Of courtlike manners; pertaining to, or exxpressive of,courtesy; characterized by courtesy; civil; obliging; well bred;polite; affable; complaisant.A patient and courteous bearing. Prescott.His behavior toward his people is grave and courteous. Fuller.
The top part of a flask or mold; the outer part of a loam mold.Knight. De Colange.
A cloth smeared with melted wax, or with some gummy orglutinous matter.Linen, besmeared with gums, in manner of cerecloth. Bacon.

An animal of various species of the genera Felis and Lynx. Thedomestic cat is Felis domestica. The European wild cat (Felis catus)is much larger than the domestic cat. In the United States the namewild cat is commonly applied to the bay lynx (Lynx rufus) See Wildcat, and Tiger cat.
The act of turning, rolling, or whirling round.A certain turbulent and irregular circumgyration. Holland.
The quality, or practice, of being ceremonious.
A small chick or chicken.
Made convex; protuberant in a spherical form. Sir T. Browne.
Millenarian. "The obstruction offered by the chiliasticerrors." J. A. Alexander.
The constitution, or fundamental law, of the French monarchy,as established on the restoration of Louis XVIII., in 1814.
A kind of molding. See Cyma.
A maker of catalogues; esp. one skilled in the making ofcatalogues.
One of the moons or satellites of the planet Jupiter. [Obs.]Derham.
A small breeze or horsefly. [North of Eng. & Scot.] Jamieson.
To shorten by omitting a letter or letters or by reducing twoor more vowels or syllables to one.

State of being commodious; suitableness for its purpose;convience; roominess.Of cities, the greatness and riches increase according to thecommodiousness of their situation. Sir W. Temple.The commodiousness of the harbor. Johnson.
A female contestant. [R.]
One who conforms; one who complies with established forms ordoctrines.
Same as Choriambus.
Having or indicating a reciprocal relation.Father and son, prince and subject, stranger and citizen, arecorrelative terms. Hume.
Any one of several umbelliferous plants, of the genera Myrrhis,Osmorrhiza, etc.
To use cabalistic language. [R] Dr. H. More.
Conceitedly. [R.]
Furnished with protuberant or hardened spots.
Of or pertaining to the Crustacea; crustaceous.-- n.
An inflammable, volatile, oily, liquid hydrocarbon, obtained bythe destructive distillation of caoutchouc.
Pertaining to, or formed by, concretion or aggregation;producing or containing concretions.
See Cantle.
A hornlike tuft of feathers on the head of some birds.
Constitutionally. [R.]Though corruptible, not complexionally vicious. Burke.
One who delays or lingers. [R.]
The daughter of Saturn and Ops or Rhea, the goddess of corn andtillage.
To bear, or be susceptible of, being calvered; as, grayling'sflesh will calver. Catton.
A genus of naked pteropods. One species (Clione papilonacea),abundant in the Arctic Ocean, constitutes a part of the food of theGreenland whale. It is sometimes incorrectly called Clio.
The act or process of gathering into a mass; the state of beingthus collected; collection; accumulation; that which isconglomerated; a mixed mass. Bacon.
Having no curb or restraint.
One who labors jointly with others to promote the same end."Coöperators with the truth." Boyle.
A prison; a jail. [Local, U. S.]
A water clock; a contrivance for measuring time by thegraduated flow of a liquid, as of water, through a small aperture.See Illust. in Appendix.
One who consoles or comforts. Johnson.
A counter account. See Control. [Obs.] Bacon.
Same as Checker.
Self-satisfied; contented; kindly; as, a complacent temper; acomplacent smile.They look up with a sort of complacent awe . . . to kings. Burke.
One of the Cirripedia.
A point where one branch of a curve crosses another branch. SeeDouble point, under Double, a.
The reading of the lines of a newspaper directly across thepage, instead of down the columns, thus producing a ludicrouscombination of ideas.
A gambling game with dice. [Local, U.S.]
A corpuscle. [Obs.]

Pertaining to, or indicating, a crisis, turning point, orspecially important juncture; important as regards consequences;hence, of doubtful issue; attended with risk; dangerous; as, thecritical stage of a fever; a critical situation.Our circumstances are indeed critical. Burke.The small moment, the exact point, the critical minute, on whichevery good work so much depends. South.Critical angle (Optics), that angle of incidence of a luminous ray atwhich it is wholly reflected, and no portion of it transmitted. Thesine of this angle is the reciprocal of the refractive index of themedium.-- Critical philosophy, the metaphysical system of Kant; -- socalled from his most important work, the "Critique of Pure Reason." -- Critical point (Physics), a certain temperature, different fordifferent gases, but always the same for each gas, regarded as thelimit above which no amount of pressure can produce condensation to aliquid.
Collusive.
To beat down the price of; to lessen the value of; todepreciate. Pope.My proffered love has cheapened me. Dryden.
Fictitious or imaginary; unreal; as, a commentitious system ofreligion. [Obs.] Warburton.

A substance obtained from the residues of the distillation ofpetroleum, essentially the same as vaseline, but of somewhat stifferconsistency, and consisting of a mixture of the higher paraffines; akind of petroleum jelly.
A genus of small beetles of many species. They and their larv¦eed on aphids or plant lice, and hence are of great benefit to man.Also called ladybirds and ladybugs.
In a clumsy manner; awkwardly; as, to walk clumsily.

In American colleges and universities, a day of thecommencement season on which the senior class celebrates thecompletion of its course by exercises conducted by the members, suchas the reading of the class histories and poem, the delivery of theclass oration, the planting of the class ivy, etc.
The great band commissural fibers which unites the two cerebralhemispheres. See corpus callosum, under Carpus.
Collapse. [R.] Johnson.
Of the same form; similar in import; conformable.  Bacon.
A measure of length; the distance from the elbow to the end ofthe middle finger; a cubit.

A cap of maintenance. See Maintenance. Chapeau bras ( Etym: [F.chapeau hat + bras arm], a hat so made that it can be compressed andcarried under the arm without injury. Such hats were particularlyworn on dress occasions by gentlemen in the 18th century. A chapeaubras is now worn in the United States army by general and staffofficers.
A small war club, esp. of savages; -- so called because of itssupposed use in crushing the skull.
Pertaining to, or resembling, an order of plants like thepalms, but having exogenous wood. The sago palm is an example.
Cylindrical, or approaching a cylindrical form.
By forgery; falsely.
An instrument for measuring the depth of the color of anything,especially of a liquid, by comparison with a standard liquid.
A large South American monkey (Lagothrix Humboldtii), withprehensile tail.
Lewdness. [Obs.] Rom. xiii. 13.
One who dwells with another, or in the same place or country.No small number of the Danes became peaceable cohabitants with theSaxons in England. Sir W. Raleigh.

The act of consummating, or the state of being consummated;completed; completion; perfection; termination; end (as of the worldor of life)."Tis a consummation Devoutly to be wished. Shak.From its original to its consummation. Addison.Quiet consummation have, And renownShak.Consummation of marrige, completion of the connubial relation byactual cohabition.
The west coast, or a portion of the west coast, of the Bay ofBengal. Coromandel gooseberry. See Carambola.-- Coromandel wood, Calamander wood.
A pustular eruptive disease of the cow, which, whencommunicated to the human system, as by vaccination, protects fromthe smallpox; vaccinia; -- called also kinepox, cowpock, andkinepock. Dunglison.
A term sometimes applied to the decomposition of organicsubstance into more simple bodies, by the use of chemical agentsalone. Thudichum.
See Cinnamic.
The act of bending or crooking.
Making hot; producing or communicating heat.
Capable of being continued [R.]
A little cable less than ten inches in circumference.
Capable of being criticised.
To embody; to form into a body. [Obs.] Boyle.
Having the lower chop or jaw depressed; hence, crestfallen;dejected; dispirited;downcast. See Chapfallen.
A kind of steward or agent. [China] S. W. Williams
The indian cane, a plant of the Palm family. It furnishes thecommon rattan. See Rattan, and Dragon's blood.
A game for two, played with 40 cards, in which each playertries to form three or four of a kind or sequences.
Agreement; accord. Bentley.

To destroy, as by decomposition, dissipation, waste, or fire;to use up; to expend; to waste; to burn up; to eat up; to devour.If he were putting to my house the brand That shall consume it. Shak.Lay up for yourselves treasures in heaven, where neither moth norrust doth consume. Matt. vi. 20 (Rev. Ver. ).Let me alone . . . that I may consume them. Ex. xxxii. 10.
Capable of being carried.
To comprehend; to include.Comprise much matter in few words. Hocker.Friendship does two souls in one comprise. Roscommon.
Pertaining to cholesterin, or obtained from it; as, cholestericacid. Ure.
Same as Cellarer.

A kind of knitting done by means of a hooked needle, withworsted, silk, or cotton; crochet work. Commonly used adjectively.Crochet hook, Crochet needle, a small hook, or a hooked needle (oftenof bone), used in crochet work.
A house on deck, where the cooking is done; -- commonly calledthe galley.
Cerulean. [Obs.] Dr. H. More.
A special branch, resembling a leaf, as in the apparent foliageof the broom (Ruscus) and of the common cultivated smilax(Myrsiphillum).
The process by which anything becomes of the color of a lemon;esp., in alchemy, the state of perfection in the philosopher's stoneindicated by its assuming a deep yellow color. Thynne.
See Couple-close.
Of or pertaining to a crusade; as, a crusading spirit.
The measurement of the heads of living persons. --Ceph`a*lo*met"ric (#),a.
The quality of being creditable.
A thin portion of the rind of a cheese.-- a.
To form into a cue; to braid; to twist.
A photographic picture obtained by the use of a cyanide.
A short, thick piece of anything. [Colloq. U. S. & Prov. Eng.]
Of or pertaining to cosmology.
The whole body of the Jewish people; -- called alsoCongregation of the Lord.It is a sin offering for the congregation. Lev. iv. 21.
A flanged wheel of a railway car or truck.
To engage in a crusade; to attack in a zealous or hot-headedmanner. "Cease crusading against sense." M. Green.

A yellowish beetle (Doryphora decemlineata), with tenlongitudinal, black, dorsal stripes. It has migrated eastwards fromits original habitat in Colorado, and is very destructive to thepotato plant; -- called also potato beetle and potato bug. See Potatobeetle.

A group of acalephs of which Lucernaria is the type. The bodyis cup-shaped with eight marginal lobes bearing clavate tentacles. Anaboral sucker serves for attachment. The interior is divided intofour large compartments. See Lucernarida.
To compensate. [Obs.] Bacon.
Cowardice. [Obs.] Shak.
Fated or decreed with something else. [R.] A. Tucker.
Curly; curled. [Obs.]

A plan proposed to the Pope in 1891 by P. P. Cahensly, a memberof the German parliament, to divide the foreign-born population ofthe United States, for ecclesiastical purposes, according to Europeannationalities, and to appoint bishops and priests of like race andspeaking the same language as the majority of the members of adiocese or congregation. This plan was successfully opposed by theAmerican party in the Church.
Without doubt or question; unquestionably.
To force (a person) to do something, or give up something, byintimidation; to coerce. Wharton.
Mutual agreement. [R.]
Consonance with the doctrines of Christianity. [Obs.] Hammond.
resembling coral; coralloid. Sir T. browne.
The state of being chalky.
Same as Chaparajos. [Sp. Amer.]
A small metal ring; a small collar fastened on an arbor; as,the collet on the balance arbor of a watch; a small socket on a stem,for holding a drill.
Matter; affair.
A person cinnected through cognation.
A relative from the country visiting the city and unfamiliarwith city manners and sights.
The god of love, son of Venus; usually represented as a naked,winged boy with bow and arrow.Pretty dimpled boys, like smiling cupids. Shak.
The leading British funded government security.
The tenth avatar or incarnation of the god Vishnu. [Writtenalso Kali.]
A small species of antelope (Rupicapra tragus), living on theloftiest mountain ridges of Europe, as the Alps, Pyrenees, etc. Itpossesses remarkable agility, and is a favorite object of chase.

A genus of American and East Indian trees, of which the bestknow species are the Catalpa bignonioides, a large, ornamental NorthAmerican tree, with spotted white flowers and long cylindrical pods,and the C. speciosa, of the Mississipi valley; -- called also Indianbean.
To give notice of danger to; to warn; to exhort [one] to takeheed.You cautioned me against their charms. Swift.
One who makes or deals in costumes, as for theaters, fancyballs, etc.
Equally extensive; having as, consciousness and knowledge arecoextensive. Sir W. Hamilton.-- Co`ex*ten"sive*ly, adv.-- Co`ex*ten"sive*ness, n.
A coming or bringing together, as in a public meeting, in adispute, in the act of comparing, or in sexual intercourse. [R.] Jer.Taylor.
In a convertible manner.

Expressing a degree greater or less than the positive degree ofthe quality denoted by an adjective or adverb. The comparative degreeis formed from the positive by the use of -er, more, or less; as,brighter, more bright, or less bright. Comparative sciences, thosewhich are based on a comprehensive comparison of the range of objectsor facts in any branch or department, and which aim to study out andtreat of the fundamental laws or systems of relation pervading them;as, comparative anatomy, comparative physiology, comparativephilology.
A king of parrot, of a beautiful green color, found in thePhilippine Islands.
Churchyard. [Obs.] Chaucer.
Having the power to create; exerting the act of creation."Creative talent." W. Irving.The creative force exists in the germ. Whewell.
A dingy blue, or grayish black, variety of spinel. It is alsocalled pleonaste. [Written also ceylonite.]
Merely imaginary; fanciful; fantastic; wildly or vainlyconceived; having, or capable of having, no existence except inthought; as, chimerical projects.
Burning together in a common flame. [R.] "The conflagrantmass."  Milton.
Resembling glue or jelly; characterized by a jellylikeappearance; gelatinous; as, colloid tumors.

A general name for the several coloring matters, red, green,yellow, etc., present in the inner segments in the cones of theretina, held in solution by fats, and slowly decolorized by light;distinct from the photochemical pigments of the rods of the retina.
A gear by means of which the speed of machinery or of a vehiclemay be changed while that of the propelling engine or motor remainsconstant; -- called also change-speed gear.
Belonging to cosmogony. B. Powell. Gladstone.
An officer who ranks next below a captain, -- ranking with alieutenant colonel in the army.
A collection of persons employed to applaud at a theatricalexhibition.
The person who weighs and proportions the materials to be madeinto glass, and who works and tempers them.
A marine fish of the family Chætodontidæ. The chætodonts havebroad, compressed bodies, and usually bright colors.
A chief judge in the Turkish empire, so named originallybecause his jurisdiction extended to the cases of soldiers, who arenow tried only by their own officers.
Punitive in order to amendment; corrective.
Of or relating to a hundred years.-- n.
The lowest group of vertebrates; -- so called from the cirriaround the mouth; the Leptocardia. See Amphioxus.
A layer of tiles forming a corona for a wall.
The cerebellum. Derham.

A dry, brown, astringent extract, obtained by decoction andevaporation from the Acacia catechu, and several other plants growingin India. It contains a large portion of tannin or tannic acid, andis used in medicine and in the arts. It is also known by the namesterra japonica, cutch, gambier, etc. Ure. Dunglison.

Common sensation or general sensibility, as distinguished fromthe special sensations which are located in, or ascribed to, separateorgans, as the eye and ear. It is supposed to depend on theganglionic system.
The quality of being cogent; power of compelling conviction;conclusiveness; force.An antecedent argument of extreme cogency. J. H. Newman.
Act or process of administering comfort. [Obs.]The gentle comfortment and entertainment of the said embassador.Hakluyt.
A plowland; as much land as one team can plow in a year and aday; -- by some said to be about 100 acres. Burrill.

The act of preserving, guarding, or protecting; the keeping (ofa thing) in a safe or entire state; preservation.A step necessary for the conservation of Protestantism. Hallam.A state without the means of some change is without the means of itsconservation. Burke.Conservation of areas (Astron.), the principle that the radius vectordrawn from a planet to the sun sweeps over equal areas in equaltimes.-- Conservation of energy, or Conservation of force (Mech.), theprinciple that the total energy of any material system is a quantitywhich can neither be increased nor diminished by any action betweenthe parts of the system, though it may be transformed into any of theforms of which energy is susceptible. Clerk Maxwell.
An empty tomb or a monument erected in honor of a person who isburied elsewhere. Dryden.A cenotaph in Westminster Abbey. Macaulay.
A genus of univale shells, abundant in tropical seas. Somespecies, as Columbella mercatoria, were formerly used as shell money.
Capable of being preserved from decay or injury.
Capability of being cheated.
A genus of plants, of the order Araceæ.
A member of the denomination called Christians or Disciples ofChrist. They themselves repudiate the term Campbellite as a nickname.See Christian, 3.
See Coehorn.
A small cleft, rent, or fissure, of greater length thanbreadth; a gap or crack; as, the chinks of wall.Through one cloudless chink, in a black, stormy sky. Shines out thedewy morning star. Macaulay.
Varicose. Cirsoid aneurism, a disease of an artery in which itbecomes dilated and elongated, like a varicose vein.
An established law. [Obs.] T. Preston.
A short, comprehensive prayer, adapted to a particular day,occasion, or condition, and forming part of a liturgy.The noble poem on the massacres of Piedmont is strictly a collect inverse. Macaulay.
Of or pertaining to the United States, or to America.
Capable of communicating color or tint to other bodies.
Free from ceremonial defilement.
The act of choosing; selection; choice. [Obs.]The first election and coöptation of a friend. Howell.
Crown. [Obs.] Chaucer.
In a cringing manner.
In the shape or form of, a hair, or of hairs.
A suit or action in court; any legal process by which a partyendeavors to obtain his claim, or what he regards as his right; case;ground of action.
Of or pertaining to a consul; performing the duties of aconsul; as, consular power; consular dignity; consular officers.
Timid; fearful; cowardly. Bunyan.
Pertaining to, or deduced from, construction or interpretation.
The great gray crane of India (Grus cinerea). [Also writtencoolen and cullum.]
The science of finance or public revenue.
See Bilirubin.
See Comfit, n.
State, quality, or business of a clerk.
Anything done deceitfully, and which could not be properlydesignated by any special name, whether belonging to contracts ornot. Burrill.
Pertaining to the bone, or cartilage, below the epibranchial ina branchial arch.-- n.
The art or occupation of making the finer articles of householdfurniture.

The change of a penalty or punishment by the pardoning power ofthe State; as, the commutation of a sentence of death to banishmentor imprisonment.Suits are allowable in the spiritual courts for money agreed to begiven as a commutation for penance. Blackstone.
See Choltry.
A map showing geographically, by shades or curves, statisticsof various kinds; a statistical map.
In a corrupt manner; by means of corruption or corruptinginfluences; wronfully.
One who compromises.
Captious disposition or manner.

An order of Crustacea including the barnacles. When adult, theyhave a calcareous shell composed of several pieces. From the openingof the shell the animal throws out a group of curved legs, lookinglike a delicate curl, whence the name of the group. See Anatifa.
pl. of Child.
A roundabout or indirect way. [Jocular] Goldsmith.
With a curl, or curls.
See Caryopsis.
Snapdragon.
One who, or that which, civilizes or tends to civilize.
Of or pertaining to a commissure.
A genus of fossil corals, common in the lower Silurianlimestones.
A kind of haircloth undergarment. Southey.
A distinctive mark; a character; a letter or sign. [Obs.] SeeCharacter.In all his dressings, characts, titles, forms. Shak.
In South Africa, a military body or command; also, sometimes,an expedition or raid; as, a commando of a hundred Boers.
A machine that separates the kernels of corn from the cob.
A member of a secret political association in Italy, organizedin the early part of the nineteenth centry for the purpose ofchanging the government into a republic.
The act or process of removing the dress of ore and of reducingthe valuable part to smaller compass, as by currents of air or water.
See Capel.
In a mass, or body; in a collected state; in the aggregate;unitedly.
A salt or carbonic acid, as in limestone, some forms of leadore, etc.

Of, pertaining to, or resembling, a corpse, or the changesproduced by death; cadaverous; as, cadaveric rigidity. Dunglison.Cadaveric alkaloid, an alkaloid generated by the processes ofdecomposition in dead animal bodies, and thought by some to be thecause of the poisonous effects produced by the bodies. See Ptomaine.
Consisting of, or accompanied by, immoderate laughter.Cachinnatory buzzes of approval. Carlyle.
Empty oyster shells and other substances laid down on oystergrounds to furnish points for the attachment of the spawn of theoyster. [Also written cutch.]
Eaten out by canker, or as by canker. [Obs.]
A genus of leguminous plants (herbs, shrubs, or trees) of manyspecies, most of which have purgative qualities. The leaves ofseveral species furnish the senna used in medicine.
The state of being colored, as in the case of images formed bya lens.
See Cuming.
The state of being concentric.
To bring forth; -- said of animals, or in contempt, of persons."Cubb'd in a cabin." Dryden.
To sprout, as seed in the ground; to vegetate. Chalmers.

Of, pertaining to, or derived from, chromium, when this elementhas a valence lower than that in chromic compounds. Chromous acid, abluish gray powder, CrO.OH, of weak acid properties and regard as anacid.
The act of making compact, or the state of being compact.[Obs.] Bacon.
Same as prefix Counter-. [Obs.]
One who practices calcography.
The woods, underbrush, etc., which shelter and conceal game;covert; as, to beat a cover; to ride to cover.
Conducted with secrecy; withdrawn from public notice, usuallyfor an evil purpose; kept secret; hidden; private; underhand; as, aclandestine marriage. Locke.
Pertaining to the Curculionideæ, or weevil tribe.
One who canvasses.
A white crystalline nitrogenous substance, found in extract ofmeat, and related to xanthin.
A genus of neuropterous insects. See Lacewing.
Of or pertaining to the Copts.-- n.
Capable of being commanded.

Of or pertaining to a choragus. Choragic monument, a buildingor column built by a victorious choragus for the reception andexhibition of the tripod which he received as a prize. Those ofLysicrates and Thrasyllus are still to be seen at Athens.
Containing or producing coral.
Participation in a common nature or character. [R.]Connature was defined as likeness in kind between either two changesin consciousness, or two states of consciousness. H. Spencer.
A miraculously given power, as of healing, speaking foreignlanguages without instruction, etc., attributed to some of the earlyChristians.

A small, low pillar, square or round, commonly having aninscription, used by the ancients for various purposes, as forindicating the distances of places, for a landmark, for sepulchralinscriptions, etc. Gwilt.
A roof having a double slope, or composed, on each side, of twoparts which have unequal inclination; a gambrel roof.

A ticket for transportation at a reduced rate in considerationof some special circumstance, as increase of travel; specif., aticket for a certain number of, or for daily, trips betweenneighboring places at a reduced rate, such as are commonly used bythose doing business in a city and living in a suburb. Commutationtickets are excepted from the prohibition against special ratescontained in the Interstate Commerce Act of Feb. 4, 1887 (24 Stat.379), and in 145 U. S. 263 it was held that party tickets were alsoexcepted as being "obviously within the commuting principle."
An inflammation of cartilage.
Crooked. [Obs.] "Corbe shoulder." Spenser.
The state of being coördinate; equality of rank or authority.
A small circumscribed tumor of the eyelid caused by retentionof secretion, and by inflammation of the Melbomian glands.
The tenth sign of zodiac, into which the sun enters at thewinter solstice, about December 21. See Tropic.The sun was entered into Capricorn. Dryden.
The end of the vertebral column beyond the sacrum in man andtailless monkeys. It is composed of several vertebræ more or lessconsolidated.
Seeing with clearness; discerning; as, clear-sighted reason
A myth accounting for the discovery of arts and sciences or theadvent of a higher civilization, as in the Prometheus myth.
One who works as a mason without having served a regularapprenticeship. [Scot.]
Pertaining to, or resembling, the electro-negative character ofchlorine; hence, electro-negative; -- opposed to basylous or zincous.[Obs.]
The position, rank, or commission of a cadet; as, to get acadetship.

A metrical break in a verse, occurring in the middle of a footand commonly near the middle of the verse; a sense pause in themiddle of a foot. Also, a long syllable on which the cæsural accentrests, or which is used as a foot.
The pit left by the explosion of a mine.

The European spotted flycatcher. Cobweb lawn, a fine linen,mentioned in 1640 as being in pieces of fifteen yards. Beck. Draper'sDict.Such a proud piece of cobweb lawn. Beau. & Fl.Cobweb micrometer, a micrometer in which threads of cobwed aresubstituted for wires.
A going round in a circle; a course not direct; a roundaboutway of proceeding.
Circinate.
To perfume with odors from burning gums and spices.The Salii sing and cense his altars round. Dryden.
To move in a contrary direction to.
Consisting of, or containing, lime and bitumen. Lyell.
The jaw. [Obs.] Spenser. Chaw bacon, a rustic; a bumpkin; alout. (Law) -- Chaw tooth, a grinder. (Law)
The yellowish, fragrant balsam yielded by the sweet gum; also,the tree itself.
See Simar.
A system or structure of many parts united.A regular compages of pipes and vessels. Ray.
The act or process of separating the finer parts of drugs fromthe coarser by sifting.
To oppose in words; to gainsay; to deny, or assert the contraryof, something.They . . . spake against those things which were spoken by Paul,contradicting and blaspheming. Acts xiii. 45.
A substance added to a medicine to mollify or modify itsaction. Dunglison.
The act or process of contaminating; pollution; defilement;taint; also, that which contaminates.
A sensualist. Burton.
The ancient Latin name of Wales. It is used by modern poets.

Pertaining to, derived from, or having certain characteristicsof, citric and aconitic acids. Citraconic acid (Chem.), a white,crystalline, deliquescent substance, C3H4(CO2H)2, obtained bydistillation of citric acid. It is a compound of the ethylene series.
Refuse wool. [Obs. or Prov.]
A handsomely banded, coral-reef fish, of Florida and the WestIndies (Pomacentrus saxatilis); -- called also mojarra.
One who communicates. Boyle.
Chainlike; -- said both or color marks and of indentations whenarranged like the links of a chain, as on shells, etc.
Of or pertaining to preaching or public addresses. [Obs.]Howell.
In a contending manner.
; jointly.
In the body; in a bodily form or manner.
A woman who comforts.To be your comfortress, and to preserve you. B. Jonson.
Carryng on war in conjunction with another power.
The art of reading character as it is delineated in the hand.-- Chei*ros"o*phist (, n.
The bitter, purgative principle of senna. It is a glucosidewith the properties of a weak acid; -- called also cathartic acid,and cathartina.
See Crackle, n., 3.
In a capacious manner or degree; comprehensively.
Copper pyrites, or yellow copper ore; a common ore of opper,containing copper, iron, and sulphur. It occurs massive and intetragonal crystals of a bright brass yellow color.
See Chant.
A suborder of Bryozoa, usually having a circle of bristlesbelow the tentacles.

A clause in a contract, or agreement, which has for its objectto suspend, to defeat, or in some way to modify, the principalobligation; or, in case of a will, to suspend, revoke, or modify adevise or bequest. It is also the case of a future uncertain event,which may or may not happen, and on the occurrence or non-occurrenceof which, the accomplishment, recission, or modification of anobligation or testamentary disposition is made to depend. Blount.Tomlins. Bouvier. Wharton. Equation of condition. (Math.) See underEquation.-- On or Upon condition (that), used for if in introducingconditional sentences. "Upon condition thou wilt swear to pay himtribute . . . thou shalt be placed as viceroy under him." Shak.-- Conditions of sale, the terms on which it is proposed to sellproperty by auction; also, the instrument containing or expressingthese terms.
Possessing, or characterized by, a crunode; -- used of curves.
The cause which moves a contracting party to enter into anagreement; the material cause of a contract; the price of astripulation; compensation; equivalent. Bouvier.
Fortuitous; casual. [Obs.]
A kind of beetle which feeds upon dung.
Collected into, or forming, a rounded mass or ball; as, theconglobate [lymphatic] glands; conglobate flowers.
See Capuchin, 3.
Of or pertaining to a clique; disposed to from cliques;exclusive in spirit.-- Cli"*quish*ness, n.
With constancy; steadily; continually; perseveringly; withoutcessation; uniformly.But she constantly affirmed that it was even so. Acts. xii. 15.
See Kumquat.
Consular. [Obs.] Holland.
A small, rounded, marine organism, capable of braking up intococcoliths.
Pertaining to conception.
To cover with, or as with, a carpet; to spread with carpets; tofurnish with a carpet or carpets.Carpeted temples in fashionable squares. E. Everett.
See Cunner.
A human being that eats human flesh; hence, any that devoursits own kind. Darwin.
One who catches crabs.
To have earth or frost stick to the feet when running, as ahare. Johnson. To carry on, to behave in a wild, rude, or rompingmanner. [Colloq.]
The act of stirring up, exciting, or agitating. [Obs.] "Theconcitation of humors." Sir T. Browne.
A theory, intermediate between realism and nominalism, that themind has the power of forming for itself general conceptions ofindividual or single objects. Stewart.
To mingle together; to mix in one mass, or intimately; toblend. Bacon.
Having the same foci; as, confocal quadrics.
See Coronet, 2.
Having a cloven foot.
Attention to all the facts and circumstances of a case;caution; watchfulness.With silent circumspection, unespied. Milton.
Churlish; rough; selfish. [Obs.] Ford.
The party who makes a covenant. Burrill.
The corner where the upper and under eyelids meet on each sideof the eye.
The state or quality of being clear or bright; brightness;conspicuosness. [R.] Chapman.
The principles, practices, or organization of the Carbonari.
One of the quinoline bases, obtained from coal tar as an oilyliquid, C11H11N; also, any one of several substances metameric with,and resembling, cryptidine proper.
Harsh and offensive, as a color; tawdry or in bad taste, as acombination of colors, or any design or work of art.
Capable of being cooked. Blount.
To heal or induce the formation of a cicatrix in, as in woundedor ulcerated flesh. Wiseman.
Any proposition which is subject to the process of conversion;-- so called in its relation to itself as converted, after whichprocess it is termed the conversae. See Converse, n. (Logic).
The state of a communty which permits promiseuous sexualintercourse among its members, as in certain societies practicingcommunism.
See Carvacrol.
Of the nature of camphor; containing camphor. Dunglison.
Capable of being classified.
Of or pertaining to a chasm; abounding in chasms. Carlyle.They cross the chasmy torrent's foam-lit bed. Wordsworth.
The state of being confounded.
See Camelet. [Obs.]
A genus of climbing plants, native of Mexico and South America.C. scandens is a consrvatory climber with large bell-shaped flowers.
A building or apartment for silkworms, when feeding and formingcocoons.
Capable of being contributed.
Like ashes; ash-colored; grayish.
The arrangement and connection of words in a sentence;syntactical arrangement.Some particles . . . in certain constructions have the sense of awhole sentence contained in them. Locke.
Borne in the escutcheon with his tail doubled between his legs;-- said of a lion.
One who describes the universe; one skilled in cosmology.
Capable of being cultivated or tilled. Todd.
The state of being conventional; adherence to socialformalities or usages; that which is established by conventional use;one of the customary usages of social life.
The sixteenth century, when applied to Italian art orliterature; as, the sculpture of the Cinquecento; Cinquecento style.

To form with short turns, bends, or wrinkles; to mold intoinequalites or sinuosities; to cause to wrinkle or curl.The houscrinkled to and fro. Chaucer.Her face all bowsy, Comely crinkled, Wondrously wrinkled. Skelton.The flames through all the casements pushing forth, Like red-notdevils crinkled into snakes. Mrs. Browning.

Either of two varieties of squash, distinguished by theirtapering, recurved necks. The summer crookneck is botanically avariety of the pumpkin (Cucurbita pepo) and matures early in theseason. It is pale yellow in color, with warty excrescences. Thewinter crookneck belongs to a distinct species (C. moschata) and issmooth and often striped. [U. S.]
To recover health and strength gradually, after sickness orweakness; as, a patient begins to convalesce.
Relating to a structure composed of a circular range ofcolumns, without a core or building within. Weale.
To climb with difficulty, or with hands and feet; -- also usedfiguratively.The narrow street that clambered toward the mill. Tennyson.
Bark; rind; specifically, cinchona bark.
A small fishing boat. Ham. Nav. Encyc.
A hood over the end of a wagon wheel hub to keep dirt away fromthe axle.
The quality of being creamy.
The office of a centumvir, or of the centumviri.
A popular name given to a few species of the genus Careopsis,especially to C. tinctoria of Arkansas.

A tube or duct; as, the alimentary canal; the semicircularcanals of the ear. Canal boat, a boat for use on a canal; esp. one ofpeculiar shape, carrying freight, and drawn by horses walking on thetowpath beside the canal. Canal lock. See Lock.
A literary or a musical composition formed by selections fromdifferent authors disposed in a new order.
Of, pertaining to, or resembling, the genus Carbus or familyCarabidæ.-- n.
Suitable for association or companionship. [Obs.] Sir H.Wotton.
To unite or coalesce. [Obs.]Let them continue to coalite. Bolingbroke.
Of or pertaining to the czar.
Having, or relating to the power of producing heat; -- appliedto foods which, being rich in carbon, as the fats, are supposed togive rise to heat in the animal body by oxidation.
To underlet a proportion of, for a single crop; -- said of afarm. [Ireland]

The part of a voltaic battery by which the electric currentleaves substances through which it passes, or the surface at whichthe electric current passes out of the electrolyte; the negativepole; -- opposed to anode. Faraday. Cathode ray (Phys.), a kind ofray generated at the cathode in a vacuum tube, by the electricaldischarge.

To lead or tend, esp. with reference to a favorable ordesirable result; to contribute; -- usually followed by to or toward.He was sensible how much such a union would conduce to the happinessof both. Macaulay.The reasons you allege do more conduce To the hot passion ofdistemper'd blood. Shak.
; sing. Calmuck. A branch of the Mongolian race inbabitingparts of the Russian and Chinese empires; also (sing.), the languageof the Calmucks. [Written also Kalmucks.]
Steel deriving its qualities from carbon chiefly, without thepresence of other alloying elements; --opposed to alloy steel.
Like a cat; stealthily; noiselessly.
To consider or think studiously; to ponder; to reflect; tomuse; to meditate.So many hours must I contemplate. Shak.
A mantelpiece.

One of the quinine group of alkaloids, found especially in redcinchona bark. It is a white crystalline substance, C19H22N2O, with abitter taste and qualities similar to, but weaker than, quinine; --sometimes called also cinchonidia.
A slope or declivity in a manege ground down which a horse ismade to gallop, to give suppleness to his haunches.
An impost. [Obs.]
One who performs the operation of cupping.
meadow irrigated by water from a spring or rivulet on the sideof hill.
In a copious manner.
Represented as running; -- said of a beast borne in a coat ofarms.
Lit., for whose benefit; incorrectly understood, it came to beused in the sense, of what good or use; and hence, (what) purpose;object; specif., the ultimate object of life.
A mark [^] used by writers and proof readers to indicate thatsomething is interlined above, or inserted in the margin, whichbelongs in the place marked by the caret.
An inferior magistrate or judge among the Mohammedans, usuallythe judge of a town or village.
One skilled in campanology; a bell ringer.
See Flaccillation.
Limping. [R.]
Adorned with sculptured leaves and branches.
One belonging to the same clan with another.
A two-wheeled car or vehicle for war, racing, stateprocessions, etc.First moved the chariots, after whom the foot. Cowper.

Any theory or system that aims to combine the teachings ofChrist with the teachings of socialism in their applications to life;Christianized socialism; esp., the principles of this natureadvocated by F. D. Maurice, Charles Kingsley, and others in Englandabout 1850. -- Christian socialist.
Having hollow teeth; -- said of a group lizards.-- n.
A warlike tribe of indians, related to the blackfeet, formerlyinhabiting the region of Wyoming, but now mostly on reservations inthe Indian Territory. They are noted for their horsemanship.
An oxide of zinc which collects on the sides of furnaces wherezinc is sublimed. Formerly applied to the mineral calamine.
The state or relation of being a child.
Rejoicing together; congratulatory.With like joy Congratulant approached him. Milton.
Hindrance; restraint. [Obs.]
Liability to be overset; -- said of a ship or other vessel.
One who capers, leaps, and skips about, or dances.The nimble capperer on the cord. Dryden.
The state of being corporeal; corporeal existence.
One who swears to another's credibility. W. Wotton.
An uncouth or disagreable sound of words, owing to theconcurrence of harsh letters or syllables. "Cacophonies of allkinds." Pope.

The platforms, consisting of two or more planks doweledtogether, for the flooring of a temporary military bridge. Wilhelm.A singular, chess, is sometimes used. "Each chess consists of threeplanks." Farrow.
A glass of fishes having a suckerlike mouth, without jaws, asthe lamprey; the Marsipobranchii.

Suitable or concordant; accordant; fit; harmonious;correspondent; consistent.Not congruous to the nature of epic poetry. Blair.It is no ways congruous that God should be always frightening meninto an acknowledgment of the truth. Atterbury.
A blue coloring matter supposed by some to be one of thecomponent parts ofchlorophyll.
That may be calcined; as, a calcinable fossil.

A bivalve mollusk of many kinds, especially those that areedible; as, the long clam (Mya arenaria), the quahog or round clam(Venus mercenaria), the sea clam or hen clam (Spisula solidissima),and other species of the United States. The name is said to have beengiven originally to the Tridacna gigas, a huge East Indian bivalve.You shall scarce find any bay or shallow shore, or cove of sand,where you may not take many clampes, or lobsters, or both, at yourpleasure. Capt. John Smith (1616).Clams, or clamps, is a shellfish not much unlike a coclke; it liethunder the sand. Wood (1634).

To cause to contract, or to render more crisp, as the flesh ofa fish, by gashing it, when living, with a knife; as, to crimp skate,etc. Crimping house, a low lodging house, into which men are decoyedand plied with drink, to induce them to ship or enlist as sailors orsoldiers.-- Crimping iron. (a) An iron instrument for crimping and curlingthe hair. (b) A crimping machine.-- Crimping machine, a machine with fluted rollers or with dies, forcrimping ruffles leather, iron, etc.-- Crimping pin, an instrument for crimping or puckering the borderof a lady's cap.
The state or quality of being congenial; natural affinity;adaptation; suitableness.  Sir J. Reynolds.
The act or condition of holding chattels; the state of being achattel.
Serving or tending to bind or constrict.
Producing or forming a crust or skin. [R.]
Parsimonious; niggardly. [Obs.] Chaucer.
One who writes in cipher, or secret characters.
Composed of shells; containing many shells.
Like a cancer; having the qualities or virulence of a cancer;affected with cancer. "Cancerous vices." G. Eliot.-- Can"cer*ous*ly, adv.-- Can"cer*ous*ness, n.
Of or resembling a clown, or characteristic of a clown;ungainly; awkward. "Clownish hands." Spenser. "Clownish mimic."Prior.-- Clown"ish*ly, adv.
Having the form of a cucumber; having the form of a cylindertapered and rounded at the ends, and either straight or curved.
A selection of passages, with notes, etc., to be used inacquiring a language; as, a Hebrew chrestomathy.
The body, or axis, of a vertebra. See Vertebra.
Quality of being contagious.

A name given to several kinds of vessels.(a) The caravel of the 16th century was a small vessel with broadbows, high, narrow poop, four masts, and lateen sails. Columbuscommanded three caravels on his great voyage.(b) A Portuguese vessel of 100 or 150 tons burden.(c) A small fishing boat used on the French coast.(d) A Turkish man-of-war.
A combining form meaning circular, of a circle or wheel.
To gain the victory; to overcome; to prevail.He went forth conquering and to conquer. Rev. vi. 2.The champions resolved to conquer or to die. Waller.
Sentinel. [Obs.] Sackville.
The front piece of a cap; -- now more commonly called visor.
Somewhat common; commonplace; vulgar.
The premium or interest paid by the buyer to the seller, to beallowed to defer paying for the stock purchased until the nextfortnightly settlement day. [Eng.]
The secant of the complement of an arc or angle. See Illust. ofFunctions.
Willfully disobedient to the summous or prders of a court.Blackstone.
In the Corinthian capital, one of the eight stalks rising outof the lower leafage and terminating in leaves which seem to suportthe volutes. See Illust. of Corinthian order, under Corinthian.
A compendium; an epitome; a summary.A compend and recapitulation of the Mosaical law. Bp. Burnet.
A girdle. [Obs.]
Somewhat cold; cool; chilly.

One of the higher aromatic hydrocarbons of coal tar, allied tonapthalene and anthracene. It is a white crystalline substance,C18H12, of strong blue fluorescence, but generally colored yellow byimpurities.
To champ; to bite. [Obs.] A. Stafford.
An instrument for exhibiting certain chromatic effects of light(depending upon the persistence of vision and mixture of colors) bymeans of rapidly rotating disks variously colored.
Having an irregular, convulsive motion. Dunglison. Clonicspasm. (Med.) See under Spasm.
Effecting confiscation; characterized by confiscations."Confiscatory and exterminatory periods." Burke.
Earthenware; vessels formed of baked clay, especially thecoarser kinds.
Bell-shaped.

A British province in North America, giving its name to variousplants and animals. Canada balsam. See under Balsam.-- Canada goose. (Zoöl.) See Whisky Jack.-- Canada lynx. (Zoöl.) See Lynx.-- Canada porcupine (Zoöl.) See Porcupine, and Urson.-- Canada rice (Bot.) See under Rick.-- Canada robin (Zoöl.), the cedar bird.
A place where coal is dug, including the machinery for raisingthe coal.
Having the same measure; commensurate; proportional.She being now removed by death, a commeasurable grief took as fullpossession of him as joy had one. I. Walton.
Same as 2d and 3d Cycloid.
