A man whose employment is to drive, or to convey goods in, acar or car.
An instrument for measuring liquids. It consists of a pistonmoving in a tube in which is contained the liquid, the quantityexpelled being indicated by the graduation upon the piston rod.

A shrub (the Myrica cerifera, or wax-bearing myrtle), common inNorth America, the little nuts of which are covered with a greenishwhite wax, which was formerly, used for hardening candles; -- alsocalled bayberry tree, bayberry, or candleberry.
(Arch.) A draped female figure supporting an entablature, inthe place of a column or pilaster.
In a crisp manner.
A sweetened hot drink of spirit and beaten eggs.
One who watches shoals of fish; a balker. See Balker.
To expel air, or obstructing or irritating matter, from thelungs or air passages, in a noisy and violent manner.
Relating to concubinage; living in concubinage.
One of the Carnivora.
See Cirrus.
A genus of exinct marine reptiles, allied to the Mosasaurus.See Illust. in Appendix.
Full of heaps.
One of the minute bodies into which the chromatin of thenucleus is resolved during mitotic cell division; the idant ofWeismann.
Cloistral. Ayliffe

The act of constraining, or the state of being constrained;that which compels to, or restrains from, action; compulsion;restraint; necessity.Long imprisonment and hard constraint. Spenser.Not by constraint, but bDryden.

The act, process, or time of celebrating.His memory deserving a particular celebration. Clarendok.Celebration of Mass is equivalent to offering Mass Cath. Dict.To hasten the celebration of their marriage. Sir P. Sidney.
A fragrant wood; agalloch.
One who cites.
The anterior region or head of insects and other arthropods.Packard.
One who prates much in his own favor, and makes unwarrantablepretensions; a quack; an impostor; an empiric; a mountebank.
A star of the first magnitude in the southern constellationArgo.
Originally, a melody of simpler form than the aria; a songwithout a second part and a da capo; -- a term now variously andvaguely used.
A bird of the family Cotingidæ, including numerous bright-colored South American species; -- called also chatterers.
Cheerful; joyous; chatty.
The state or quality of being conducible; conducibleness. Bp.Wilkins.
A kind of spade. [Eng.]
To confine in, or as in, a cloister; to seclude from the world;to immure.None among them are throught worthy to be styled religious personsbut those that cloister themselves up in a monastery. Sharp.
Same as Correi. [Scot.] Geikie.
To corrupt. See Corrupt. [Obs.] Chauser.
A vessel for perfumes; esp. one in which incense is burned.
Pertaining to, or resembling, the bracts of a calycle.
An opposing charge.
To cause (a ship taken aback in a light breeze) so to turn ormake a circuit as to recover, without bracing the yards, the sametack on which she had been sailing.
One who heals disease of cows; a cow doctor.
The act of compressing, or state of being compressed."Compression of thought." Johnson.
Soot; coal dust; refuse matter, as the dirty grease which comesfrom axle boxes, or the refuse at the mouth of an oven. Phillips.Bailey.
See Cowhage.

That from of attraction by which the particles of a body areunited throughout the mass, whether like or unlike; -- distinguishedfrom adhesion, which unites bodies by their adjacent surfaces.Solids and fluids differ in the degree of cohesion, which, beingincreased, turns a fluid into a solid. Arbuthnot.
A money changer. [Obs.]In the face of these guilty collybists. Bp. Hall.
Easily deceived; gullible.
Candlestick. [Obs.] Shak.
Wine with a mixture of honey and species. [Obs.] Chaucer.
An exchanger or an exchange of benefices. [Cant]
She who chides. [Obs.]
a carriage in general. Cowper.
A plant (Agathotes Chirayta) found in Northern India, havingmedicinal properties to the gentian, and esteemed as a tonic andfebrifuge.
The person in whose favor a covenant is made.
The pointless sword carried before English monarchs at theircoronation, and emblematically considered as the sword of mercy; --also called the sword of Edward the Confessor.
A mean wretch; a base fellow; a poltroon; a scullion. "Away,base cullions." Shak.
A public nursery, where the young children of poor women arecared for during the day, while their mothers are at work.
See Ciclatoun. [Obs.] Chaucer.
In a consubstantial manner; with identity of substance ornature.
See 2d & 3d Curry.
Liable to melt, grow soft, or become fluid. [Obs.] Harvey.
Of or pertaining to chirography.

A sharp, brief, ringing sound, made by a collision of metallicor other sonorous bodies; -- usually expressing a duller or lessresounding sound than clang, and a deeper and stronger sound thanclink.But not in chains to pine, His spirit withered with tyeur clank.Byron.
Having the form of a crown or coronet; resembling a crown.
A square piece of linen used formerly by women instead of acap; a kerchief. [Scot.] [Written also curch.] Jamieson.
One who enters a caveat.

That process by which a number of isolated facts are broughtunder one conception, or summed up in a general proposition, as whenKepler discovered that the various observed positions of the planetMars were points in an ellipse. "The colligation of facts." Whewell.Colligation is not always induction, but induction is alwayscolligation. J. S. Mill.
Of, pertaining to, or resembling, a family of plants which havefour petals arranged like the arms of a cross, as the mustard,radish, turnip, etc.
A weed of the genus Melampyrum, with black seeds, found onEuropean wheatfields.
The state of being contiguous; intimate association; nearness;proximity.The convicinity and contiguity of the two parishes. T. Warton.
To crowd together in disorder; to fill or cover with things indisorder; to throw into disorder; to disarrange; as, to clutter aroom.
Promoting circulation; circulating. [R.] Coleridge.
To poison with curare.
To choose [Obs.] Chaucer.
The quality of being compressible of being compressible; as,the compressibility of elastic fluids.
Cardiac.
Resembling a ring; -- said esp. of the cartilage at the larynx,and the adjoining parts.
A licensed lighter employed in the transportation of goods toand from vessels. [China] S. W. Williams.
A Linnean genus of mollusks having a conical shell. See Cone,n., 4.
A vault under altar of a Greek church.
Content; satisfaction. [Obs.] Bacon.
A tool for forming the necks of bottles, etc.

A level oblong space surrounded on three sides by seats ofwood, earth, or stone, rising in tiers one above another, and dividedlengthwise through the middle by a barrier around which the track orcourse was laid out. It was used for chariot races, games, and publicshows.
A condition produced by the excessive or long-continued use ofquinine, and marked by deafness, roaring in the ears, vertigo, etc.
A small chain. Sir W. Scott.
Gnat-shaped.
One who conspires; a conspirator.
A Hindoo measure of distance, varying from one and a half totwo English miles. Whitworth.
Of the nature of a codicil.
See under Capric.
An equal share of an inheritance.
A calk on a shoe. See Calk, n., 1.
Soot; smut. See 1st Colly. [Obs.]
A liquid, C3H7.C6H4.CHO, obtained from oil of caraway; --called also cuminic aldehyde.

A game, called also daughts, played on a checkerboard by twopersons, each having twelve men (counters or checkers) which aremoved diagonally. The game is ended when either of the players haslost all his men, or can not move them.
A red coloring matter obtained from the safflower, or Carthamustinctorius.
See Cooky.
Same as Curtana.

To accuse falsely and maliciously of a crime or offense, or ofsomething disreputable; to slander; to libel.Hatred unto the truth did always falsely report and calumniate allgodly men's doings. Strype.Syn.-- To asperse; slander; defame; vilify; traduce; belie; bespatter;blacken; libel. See Asperse.
A large, edible, marine fish (Brosmius brosme), allied to thecod, common on the northern coasts of Europe and America; -- calledalso tusk and torsk.

A pump consisting of an endless chain, running over a drum orwheel by which it is moved, and dipping below the water to be raised.The chain has at intervals disks or lifts which fit the tube throughwhich the ascending part passes and carry the water to the point ofdischarge.
Height; altitude. [Obs.]
A large pebble; a rounded stone not too large to be handled; asmall boulder; -- used for paving streets and for other purposes.
A glass water bottle for the table or toilet; -- called alsocroft.
Coeaval [Obs.] South.
Used in English only in the expression en creux. Thus,engraving en creux is engraving in intaglio, or by sinking orhollowing out the design.
To stop or fasten, as with a wedge, or block; to scotch; as, tochock a wheel or cask.
Inflammable. [Obs.] Shak.
Joint ordinance.
Of pertaining to, or resembling, the family of plants(Camponulaceæ) of which Campanula is the type, and which includes theCanterbury bell, the harebell, and the Venus's looking-glass.
The quality of being cosmopolitan; cosmopolitism.
Gullibility. [R.] Swift.
A confederate. Grafton.
Dried cow dung used as fuel.[Prov. Eng.] Simmonds.

One who is receiving rudimentary instruction in the doctrinesof Christianity; a neophyte; in the primitive church, one officiallyrecognized as a Christian, and admitted to instruction preliminary toadmission to full membership in the church.

A rare metallic element, occurring in the minerals cerite,allanite, monazite, etc. Symbol Ce. Atomic weight 141.5. It resemblesiron in color and luster, but is soft, and both malleable andductile. It tarnishes readily in the air.
A vessel in which milk or cream is stirred, beaten, orotherwise agitated (as by a plunging or revolving dasher) in order toseparete the oily globules from the other parts, and obtain butter.

Having or showing good spirits or joy; cheering; cheery;contented; happy; joyful; lively; animated; willing.To entertain a cheerful disposition. Shak.The cheerful birds of sundry kind Do chant sweet music. Spenser.A cheerful confidence in the mercy of God. Macaulay.This general applause and cheerful shout. Shak.
Coercive. "Coercitive power in laws." Jer. Taylor.
Of or pertaining to a confederation.
To fight; to scuffle; to box.While the peers cuff to make the rabble sport. Dryden.
Cribriform.
Tending to conflict; conflicting.  Sir W. Hamilton.
Inclined to communicate; ready to impart to others.Determine, for the future, to be less communicative. Swift.
A kind of tobacco for smoking, made of the dried leaves,coarsely broken; -- so called from the rush baskets in which it ispacked in South America. McElrath.
One versed in the cabala, or the mysteries of Jewishtraditions. "Studious cabalists." Swift.
Characteristic of, or resembling, cockneys.
An appropriation of, and dealing with the property of anotheras if it were one's own, without right; as, the conversion of ahorse.Or bring my action of conversion And trover for my goods. Hudibras.
To break in pieces; to crack. [Obs.] "The pot was crased."Chaucer.
To excite or stir up. [Obs.] Cotgrave.
A kind of hammer having a head formed of a group of pointedsteel bars, used for dressing ashlar, etc. -- v. t.
A carbide. See Carbide [Archaic]
A trull or prostitute; a scold or gossip. [Obs.] [Written alsocallat.]
Conversance [R.]
To treat with cruel playfulness, as a cat treats a mouse; toabuse. [Obs.] Birch.
Of or relating to a feast or entertainment, or to eating anddrinking, with accompanying festivity; festive; social; gay; jovial.Which feasts convivial meetings we did name. Denham.

Governed or characterized by caprice; apt to change suddenly;freakish; whimsical; changeable. "Capricious poet." Shak. "Capricioushumor." Hugh Miller.A capricious partiality to the Romish practices. Hallam.
To crush with the teeth; to chew with a grinding noise; tocraunch; as, to crunch a biscuit.

A mineral, composed of silica, magnesia, and iron, of a yellowto green color. It is common in certain volcanic rocks; -- calledalso olivine and peridot. Sometimes used as a gem. The name was alsoearly used for yellow varieties of tourmaline and topaz.
A kind of duck. See Old squaw.
A drain trench, in a ditch or moat; -- called also cuvette.
To impregnate or treat with camphor.
A tough old goose; hence, coarse, bad food of any kind. [Prov.Eng.] Halliwell.
See Shagreen.
Rigged like a catboat.

Same as Chromium. Chrome alum (Chem.), a dark violet substance,(SO4)3Cr2.K2SO4.24H2O, analogous to, and crystallizing like, commonalum. It is regarded as a double sulphate of chromium and potassium.-- Chrome green (a) The green oxide of chromium, Cr2O3, used inenamel painting, and glass staining. (b) A pigment made by mixingchrome yellow with Prussian blue.-- Chrome red, a beautiful red pigment originally prepared from thebasic chromate of lead, but now made from red oxide of lead.-- Chrome yellow, a brilliant yellow pigment, PbCrO4, used bypainters.
See Clodpoll. [Obs.] Shak.
A species of Vaccinium (V. Vitis-id), which bears acid redberries which are sometimes used in cookery; -- locally calledmountain cranberry.
Contagion; contagious matter. "Contagium of measles." Tyndall.
Connected with, or related to, the deluge, or to a cataclysm;as, clysmian changes. Smart.
A window sash opening on hinges affixed to the upright side ofthe frame into which it is fitted. (Poetically) A window.A casement of the great chamber window. Shak.
In a concordant manner.
Of or pertaining to a colony; as, colonial rights, traffic,wars.
Quality of being customary.
Belonging to, forming, or containing carpels.
The small pastern bone of the horse and allied animals.
In a conditional manner; subject to a condition or conditions;not absolutely or positively. Shak.

Attentive to examine probable effects and consequences of actswith a view to avoid danger or misfortune; prudent; circumspect;wary; watchful; as, a cautious general.Cautious feeling for another's pain. Byron.Be swift to hear; but cautious of your tongue. Watts.
The Brazilian porcupine (Cercolades, or Sphingurus,prehensiles), remarkable for its prehensile tail.

An atmosphere of rare matter, composed principally ofincandescent hydrogen gas, surrounding the sun and enveloping thephotosphere. Portions of the chromosphere are here and there thrownup into enormous tongues of flame.
To provide with a chokebore.

Resembling, or having the form of, a sieve; pierced with hokes;as, the cribriform plate of the ethmoid bone; a cribriform compress.Cribriform cells (Bot.), those which have here and there oblique ortransverse sieve plates, or places perforated with many holes.
One of the quinine group of alkaloids isomeric with andresembling cinchonidine; -- called also cinchonia.
In caressing manner.
In a conversable manner.
Constraining; compulsory. [R.] "Any constraintive vow." R.Carew.
A bun or cake marked with a cross, and intended to be eaten onGood Friday.
To inhere or exist together, as in one substance. Sir W.Hamilton.
A medicine or application that promotes the healing of a soreor wound, or the formation of a cicatrix.
To mark or cover with cross lines; as, a paper was crisscrossedwith red marks.
A little bud or knob at the top of a deer's antler.
A gasket. See Gasket.
A vault or crypt in connection with a church, used as arepository for human bones disintered from their original burialplaces; a charnel house.
In a literal, limited, or narrow manner. [R.] Milton.

One who contracts; one of the parties to a bargain; one whocovenants to do anything for another; specifically, one who contractsto perform work on a rather large scale, at a certain price or rate,as in building houses or making a railroad.
An andiron with a knob at the top. Bacon.
Specifically, having such a combination of concave and convexsides as makes the focal axis the shortest line between them. SeeIllust. under Lens.
A ballet dancer.
A little castle.

To move of draw (a sail or yard) by means of the clew garnets,clew lines, etc.; esp. to draw up the clews of a square sail to theyard. To clew down (Naut.), to force (a yard) down by hauling on theclew lines.-- To clew up (Naut.), to draw (a sail) up to the yard, as forfurling.
One who, or that which cards wool flax, etc. Shak.
Expressive of regard or praise; of the nature of, orcontaining, a compliment; as, a complimentary remark; a complimentaryticket. "Complimentary addresses." Prescott.
A cabin on the after part of the quarterdeck, usually occupiedby the captain. [Written also couch.] [Obs.]The commanders came on board and the council sat in the coach. Pepys.
One joined in a plot. Dryden.
The state or quality of being contemptible, or of beingdespised.
The condition of being compatriots.
pret. of Carve. [Obs.] Chaucer.
Open country. Sir W. Temple.
The first day of each month in the ancient Roman calendar.[Written also kalends.] The Greek calends, a time that will nevercome, as the Greeks had no calends.
The projecting part of a Classic cornice, the under side ofwhich is cut with a recess or channel so as to form a drip. SeeIllust. of Column.
Consisting of several kinds mingled together; mixed; as,chowchow sweetmeats (preserved fruits put together).

One who creeps, halts, or limps; one who has lost, or neverhad, the use of a limb or limbs; a lame person; hence, one who ispartially disabled.I am a cripple in my limbs; but what decays are in my mind, thereader must determine. Dryden.
A tough, lustrous, reddish white metal of the iron group, noteasily fusible, and somewhat magnetic. Atomic weight 59.1. Symbol Co.
Of or pertaining to calisthenics.

A house of entertainment, where guests are supplied with coffeeand other refreshments, and where men meet for conversation.The coffeehouse must not be dismissed with a cursory mention. Itmight indeed, at that time, have been not improperly called a mostimportant political institution . . . The coffeehouses were the chieforgans through which the public opinion of the metropolis venteditself . . . Every man of the upper or middle class went daily to hiscoffeehouse to learn the news and discuss it. Every coffeehouse hadone or more orators, to whose eloquence the crowd listened withadmiration, and who soon became what the journalists of our own timehave been called -- a fourth estate of the realm. Macaulay.
Carried to the utmost extent or degree; of the highest quality;complete; perfect. "A man of perfect and consummate virtue." Addison.The little band held the post with consummate tenacity. Motley
A gummy or mucilaginous tasteless substance obtained from themarigold or calendula, and analogous to bassorin.
A carack. See Carack. Carrick bend (Naut.), a kind of knot,used for bending together hawsers or other ropes.-- Carrick bitts (Naut.), the bitts which support the windlass.Totten.
Established or accepted religious rites or usages of worship;state of religious development. Cf.Cult, 2.
A bombproof chamber, usually of masonry, in which cannon may beplaced, to be fired through embrasures; or one capable of being usedas a magazine, or for quartering troops.
To form a head like that the cabbage; as, to make lettucecabbage. Johnson.

The principle of heat, or the agent to which the phenomena ofheat and combustion were formerly ascribed; -- not now used inscientific nomenclature, but sometimes used as a general term forheat.Caloric expands all bodies. Henry.
A fellow rival; a competitor; a rival; also, a companion. [R.]Shak.
A small roll of tobacco, used for smoking. Cigar fish (Zoöl.),a fish (Decapterus punctatus), allied to the mackerel, found on thecoast of the Gulf of Mexico.

A thickening of the epidermis at some point, esp. on the toees,by friction or pressure. It is usually painful and troublesome.Welkome, gentlemen! Ladies that have their toes Unplagued with corns,will have a bout with you. Shak.
To agree; to concur. [Obs.] Sir T. Elyot.
A thin muscle which serves to draw up the testicle.
Consisting of copper or resembling copper; coppery.
The act of congratulating; an expression of sympatheticpleasure.With infinite congratulations for our safe arrival. Dr. J. Scott.
A counterpoise.
A long gown or surcoat (cut off in front), worn in the MiddleAges. It was sometimes embroidered or interwoven with gold. Also, arich stuff from which the gown was made.
Capable of being concealed.
Of or pertaining to the clavicle.
Same as King-post.
Complimentary. [Obs.]Languages . . . grow rich and abundant in complimental phrases, andsuch froth. Sir H. Wotton.-- Com`pli*men"tal*ly, adv. [Obs.] Boyle.-- Com`pli*men"tal*ness, n. [Obs.] Hammond.
Same as Crossbill.
One who is called upon to answer a summons or other proceedingjointly with another.
A partially compacted bed of gravel mixed with shells, of theTertiary age.
A peculiar toothlike fossil of many forms, found especially incarboniferous rocks. Such fossils are supposed by some to be theteeth of marsipobranch fishes, but they are probably the jaws ofannelids.
Bad speaking; bad choice or use of words. Buchanan.
Public festivals in honor of Ceres.
A liquid injected into the lower intestines by means of asyringe; an injection; an enema. Clyster pipe, a tube or pipe usedfor injections.
A small furnace or iron cage to hold fire for charring theinside of a cask, and making the staves flexible. Knight.
The quality of being corrupt.
Same as Cooly.
Travelling from house to house or from town to town; itinerant.[Obs.] "Circulatorious jugglers." Barrow.
Firmly barred or closed.
A small cell.
Same as Crinite,

Following by necessary inference or rational deduction; as, aproposition consequent to other propositions. Consequent points,Consequent poles (Magnetism), a number of poles distributed undercertain conditions, along the axis of a magnetized steel bar, whichregularly has but the two poles at the extremities.
A salt formed by the union of croconic acid with a base.
Having a chevron; decorated with an ornamental figure of azigzag from.[A garment] whose nether parts, with their bases, were of watchetcloth of silver, chevroned all over with lace. B. Jonson.
A cognomen or surname. [R.] Jer. Taylor.
That which may decay and perish; the human body. [Archaic] 1Cor. xv. 53.

Having similarity of sequence; -- said of certain parallelprogressions of two parts in a piece of harmony; as, consecutivefifths, or consecutive octaves, which are forbidden. Consecutivechords (Mus.), chords of the same kind suceeding one another withoutinterruption.
See Animé, n.
See Krang.

A large genus of plants having monopetalous flowers, includingthe common bindweed (C. arwensis), and formerly the morning-glory,but this is now transferred to the genus Ipomæa.The luster of the long convolvuluses That coiled around the statelystems. Tennyson.
Like a cad; lowbred and presuming.
The quality of being conditional, or limited; limitation bycertain terms.
Short and thick. [U. S.] Kane.
A sofa having a seat at each end at right angles to the mainseats.
A headdress, or manner of dressing the hair. Addison.
See Quinidine.
In a celestial manner.
To talk familiarly together; to chat; to prattle.I shall not ask Jean Jaques Rousseau If birds confabulate or no.Cowper.
Silence; hush. [Obs.] Chaucer.
Same as Courtesy, an act of respect.
Quality or state of being careful.
The bark of a South American vine (Gonolobus Condurango) of theMilkweed family. It has been supposed, but erroneously, to be a curefor cancer. [Written also condurango.]
Act of convincing, or state of being convinced; conviction.[R.]The fear of a convincement. Milton.
The business of a conveyancer; the act or business of drawingdeeds, leases, or other writings, for transferring the title toproperty from one person to another.
See Cottise.
The office of a chairman of a meeting or organized body.
In a suitable or becoming manner. [R.] Sherwood.
Disputing or wrangling. [Obs.] -- n.
A meeting or assembly for conversation, particularly onliterary or scientific subjects. Gray.These conversazioni [at Florence] resemble our card assemblies. A.Drummond.
The apartment in which a club meets. Addison.
Suitable for a cabinet; small.He [Varnhagen von Ense] is a walking cabinet edition of Goethe. For.Quar. Rev.
An American parrakeet of the genus Conurus. Many species areknown. See Parrakeet.

A Species of duck (Aythya vallisneria), esteemed for thedelicacy of its flesh. It visits the United States in autumn;particularly Chesapeake Bay and adjoining waters; -- so named fromthe markings of the plumage on its back.
The wild poppy, or red corn rose.
Contemplation. [Obs.] Chaucer.
In a confirming manner.
Of the same species.
To sign on the opposite side of (an instrument or writing);hence, to sign in addition to the signature of a principal orsuperior, in order to attest the authenticity of a writing.
A white crystalline substance obtained from castoreum.
Crooked. [Obs.]
Vocal music colored, as it were, by florid ornaments, runs, orrapid passages.
See 4th Crowd.
One who colors; an artist who excels in the use of colors; oneto whom coloring is of prime importance.Titian, Paul Veronese, Van Dyck, and the rest of the good colorists.Dryden.
See Sourkrout.
A carnivorous animal (Canis latrans), allied to the dog, foundin the western part of North America; -- called also prairie wolf.Its voice is a snapping bark, followed by a prolonged, shrill howl.
A half turn which a horseman makes, either to the right or theleft.
A glossy woolen stuff, plain, striped, or checked. "a gaycalamanco waistcoat." Tatler.

Expressing much in a few words; condensed; brief and compacted;-- used of style in writing or speaking.The concise style, which expresseth not enough, but leaves somewhatto be understood. B. Jonson.Where the author is . . . too brief and concise, amplify a little. I.Watts.
Relating to, or involving, crimination; accusing; as, acriminatory conscience.
One of two small holes astern, above the gunroom ports, throughwhich hawsers may be passed.
A bearing worn, not upon the shield, but usually above it, orseparately as an ornament for plate, liveries, and the like. It is arelic of the ancient cognizance. See Cognizance, 4.

A colony of the British Empire not having an electivemagistracy or a parliament, but governed by a chief magistrate(called Governor) appointed by the Crown, with executive councilorsnominated by him and not elected by the people.
To render costive; to cause constipation in.
Having a leafy stem.
To quicken or animate by chirping; to cherup.
Possessing peculiarities that are characteristic of severaldiverse groups.
The act corrugating; contraction into wrinkles or alternateridges and grooves.
Fretfully; spitefully.
One who carouses; a reveler.
a wool-like fabric.[WordNet 1.5]
A salt of caprylic acid.
The quality of conducing.
The act or state of becoming cancerous or growing into acancer.
A combination of tones simultaneously performed, producing moreor less perfect harmony, as, the common chord.
On the hither side of the Alps with reference to Rome, that is,on the south side of the Alps; -- opposed to transalpine.
A freeman of the lowest class; one not a thane or of theservile classes; a churl.
Of or pertaining to the Czechs. "One Czechic realm." TheNation.
Accountable; responsible; sensitive. [Obs.]I am very comptible even to the least sinister usage. Shak.
The embryological history of groups or families of individuals.

A beam or bar across the head or end of a rod, etc., or a blockattached to it and carrying a knuckle pin; as the solid crosspiecerunning between parallel slides, which receives motion from thepiston of a steam engine and imparts it to the connecting rod, whichis hinged to the crosshead.
A group of beetles having club-shaped antennæ.
One who chastises; a punisher; a corrector. Jer. Taylor.The chastiser of the rich. Burke.
A glucoside extracted from rhubarb as a bitter, yellow,crystalline powder, and yielding chrysophanic acid on decomposition.
Like coral, or partaking of its qualities.
A curve of the third degree. Circular cubic. See underCircular.
Pitiable. [Obs.] Bacon.
The pronghorn antelope. [Also written cabrit, cabret.]
To ornament with figured work, as the side of a stocking.
The office of a churchwarden.

A compound of carbon and oxygen, as carbonyl, with some elementor radical; as, potassium carboxide. Potassium carboxide, a grayishexplosive crystalline compound, C6O6K, obtained by passing carbonmonoxide over heated potassium.
Cone-shaped; conical.
The arrangement of bristles on an insect.
The erosion of the bed of a stream by running water,principally by attrition of the detritus carried along by the stream,but also by the solvent action of the water.
An under-garment, worn by women, usually covering the neck,shoulders, and breast.
A picture printed in tints and colors by repeated impressionsfrom a series of stones prepared by the lithographic process.
Characterized by copses. "Copsy villages." "Copsy banks." J.Dyer.

A white, crystalline, nitrogenous body closely related tocreatin but more basic in its properties, formed from the latter bythe action of acids, and occurring naturally in muscle tissue and inurine. [Written also kretinine.]
In a correct manner; exactly; acurately; without fault orerror.
Capable of being chased; fit for hunting. Gower.
A perforated pasteboard or sheet-metal plate for warp threads,making part of the Jacquard apparatus of a loom. See Jacquard.
Disposition to or manifestion of contempt; insolence;haughtiness.
Hernia in which the urinary bladder protrudes; vesical hernia.
Having feet like those of a goat.
The fruit or berry of the Anamirta Cocculus, a climbing plantof the East Indies. It is a poisonous narcotic and stimulant.
Compressing, or having power or tendency to compress; as, acompressive force.
Feeding upon dung, as certain insects.
Junction; adaptation [R.]Consertion of design, how exquisite. Young.
Stiff, stubborn, clayey, or tenacious; as, a cledgy soil.Halliwell.
Pertaining to Corinth.
The fire beetle of Mexico and the West Indies.
A meteoric stone characterized by the presence of chondrules.

A name formerly given to various fevers occuring in tropics;esp. to a form of furious delirium accompanied by fever, amongsailors, which sometimes led the affected person to imagine the seato be a green field, and to throw himself into it.
The fold of membrane loaded with fat, which covers more or lessof the intestines in mammals; the great omentum See Omentum.The caul serves for warming of the lower belly. Ray.
The larval stage of a tapeworm (Tænia coenurus) which formsbladderlike sacs in the brain of sheep, causing the fatal diseaseknown as water brain, vertigo, staggers or gid.
A follower of Confucius; a Confucian.  S. W. Williams.

Contained within limits; hence, having the desires limited bythat which one has; not disposed to repine or grumble; satisfied;contented; at rest.Having food rainment, let us be therewith content. 1 Tim. vi. 8.
A cycler.
See Corporas.
An apparatus for receiving and condensing the volatile productsof distillation to a liquid or solid form, by cooling.
Having no coffin.
See Cosier.
A genus of fishes, common on the Atlantic coast, including theyellow or goldon mackerel.
The implement with which the ball is thrown and caught in thegame of lacrosse.
The steersman of a boat; a petty officer who has charge of aboat and its crew.

A kind of pipe, used by the North American Indians for smokingtobacco. The bowl is usually made of soft red stone, and the tube isa long reed often ornamented with feathers.Smoked the calumet, the Peace pipe, As a signal to the nations.Lowgfellow.
The building where customs and duties are paid, and wherevessels are entered or cleared. Customhouse broker, an agent who actsfor merchants in the business of entering and clearing goods andvessels.
The meeting of two or more stars or planets in the same degreeof the zodiac; as, the conjunction of the moon with the sun, or ofJupiter and Saturn. See the Note under Aspect, n., 6.
In a customary manner; habitually.
Having the ears cropped.
A hydrous chloride of potassium and magnesium, sometimes foundassociated with deposits of rock salt.
Happening at the same instant. C. Darwin.
Tending or liable to contaminate.
A horse. [Sp. Amer.]
One who offers congratulation. Milton.
An orthopterous insect of the genus Gryllus, and allied genera.The males make chirping, musical notes by rubbing together the basalparts of the veins of the front wings.
In a consummate manner; completely. T. Warton.

Pertaining to, derived from, or containing, cobalt; -- saidesp. of cobalt compounds in which the metal has its lower valence.Cobaltous chloride, a crystalline compound, CoCl2, of a pale rosecolor when hydrous, blue when dehydrated. Its solution is used for asympathetic ink, the writing being nearly colorless when dried in theair, owing to absorbed moisture, and becoming bright blue whenwarmed.
The curve or tracing made by a cardiograph.

Of or pertaining to a clan; closely united, like a clan;disposed to associate only with one's clan or clique; actuated by thetraditions, prejudices, habits, etc., of a clan.-- Clan"nish*ly, adv.-- Clan"nish*ness, n.
To distribute into classes; to arrange according to a system;to arrnge in sets according to some method founded on commonproperties or characters.
Corpuscular. Tyndall.
The frontal plate of the head of an insect.
To calcine. [R.]
Of, pertaining to, or resembling, the stern old Roman, Cato theCensor; severe; inflexible.
The act of placing in a circle, or round about, or the state ofbeing so placed. Evelyn.
One of the bladders or air vessels of certain algæ, as of thegreat kelp of the Pacific, and common rockweeds (Fuci) of our shores.D. C. Eaton.
The principle of civil government.
One of the middle parts in music, between the tenor and thetreble; high tenor. Counter-tenor clef (Mus.), the C clef when placedon the third line; -- also called alto clef.
Steel produced by cementation; blister steel.

Relative position or aspect of the planets; the face of thehoroscope, according to the relative positions of the planets at anytime.They [astrologers] undertook . . . to determine the course of a man'scharacter and life from the configuration of the stars at the momentof his birth. Whewell.
A subdeacon who bears a cross before an archbishop or primateon solemn occasions.
Making a clangor; having a ringing, metallic sound.
Having jointed stems or culms.

One of a large group of beetles (Rhynchophora) of many genera;-- called also weevils, snout beetles, billbeetles, and billbugs.Many of the species are very destructive, as the plum curculio, thecorn, grain, and rice weevils, etc.
To compress; to shut up. [Obs.] Burton.
Leaping from each other; -- said of two figures on a coast ofarms.
A general sketch or outline of a subject; a synopsis; anepitome.
Any curiosity or article of virtu.The busy world, which does not hunt poets as collectors hunt forcurios. F. Harrison.
Covered with a crust; as, crustated basalt.
One line or radius falling perpendicularly on another; as, thecatheti of a right-angled triangle, that is, the two sides thatinclude the right angle. Barlow.
A part of a turtle which is attached to the lower shell. Itcontains a fatty and gelatinous substance of a light yellowish color,much esteemed as a delicacy. Thackeray.
Tending to circumvent; deceiving by artifices; deluding.
The art of measuring time; the measuring of time by periods ordivisions.
The wife of a constable. [Obs.]
An igneous rock of feldspathic composition, lamellar instructure, and clinking under the hammer. See Phonolite.
See Covinous, and Covin.
To connect. Sir M. Hale.
The quality of being chatty, or of talking easily andpleasantly.
A white amorphous horny substance forming the harder part ofthe outer integument of insects, crustacea, and various otherinvertebrates; entomolin.
An adherent crust; an incrustation. Pepys.
Of or pertaining to a canonist. "This canonistic exposition."Milton.
Capable of contraction.Small air bladders distable and contractible. Arbuthnot.
The blasting of the young buds of trees or plants, by excessiveheat or caold. Harris.
See Saint Elmo's fire, under Saint.
Having the petals held together by stamens, which grow to theirbases, as in the mallow.
Changeableness of color, as in a mineral; play of colors.Cleaceland.
A counter. [Obs.] Shak.
Joint help; coöperation. Sir T. Browne.
Affirming the opposite; so opposed as to destroy each other;as, contrary propositions. Contrary motion (Mus.), the progression ofparts in opposite directions, one ascending, the other descending.
See Quinaldine.

Of, pertaining to, or resembling, the family of plants ot whichthe oak and the chestnut are examples, -- trees bearing a smooth,solid nut inclosed in some kind of cup or bur; bearing, or furnishedwith, a cupule.
A hollow way, adapted to cover troops, and facilitate theiraproach to a place. Farrow.
A vaulting or arching over. [R.]
One who blows a cornet.
Surgery. [Obs.]
The act of making concave.
Pertaining to that mode of projection in drawing in which therays of light are supposed to fall obliquely on the plane ofprojection.
One who calls.
Having a cartilaginous skeleton.-- n.
A peculiar whistling sound made by the Australian aborigenes asa call or signal. [Written also cooie.]
A tool for making the band impression distinct on the back.Knight.
See Common sense, under Sense.
An agreement, manifesting itself in words or deeds, by whichtwo or more persons confederate to do an unlawful act, or to useunlawful to do an act which is lawful; confederacy.
Wearing a cravat.The young men faultlessly appointed, handsomely cravatted. Thackeray.
In a clinical manner.
United at the base, as contiguous lobes of a leaf.
A weight divisible first into a hundred parts, and then intosmaller parts.
The act or art of writing in secret characters; also, secretcharacters, or cipher.
To seize; clutch; snatch; catch; pluck.
A colorless crystalline substance extracted from the Capsicumannuum, and giving off vapors of intense acridity.

A tract of crown land in Buckinghamshire and Oxfordshire,England, to which is attached the nominal office of steward. Asmembers of Parliament cannot resign, when they wish to go out theyaccept this stewardship, which legally vacates their seats.
Suitable; consistent. [Obs.] "Some comportable method." Wotton.
A low stool. [Scot.]

A class of parasitic worms (Platelminthes) of which thetapeworms are the most common examples. The body is flattened, andusually but not always long, and composed of numerous joints orsegments, each of which may contain a complete set of male and femalereproductive organs. They have neither mouth nor intestine. SeeTapeworm. [Written also Cestoda.]
Having the same bounds; terminating at the same time or place;conterminous.Love and life not conterminable. Sir H. Wotton.
Conclusively. [R.] Digby.
Adhesive; -- said of a roof in a mine to which coal clings.
The employment or arrangement of columns in a structure. Gwilt.
Wearing shoes; calceated; -- in distintion from discalced orbarefooted; as the calced Carmelites.
The tree producing the aligator apple. (3)
To march back, or to march in reversed order.The two armies marched and countermarched, drew near and receded.Macaulay.
Cognizable; liable to be tried or judged. [Obs.] Bp. Barlow.
To make like a creature; to degrade [Obs.]Degrade and creaturize that mundane soul. Cudworth.
An excessive devotion to the interests of the sacerdotal order;undue influence of the clergy; sacerdotalism.
To sail completely round.Having circumnavigated the whole earth. T. Fuller.
One who deals incheese. B. Jonson.
Sucked by cubs. [R.]This night, wherein the cub-drawn bear would couch. Shak.
The qquality of being conjoint.
Growing together, or into union; uniting. [R.] Eclec. Rev.
Of the nature of, or pertaining to, a tail; having a tail-likeappendage.The male widow-bird, remarkable for his caudal plumes. Darwin.Caudal fin (Zoöl.), the terminal fin (or "tail") of a fish.
A supposed new element of the rare-earth group, accompanyinglutecium and scandium in the gadolinite earths. Symbol, Ct (noperiod).
Containing a body cavity; as, the cavitary or nematoid worms.

To copy, as a drawing, by rubbing the back of it with red orblack chalk, and then passing a blunt style or needle over the lines,so as to leave a tracing on the paper or other thing against which itis laid or held. [Writting also calque]
Affected with darkness or dimness; dark; obscure. [R.] Blount.The caliginous regions of the air. Hallywell.-- Ca*lig"i*nous*ly, adv.-- Ca*lig"i*nous*ness, n.
To coo, as a pigeon. [Obs.]
The process or operation of feeding the contents of thecrucilbe with fresh material. B. Jonson.
In a contented manner. [Obs.]

Of or pertaining to the pointed tooth on each side theincisors. Canine appetite, a morbidly voracious appetite; bulimia.-- Canine letter, the letter r. See R.-- Canine madness, hydrophobia.-- Canine toth, a toth situated between the incisor and bicuspidteeth, so called because well developen in dogs; usually, the thirdtooth from the front on each side of each jaw; an eyetooth, or thecorresponding tooth in the lower jaw.
Being vertical, or at the highest point of altitude; hence,predominant. [R.]
Pertaining to, or made by, chromolithography.
A first cousin. See Note under Cousin, 1.
an obs. form of began, imp. & p. p. of Begin, sometimes used inold poetry.
An advocate of communalism.

The inner envelope of a flower; the part which surrounds theorgans of fructification, consisting of one or more leaves, calledpetals. It is usually distinguished from the calyx by the fineness ofits texture and the gayness of its colors. See the Note underBlossom.
A ditch or drain for catching water. See Catchdrain.
Chromatic. [Obs.]

The alphabet; -- formerly so called, either from the crossusually set before it, or from a superstitious custom, sometimespracticed, of writing it in the form of a cross, by way of a charm.From infant conning of the Christcross-row. Wordsworth.
A cyanide. [Obs.]
A printing process of engraving on a surface of wax spread on asteel plate, for electrotyping.

Relating to, or derived from, a city or citizen; relating toman as a member of society, or to civil affairs. Civic crown (Rom.Antiq.), a crown or garland of oak leaves and acorns, bestowed on asoldier who had saved the life of a citizen in battle.
Without conscience; indifferent to conscience; unscrupulous.Conscienceless and wicked patrons. Hookre.

Green vitriol, or sulphate of iron; a green crystallinesubstance, of an astringent taste, used in making ink, in dyeingblack, as a tonic in medicine, etc. It is made on a large scale bythe oxidation of iron pyrites. Called also ferrous sulphate.
In a manner to cheer or encourage.
A warlike, savage, and nomadic tribe of the Shoshone family ofIndians, inhabiting Mexico and the adjacent parts of the UnitedStates; -- called also Paducahs. They are noted for plundering andcruelty.
The brace of the fore-topsail on the leeward side of a vessel.

Assuming or positing the actual existence or reality of thephysical or external world. Cosmothetic idealists (Metaph.), thosewho assume, without attempting to prove, the reality of externalobjects as corresponding to, and being the ground of, the ideas ofwhich only the mind has direct cognizance.The cosmothetic idealists . . . deny that mind is immediatelyconscious of matter. Sir W. Hamilton.
A description of, or a treatise concerning, comets.
A chain or series of things connected with each other.I have . . . in no case sought to construct those catenæ of games,which it seems now the fashion of commentators to link together. C.J. Ellicott.
Carbuncle. [Written also Charboncle.] [Obs.] Chaucer.
One of the Conirostres.
The season of Christmas.
A dangerous whirlpool on the coast of Sicily opposite Scylla onthe Italian coast. It is personified as a female monster. See Scylla.
Attempts to attract admoration, notice, or love, for the meregratification of vanity; trifling in love. "Little affectations ofcoquetry." Addison.
A slightly convex mirror, commonly of black glass, used as atoy for viewing the reflected landscape.
Passant in opposite directions; -- said of two animals.
An advocate or professional pleader; one who counted for hisclient, that is, orally pleaded his cause. [Obs.] Burrill.
Mutual adjustment.
In a courteous manner.
Pert; saucy. [Obs.] Halliwell.
See Strabismus.
See Color.

A notice given by an interested party to some officer not to doa certain act until the party is heard in opposition; as, a caveatentered in a probate court to stop the proving of a will or thetaking out of letters of administration, etc. Bouvier.
See Coletit.

The name of various instruments for passing along mucouscanals, esp. applied to a tubular instrument to be introduced intothe bladder through the urethra to draw off the urine. Eustachiancatheter. See under Eustachian.-- Prostatic catheter, one adapted for passing an enlarged prostate.
Contracted or compressed so as to be smaller in certain placesor parts than in others.
A fine, small line, fastened to a hawk's leash, when it isfirst lured.
Capable of being collected.
In the position of fighting; -- said of two lions set face toface, each rampant.
Rudeness of manners or temper; lack of kindness or courtesy.
To unite in a small party to promote private views andinterests by intrigue; to intrigue; to plot.Caballing still against it with the great. Dryden.
See Cognizor.
One who contests; an opponent; a litigant; a disputant; one whoclaims that which has been awarded to another.
A castrated cock, esp. when fattened; a male chicken gelded toimprove his flesh for the table. Shak.The merry thought of a capon. W. Irving.
Formed by, or relating to, construction, interpretation, orinference. Construct form or state (Heb. Gram.), that of a noun usedbefore another which has the genitive relation to it.

A school that teaches by correspondence, the instruction beingbased on printed instruction sheets and the recitation papers writtenby the student in answer to the questions or requirements of thesesheets. In the broadest sense of the term correspondence school maybe used to include any educational institution or department forinstruction by correspondence, as in a university or othereducational bodies, but the term is commonly applied to variouseducational institutions organized on a commercial basis, some ofwhich offer a large variety of courses in general and technicalsubjects, conducted by specialists.
A machine for raising guns or mortar into their carriages.
Cowardly. [Obs.] " A base and a cowardish mind." Robynson(More's Utopia).
See Clavate.
A very large bird of the Vulture family (Sarcorhamphusgryphus), found in the most elevated parts of the Andes.

A tree or shrub of the genus Prunus (Which also includes theplum) bearing a fleshy drupe with a bony stone; (a) The common gardencherry (Prunus Cerasus), of which several hundred varieties arecultivated for the fruit, some of which are, the begarreau,blackheart, black Tartarian, oxheart, morelle or morello, May-duke(corrupted from Médoc in France). (b) The wild cherry; as, prunusserotina (wild black cherry), valued for its timber; P. Virginiana(choke cherry), an American shrub which bears astringent fruit; P.avium and P. Padus, European trees (bird cherry).
The exterior or under surface embraced between the branches ofthe lower jaw bone, in birds.
The successive bowing or bending in different directions of thegrowing tip of the stems of many plants, especially seen in climbingplants.
The conversion of food into chyme by the digestive action ofgastric juice.
Of or pertaining to the deer, or to the family Cervidæ.
A white amorphous substance, regarded as a glucoside, extractedfrom the corm of Cyclamen Europæum.
One who has an equal portion with others of an inheritance.All the coparceners together make but one heir, and have but oneestate among them. blackstone.
An ordained minister; a man regularly authorized to peach thegospel, and administer its ordinances; in England usually restrictedto a minister of the Established Church.
Any volatile liquid used in charging illuminating gases.
An umbelliferous plant, the Coriandrum sativum, the fruit orseeds of which have a strong smell and a spicy taste, and in medicineare considered as stomachic and carminative.
Suppression of such facts and circumstances as in justice oughtto be made known. Wharton.
A character [0] which, standing by itself, expresses nothing,but when placed at the right hand of a whole number, increases itsvalue tenfold.
To agitate on all sides. Jer. Taylor.
The versed sine of the complement of an arc or angle. SeeIllust. of Functions.
The exterior slope or wall of the ditch; -- sometimes, thewhole covered way, beyond the ditch, with its parapet and glacis; as,the enemy have lodged themselves on the counterscarp.
Washed with a preparation of white lead; as, cerused face.Beau. & Fl.
See Calumba.
The principal gaseous substance forming the solar corona,characterized by a green line in the coronal spectrum.
Fitting the body exactly; setting close, as a garment. Ayliffe.
A hindoo hall of justice. Malcom.
The act or result of curtailing or cutting off. Bancroft.
A woman who conquers. Fairfax.
One possessed of land in copyhold.
A defect or malformation; esp., a fissure of the iris supposedto be a persistent embryonic cleft.
The assistant of a bishop or of a priest holding a benefice.
See Climacteric. Evelyn.
Pertaining to, produced by, or attending, catarrh; of thenature of catarrh.
Of or pertaining to process of using the calorimeter.Satisfactory calorimetric results. Nichol.
Capable or deserving of chastisement; punishable. Sherwood.
A white, crystalline, bitter substance. See Calumbin.
An extinct genus of Devonian ganoid fishes, having the broadplates about the head studded with berrylike tubercles.
A composite stone (quartz, schorl, and hornlende) in the wallsof tin and copper lodes.
A cognomen formerly prefixed to his name by the oldest son,until he succeeded to his ancestral titles, or was knighted; as,Childe Roland.
To make warm or hot.
Same as Cirrose.
See Cofessedly.

A beautiful gem of a deep red color (with a mixture of scarlet)called by the Greeks anthrax; found in the East Indies. When held upto the sun, it loses its deep tinge, and becomes of the color ofburning coal. The name belongs for the most part to ruby sapphire,though it has been also given to red spinel and garnet.
Containing or making correction; corrective.
With confidence; with strong assurance; positively.
A kind of cigar, originally brought from Mania, in thePhilippine Islands; now often made of inferior or adulteratedtabacco.
A woman who prostitutes herself for hire; a prostitute; aharlot.Lasciviously decked like a courtesan. Sir H. Wotton.
A kind of meat pie. [Obs.]
A chair, litter, or other contrivance fitted to the back orpack saddle of a mule for carrying travelers in mountainousdistricts, or for the transportation of the sick and wounded of anarmy.
To break into bends, turns, or angles; to crinkle.Old Veg's stream . . . drew her humid train aslope, Crankling herbanks. J. Philips.
A kind of pillar; a cylindrical or polygonal support for aroof, ceiling, statue, etc., somewhat ornamented, and usuallycomposed of base, shaft, and capital. See Order.
Relating to chironomy.
A plastic operation on the pupil, as for forming an artificialpupil. -- Cor`e*plas"tic (-plas"tik), a.
The American quail or bobwhite. The name is also applied toother related species. See Bobwhite.
A short, distorted hand; also, the deformity of having such ahand.
A British wagtail.
A white, crystalline, nitrogenous substance found abundantly inmuscle tissue. [Written also kreatine.]
In a converse manner; with change of order or relation;reciprocally. J. S. Mill.
The fruit of the Viburnum obovatum, a shrub which grows fromVirginia to Florida.
The quality of being credible; credibleness; as, thecredibility of facts; the credibility of witnesses.
One who receives baptism on a sick bed. [Obs.] Hook.

Having the qualities of chalk;abounding with chalk; chalky; as,cretaceous rocks and formations. See Chalk. Cretaceous acid, an oldname for carbonic acid.-- Cretaceous formation (Geol.), the series of strata of variouskinds, including beds of chalk, green sand, etc., formed in theCretaceous period; -- called also the chalk formation. See theDiagram under Geology.-- Cretaceous period (Geol.), the time in the latter part of theMesozoic age during which the Cretaceous formation was deposited.

A courting of favor or applause, by flattery or address; acaptivating quality; an attraction. [Obs.]Without any of those dresses, or popular captations, which some menuse in their speeches. Eikon Basilike.
Of or pertaining to a consistory. "Consistorial laws." Hooker."Consistorial courts." Bp. Hoadley.

tending to contract; having the power or property ofcontracting, or of shrinking into shorter or smaller dimensions; as,the contractile tissues.The heart's contractile force. H. Brooke.Each cilium seems to be composed of contractile substance. Hixley.Contractile vacuole (Zoöl.), a pulsating cavity in the interior of aprotozoan, supposed to be excretory in function. There may be one,two, or more.
One who carries the cross before an archbishop. [Obs.]
So as to surround or encircle.
The critical moment in a play, when, contrary to expectation,the action is embroiled in new difficulties. Dryden.
The conger eel; -- called also congeree. Conger sea (Zoöl.),the sea eel; a large species of eel (Conger vulgaris), whichsometimes grows to the length of ten feet.
A light, covered, four-wheeled pleasure carriage with twoseats.
Pertaining to, or resembling, a cycloid; as, the cycloidalspace is the space contained between a cycloid and its base.Cycloidal engine. See Geometric lathe.
To render Celtic; to assimilate to the Celts.
Same as Cheliferous.
In a cutting manner.
An instrument for describing circles, measuring figures, etc.,consisting of two, or (rarely) more, pointed branches, or legs,usually joined at the top by a rivet on which they move.
Same as Cochleate.
To gather into a ball; to collect into a round mass.Then founded, then conglobed Like things to like. Milton.
One who consumes candles by being up late for study ordissipation.A bookworm, a candlewaster. B. Jonson.
Passages selected from various authors, usually for purposes ofinstruction; miscellany; anthology.
One of a numerous family of hymenopterous insects (Chalcididæ.Many are gallflies, others are parasitic on insects.
The art of measuring shells or their curves; conchyliometry.
Nothingness. [R.] Goodwin.
A disease affecting grapes, esp. in California, manifested bythe premature dropping of the fruit.
To declare elapsed, as the time allowed for introducingevidence. Sir W. Scott.
A short expressive title used for abbreviated book lists, etc.
To search after lodes. See Costeaning.
Rising to a point; conical; copped. [Obs.] Woodward.
An amphibian (Amphiuma means) of the order Urodela, found inthe southern United States. See Amphiuma.
One of a court of about one hundred judges chosen to try civilsuits. Under the empire the court was increased to 180, and metusually in four sections.
A broken state; decrepitude; an impaired state of theintellect.
The bloom or blossom of the wild rose or dog-rose.
A stick or switch used among some American Indians in making orcounting a coup.
A carbine.

A perennial American herb (Caulophyllum thalictroides), whoseroostock is used in medicine; -- also called pappoose root. The nameis sometimes also given to the Cimicifuga racemosa, and to twospecies of Actæa, plants of the Crowfoot family.

To oppose with an equal weight or power; to counteract thepower or effect of; to countervail; to equiponderate; to balance.The remaining air was not able to counterbalance the mercurialcylinder. Boyle.The cstudy of mind is necessary to counterbalance and correct theinfluence of the study of nature. Sir W. Hamilton.
Spoon-shaped.
Compilation. [R.]
Cotton cloth, printed with flowers and other devices, in anumber of different colors, and often glazed. Swift.
The conversion of obscure radiant heat info kight; thetransmutation of rays of heat into others of higher refrangibility.Tyndall.
To chirp or chirrup. [ Prov. Eng.] Forby.
An avaricious, grasping fellow; a miser; a niggard; a churl.A gray-headed curmudgeon of a negro. W. Irving.
A California rosaceous shrub (Adenostoma fasciculatum) whichoften forms an impenetrable chaparral.
Awry. [Obs.] Skelton.
To ordain or appoint for some purpose along with another.
A conjecturer. [R.] Month. rev.
One who circumvents; one who gains his purpose by cunning.
An old Portuguese coin, worth about seventy cents. [Writtenalso cruade.] Shak.

The prosecution or defense of a suit, whether by furnishingmoney or personal services, by one who has no legitimate concerntherein, in consideration of an agreement that he shall receive, inthe event of success, a share of the matter in suit; maintenance withthe addition of an agreement to divide the thing in suit. SeeMaintenance.
A rude, rustic fellow.
To move the castle to the square next to king, and then theking around the castle to the square next beyond it, for the purposeof covering the king.
A garment worn throughout the Levant, consisting of a long gownwith sleeves reaching below the hands. It is generally fastened by abelt or sash.
Same as Chartist.
A bird; the flicker.

Designating furniture designed, or like that designed, byThomas Chippendale, an English cabinetmaker of the 18th century.Chippendale furniture was generally of simple but graceful outlinewith delicately carved rococo ornamentation, sculptured either in thesolid wood or, in the cheaper specimens, separately and glued on. Inthe more elaborate pieces three types are recognized: FrenchChippendale, having much detail, like Louis Quatorze and LouisQuinze; Chinese Chippendale, marked by latticework and pagodalikepediments; and Gothic Chippendale, attempting to adapt medievaldetails. The forms, as of the cabriole and chairbacks, often resembleQueen Anne. In chairs, the seat is widened at the front, and the backtoward the top widened and bent backward, except in ChineseChippendale, in which the backs are usually rectangular. --Chip"pen*dal*ism (#), n.
Having the margins only a little curved; -- said of leaves.Henslow.
Partnership in office. Milton.
A young swan. Shak.
See Coddle.
Grossness. [Obs.] Glanvill.
One aiming at or pretending to a greater purity of like thanothers about him; -- applied to persons of various sects. SeeAlbigenses.
Reasonably; justly.
The condition or quality of being crooked; hence, deformity ofbody or of mind; deviation from moral rectitude; perverseness.
Operating together; as, coöperant forces.
Characteristic.
To tame. [Obs.] Sir T. Browne.
Troops that are mounted on camels.
Of or pertaining to Candia; Cretary.
Destitute of charms. Swift.
A praying together. [Obs.] Bp. Wilkins.
Of or pertaining to a commissary.
An annual plant of the genus Iberis, cultivated in gardens. Thename was originally given to the I. umbellata, first, discovered inthe island of Candia.
Invested with, or embodied in, flesh.
Capable of being cited.

United; connected; associated. "Influence conjoint." Glover.Conjoint degrees (Mus.), two notes which follow each otherimmediately in the order of the scale, as ut and re. Johnson.Conjoint tetrachords (Mus.), two tetrachords or fourths, where thesame note is the highest of one and the lowest of the other; -- alsowritten conjunct.

One of a race of giants, sons of Neptune and Amphitrite, havingbut one eye, and that in the middle of the forehead. They were fabledto inhabit Sicily, and to assist in the workshops of Vulcan, underMt. Etna.
A wooden rattle sometimes used as a substitute for a bell, inthe Roman Catholic church, during the latter part of Holy Week, orthe last week of Lent.
A short caulis or stem, esp. the rudimentary stem seen in theembryo of seed; -- otherwise called a radicle.
Of or pertaining to the older characters of the Arabiclanguage. [Written also Kufic.]
The broken noise of a goose or a hen.
Without created beings; alone.God was alone And creatureless at first. Donne.

The act of consoling; the state of being consoled; allevationof misery or distress of mind; refreshment of spirit; comfort; thatwhich consoles or comforts the spirit.Against such cruelties With inward consolations recompensed. Milton.Are the consolations of God small with thee Job xv. 11.
To bend; to crouch; to cringe. [Obs.]Virtue itself of vice must pardon beg, Yea, curb and woo for leave todo him good. Shak.
Capable of being circumscribed.
Formed into a solid mass; made firm; consolidated. [R.]A gentleman [should learn to ride] while he is tender and the brawnsand sinews of his thighs not fully consolidate. Elyot.
To hold in check; to restrain. [R.] Carlyle.
To render cowardly. [Obs.]God . . . cowardizeth . . . insolent spirits. Bp. Hall.
The collar bone, which is joined at one end to the scapula, orshoulder blade, and at the other to the sternum, or breastbone. Inman each clavicle is shaped like the letter
In a circular manner.
Drawing together; contracting; -- said of the corrugator.[Obs.]
A position in thrusting or parrying, with the inside of thehand turned upward and the point of the weapon toward the adversary'sright breast.
The act of joining, or the state of being joined, together;union. [Obs.] B. Jonson.
A phantasmic or "astral" body deemed to be separable from thephysical body and capable of acting independently; a doppelgänger.
One of the steps in which a gable wall is often finished inplace of a continuous slope; -- also called crowstep.
A Carthusian.
See Cormorant.
Having a clear sound. [Obs.] Ash.
One who chews.
Combined or impregnated with carbonic acid.
Candidacy.
In the way of conclusion; decisively; positively. Burke.
To flow round, as waves. [R.]
A kind of madness in which men fancy themselves changed intodogs, and imitate the voice and habits of that animal.
Conducted with secrecy; clandestine; concealed. [Obs.]Not close and clancular, but frank and open. Barrow.

China; -- an old name for the Celestial Empire, said have beenintroduced by Marco Polo and to be a corruption of the Tartar namefor North China (Khitai, the country of the Khitans.)Better fifty years of Europe than a cycle of Cathay. Tennyson.
Quicklime; also, plaster or mortar. [India] Whitworth.
Plain India muslin, of various qualities and widths.
A canoeman.
To flow across, or in a contrary direction. "His crossflowingcourse." Milton.
A clerk, a clergyman. [R.] Bp. Horsley.

A tenacious, elastic, gummy substance obtained from the milkysap of several plants of tropical South America (esp. theeuphorbiaceous tree Siphonia elastica or Hevea caoutchouc), Asia, andAfrica. Being impermeable to liquids and gases, and not readlyaffected by exposure to air, acids, and alkalies, it is used,especially when vulcanized, for many purposes in the arts and inmanufactures. Also called India rubber (because it was first broughtfrom India, and was formerly used chiefly for erasing pencil marks)and gum elastic. See Vulcanization. Mineral caoutchouc. See underMineral.
Descending from the same stock or ancestor, but not in the sameline or branch or one from the other; -- opposed to lineal.
Deserving compassion or pity; pitiable. [R.] Barrow.
To coo. [Scot.]The owlets hoot, the owlets curr. Wordsworth.
A motion in dancing, when one leg is a little bent, and raisedfrom the floor, and with the other a forward motion is made.Chambers.
A colorless, oily liquid, formerly obtained by distillation ofcolophony. It is regarded as a polymeric form of terebenthene. Calledalso diterebene.
To divide; to mark out into parts or subdivisions. [R.]The crystal surface is comparted all In niches verged with rubies.Glover.

An Appalachian tribe of Indians, formerly inhabiting the regionabout the head waters of the Tennessee River. They are now mostlysettled in the Indian Territory, and have become one of the mostcivilized of the Indian Tribes.

Dependent on conjecture; fancied; imagined; guessed at;undetermined; doubtful.And mak'st conjectural fears to come into me. Shak.A slight expense of conjectural analogy. Hugh Miller.Who or what such editor may be, must remain conjectural. Carlyle.
The marriage tie.
The quality of being casual.
Checking or arresting the heart's action.
Capable of being contrived, planned, invented, or devised.A perpetual motion may seem easily contrivable. Bp. Wilkins.
One of the Cyprinodontidae, a family of fishes including thekillifishes or minnows. See Minnow.
An instrument for determining the dip of beds or strata, pr theslope of an embankment or cutting; a kind of plumb level. Dana.
A verbal or acted enigma based upon a word which has two ormore significant syllables or parts, each of which, as well as theword itself, is to be guessed from the descriptions orrepresentations.
A kind of weir or dam for trapping salmon; also, a hovel.[Scot.]
Of a pertaining to a catastrophe. B. Powell.

An apparatus used in controlling certain kinds of aëroplanes,and consisting principally of a steering column mounted with auniversal joint at the base, which is bellshaped and has attached toit the cables for controlling the wing-warping devices, elevatorplanes, and the like.
Cowardice.
Set; placed. [Obs.] Bacon.
An equal, as in rank, age, prowess, etc.; a companion; acomrade; a mate.And him thus answer 'd soon his bold compeer. Milton.
Bile; choler. [Obs.] Chaucer.
Pertaining to, founded by, of descended from, Charlemagne; as,the Carlovingian race of kings.
See Cibol.
Wearing a collar; -- said of a man or beast used as a bearingwhen a collar is represented as worn around the neck or loins.
In a commanding manner.
One who writes a chronography; a chronologer. Tooke.
Mutually contrived or planned; agreed on; as, concertedschemes, signals. Concerted piece (Mus.), a composition in parts forseveral voices or instrument, as a trio, a quartet, etc.

The act of compelling, or the state of being compelled; the actof driving or urging by force or by physical or moral constraint;subjection to force.If reasons were as plentiful as blackberries, I would give no man areason upon compulsion. Shak.With what complusion and laborious flight We sunk thus low. Milton.

A monk of the prolific branch of the Benedictine Order,established in 1098 at Cîteaux, in France, by Robert, abbot ofMolesme. For two hundred years the Cistercians followed the rule ofSt. Benedict in all its rigor.-- a.
See Christcross-row.
The state or quality of being canonical; agreement with thecanon.
The complement of attributes which make up the notion signifiedby a general term.
A white substance extracted from the lichen, Iceland moss(Cetraria Islandica). It consists of several ingredients, among whichis cetraric acid, a white, crystalline, bitter substance.
See Collop.
A rule for construing written instruments so as to conform asnearly to the intention of the parties as is consistent with law.Mozley & W.

A bird of the Crow family (Fregilus graculus) of Europe. It isof a black color, with a long, slender, curved bill and red legs; --also called chauk, chauk-daw, chocard, Cornish chough, red-leggedcrow. The name is also applied to several allied birds, as the Alpinechough. Cornish chough (Her.), a bird represented black, with redfeet, and beak; -- called also aylet and sea swallow.
A struggling to resist; a striving against; resistance;opposition of nature. [Obs.]
Closely united by the coalescence, or sticking together, ofcontiguous faces, as in the case of the cotyledons of the live-oakacorn.
Serving to commemorate; commomerative. Bp. Hooper.
Without joy, gladness, or comfort.-- Cheer"less*ly, adv.-- Cheer"less*ness, n.My cheerful day is turned to cheerles night. Spenser.

A figure of which the parts of a sentence or paragraph are soarranged that each sicceeding one rise"Tribulation worketh patience, patience experience, and experiencehope" -- a happy climax. J. D. Forbes.

The sperm whale (Physeter macrocephalus). It has in the top ofits head a large cavity, containing an oily fluid, which, afterdeath, concretes into a whitish crystalline substance calledspermaceti. See Sperm whale.
Land of superior quality, on which successive crops are raised.[Scot.] Jamieson.
A road that crosses another; an obscure road intersecting oravoiding the main road.
A present or bonus; -- originally applied to that paid on shipswhich entered the port of Canton. S. Wells Williams.
Relating to commission; of the nature of, or involving,commission. [R.]

A system of healing disease of mind and body which teaches thatall cause and effect is mental, and that sin, sickness, and deathwill be destroyed by a full understanding of the Divine Principle ofJesus' teaching and healing. The system was founded by Rev. MaryBaker Glover Eddy, of Concord, N. H., in 1866, and bases its teachingon the Scriptures as understood by its adherents.
A mock serenade of discordant noises, made with kettles, tinhorns, etc., designed to annoy and insult.
Having a large admixture of small pebbles or gravel; -- said ofa soil. Gardner.

The state or quality of being congenial; natural affinity;adaptation; suitableness. Sir J. Reynolds.If congeniality of tastes could have made a marriage happy, thatunion should have been thrice blessed. Motley.
Of marked ability or excellence. [Slang]
To upset or overturn, as a vessel or other body.But what if carrying sail capsize the boat Byron.

Any Old French epic poem having for its subject events orexploits of early French history, real or legendary, and writtenoriginally in assonant verse of ten or twelve syllables. The mostfamous one is the Chanson de Roland.
To cause to pass through a sieve or riddle; to sift.
In a manner inducing belief; as, I have been credibly informedof the event.
To surrender or transfer, as an army or a fortress, on certainconditions. [R.]
Native silver chloride, a mineral of a white to pale yellow orgray color, darkening on exposure to the light. It may be cut by aknife, like lead or horn (hence called horn silver).
A rushlike plant, the reed mace or cat-tail, or some species ofthe genus Scirpus. See Bulrush.
The theological tenets or doctrines of John Calvin (a Frenchtheologian and reformer of the 16th century) and his followers, or ofthe so-called calvinistic churches.
The creaking of a door, or a noise resembling it. [Obs.]Johnson.
See Cruet.
Circumesophagal.
Running in an opposite direction.
To take form or position, as the parts of a complex structure;to agree with a pattern.Known by the name of uniformity; Where pyramids to pyramids relateAnd the whole fabric doth configurate. Jordan.
See under Cloud.
A common; a piece of land in which two or more persons have acommon right. Bell.

An event; an occurrence; an occasion; a combination ofcircumstances; a case; an act of God. See the Note under Accident.Casus belli, an event or combination of events which is a cause war,or may be alleged as a justification of war.-- Casus fortuitus, an accident against which due prudence could nothave provided. See Act of God, under Act.-- Casus omissus, a case not provided for by the statute.
Entering into covenant; contracting; as, contrahent parties.[Obs.] Mede.
Action in opposition; hindrance resistance.[They] do not . . . overcome the counteraction of a false principleor of stubborn partiality. Johnson.
The state of being curved; a bending in a regular form;crookedness. Holder.
Same as Rose window and Wheel window. Called also Catherine-wheel window.
Capable of being conducted.
Red sulphide of mercury, occurring in brilliant red crystals,and also in red or brown amorphous masses. It is used in medicine.
A female professional singer.
The good humor or mirth indulged in upon festive occasions; aconvivial spirit or humor; festivity.
A cauterizing substance.

A bottle of leather, earthenware, or wood, having ears by whichit was suspended at the side. [Archaic]A youth, that, following with a costrel, bore The means of goodlywelcome, flesh and wine. Tennyson.
Pectinate.
The art of ornamenting metal by means of chasing tools; also, apiece of ornamental work produced in this way.
See Cruddle.
Same as Cespitious. [R.] Gough.
A striped satin made in India. McElrath.
One who claims; a claimant.
A compound of chlorine and iodine. [R.]
Meal-taking; dining or supping. [Obs.] Sir T. Browne.
A parenthetic flourish or flight of ornament in the course of apiece, commonly just before the final cadence.
The crowing noise made by children affected with spasm of thelaryngeal muscles; false croup.
A hydrous silicate of copper, occurring massive, of a blue orgreenish blue color.
A genus of trees including the orange, lemon, citron, etc.,originally natives of southern Asia.
Cotton prepared in sheets or rolls for quilting, upholstering,and similar purposes.

A tall rush or flag (Typha latifolia) growing in marshes, withlong, glat leaves, and having its flowers in a close cylindricalspike at the top of the stem. The leaves are frequently used forseating chairs, making mats, etc. See Catkin.
In a competent manner; adequately; suitably.
The artificial features of a district as distinguished from thenatural.
A yard, courtyard, or piece of ground, included within thefence surrounding a dwelling house. Burrill.
To roll round; to cause to revolve; to put into a circularmotion. Herrick.
See Cirrose.
To press between rollers for the purpose of making smooth andglossy, or wavy, as woolen and silk stuffs, linens, paper, etc. Ure.
Broken in pieces; severed. [Obs.]
That branch of botany which relates to the structure of seedsand fruit.
See Comrade, [Obs.]
A deposit of pebbles, gravel, and ferruginous sand, in whichthe Brazilian diamond is usually found.
An instrument for exhibiting and measuring wave motion; specif.(Elec.),
Same as Cumin.Ye pay tithe of mint, and cummin. Matt. xxiii. 23.
Fit to be felled. [Obs.] Eyelyn.
Caryatids.
Remorse. [Obs.] "With sad commorse." Daniel.
A Hindoo caravansary.

A system of government in which unrestricted power is exercisedby a single person, to whom, as Cæsar or emperor, it has beencommitted by the popular will; imperialism; also, advocacy or supportof such a system of government.
A cistern or vault at the point where a street gutterdischarges into a sewer, to oatch bulky matters which would not passreadly throught the sewer. Knight.
Same as Anthozoa.
A loft for corn; a granary.
To produce cinchonism in; to poison with quinine or withcinchona.
A woman who preserves from loss, injury, etc.
See Cowhage.
The quality or state of being credible; worthness of belief;credibility. [R.] Boyle.
See Cartilaginous. Ray.
One who gives consolation.
Inflammation of the cerebrum.
state or quality of being contrary; opposition; inconsistency;contrariety; perverseness; obstinancy.
A genus of ruminants, including the common goat.
Stupid. [Obs.] Shak.
A saw in the form of a hollow cylinder, with teeth on the endor edge, and operated by a rotative motion.
Pertaining to Copernicus, a Prussian by birth (b. 1473, d.1543), who taught the world the solar system now received, called theCopernican system.
A French mechanical lamp, for lighthouses, in which asuperbundance of oil is pumped to the wick tube by clockwork.
To rub; to come together so as to wear by rubbing; to wear byfriction.Made its great boughs chafe together. Longfellow.The troubled Tiber chafing with her shores. Shak.

A judgment of condemnation entered by a court havingjurisdiction; the act or process of finding guilty, or the state ofbeing found guilty of any crime by a legal tribunal.Conviction may accrue two ways. Blackstone.
A crucible. [Obs.] Chaucer.

Something used to give relish to food, and to gratify thetaste; a pungment and appetizing substance, as pepper or mustard;seasoning.As for radish and the like, they are for condiments, and not fornourishment. Bacon.
To support on crutches; to prop up. [R.]Two fools that crutch their feeble sense on verse. Dryden.

The distance by which one object clears another, as thedistance between the piston and cylinder head at the end of a strokein a steam engine, or the least distance between the point of acogwell tooth and the bottom of a space between teeth of a wheel withwhich it engages. Clearance space (Steam engine), the space inclosedin one end of the cylinder, between the valve or valves and thepiston, at the beginning of a stroke; waste room. It includes thespace caused by the piston's clearance and the space in ports,passageways, etc. Its volume is often expressed as a certainproportion of the volume swept by the piston in a single stroke.
Troubled with bad digestion. [R.] Carlyle.
A hollow case or shell, filled with combustibles, to be thrownfrom a mortar or howitzer, to set fire to buldings, ships, etc.A discharge of carcasses and bombshells. W. Iving.
One who belongs to the ultramontane party in the Latin Church.Shipley.
Without design; accidentally; fortuitously; by chance;occasionally.
A joint patriot.
To serve as a medium for conveying; to transmit, as heat,light, electricity, etc.
Having a chin; -- used chiefly in compounds; as, short-chinned.
Inflammation of the fleshy or muscular substance of the heart.See Endocardris and Pericarditis. Dunglison.

The act of rubbing, or wearing by friction; making by rubbing.Chafing dish, a dish or vessel for cooking on the table, or forkeeping food warm, either by coals, by a lamp, or by hot water; aportable grate for coals.-- Chafing gear (Naut.), any material used to protect sails,rigging, or the like, at points where they are exposed to friction.
The hard parts or skeleton of various Anthozoa, and of a fewHydrozoa. Similar structures are also formed by some Bryozoa.
The act of sleeping, or of lulling, to sleep. [Obs.] Pope.
One who beats with a cudgel. [Written also cudgeller.]

The act of annulling.A general cassation of their constitutions. Motley.Court of cassation, the highest court of appeal in France, which haspower to quash (Casser) or reverse the decisions of the inferiorcourts.
The spiritual court of a diocesan bishop held before hischancellor or commissioner in his cathedral church or elsewhere.Hook.
In a commodious manner.To pass commodiously this life. Milton.
See Calorificient.
In the Philippines, a light, two-wheeled, boxlike vehicleusually drawn by a single native pony and used to convey passengerswithin city limits or for traveling. It is the common publiccarriage.
Having a hundred leaves.
The quality of being capacious, as of a vessel, a reservoir abay, the mind, etc.
The quality of being capillary.
Cursory; hasty. [Obs.]With a cursorary eye o'erglanced the articles. Shak.
One who corrupts, or who upholds corruption. Sydney Smith.
a lynxlike animal of Asia and Africa (Lynx Lybicus).
A kind of oak-leaf gall. See Gall.
A game of football. [Prov. Eng.]
A red liquid or soft resin extracted from various species ofcapsicum.
One who coincides with another in an opinion.
Broken; fissured.Climb the Andeclifted side. Grainger.
See Chrisom. [Obs.] Shak.
Expressing contortion.
The quality of being corky.
That which depends upon guess; guesswork. [R.] Sir T. Browne.
In a manner to promote. [R.]

A genus of plants of the Primrose family, having depressedrounded corms, and pretty nodding flowers with the petals so reflexedas to point upwards, whence it is called rabbit's ears. It is alsocalled sow bread, because hogs are said to eat the corms.

Forgiveness, either express or implied, by a husband of hiswife or by a wife of her husband, for a breach of marital duty, asadultery, with an implied condition that the offense shall not berepeated. Bouvier. Wharton.
The governor of a sanjak or district in Turkey.
To cause to form crystals, or to assume the crystalline form.
An artificer who works in timber; a framer and builder ofhouses, ships, etc.
One who cheats or defrauds.
See Jowl. Sir W. Scott.
A cloth to be laid under a dining table to receive fallingfragments, and keep the carpet or floor clean. [Written alsocrumcloth.]
