The quality or state of being criminal; that which constitutesa crime; guiltiness; guilt.This is by no means the only criterion of criminality. Blackstone.
imp. of Cling. [Obs.]

The operation of drawing blood to or from the surface of theperson by forming a partial vacuum over the spot. Also, sometimes, asimilar operation for drawing pus from an abscess. Cupping glass, aglass cup in which a partial vacuum is produced by heat, in theprocess of cupping.-- Dry cupping, the application of a cupping instrument withoutscarification, to draw blood to the surface, produce counterirritation, etc.-- Wet cupping, the operation of drawing blood by the application ofa cupping instrument after scarification.
A jovial feast or festival; a drunken revel; a carouse.The swains were preparing for a carousal. Sterne.
Related to, or like, the chimæra.
The quality of being conservative.
The art of judging character by the shape and apperance of thehand.

One of a group of compounds including the sugars, starches, andgums, which contain six (or some multiple of six) carbon atoms,united with a variable number of hydrogen and oxygen atoms, but withthe two latter always in proportion as to form water; as dextrose,C6H12O6.
The quality of being consequential.
The phylogeny of groups or families of individuals. Haeckel.
The quality of being cautious.
Crystallizaton.
An instrument in writting whereby a defendant in an actionacknowledges a plaintiff's demand to be just. Mozley & W.
A citizen who put himself under the protection of a man ofdistinction and influence, who was called his patron.
In a consecutive manner; by way of sequence; successively.
Of so much per head; as, a capitatim tax; a capitatim grant.
Any bird of the genus Colius and allied genera. They inhabitAfrica.
A knife; a dagger.
Embroidery in crewels, commonly done upon some plain material,such as linen.
A chapman; a dealer; a merchant. [Obs.]He would have sold his part of paradise For ready money, had he met acopeman. B. Jonson.
Th treat with too great tenderness; to fondle; to indulge; topamper.Cocker thy child and he shall make thee afraid. Ecclesiasticus xxx.9.Poor folks cannot afford to cocker themselves up. J. Ingelow.
The act or process of converting or being converted to a trueChristianity.
A piece in a free form, with frequent digressions from thetheme; a fantasia; -- often called caprice.
See Caribou.

Anything which covers or conceals, as a roof, a screen, awrapper, clothing, etc.Noah removed the covering of the ark. Gen. viii. 13.They cause the naked to lodge without clothing, that they have nocovering in the cold. Job. xxiv. 7.A covering over the well's mouth. 2 Sam. xvii. 19.
The tangent of the complement of an arc or angle. See Illust.of Functions.
Collegiate. [R.]
Said of potash, probably in reference to its having beenobtained from billets of wood by burning. [Obs.]
The first joint of the leg of an insect or crustacean.
One who engages in conversation.

Producing or containing carbon or coal. Carboniferous age(Geol.), the age immediately following the Devonian, or Age offishes, and characterized by the vegatation which formed the coalbeds. This age embraces three periods, the Subcarboniferous, theCarboniferous, and Permian. See Age of acrogens, under Acrogen.-- Carboniferous formation (Geol.), the series of rocks (includingsandstones, shales, limestones, and conglomerates, with beds of coal)which make up the strata of the Carboniferous age or period. See theDiagram under Geology.
Of or pertaining to dinner or supper. [R.]The Romans washed, were anointed, and wore a cenatory garment. Sir T.Browne.
One of a tropical family of snakelike lizards (Chalcidæ),having four small or rudimentary legs.

One who comes, or who has come; one who has arrived, and ispresent. All comers, all who come, or offer, to take part in amatter, especially in a contest or controversy. "To prove it againstall comers." Bp. Stillingfleet.
See Crampet.
A large variety of the domestic fowl, originally from CochinChina (Anam).
Of or pertaining to a cloaca.
In a catholic manner; generally; universally. Sir L. Cary.
Quality of being corrigible; capability of being corrected;corrigibleness.
To enter upon; to begin; to perform the first act of.Many a wooer doth commence his suit. Shak.
An ornament in a building; a corbel.
Cognizance. [R.] Dr. H. More.
An african ape (Anthropithecus troglodytes or Troglodytesniger) which approaches more nearly to man, in most respects, thanany other ape. When full grown, it is from three to four feet high.
Cloistral. [Obs.] I. Walton.
A fellow adventurer.
To declare (a deceased person) a saint; to put in the catalogueof saints; as, Thomas a Becket was canonized.

A clay tablet on which was inscribed a contract, for safekeeping.  Such tablets were inclosed in an outer case (often calledthe envelope), on which was inscribed a duplicate of the inscriptionon the inclosed tablet.
A board with sixty-four squares of alternate color, used forplaying checkers or draughts.
Consisting of, or having, clauses. Smart.
The free-swimming, bivalve larva of certain Bryozoa.
Of, pertaining to, or resembling, a callithump. [U. S.]
See Carbonic acid, under Carbonic.
A female creditor.
A sleeper supporting and connecting the rails, and holding themin place.
Lithography adapted to printing in inks of various colors.
Contrarily. [Obs.]
A rough, hairy, perennial plant of several species, of thegenus Symphytum.
Remaining unchanged or invariable, as a quantity, forc, law,etc.
A long cloak or overcoat, especially one with a hood.
One who collates to a benefice.
Without a chief or leader.
A contrite person. Hooker.
The state or quality of being conjunctive. Johnson.
Such as can be correlated; as, correlatable phenomena.
See Cloak. [Obs.]
See Coke, n.
Pertaining to classification; admitting of classification. "Aclassificatory system." Earle.
Having a cause. [Obs.]
Bear baiting with a dog. Hudibras.
A person or thing that cements.
The faculty of tracing effects to their causes. G. Combe.
An instrument to test the decoloring or bleaching power ofchloride of lime.
State of citizenship. [R.] Dyer.
Union of things in one mass or body. [R.] Dr. H. More.
One who lives on the common, without paying any rent, or havingland of his own.

Hidden; kept from sight; secreted.-- Con*ceal"ed*ly (, adv.-- Con*ceal"ed*ness, n. Concealed weapons (Law), dangerous weaponsso carried on the person as to be knowingly or willfully concealedfrom sight, -- a practice forbidden by statute.
A partaker of supremacy; one jointly supreme. Shak.
See Cion, and Scion.
Successor or vicar; -- a title of the successors of Mohammedboth as temporal and spiritual rulers, now used by the sultans ofTurkey, [Writting also calif.]
A telephone transmitter in which a carbon contact is used.
Force; compulsion, either in restraining or impelling. Sojth.
The practice of hanging, upon the cultivated fig tree, branchesof the wild fig infested with minute hymenopterous insects.
To grow into a canser; to become cancerous. Boyle.
Of or pertaining to flesh; specif. (Physiol. Chem.),
A framework of timbers and plank backing for a shaft lining, toprevent caving, percolation of water, etc.
Of the nature of cedar. [R.]
Without a cloud; clear; bright.A cloudless winter sky. Bankroft.-- Cloud"less*ly, adv.-- Cloud"less*ness, n.
With temporary gills: -- applied to those Amphibia in which thegills do not remain in adult life.
The state of being curable; curableness.
An officer who ranks next above a captain; sometimes, bycourtesy, the senior captain of a squadron. The rank of commodorecorresponds with that of brigadier general in the army.
Same as Impanator.
Like, or pertaining to, the crocodile; characteristic of thecrocodile.-- n.

A venereal sore or ulcer; specifically, the initial lesion oftrue syphilis, whether forming a distinct ulcer or not; -- calledalso hard chancre, indurated chancre, and Hunterian chancre. Softchancre. A chancroid. See Chancroid.
See Clinker-built.
A bale or package. covered with hide, or with wood bound withhide; as, a ceroon of indigo, cochineal, etc.
A plea, in which it is alleged that the woman suing for dowerwas not lawfully married to the man in whose lands she seeks to beendowed, but that she was his concubine.
The tin ore which collects in the central part of the washingpit or buddle.
A woman born, or dwelling, in the country, as opposed to thecity; a woman born or dwelling in the same country with anothernative or inhabitant. Shak.
See Cléché.

One of the sections into which a church or congregation isdivided, and which is under the supervision of a class leader. Classof a curve (Math.), the kind of a curve as expressed by the number oftangents that can be drawn from any point to the curve. A circle isof the second class.-- Class meeting (Methodist Church), a meeting of a class under thecharge of a class leader, for counsel and relegious instruction.
Charcoal; a cinder. [Obs.] DeFoe.
One who computes or reckons: one who estimates or considers theforce and effect of causes, with a view to form a correct estimate ofthe effects.Ambition is no exact calculator. Burke.
Affected with compunction; conscience-stricken. [Obs.]
A person employed to scare off crows; hence, a scarecrow.[Obs.]Scaring the ladies like a crowkeeper. Shak.
The state of being childless.
To cause an overfullness of the blood vessels (esp. thecapillaries) of an organ or part.
One of two magistrates of Rome who took a register of thenumber and property of citizens, and who also exercised the office ofinspector of morals and conduct.
The sterm of a tree., esp. a sterm without a branch, as of apalm or a tree fern; also, the pernnial rootstock of an herbaceousplant.
A calculating machine; an arithmometer.
A strap leading from the bellyband to the lower part of thecollar, to keep the collar in place.
The act or practice of pitting gamecocks to fight.
In two figures having relative motion, one of the two curveswhich are the loci of the instantaneous center.
Meeting in one point.
A hydrous silicate of magnesium, allied to serpentine,occurring in waxlike masses of a yellow or greenish color.
A concretion of mineral matter within a leaf or other part of aplant.
That may be circulated.

A disease communicable by contact with a patient suffering fromit, or with some secretion of, or object touched by, such a patient.Most such diseases have already been proved to be germ diseases, andtheir communicability depends on the transmission of the livinggerms.  Many germ diseases are not contagious, some special method oftransmission or inoculation of the germs being required.
Same as Cryptographer.
State or quality of being conical.
The art of measuring the world or the universe. Blount.
Penuriousness. [Obs.]By cause of his skarsete and chincherie. Caucer.
A message sent by a submarine telegraphic cable.
A favorite dish in Barbary. See Couscous.
A cyst. See Cyst.
Apt to cling; adhesive. [R.]
The crushing of a child's head, as with the cranioclast orcraniotomy forceps in cases of very difficult delivery. Dunglison.
One of the Chromidæ, a family of fresh-water fishes abundant inthe tropical parts of America and Africa. Some are valuable foodfishes, as the bulti of the Nile.
The chief magistrate of a Spanish town.
One who advocates a constitutional form of government; aconstitutionalist.
Pertaining to the cilia, or eyelashes. Also applied to specialparts of the eye itself; as, the ciliary processes of the choroidcoat; the ciliary muscle, etc.
Of or pertaining to the centumviri, or to a centumvir.
A tax or imposition an a dwelling within a certain distance ofa castle, for the purpose of maintaining watch and ward in it;castle-ward.
One who calcimines.
Any plant of the natural order Cycadeceæ, as the sago palm,etc.
A small rodent (Chinchilla lanigera), of the size of a largesquirrel, remarkable for its fine fur, which is very soft and of apearly gray color. It is a native of Peru and Chili.
To arrange or dispose in a certain form, figure, or shape.Bentley.
Expressing condolence. Smart.

Propositions which directly and destructively contradict eachother, but of which the falsehood of one does not establish the truthof the other.If two universals differ in quality, they are contraries; as, everyvine is a tree; no vine is a tree. These can never be both truetogether; but they may be both false. I. Watts.
The smaller intestines of swine, etc., fried for food.
Signing some important public document with another or withothers; as, a treaty violated by one of the cosignitary powers.
Producing or containing columbium.
Pertaining to food; edible. Johnson.
The reciprocal existence in each other of the three persons ofthe Trinity.
An officer in the Court of Chancery, whose business is to makeout original writs.
A tree (Galactodendron utile or Brosimum Galactodendron) ofSouth America, which yields, on incision, a nourishing fluid,resembling milk.
A floss or waste obtained from the cocoon after the silk hasbeen reeled off, used for shag.
A Highland robber: a kind of irregular soldier. [Scot.] Sir W.Scott.
The red-bellied wood pecker (Melanerpes Carolinus).
A corolla.
Inactive; dormant [Obs.] W. Montagu.
A leap that a horse makes with all fours, upwards only, withoutadvancing, but with a kick or jerk of the hind legs when at theheight of the leap.
See 3d Chase, n., 3.
A small can or drinking vessel.
Containing, or derived from, carbon and nitrogen. Carbazoticacid (Chem.), picric acid. See under Picric.
A young capon. [R.] Chapman.
A male person castrated for the purpose of improving his voicefor singing; an artificial, or male, soprano. Swift.
Any one of three metameric substances, CH3.C6H4.OH, homologouswith and resembling phenol. They are obtained from coal tar and woodtar, and are colorless, oily liquids or solids.
In Louisiana, a person reputed to be Acadian French descent.
One skilled in cryptogamic botany.
A cave, grotto, or subterraneous place of large extent used forthe burial of the dead; -- commonly in the plural.
Extremely; odiously; detestably. [Colloq.] "Confoundedly sick."Goldsmith.
Partnership; as to go in cahoot with a person. [Slang,southwestern U. S.] Bartlett.
The doctrine that all things exist or are controlled by chance.
In a concerned manner; solicitously; sympathetically.
Am, is, or are, not able; -- written either as one word or two.
One who, or that which, contains.
A nun. [R.] Shak.
Chimerical.
A form of malarial fever occurring along the Chagres River,Panama.
Bearing the cross; marked with the figure of a cross. Sir. T.Browne.
Plain; undyed; -- applied to Indian silk. -- n.
A genus of poisonous serpents, including the rattlesnakes.
Steel blue; of the color of tempered steel.
The act or process of confuting; refutation.  "For theedification of some and the confutation of others."  Bp. Horne.
The pharalope; -- so called because its toes are like thecoot's.
See under Tennis.
See Check.
A girl; a maiden. [Anglo-Irish]
A translucent, elastic tissue; gristle.

A california woodpecker (Melanerpes formicivorus), noted forits habit of inserting acorns in holes which it drills in trees. Theacorns become infested by insect larvæ, which, when grown, areextracted for food by the bird.
One of a fraternity of seculars, also called Penitents.
A poetic foot, composed of one short syllable between two longones (-Bentley.
Of or pertaining to the act of consecration; dedicatory.The consecratory prayer. Bp. Burnet.
A cooper's tool for making the grooves for the heads of casks,etc.; also, the groove itself.
Moving by means of cilia, or cilialike organs; as, theciliograde Medusæ.
Signals made by burning lights of different colors and used byvessels at sea, and in the life-saving service; -- named after theirinventor.
A measure of grain equal to 0.7218 of an imperial quarter, or5.95 Winchester bushels. [Russia]

A leguminous climbing plant of the genus Mucuna, having crookedpods covered with sharp hairs, which stick to the fingers, causingintolerable itching. The spiculæ are sometimes used in medicine as amechanical vermifuge. [Written also couhage, cowage, and cowitch.]
Pertaining to, derived from, or containing, cadmium; as, cadmicsulphide.
Nasal catarrh.
A voracious appetite, like that of a starved dog.
See Commorancy.
On the Austrian side of the river Leitha; Austrian.

The larval state of a butterfly or any lepidopterous insect;sometimes, but less commonly, the larval state of other insects, asthe sawflies, which are also called false caterpillars. The truecaterpillars have three pairs of true legs, and several pairs ofabdominal fleshy legs (prolegs) armed with hooks. Some are hairy,others naked. They usually feed on leaves, fruit, and succulentvegetables, being often very destructive, Many of them are popularlycalled worms, as the cutworm, cankerworm, army worm, cotton worm,silkworm.
Furnished with cannon. [Poetic] "Gilbralter's cannoned steep."M. Arnold.
Tending to contract; having the property or power or power ofcontracting.
Compact; pressed close; concentrated; firmly united.
To make sad. [Obs.]To deject and contrist myself. Sterne.
A present, as of corn, wine, or oil, made by a Roman emperor tothe soldiers or the people; -- so called because measured to each ina congius. Addison.
A speaker in a colloquy or dialogue. Malone.
A perfumed liquid, composed of alcohol and certain aromaticoils, used in the toilet; -- called also cologne water and eau decologne.
See Cæsura.
Skill in driving a coach.
A woman invested with authority to command. Hooker.
A style of type having a narrow and heave face. It is made inall sizes.
A filament. [R.]
A receptacle, as in a dining room, for a few bottles of wine orliquor, made in the form of a chest or coffer, or a deep drawer in asideboard, and usually lined with metal.
In a contingent manner; without design or foresight;accidentally.
The space between the strands on the outside of a rope. Knight.
An instrument measuring the dimensions of the head of a fetusduring delivery.
Contemptuously. [R.]
A joint legatee.
Serving to fulfill.Completory of ancient presignifications. Barrow.

Of camel's hair. Camel's-hair pencil, a small brush used bypainters in water colors, made of camel's hair or similar materials.-- Camel's-hair shawl. A name often given to a cashmere shawl. SeeCashmere shawl under Cashmere.
A joint guardian.
Prison fees. [Obs.]
In the manner or form of an ecclesiastical chapter. Sterne.
Perishable; frail; transitory. [Obs.] Hickes.The caduke pleasures of his world. Bp. Fisher.
A kind of roughness on the surface of glass, which clouds itstransparency. [Written also crizzeling and crizzle.]

A sound like the cry of a cat, such as is made in playhouses toexpress dissatisfaction with a play; also, a small shrill instrumentfor making such a noise.Upon the rising of the curtain. I was very much surprised with thegreat consort of catcalls which was exhibited. Addison.
A chime of bells diatonically tuned, played by clockwork or byfinger keys.

The process of estimating the caliber a tube, as of athermometer tube, in order to graduate it to a scale of degrees;also, more generally, the determination of the true value of thespaces in any graduated instrument.
Pertaining to, or according to the rules of, counterpoint.
The taking of the position of a candidate; specifically, thepreaching of a clergyman with a view to settlement. [Cant, U. S.]
In a cosmographic manner; in accordance with cosmography.
To walk round about.-- Cir`cum*am`bu*la"tion, n.
A series of formative cells lying outside of the wood properand inside of the inner bark. The growth of new wood takes place inthe cambium, which is very soft.
A mineral, the hydrous silicate of zinc.
A comprehensive division of animals including all Vertebratatogether with the Tunicata, or all those having a dorsal nervouscord.
A degeneration of animal tissue into a cheesy or curdy mass.
Pertaining to, indicating, or attended with, congestion in somepart of the body; as, a congestive fever.
The quality of being conscionable; reasonableness. Johnson.
A red wine from Chambertin near Dijon, in Burgundy.

A proteid substance present in both the animal and thevegetable kingdom. In the animal kindom it is chiefly found in milk,and constitutes the main part of the curd separated by rennet; in thevegetable kingdom it is found more or less abundantly in the seeds ofleguminous plants. Its reactions resemble those of alkali albumin.[Written also caseine.]
A small village containing a church. [Scot.] Sir W. ScottSitting at the clachon alehouse. R. L. Stevenson.
Having the power to cause coagulation; as, a coagulative agent.Boyle.
Pertaining to chorography.-- Cho`ro*graph"ic*al*ly, adv.
One of the ten laws or precepts given by God to the Israelitesat Mount Sinai.

A badge, usually in the form of a rosette, or knot, andgenerally worn upon the hat; -- used as an indication of military ornaval service, or party allegiance, and in England as a part of thelivery to indicate that the wearer is the servant of a military ornaval officer.Seduced by military liveries and cockades. Burke.
America; the United States; -- a poetical appellation given inhonor of Columbus, the discoverer. Dr. T. Dwight.
A thick gruel of oatmeal and milk or water; food of theporridge kind. [Scot.]
Belonging a prison. [R.] Foxe.
A callous growth, esp. one the foot; a corn.
See Compony.
Coincidence. [R.]
An old mname for the harpsichord.
To fasten with a cotter.
Catarrhal. [R.]
The faculty of seeing; sight; eye.
A name for a negro. [Slang]
That part of military force which serves on horseback.
Convex on one side, and concave on the other. The curves of theconvex and concave sides may be alike or may be different. SeeMeniscus.
A key adapted to open only one of a set of locks; --distinguished from a master key.
To chirp or to make a mournful cry, as a bird. [Obs.] Huloet.

A cruciferous plant (Brassica sinapistrum) with yellow flowers;wild mustard. It is troublesome in grain fields. Called alsochardock, chardlock, chedlock, and kedlock. Jointed charlock, Whitecharlock, a troublesome weed (Raphanus Raphanistrum) with straw-colored, whitish, or purplish flowers, and jointed pods: wild radish.
Pertaining to, caused by, or affected with, cirrhosis; as,cirrhotic degeneration; a cirrhotic liver.
A court consisting of military or naval officers, for the trialof one belonging to the army or navy, or of offenses against militaryor naval law.

A piece or point of land, extending beyind the adjacent coastinto the sea or a lake; a promonotory; a headland. Cape buffalo(Zoöl.) a large and powerful buffalo of South Africa (BubalusCaffer). It is said to be the most dangerous wild beast of Africa.See Buffalo, 2.-- Cape jasmine, Cape jassamine. See Jasmine.-- Cape pigeon (Zoöl.), a petrel (Daptium Capense) common off theCape of Good Hope. It is about the size of a pigeon.-- Cape wine, wine made in South Africa [Eng.] -- The Cape, the Capeof Good Hope, in the general sense of southern extremity of Africa.Also used of Cape Horn, and, in New England, of Cape Cod.
Of or pertaining to a clerk. Cranmer.
A covenant. [Obs.] Shak.
The quality of being cognoscible. Cudworth.
Consisting of the same material. [Obs.] Bacon.
A cross having the three upper ends crossed, so as to fromthree small crosses.
The complement of the latitude, or the difference between anylatitude and ninety degrees.
An East Indian tree (Averrhoa Carambola), and its acid, juicyfruit; called also Coromandel gooseberry.
A convent or monastery. [Obs.] Bale. Covent Garden, a largesquare in London, so called because originally it was the garden of amonastery.
Having bent ribs.
One who conquers. The Conqueror (Eng. Hist.). William theNorman (1027-1067) who invaded England, defeated Harold in the battleof Hastings, and was crowned king, in 1066.
A rodent of the genera cavia and Dolichotis, as the guinea pig(Cavia cabaya). Cavies are natives of South America. Water cavy(Zoöl.), The capybara.
A particular rural district; a country neighborhood. [Eng.] W.Black. Blackmore.
A joint executor.
The act or process of conciliating; the state of beingconciliated.The house has gone further; it has declared conciliation admissibleprevious to any submission on the part of America. Burke.
A disease in which the body is colored blue in its surface,arising usually from a malformation of the heart, which causes animperfect arterialization of the blood; blue jaundice.

To extend through the same space or time with another; toextend to the same degree.According to which the least body may be coextended with thegreatest. Boyle.Has your English language one single word that is coextended throughall these significations Bentley.

Pertaining to chemistry; characterized or produced by theforces and operations of chemistry; employed in the processes ofchemistry; as, chemical changes; chemical comnbinations. Chemicalattraction or affinity. See under Attraction.
A fish of the genus Coryphæna. See Dolphin. (2)
Of or pertaining both to the cricoid and the thyroidcartilages.
Cipher; something written in cipher. "Decipherers ofcryptograph." J. Earle.
Pertaining to, or resembling, a corolla; having the form ortexture of a corolla.

One who cries; one who makes proclamation. Specifically, anofficer who proclams the orders or directions of a court, or whogives public notice by loud proclamation; as, a town-crier.He openeth his mouth like a crier. Ecclus. xx. 15.
That may be challenged.
Athwart; adversely; unfortunately; peevishly; fretfully; withill humor.
The essential principle of cacao; -- now called theobromine.
Like ashes; having the color of ashes, -- as the corticalsubstance of the brain.
Pertaining to an advocate, or to the maintenance and defense ofsuits.
Lameness. [R.] Johnson.

The person to whom goods or other things are consigned; afactor; -- correlative to consignor.Consigner and consignee are used by merchants to express generallythe shipper of merchandise, and the person to whom it is addressed,by bill of lading or otherwise. De Colange.
A soldier armed with a cuirass. Milton.
Heated to whiteness; glowing with heat. "A candent vessel."Boyle.
The chick-pea.
A genus of a single species belonging to the order Uricaceæ;hemp. Cannabis Indica (, the Indian hemp, a powerful narcotic, nowconsidered a variety of the common hemp.
A small line made of spun yarn, to bind or worm cables, seizetackles, etc.
Indistinctly crystalline; -- applied to rocks and minerals,whose state of aggregation is so fine that no distinct particles arevisible, even under the microscope.
A violent and widely extended change in the surface of theearth, as, an elevation or subsidence of some part of it, effected byinternal causes. Whewell.
Having the measure of a cubit.
Vaulting formed by the intersection of two or more simplevaults.
With clattering.
A licensed or official coal measurer in London. See Meter.Simmonds.
Act of fastening. [Obs.]
A captive; a prisoner. [Obs.]Avarice doth tyrannize over her caitiff and slave. Holland.
See Cheve, v. i. [Obs.]
A procession of persons on horseback; a formal, pompous marchof horsemen by way of parade.He brought back war-worn cavalcade to the city. Prescott.
(adv. In a contrary manner; in opposition; on the other side;in opposite ways.
Affording chondrin.

Of or pertaining to the Corinthian order of architecture,invented by the Greeks, but more commonly used by the Romans.This is the lightest and most ornamental of the three orders used bythe Greeks. Parker.
The connecting crook of a harrow. [Prov. Eng.]
An officer appointed and commissioned to collect and receivecustoms, duties, taxes, or toll.A great part of this is now embezzled . . . by collectors, and otherofficers. Sir W. Temple.
Wanting passion or feeling; indifferent.-- Cold"-heart`ed*ness, n.
The state or quality of being crisp.
Producing reeds; reedy.
One who holds the theory or catastrophism.
The fight of a hawk.

Pertaining to an acid so called. Carbamic acid (Chem.), anamido acid, NH2.CO2H, not existing in the free state, but occurringas a salt of ammonium in commercial ammonium carbonate; -- calledalso amido formic acid.
A dealer in cogware or coarse cloth. [Obs.] Wright.
One who claims; one who asserts a right or title; a claimer.
In a central manner or situation.
Of or pertaining to the chalaza.
Young cabbage, used as "greens"; esp. a kind cultivated forthat purpose; colewort. [Colloq. Souther U. S.]
A folded piece of cloth, pledget of lint, etc., used to coverthe dressing of wounds, and so placed as, by the aid of a bandage, tomake due pressure on any part.
Having the power of digesting or ripening; digestive.Hence the concoctive powers, with various art, Subdue the cruderaliments to chyle. J. Armstrong.
A product from cottonseed, used as lard.
See Chaceleon. [Obs.]
A so-called immediate inference which consists in denying theoriginal subject of the contradictory predicate; e.g.: Every S is P;therefore, no Not-P is S.
The answer to the theme (dux) in a fugue.
Producing horns; forming horn.
One who cites. [R]
A very pure form of gelatin.
Customary.
Of or pertaining to a climate; depending on, or limited by, aclimate.
That confides; trustful; unsuspicious.-- Con*fid"ing*ly, adv.-- Con*fid"ing*ness, n.
An oily substance, C8H14, obtained from several derivatives ofconine.

An elementary substance, not metallic in its nature, which ispresent in all organic compounds. Atomic weight 11.97. Symbol C. itis combustible, and forms the base of lampblack and charcoal, andenters largely into mineral coals. In its pure crystallized state itconstitutes the diamond, the hardest of known substances, occuring inmonometric crystals like the octahedron, etc. Another modification isgraphite, or blacklead, and in this it is soft, and occurs inhexagonal prisms or tables. When united with oxygen it forms carbondioxide, commonly called carbonic acid, or carbonic oxide, accordingto the proportions of the oxygen; when united with hydrogen, it formsvarious compounds called hydrocarbons. Compare Diamond, and Graphite.Carbon compounds, Compounds of carbon (Chem.), those compoundsconsisting largely of carbon, commonly produced by animals andplants, and hence called organic compounds, though their synthesismay be effected in many cases in the laboratory.The formation of the compounds of carbon is not dependent upon thelife process. I. Remsen-Carbon dioxide, Carbon monoxide. (Chem.) See under Carbonic.-- Carbon light (Elec.), an extremely brilliant electric lightproduced by passing a galvanic current through two carbon points keptconstantly with their apexes neary in contact.-- Carbon point (Elec.), a small cylinder or bit of gas carbon movedforward by clockwork so that, as it is burned away by the electriccurrent, it shall contantly maintain its proper relation to theopposing point.-- Carbon tissue, paper coated with gelatine and pigment, used inthe autotype process of photography. Abney.-- Gas carbon, a compact variety of carbon obtained as anincrustation on the interior of gas retorts, and used for themanufacture of the carbon rods of pencils for the voltaic, arc, andfor the plates of voltaic batteries, etc.
A kind of fine, hard, white or mottled soap, made with oliveand soda; also, a soap made in imitation of the above-described soap.
One who covets.
A receptacle for clothes.
Having the property of condensing.
Dovetail.
Form or development of the skull; as, the races of man differgreatly in cephalism.
An apparatus for taking the conformation of anything, as of thehead for fitting a hat, or, in craniometry, finding the largesthorizontal area of the head.
Relating to compromise. [R.] Chalmers.
The dark space within the negative-pole glow at the cathode ofa vacuum tube, observed only when the pressure is low enough to givea striated discharge; -- called also Crookes layer.
See Crewel.
Cast steel made by fusing in crucibles crude or scrap steel,wrought iron, and other ingredients and fluxes.
Abounding in cobwebs. "The cobwebbed cottage." Young.
One of the separable carpels of a dry fruit.
Feeling or expressing commiseration. Todd.
The larva of two species of geometrid moths which are veryinjurious to fruit and shade trees by eating, and often entirelydestroying, the foliage. Other similar larvæ are also calledcankerworms.
Inflammation of the conjunctiva.
A hood-shaped organ, resembling a cowl or monk's hood, ascertain concave and arched sepals or petals.
A chromoplastid.
A small hill or mount. [Obs.]And watered park, full of fine collines and ponds. Evelyn.
See Capelin.
A genus of composite plants, mostly perennial, and of manyspecies including the many varieties of garden chrysanthemums (annualand perennial), and also the feverfew and the oxeye daisy.
To annex with something else.

A smokeless powder composed of nitroglycerin, guncotton, andmineral jelly, and used by the British army and in other services. Inmaking it the ingredients are mixed into a paste with the addition ofacetone and pressed out into cords  (of various diameters) resemblingbrown twine, which are dried and cut to length. A variety containingless nitroglycerin than the original is known  as cordite M. D.
Without pause or end; incessant.
The substitution of business principles and methods forpolitical methods in the conduct of the civil service. esp. the meritsystem instead of the spoils system in making appointments to office.

A printing process depending on the effect of light onbichromatized gelatin. Paper coated with a mixture of the gelatin anda pigment is called carbon paper or carbon tissue. This is exposedunder a negative and the film is transferred from the paper to someother support and developed by washing (the unexposed portions beingdissolved away). If the process stops here it is called singletransfer; if the image is afterward transferred in order to give anunreversed print, the method is called double transfer.
An extract or preparation of opium, used in China and India forsmoking. Balfour.
A superior wine, white and red, from Constantia, in CapeColony.
A flowerless plant which forms a true fruit as the result offertilization, as the red seaweeds, the Ascomycetes, etc.
A sweet wine. See Calcavella.
See Cupel.
See Cundurango.
Of or pertaining to animals of the tortoise kind.-- n.
A gripping device, as for stretching wire, etc., consisting oftwo jaws so attached to a ring that they are closed by pulling on thering.

The presiding justice, or principal judge, of a court. LordChief Justice of England, The presiding judge of the Queen's BenchDivision of the High Court of Justice. The highest judicial officerof the realm is the Lord High Chancellor.-- Chief Justice of the United States, the presiding judge of theSupreme Court, and Highest judicial officer of the republic.
One skilled in, or who practices, cranioscopy.It was found of equal dimension in a literary man whose skull puzziedthe cranioscopists. Coleridge.
Migration together. [R.] Woodward.

A disease of the liver in which it usually becomes smaller insize and more dense and fibrous in consistence; hence sometimesapplied to similar changes in other organs, caused by increase in thefibrous framework and decrease in the proper substance of the organ.
Centripetency.

The process by which miners seek to discover metallic lodes. Itconsist in sinking small pits through the superficial deposits to thesolid rock, and then driving from one pit to another across thedirection of the vein, in such manner as to cross all the veinsbetween the two pits.
One skilled in some trade or manual occupation; an artificer; amechanic.
A condition of lowered functional activity, without visiblestructural change, produced in an organ by a shock, as by fall orblow; as, a concussion of the brain.

Assemblage of related things; colletion; complication.This parable of the wedding supper comprehends in it the wholecomplex of all the blessings and privileges exhibited by the gospel.South.Complex of lines (Geom.), all the possible straight lines in spacebeing considered, the entire system of lines which satisfy a singlerelation constitute a complex; as, all the lines which meet a givencurve make up a complex. The lines which satisfy two relationsconstitute a congruency of lines; as, the entire system of lines,each one of which meets two given surfaces, is a congruency.
Of or pertaining to a century; as, a centurial sermon. [R.]
The state of being a cur; one who is currish. [Jocose]How durst he, I say, oppose thy curship! Hudibras.
Of or pertaining to Caledonia or Scotland; Scottish; Scotch.-- n.
Participation of the same nature; natural union. I. Walton.
A form of prayer in which public confession of sins is made.
A kind of frenzy in which the patient is tormented by fantasticvisions and want of sleep. Dunglison.
A member of the Conservative party.
Flattened to a level surface. [R.]
To levy certain exactions or tribute upon; to lodge and eat atthe expense of. See Coshering.
Pertaining to, or containing, chlorite; as, chloritic sand.
Mutual help; coöperation. [R.] Johnson.
An impure aqueous solution of chloride of aluminium, used as anantiseptic and disinfectant.
A simpleton; a gull; a dupe. [Obs.] B. Jonson.
Of the color of lavender; pale blue with a slight mixture ofgray. Lindley.
Applied to those nerve fibers which go from the brain to thespinal cord, and so transfer cerebral impulses (centrifugalimpressions) outwards.
Any invigorating and stimulating preparation; as, a peppermintcordial.
The radical (CO)'\'b7, occuring, always combined, in manycompounds, as the aldehydes, the ketones, urea, carbonyl chloride,etc.
That which is suitable, agreeable, or convenient.And they missed Their wonted convenance, cheerly hid the loss.Emerson.
One who confides.
Partial blindness, or a tendency to blindness. [R.] Sir T.Browne.
A tribe or confederacy of North American Indians, including theMuskogees, Seminoles, Uchees, and other subordinate tribes. Theyformerly inhabited Georgia, Florida, and Alabama.
A small visorless cap, worn by members of German student corps.It is made in the corps colors, and usually bears the insignia of thecorps.
Positivism; the positive philosophy. See Positivism.
Of or pertaining to marriage, or the marriage state; conjugal;nuptial.Nor Eve the rites Mysterious of connubial love refused. Milton.Kind, connubial tenderness. Goldsmith.
Convincing. [R.]The best and most convictive argument. Glanwill.-- Con*vict"ive*ly, adv.-- Con*vict"ive*ness, n.
Counteracting the effects of stimulants; relating to a courseof medical treatment based on a theory of contrastimulants.-- n. (Med.)
An a
A tabular statement of the dates of feasts, offices, saints'days, etc., esp. of those which are liable to change yearly accordingto the varying date of Easter.
A crucible or melting pot; a cruset. Crabb.
The peculiar action by which the surface of a liquid, where itis in contact with a solid (as in a capillary tube), is elevated ordepressed; capillary attraction.
The act of seizing or taking hold of Catching bargain (Law), abargain made with an heir expectant for the purchase of hisexpectancy at an inadequate price. Bouvier.
Any item of movable or immovable property except the freehold,or the things which are parcel of it. It is a more extensive termthan goods or effects.
A bluish violet, crystalline substance obtained in thepurification of crude wood vinegar. It is regarded as a complexquinone derivative of diphenyl; -- called also cedriret.
A superintendent or keeper of a church's valuables; achurchwarden. [Obs.] Bailey.
Commixture. Shak.
A tropical humming bird of the genus Lophornis, with veryelegant neck plumes. Several species are known. See Illustrationunder Spangle, v. t.
Chronic.Partly on a chronical, and partly on a topical method. J. A.Alexander.
The district of a collector of customs; a collectorship.
A fleshy excrescence; esp. a small excrescence or fungousgrowth. Wiseman.
One who chimes.
A species of Galium (G. Aparine), having a fruit set withhooked bristles, which adhere to whatever they come in contact with;-- called also, goose grass, catchweed, etc.

A thick, black, tarry liquid, obtained by the distillation ofbituminous coal in the manufacture of illuminating gas; used formaking printer's ink, black varnish, etc. It is a complex mixturefrom which many substances have been obtained, especiallyhydrocarbons of the benzene or aromatic series.
A prefix denoting that chlorine is an ingredient in thesubstance named.
Washing; cleansing.
Bred by hand; domesticated; petted.He brought his cade lamb with him. Sheldon.

To talk or confer secretly and confidentially; to converse,especially with evil intentions; to plot mischief. [Archaic orColloq.]Pray go in; and, sister, salve the matter, Collogue with her again,and all shall be well. Greene.He had been colloguing with my wife. Thackeray.
harmonizing together; accordant; as, consonant tones, consonantchords.
The infliction of the death penalty upon one person in everyhundred, as in cases of mutiny.
A quaver. [Obs.]
To compose; to settle; to arrange. [Obs.]A good pretense for componing peace. Strype.
A variety of Cratægus, or hawthorn (C. Crus-galli), havinglong, straight thorns; -- called also Cockspur thorn.
The use of light, frivolous language by way of fun or ridicule;raillery; banter.
See Cognizor. [Obs.]
Having tthe character of a child; belonging, or appropriate, toa child. Gower.
Tending to, or intended for, correction; used for correction;as, a correctional institution.
Resembling, or composed of, cinders; full of cinders.
Shaped like a little column, or columella.
Manuscript or printed matter to be set up in type; as, theprinters are calling for more copy.

A figure by which one word is wrongly put for another, or bywhich a word is wrested from its true signification; as, "To takearms against a sea of troubles. " Shak. "Her voice was but the shadowof a sound." Young.
See A cappella.
The stars also called Charles's Wain, the Great Bear, or theDipper.The Pleiads, Hyads, and the Northern Car. Dryden.

A stereotype plate or any similar reproduction of ornament, orlettering, in relief. Cliché casting, a mode of obtaining animpression from a die or woodcut, or the like, by striking itsuddenly upon metal which has been fused and is just becoming solid;also, the casting so obtained.

A comparatively rare element occurring most abundantly in themineral chromite. Atomic weight 52.5. Symbol Cr. When isolated it isa hard, brittle, grayish white metal, fusible with difficulty. Itschief commercial importance is for its compounds, as potassiumchromate, lead chromate, etc., which are brilliantly colored and areused dyeing and calico printing. Called also chrome.
A sash for the waist; a girdle. [India]
The department of science (as of ethnology or archæology) whichdeals with the shape, size, proportions, indications, etc., ofskulls; the study of skulls.
Agency in common; joint agency or agent. Coleridge.
Suretyship.
A chicken; a fowl; also, a trivial term of endearment for achild.
Broken; uneven. [Obs.] "Confragose cataracts."  Evelyn.
See Coellac.
The office or power of a censor; as, to stand for a censorship.Holland.The press was not indeed at that moment under a general censorship.Macaulay.
To kick.
A catechumen. Bp. Morton.
Of or pertaining to a horse.-- n.
A form of stitch, where the stitches are diagonal and in pairs,the thread of one stitch crossing that of the other. "Tent and cross-stitch." Sir W. Scott.-- Cross"-stitch`, v. t. & i.
To make hollow; to scoop out. [Obs.]The mouldred earth cav'd the banke. Spenser.

To twist, or twist together; to turn awry; to bend; to distort;to wrest.The vertebral arteries are variously contorted. Ray.Kant contorted the term category from the proper meaning ofattributed. Sir W. Hamilton.
Capable of according; agreeing; harmonious.
Having a clear understanding; quick of perception; intelligent."He was laborious and clear-headed." Macaulay.-- Clear"-head`ed*ness, n.
Relating to, or causing, catalysis. "The catalytic power is illunderstood." Ure. Catalytic force, that form of chemical energyformerly supposed to determine catalysis.

Having curls; curly; sinuous; wavy; as, curled maple (maplehaving fibers which take a sinnuous course). Curled hair (Com.), thehair of the manes and tails of horses, prepared for upholsterypurposes. McElrath.
A plotting together; a confederacy in some evil design; aconspiracy.I know their complot is to have my life. Shak.
Any chemical group or residue (as NO
A coverlet.All the coverlid was clocth of gold. Tennyson.
Having surrendered the effects; as, a cessionary bankrupt.Martin.
The chestnut tree. [Obs.]Wilwe, elm, plane, assch, box, chesteyn. Chaucer.
Of the goat kind.
See Borneol.
Any crop grown between the rows of another crop or intermediatebetween two crops in ordinary rotation in point of time. -- Catch"-crop`ping, n.
One who enters into a convention, covenant, or contract.
Any external application intended to beautify and improve thecomplexion.
A covering. [Obs.] Sir T. Browne.
A court of record held once a year, in a particular hundred,lordship, or manor, before the steward of the leet. Blackstone.

A narrow opening resulting from a split or crack or theseparation of a junction; a cleft; a fissure; a rent.The mouse, Behind the moldering wainscot, shrieked, Or from thecrevice peered about. Tennyson.
Of or pertaining to the tail.
In the form of chalk or lime.
A stone for coping. See Coping.
Induration of the heart, caused by development of fibroustissue in the cardiac muscle.
Brittle when cold; as, cold-short iron.
Of or pertaining to a range of mountains in Austro-Hungary,called the Carpathians, which partially inclose Hungary on the north,east, and south.
A name given to several plants of different genera, butparticularly to Celosia cristata, or garden cockscomb. Same asCockscomb.
A term used when a narrow ribbon of veneer is inserted into thesurfase of any piece of furniture, wainscoting, etc., so that thegrain of it is contrary to the general surface.
A fire extending to many objects, or over a large space; ageneral burning.
Same as Affronté.
Pertaining to, or resembling, coal; containing coal; of thenature of coal.
A sort of Russian isinglass, made from the air bladder of thesturgeon, and used in clarifying wine.
A frame to hang clothes on.
Having the lowest inferior segment of a pinna nearer the rachisthan the lowest superior one; -- said of a mode of branching inferns, and opposed to anadromous.
A work made across or in the ditch, to protect it from theenemy, or to serve as a covered passageway.
In a cold manner; without warmth, animation, or feeling; withindifference; calmly.Withdraw unto some private place, And reason coldly of yourgrievances. Shak.
The coping of the scarp wall, which projects beyong the face ofthe wall a few inches.
Of or pertaining to the cypress.
Little sticks; twigs for burning; fuel. Johnson.
See Keg. [Obs.]
A bracket supporting a superincumbent object, or receiving thespring of an arch. Corbels were employed largely in Gothicarchitecture.
St. Elmo's fire. See under Saint.
The nucleus or central part of the earth, forming most of itsmass; -- disting. from lithosphere, hydrosphere, etc.
Adapted to console or comfort; cheering; as, this is consolingnews.
Quality or state of being catacrotic. -- Cat`a*di*crot"ic (#),a.

Trust given or received; expectation of future playment forproperty transferred, or of fulfillment or promises given; mercantilereputation entitling one to be trusted; -- applied to individuals,corporations, communities, or nations; as, to buy goods on credit.Credit is nothing but the expectation of money, within some limitedtime. Locke.
A coronet. [Poetic] Sir W. Scott.
To utter imprecations or curses; to affirm or deny withimprecations; to swear.Then began he to curse and to swear. Matt. xxi. 74.His spirits hear me, And yet I need must curse. Shak.
To ascertain the caliber of, as of a thermometer tube; also,more generally, to determine or rectify the graduation of, as of thevarious standards or graduated instruments.
A muscle which contracts or closes an orifice, or whichcompresses an organ; a sphincter.
A cruciferous herb of certain species of Dentaria; -- calledalso toothwort, tooth violet, or pepper root.

Any crustacean of the family Astacidæ, resembling the lobster,but smaller, and found in fresh waters. Crawfishes are esteemed verydelicate food both in Europe and America. The North American speciesare numerous and mostly belong to the genus Cambarus. The blindcrawfish of the Mamoth Cave is Cambarus pellucidus. The commonEuropean species is Astacus fluviatilis.
A rounded mass or nodule produced by an aggregation of thematerial around a center; as, the calcareous concretions common inbeds of clay.
Behavior; comport. [Obs.]Goodly comportance each to other bear. Spenser.
A certificate showing what appears upon record touching amatter in question.
Blowing around. [Obs.] Evelyn.
A large division of Mollusca, including all except thebivalves; -- so called because the head is distinctly developed. SeeIllustration in Appendix.
Relating to a climacteric; critical.
Of or pertaining to craniology.
Full of crags; rugged with projecting points of rocks; as, thecraggy side of a mountain. "The craggy ledge." Tennyson.
To slide down hill; to slide on a sled, upon snow or ice.[Local, U. S.]
Having the property of conducting. [R.]
Possesing harmony; accordant. [R.] Warton.
A gatherer of cods or peas. [Obs. or Prov.] Johnson.
Same as Seggar.
To strike noisily against or together.
Pertaining to, or resembling, cinnabar; consisting of cinnabar,or containing it; as, cinnabarine sand.
A bruise; an injury attended with more or less disorganizationof the subcutaneous tissue and effusion of blood beneath the skin,but without apparent wound.
Acquisitiveness.
See Lumpfish. [Scot.]

The chancel. Choir organ (Mus.), one of the three or fivedistinct organs included in the full organ, each separable from therest, but all controlled by one performer; a portion of the fullorgan, complete in itself, and more practicable for ordinary serviceand in the accompanying of the vocal choir.-- Choir screen, Choir wall (Arch.), a screen or low wall separatingthe choir from the aisles.-- Choir service, the service of singing performed by the choir. T.Warton.
A short, variously distorted foot; also, the deformity, usuallycongenital, which such a foot exhibits; talipes.
Of or pertaining to a cantor; as, the cantoris side of a choir;a cantoris stall. Shipley.
Shield-shaped; clypeate.
A moderate state of cold; coolness; -- said of the temperatureof the air between hot and cold; as, the cool of the day; the cool ofthe morning or evening.
One who suffers with another. Wycherley.
See Quinoline.

Insurance jointly with another or others; specif., that systemof fire insurance in which the insurer is treated as insuring himselfto the extent of that part of the risk not covered by his policy, sothat any loss is apportioned between him and the insurance company onthe principle of average, as in marine insurance or between otherinsurers.
The quality of being conversable; disposition to converse;sociability.
One who contemns; a despiser; a scorner. "Contemners of thegods." South.
Of or pertaining to, or resembling, Cerberus. [Written alsoCerberian.]With wide Cerberean mouth. Milton.
One who makes a confession.
One who conceals.
Land or region where one was cradled; hence, land of origin.
A species of oak (Quercus cerris) native in the Orient andsouthern Europe; -- called also bitter oak and Turkey oak.
A reference to decided cases, or books of authority, to prove apoint in law.
One who promotes or establishes a colony; a colonist. Bancroft.

Finely prepared charcoal in small sticks, used as a drawingimplement. Animal charcoal, a fine charcoal prepared by calciningbones in a closed vessel; -- used as a filtering agent in sugarrefining, and as an absorbent and disinfectant.-- Charcoal blacks, the black pigment, consisting of burnt ivory,bone, cock, peach stones, and other substances.-- Charcoal drawing (Fine Arts), a drawing made with charcoal. SeeCharcoal, 2. Until within a few years this material has been usedalmost exclusively for preliminary outline, etc., but at present manyfinished drawings are made with it.-- Charcoal point, a carbon pencil prepared for use un an electriclight apparatus.-- Mineral charcoal, a term applied to silky fibrous layers ofcharcoal, interlaminated in beds of ordinary bituminous coal; --known to miners as mother of coal.
The power of exciting mirth; comicalness. [R.] H. Giles.
A twisting; a writhing; wry motion; a twist; as, the contortionof the muscles of the face. Swift.All the contortions of the sibyl, without the inspiration. Burke.
A dyestuff, obtained from the Chinese croicin, which produces abrilliant yellow.
Same as Colporteur.
A writer of chronograms.
The wrist; the bones or cartilages between the forearm, orantibrachium, and the hand or forefoot; in man, consisting of eightshort bones disposed in two rows.
A computer.
Having the same bounds, or limits; bordering upon; contiguous.This conformed so many of them as were conterminous to the coloniesand garrisons, to the Roman laws. Sir M. Hale.
One who curries and dresses leather, after it is tanned.
Same as Cyprus. Milton.
Furnished with claws. N. Grew.
Conducting power; -- the reciprocal of resistance. A suggestedunit is the mho, the reciprocal of the ohm.
The nightmare. Dunaglison.
Resembling a click; abounding in clicks. "Their strange clickylanguage." The Century.
Act of touching. [Obs.]
A chalklike concretion, consisting mainly of urate of sodium,found in and about the small joints, in the external ear, and inother situations, in those affected with gout; a tophus.
An enchantress. Chaucer.
Congeneric. [Obs.]
The quality or state of being cross; peevishness; fretfulness;ill humor.
Existing, or made, by the mutual consent of two or moreparties.
See Cider. [Archaic]
Aping, or having, the manners of a city.
In a contemptible manner.
Rolled together downward, the tip occupying the center; -- aterm used in reference to foliation or leafing, as in ferns. Gray.
Practicing or exhibiting coquetry; alluring; enticing.A pretty, coquettish housemaid. W. Irving.

the state of being continuous; uninterupted connection orsuccession; close union of parts; cohesion; as, the continuity offibers. Grew.The sight would be tired, if it were attracted by a continuity ofglittering objects. Dryden.Law of continuity (Math. & Physics), the principle that nothingpasses from one state to another without passing through all theintermediate states.-- Solution of continuity. (Math.) See under Solution.
A division of Protozoa, of which Magosphæra is the type. Theyexist both in a myxopod state, with branched pseudopodia, and in theform of ciliated bodies united in free, spherical colonies.
A treatise on the bile and bilary organs. Dunglison.
The killing of a person in an affray, in the heat of blood, andwhile under the influence of passion, thus distinguished from chance-medley or killing in self-defense, or in a casual affray. Burrill.
See catherine wheel.
One of a race inhabiting the valleys of the Pyrenees, who until1793 were political and social outcasts (Christian Pariahs). They aresupposed to be a remnant of the Visigoths.
An old Spanish dance in moderate three-four measure, like thePassacaglia, which is slower. Both are used by classical composers asthemes for variations.
In a catechetical manner; by question and answer.
The circulation or movement of protoplasmic granules within aliving vegetable cell.
A spicy plant and its bright red berry; the wintergreen(Gaultheria procumbens). Also incorrectly applied to the partridgeberry (Mitchella repens).
A remedy for all diseases; a panacea.
See Clear-cut.
To join; to conjoin. [R.] Shak.
Examination of the brain for the diagnosis of diseas; esp., theact or process of diagnosticating the condition of the brain byexamination of the interior of the eye (as with an ophthalmoscope).Buck.

The Latin and English form of a Greek preposition, used as aprefix to signify down, downward, under, against, contrary or opposedto, wholly, completely; as in cataclysm, catarrh. It sometimes dropsthe final vowel, as in catoptric; and is sometimes changed to cath,as in cathartic, catholic.
A mammal of tropical America of the genus Nasua, allied to theraccoon, but with a longer body, tail, and nose.
A minute canal.
See Cast steel, under Steel.
To chew. [Obs. or Prov. Eng.] Sir T. More.
Covered with a cataphract, or armor of plates, scales, etc.; orwith that which corresponds to this, as horny or bony plates, hard,callous skin, etc.

To cheer in distress or depression; to alleviate the grief andraise the spirits of; to relieve; to comfort; to soothe.And empty heads console with empty sound. Pope.I am much consoled by the reflection that the religion of Christ hasbeen attacked in vain by all the wits and philosophers, and itstriumph has been complete. P. Henry.
In a compact manner; with close union of parts; densely;tersely.
A plotting together. [R.]
Capable of being civilized.
Governed by, or according to, conscience; reasonable; just.Let my debtors have conscionable satisfaction. Sir H. Wotton.
Pertaining to, or derived from, cubebs; as, cubebic acid (asoft olive-green resin extracted from cubebs).
To stiffen with starch, and then make clear by clapping withthe hands; as, to clearstarch muslin.
To blow together; to bring together; to collect;  to fusetogether; to join or weld; to consolidate.
Convex on one side, and flat on the other; plano-convex.
See Cowpox. Dunglison.
To make congenial. [R.]
See Curd. [Obs.]
A bad quality or disposition in a disease; an incurable ulcer.
To compel to perform military service; to seize for militarypurposes; -- orig. used of the Boers.
In a clammy manner. "Oozing so clammily." Hood.
A term designating both a quality and the subject in which itexists; a concrete term.The concretes "father" and "son" have, or might have, the abstracts"paternity" and "filiety". J. S. Mill.
In the form of a crescent; like a crescent. Tennyson.
Coagulated. [Obs.] Shak.
A genus of plants including the cucumber, melon, and same kindsof gourds.
A description of the world or of the universe; or the sciencewhich teaches the constitution of the whole system of worlds, or thefigure, disposition, and relation of all its parts.
See Chiaroscuro.
One who captures any person or thing, as a prisoner or a prize.
Nimbus, or rain cloud. See Nimbus, and Cloud.
To plead the contrary of; to plead against; to deny.
Careful; wary; cautious; not rash, reckless, or spendthrift;saving; frugal.His rising reputation made him more chary of his fame. Jeffrey.
Belonging to the Crustacea; crustacean.
State of being cleanly; neatness of person or dress.Cleanliness from head to heel. Swift.
See Cauliflower.
A foot covering of any kind.
A civilian. [R.] Warbur
To view or treat with contempt, as mean and despicable; toreject with disdain; to despise; to scorn.Thy pompous delicacies I contemn. Milton.One who contemned divine and human laws. Dryden.
One of a religious order, dwelling in a convent, or acommunity, in opposition to an anchoret, or hermit, who lives insolitude. Gibbon.
A minute vesicle in a red seaweed, which contains thereproductive spores.
The rotation of a limb round an imaginary axis, so as todescribe a concial surface.
One to whom anuthing is confirmed.
Corrosive. [Obs.]Corrasive sores which eat into the flesh. Holland.
A cornemuse.
a Brazen-faced; impudent; bold. [Slang.]
To act or operate jointly with another or others; to concur inaction, effort, or effect.Whate'er coöperates to the common mirth. Crashaw.
Of or pertaining to the Chilostoma.
Act of hearing, or the ability to hear, sounds not normallyaudible; -- usually claimed as a special faculty of spiritualisticmediums, or the like.
Manure; compost. [Obs.] Shak.
An Australian parrot (Calopsitta Novæ-Hollandiæ); -- so calledfrom its note.
Vexation; mortification.I must own that I felt rather vexation and chagrin than hope andsatisfaction. Richard Porson.Hear me, and touch Belinda with chagrin. Pope.
Allied; akin. [Obs.] Chaucer.
A system of control in which a separate manipulation, as of arudder, may be effected by either of two movements, in differentdirections, of a single lever, etc.
Pertaining to Crete, or Candia.-- n.
The state of being carnal; fleshly lust, or the indulgence oflust; grossness of mind.Because of the carnality of their hearts. Tillotson.
Congruence. Congruency of lines. (Geom.) See Complex of lines,under Complex, n.

A self-loading or semi-automatic pistol with removable magazinein the handle holding seven cartridges. The recoil extracts andejects the empty cartridge case, and reloads ready for another shot.Called also Browning, and Colt-Browning, pistol.
Relating to, or employed in, the cure of diseases; tending tocure. Arbuthnot.
A fellow rogue. [Obs.]

An instrument used to illustrate the freezing of water by itsown evaporation. The ordinary form consist of two glass bulbs,connected by a tube of the same material, and containing only aquantity of water and its vapor, devoid of air. The water is in oneof the bulbs, and freezes when the other is cooled below 32º Fahr.
The condition of being a creature.
The qualityof being corrodible. [R.] Johnson.
An umbelliferous plant of the genus Chærophyllum (C. temulumand C. sylvestre).
A gymnasium; esp. one for light physical exercise by women andchildren.
Capable of being confined, restricted, or limited.Not confinable to any limits. Bp. Hall.

A small interval (the difference beyween a major and minor halfstep), seldom used except by tuners. Comma bacillus (Physiol.), avariety of bacillus shaped like a comma, found in the intestines ofpatients suffering from cholera. It is considered by some as having aspecial relation to the disease; -- called also cholera bacillus.-- Comma butterfly (Zoöl.), an American butterfly (Grapta comma),having a white comma-shaped marking on the under side of the wings.
To cause to pass from place to place, or from person to person;to spread; as, to circulate a report; to circulate bills of credit.Circulating pump. See under Pump.
A metal covering plate which passes over the trunnions of acannon, and holds it in place.
See Catopter.
The state of being conceited; conceit; vanity. Addison.
See Kermes.
Courteous. [Obs.] Chaucer.
A white or colored wash for the ceiling or other plastering ofa room, consisting of a mixture of clear glue, Paris white or zincwhite, and water. [Also spelt kalsomine.]
A knobike protuberance of any part, esp. at the end of a boneor cartilage.

In actual contact; touching; also, adjacent; near; neighboring;adjoining.The two halves of the paper did not appear fully divided . . . butseemed contiguous at one of their angles. Sir I. Newton.Sees no contiguous palace rear its head. Goldsmith.Contiguous angles. See Adjacent angles, under Angle.
In a congenital manner.
One of the bones or cartilages of the carpus; esp. one of theseries articulating with the metacarpals.
The art or act of measuring skulls.

The act of causing; also the act or agency by which an effectis produced.The kind of causation by which vision is produced. Whewell.Law of universal causation, the theoretical or asserted law thatevery event or phenomenon results from, or is the sequel of, someprevious event or phenomenon, which being present, the other iscertain to take place.
A warm jacket of knit worsted with or without sleeves.
To bite or chew impatiently.They began . . . irefully to champ upon the bit. Hooker.
Pertaining to, or suitable for, the church; ecclesiastical.
A native or inhabitant of Cyprus.
One who directs work; an overseer. [Sp. Amer.]
Having a chamber or chambers; as, a chambered shell; achambered gun.
Crested.
The act of sprinkling. [Obs.]The conspersion washing the doorposts. Jer. Taylor.
A dry sweetmeat; any kind of fruit, root, or seed preservedwith sugar and dried; a confection.
Defilement. [Obs.]
The interval by which the curtate distance of a planet is lessthan the true distance.
Stout or plump; large. [Obs.] Fenton.
Glittering; dressed in, or overlaid with, tinsel finery. [Obs.]Shak.
p. pr. & vb. n. of Climb. Climbing fern. See under Fern.-- Climbing perch. (Zoöl.) See Anabas, and Labyrinthici.
To work in oppositeion to; to counteract.That counterworksh folly and caprice. Pope.
Conjugal. [R.] Swedenborg.
Having a large head; thickheaded; dull; stupid. Smart.
Having curled locks of hair; supporting cirri, or hairlikeappendages.
A kind of French brandy, so called from the town of Cognac.
One nominated in conjunction with another; a joint nominee.Kirby.
To inclose in corsets.
A kind of campion; according to Gerarde, the Lychnis Flos-cuculi.

A certificate of interest due, printed at the bottom oftransferable bonds (state, railroad, etc.), given for a term ofyears, designed to be cut off and presented for payment when theinterest is due; an interest warrant.
To cross-examine; to subject to close questioning.

To inflect according to the degrees of comparison; to statepositive, comparative, and superlative forms of; as, most adjectivesof one syllable are compared by affixing "-er" and "-est" to thepositive form; as, black, blacker, blackest; those of more than onesyllable are usually compared by prefixing "more" and "most", or"less" and "least", to the positive; as, beautiful, more beautiful,most beautiful.
A power, attributed to some persons while in a mesmeric state,of discering objects not perceptible by the senses in their normalcondition.
Cerium oxide, CeO2, a white infusible substance constitutingabout one per cent of the material of the common incandescent mantle.
With craft; artfully; cunningly.
A Franciscan; -- so called in France from the girdle of knottedcord worn by all Franciscans.

A sensation of cold with convulsive shaking of the body,pinched face, pale skin, and blue lips, caused by undue cooling ofthe body or by nervous excitement, or forming the precursor of someconstitutional disturbance, as of a fever.
One who certifies or assures.
A hydrocarbon.
A colorless, volatile, pungent liquid, C4H6, producedartificially, and regarded as an unsaturated hydrocarbon of theacetylene series, and analogous to crotonic acid.
The anterior end of the notochord and its bony sheath in thebase of cartilaginous crania.
A combination of two or more persons to commit an unlawful act,or to do a lawful act by unlawful means. See Conspiracy.
To render void or useless; to vacate or annul. [Obs.]
To grow together. [Obs.] Spenser.
A filter, as for sugar, in which a cylinder with a porous orforaminous periphery is rapidly rotated so as to drive off liquid bycentrifugal action.
A small, rudely-formed boat. Bell cot. (Arch.) See under Bell.
An orange-colored dyestuff, of artificial production.

Pressed together; closely connected; -- applied to insectshaving the abdomen separated from the thorax only by a constriction.Coarctate pupa (Zoöl.), a pupa closely covered by the old larvalskin, as in most Diptera.
A body of individuals; an assemblage. [Obs.]He was in a core of people. Bacon.
Serving to unite or consolidate; having the quality ofconsolidating or making firm.
One who criticises; a critic.
A decorative construction around the opning of a fireplace.
In a coherent manner.
One that commingles; specif., a device for noiseless heating ofwater by steam, in a vessel filled with a porous mass, as of pebbles.
Compliance; disposition to yield to others. Goldsmith.
One who courts; one who plays the lover, or who solicits inmarriage; one who flatters and cajoles. Sherwood.
in a convulsive manner.
That which is held together with another thing; that which isconnected with a tenetment, or thing holden, as a certin quantity ofland a Burrill.
A singing. [Obs.] Blount.
A term applied to the centrifugal, or efferent course of thenervous infuence. Marshall Hall.
A mountain ridge or chain.
Of or pertaining to a cast.
A kind of small black perch.

Of, pertaining to, or obtained from, carbon; as, carbonicoxide. Carbonic acid (Chem.), an acid H2CO3, not existing separately,which, combined with positive or basic atoms or radicals, formscarbonates. On common language the term is very generally applied toa compound of carbon and oxygen, CO2, more correctly called carbondioxide. It is a colorless, heavy, irrespirable gas, extinguishingflame, and when breathed destroys life. It can be reduced to a liquidand solid form by intense pressure. It is produced in thefermentation of liquors, and by the combustion and decomposition oforganic substances, or other substances containing carbon. It isformed in the explosion of fire damp in mines, and is hance calledafter damp; it is also know as choke damp, and mephilic air. Waterwill absorb its own volume of it, and more than this under pressure,and in this state becomes the common soda water of the shops, and thecarbonated water of natural springs. Combined with lime itconstitutes limestone, or common marble and chalk. Plants imbibe itfor their nutrition and growth, the carbon being retained and theoxygen given out.-- Carbonic oxide (Chem.), a colorless gas, CO, of a light odor,called more correctly carbon monoxide. It is almost the onlydefinitely known compound in which carbon seems to be divalent. It isa product of the incomplete combustion of carbon, and is an abundantconstituent of water gas. It is fatal to animal life, extinguishescombustion, and burns with a pale blue flame, forming carbon dioxide.
The state or quality of being colloidal.
One who is related to another on the female side. Wharton.
Of the nature of familiar talk; in the form of a dialogue.Weever.
Hot; burning; ardent. [Obs.] Bailey.
To utter rapidly, idly, or indistinctly.Begin his witless note apace to chatter. Spenser.
One who believes that the most important geological phenomenahave been produced by cataclysms.
A stem structure or stem axis of a plant, viewed as a whole. --Cau*lom"ic (#), a.
A turning to the opposite side; antistrophe. Congreve.
An oily substance, C10H16, extracted from oil caraway.

Speaking and repeating loud words; full of clamor; calling ordemanding loudly or urgently; vociferous; noisy; bawling; loud;turbulent. "My young ones were clamorous for a morning's excursion."Southey.-- Clam"or*ous*ly, adv.-- Clam"or*ous*ness, n.
A retort, used in the Bessemer process, in which molten castiron is decarburized and converted into steel by a blast of airforced through the liquid metal.
A surety or sponsor.
Capable of being contained or comprised. Boyle.
Pertaining to, or resembling, a crater. [R.] R. Browning.
Same as Cespitose.
A supposed alkaloid obtained from croton oil by boiling it withwater and magnesia, since found to be merely a magnesia soap of theoil. Watts.
Having a head.
Sensitive in respect of wrongdoing; conscientious. [Obs.] Jer.Taylor.
Concurrence.

Overfullness of the capillary and other blood vessels, etc., inany locality or organ (often producing other morbid symptoms); localhyperas, arterial congestion; venous congestion; congestion of thelungs.
Having a cornice.
The heron [Obs.] Ainsworth.
A case for visiting cards.
See Cenozoic.
To give chase; to hunt; as, to chase around after a doctor.[Colloq.]
A kind of coccolith, which in shape resembles a minute cupwidened at the top, and varies in size from
A valuable kind of Peruvian bark obtained from the CinchonaCalisaya, and other closely related species.
A contrary order; revocation of a former order or command.Have you no countermand for Claudio yet, But he must die to-morrowShak.
The amphitheater of Vespasian at Rome, the largest in theworld. [Written also Colosseum.]

A monument of rough stones composed of one or more large onessupported in a horizontal position upon others. They are foundchiefly in countris inhabited by the ancient Celts, and are of aperiod anterior to the introduction of Christianity into thesecountries.
A coarse, narrow cloth, like frieze, used by the lower classesin the sixteenth century. Halliwell.
Tending to strengthen of confirm.
Having cliffs; broken; craggy.
A genus of plants of the Cactus family. They are natives ofAmerica, from California to Chili.
One of a series of artificial blue or red dyes obtained fromquinoline and lepidine and used in calico printing.
The chief ornament. [Obs.]Thou makest the triumviry the cornercap of society. Shak.
Specifically, the form of government established on the deathof Charles I., in 1649, which existed under Oliver Cromwell and hisson Richard, ending with the abdication of the latter in 1659.
The seed of gold; a means of creating gold. [Obs.] B. Jonson.
One who lives unmarried. [R.]
Hairy. [R.]
In the manner or shape of a cylinder; so as to be cylindrical.
A limpid, colorless oil with a peculiar odor, obtained frombeech tar. Watts.
A melting together; the reduction of different bodies into onemass by fusion.The incorporation of metals by simple colliquefaction. Bacon.
Of or pertaining to a chronograph.
A kind of red pepper. See Capsicum [Written also chilli andchile.]
To be convereted into a powder or friable substance, or into acalx, by the action of heat. "Calcining without fusion" Newton.
Suitableness of one thing to another; agreement; consistency.Holland.
See Capper, a plant, 2.
Former; previous; of times gone by; as, a cidevant governor.
Expressing reproach; abusive; railing; taunting. [Obs.]"Convicious words." Queen Elizabeth (1559).
A carbineer.
See Crosslet.
A cartilaginous fish of several species, belonging to the orderHolocephali. The teeth are few and large. The head is furnished withappendages, and the tail terminates in a point.
Caused or accomplished by convection; as, a convectivedischarge of electricity. Faraday.
Cautious in speaking; secret; wary; uncommunicative.
A coxcomb; a simpleton; a gull. [Obs.]Go; you're a brainless cox, a toy, a fop. Beau. & Fl.
See Chloridate.

Having a small surface in proportion to bulk, as in the cactus.Consolidated plants are evidently adapted and designed for very dryregions; in such only they are found. Gray.The Consolidated Fund, a British fund formed by consolidating (in1787) three public funds (the Aggregate Fund, the General Fund, andthe South Sea Fund). In 1816, the larger part of the revenues ofGreat Britian and Ireland was assigned to what has been known as theConsolidated Fund of the United Kingdom, out of which are paid theinterest of the national debt, the salaries of the civil list, etc.
The bedbug. [Obs.] Wright.
See Cat-harping.
A cargo. [Obs.]
One skilled in his craft or trade; one of superior cunning.In cunning persuasion his craftsmaster. Holland.
A small, active, winged species of cockroach (EctobiaGermanica), the water bug. It is common aboard ships, and in housesin cities, esp. in those with hot-water pipes.
A genus of flowerless plants, having articulated stems andwhorled branches. They flourish in wet places.
The legislative assembly, composed of nobility, clergy, andrepresentatives of cities, which in Spain and in Portugal answers, insome measure, to the Parliament of Great Britain.
Mutual adaption. R. Owen.
The court of a sovereign or of a feudal lord; also; hisresidence or his household. Burrill.
To rate; to tax; to assess. Spenser.
A hood-shaped bandage for the head, the shoulder, or the stumpof an amputated limb.
Something incidental to the main subject, but of lessimportance; opposed to an essential; -- generally in the plural; as,the circumstantials of religion. Addison.
A kind of lace. [Obs.]Pinners edged with colbertine. Swift.Difference rose between Mechlin, the queen of lace, and colbertine.Young.
That may be calculated or ascertained by calculation.
The chemical basis of ordinary connective tissue, as of tendonsor sinews and of bone. On being boiled in water it becomes gelatin orglue.
The office, dignity, or government of a caliph or of thecaliphs.

An act of civility, respect, or reverence, made by women,consisting of a slight depression or dropping of the body, withbending of the kness. [Written also curtsy.]The lady drops a courtesy in token of obedience, and the ceremonyproceeds as usual. Golgsmith.
Relating to, or produced by, flesh or animal food; as, creaticnausea. [Written also kreatic.]
An inferior court of civil jurisdiction, attached to a manor,and held by the steward; a baron's court; -- now fallen into disuse.
Surrounding the esophagus; -- in Zool. said of the nervecommissures and ganglia of arthropods and mollusks.
Counter tenor; contralto.
The quality of being commonplace; commonness.
Of or pertaining to husbandmen. [Obs.]
A natural tendency inherent in a body to develop itself; anattempt; an effort.What conatus could give prickles to the porcupine or hedgehog, or tothe sheep its fleece Paley.
To unite or hold together; as, the side pieces compaginate theframe. [Obs.] W. Montagu.
A cutaneous affection characterized by yellow or yellowishbrown pigmented spots.
To cultivate; to educate.They came . . . into places well inhabited and cultured. Usher.

A Franciscan monk of the austere branch established in 1526 byMatteo di Baschi, distinguished by wearing the long pointed cowl orcapoch of St. Francis.A bare-footed and long-bearded capuchin. Sir W. Scott.
Affected with, or inclined to, consumption.The lean, consumptive wench, with coughs decayed. Dryden.
Low, fertile land; a river valley. [Scot.] Jomieson.
Of or pertaining to Complutum (now Alcala de Henares) a citynear Madrid; as, the Complutensian Bible.
A salt of chloric acid; as, chlorate of potassium.
A genus of extinct animals, so named from fossil footprintsrudely resembling impressions of the human hand, and believed to havebeen made by labyrinthodont reptiles. See Illustration in Appendix.
A co-religion
A Latin preposition, used as a prefix in many English words,and signifying around or about.
The act of lying down; a reclining. [Obs.]
Apartments in a lodging house. "A bachelor's life in chambers."Thackeray.
A song or verses. [Obs.] Spenser.
A mineral. See Turquoise.
One who cleaves, or that which cleaves; especially, a butcher'sinstrument for cutting animal bodies into joints or pieces.
Affording compensation.

A species to fresh-water fish of the Cyprinidæ or Carp family.The common European species is Leuciscus cephalus; the cheven. InAmerica the name is applied to various fishes of the same family, ofthe genera Semotilus, Squalius, Ceratichthys, etc., and locally toseveral very different fishes, as the tautog, black bass, etc. Chubmackerel (Zoöl.), a species of mackerel (Scomber colias) in someyears found in abundance on the Atlantic coast, but absent in others;-- called also bull mackerel, thimble-eye, and big-eye mackerel.-- Chub sucker (Zoöl.), a fresh-water fish of the United States(Erimyzon sucetta); -- called also creekfish.
In Great Britain and Ireland, a person who hires a smallcottage, with or without a plot of land. Cottiers commonly aid in thework of the landlord's farm. [Written also cottar and cotter.]
A rope used in hoisting the anchor to the cathead. Totten.

To give or grant i common with others; to give to a commonstock or for a common purpose; to furnish or suply in part; to give(money or other aid) for a specified object; as, to contribute foodor fuel for the poor.England contributes much more than any other of the allies. Addison.
The quality or state of being cragged; cragginess.
A patent anodyne medicine, containing opium, chloroform, Indianhemp, etc.
The large, hard-shelled nut of the cocoa palm. It yields anagreeable milky liquid and a white meat or albumen much used as foodand in making oil.
A bivalve mollusk, with radiating ribs, of the genus Cardium,especially C. edule, used in Europe for food; -- sometimes applied tosimilar shells of other genera.
Fellowship at table; the act or practice of eating at the sametable. [Obs.] "Promiscuous commensality." Sir T. Browne.
One who contemplates. Sir T. Browne.
