The system of teaching law in which the instruction isprimarily a historical and inductive study of leading or selectedcases, with or without the use of textbooks for reference andcollateral reading.

To win ower; to gain from a state of hostility; to gain thegood will or favor of; to make friendly; to mollify; to propitiate;to appease.The rapacity of his father's administration had excited suchuniversal discontent, that it was found expedient to conciliate thenation. Hallam.
A constabulary. [Obs.] Bp. Burnet.

Some thing curled or spiral,, as a flourish made with a pen onpaper, or with skates on the ice; a trick; a frolicsome caper.[Sometimes written carlicue.] [ Colloq. U.S.] To cut a curlycue, tomake a flourish; to cut a caper.I gave a flourishing about the room and cut a curlycue with my rightfoot. McClintock.

Two small, concave shells of ivory or hard wood, shaped likespoons, fastened to the thumb, and beaten together with the middlefinger; -- used by the Spaniards and Moors as an accompaniment totheir dance and guitars.
The government of a castle. Blount.
A coffeehouse; a restaurant; also, a room in a hotel orrestaurant where coffee and liquors are served.
A Cantabrigian. [Colloq.] Sir W. Scott.
A genus of biennial, poisonous, white-flowered, umbelliferousplants, bearing ribbed fruit ("seeds") and decompound leaves.
The quality or state of being complex or involved;complication.The complexedness of these moral ideas. Locke.
A salt of citric acid.
The refrain of a famous song of the French Revolution.
An irregular, tortuous folding of an organ or part; as, theconvolutions of the intestines; the cerebral convolutions. See Brain.
The policy or practice of transporting convicts to penalsettlements. "The evils of convictism." W. Howitt.
A sea bird of the Atlantic (Rhynchops nigra); -- called alsoblack skimmer, scissorsbill, and razorbill. See Skimmer.
In a crude, immature manner.
Native iron carbonate; -- usually called siderite.
See Colitis.
Produced by mixing distinct breeds; mongrel.
Corporeality; corporeity.

A mixture of milk and eggs, sweetened, and baked or boiled.Custard apple (Bot.), a low tree or shrub of tropical America,including several species of Anona (A. squamosa, reticulata, etc.),having a roundish or ovate fruit the size of a small orange,containing a soft, yellowish, edible pulp.-- Custard coffin, pastry, or crust, which covers or coffins acustard [Obs.] Shak.
Furnished with a chape or chapes. [Obs.] Chaucer.
Agreement. W. Montagu.
A thickened glandular portion of the body of the adultearthworm, consisting of several united segments modified forreproductive purposes.
The quality or state of being careless; heedlessness;negligenece; inattention.
A machine for spreading out cotton cloths to prepare them forprinting.
One who attends church.
A fluosilicate of magnesia and iron, yellow to red in color,often occurring in granular form in a crystalline limestone.
The depertment of zoölogy which treats of the Crustacea(lobsters, crabs, etc.); -- called also malacostracology andcrustaceology.
Having the same signification. Cockerham.
A member of a club; a frequenter of clubs. [R.] Burke.
A native or inhabitant of north or South Carolina.
A subdivision of a regiment of troops under the command of acaptain, numbering in the United States (full strength) 100 men.
A whisk to keep off files, used in the East Indies. Malcom.
To erode, as the bed of a stream. See Corrosion.
Tendency toward the center.
An animal, not truly parasitic, which lives in with, or on,another, partaking usually of the same food. Both species may bebenefited by the association.
Creative; formative. [R.] Mrs. Browning.
The art of drawing with chalk.
A mineral occurring in hexagonal crystals, also massive,generally of a yellow color, containing silica, alumina, lime, soda,and carbon dioxide.

Certain deities originally worshiped with mystical rites by thePelasgians in Lemnos and Samothrace and afterwards throughout Greece;-- also called sons of Hephæstus (or Vulcan), as being masters of theart of working metals. [Written also Cabeiri.] Liddell & Scott.
One who constitutes or appoints.
Those pieces of a machine, or of any timber, or stone work,which form corresponding sides, or which are similar and in pair; as,the cheeks (jaws) of a vise; the cheeks of a gun carriage, etc.
Belonging to marriage; suitable or appropriate to the marriagestate or to married persons; matrimonial; connubial. "Conjugalaffection." Milton.
Whooping cough.
The fragrant flowers of the Chloranthus inconspicuus, used inChina for perfuming tea.
Mutually assisting. [Obs.] Drayton.
A strip of wood or iron fastened on transversely to somethingin order to give strength, prevent warping, hold position, etc.
The act of eating together; table fellowship.
Serving to compel; compulsory. [R.]
To follow closely; to endeavor to overtake; to pursue. [Obs.]Bp. Burnet.
A cartilaginous tumor or growth.
In a caviling manner.
Drawers. [Obs.]
Characterised by circumlocution; periphrastic. Shenstone.The officials set to work in regular circumlocutory order. Chambers'sJournal.
A fossil or petrified conch or shell.
Same as Chromium steel, under Steel.

A genus of herbaceous composite plants, having the achenes two-horned and remotely resembling some insect; tickseed. C. tinctoria,of the Western plains, the commonest plant of the genus, has beenused in dyeing.
A bar connecting the ends of the side rods or levers of abackaction or side-lever engine.
The harpsichord.
One who couches paper.
A conversationist.

tending to one point of focus; tending to approach each other;converging.As many rays of light, as conveniently can be let in, and madeconvergent. Boyle.The vast dome of its cathedral . . . directing its convergent curvesto heaven. Hallam.
A conceptualist.
A morbid condition in which the urine contains chyle or fattymatter, giving it a milky appearance.
Having all the parts or organs which belong to it or to thetypical form; having calyx, corolla, stamens, and pistil.
An organ of the Ctenophora, supposed to be sensory.
A woman's girdle; a cestus. [R.] Collins.
Companionable; sociable. [Obs.] Chaucer.
Of or pertaining to competition; producing competition;competitory; as, a competitive examination.
A rib of an animal or a human being.
The reducing of anything to ashes by combustion; cinefaction.
To know or perceive; to recognize.The reasoning faculty can deal with no facts until they are cognizedby it. H. Spencer.
Of or pertaining to Clement, esp. to St.Clement of Rome and thespurious homilies attributed to him, or to Pope Clement V. and hiscompilations of canon law.
A variety of amianthus which is very light, like cork.
To cause to wheel or turn in an opposite direction.
Wasting away gradually. Darwin. - Con*ta*bes"cence, n.
A point; a sharp end.
One who, or a vessel that, cruises; -- usually an armed vessel.
Living or being at the same time; contemporaneous.-- Co*tem`po*ra"ne*ous*ly, adv.-- Co*tem`po*ra"ne*ous*ness, n.
A rabbit burrow. [Obs.]
One who confiscates. Burke.
The act of crying out. Sir T. Browne.
A movement or phase in post-impressionism (which see, below). -- Cu"bist (#), n.
A burning; esp., the act or practice of cremating the dead.Without cremation . . . of their bodies. Sir T. Browne.
The act of making into a castle.
A nitrogenous organic base, C8H6N2, analogous to quinoline,obtained from certain complex diazo compounds.
A climate; a tract or region of the earth. See Climate.Turn we to sutvey, Where rougher climes a nobler race display.Goldsmith.
The quality of being chargeable or expensive. [Obs.]Whitelocke.
Loading or tending; helpful; contributive; tending to promote.However conducive to the good or our country. Addison.
Like a calf; stupid. Sheldon.
A female heir who inherits with other heiresses; a jointheiress.
The quality of being costy; expensiveness; sumptuousness.
The act of castrating.
A canopy usually standing free and supported on four columns,covering the high altar, or, very rarely, a secondary altar.
One who chides or quarrels. Shak.
Pertaining to the choroid coat.
A kind of oven, or reverberatory furnace, used for thecalcination of sand and potash, and converting them into frit. Ure.
A society or body of men united for some purpose, or in someprofession; a brotherhood.
The act of searing some morbid part by the application of acautery or caustic; also, the effect of such application.
A small molding, carved into beads, pearls, olives, etc.

Living, existing, or occurring at the same time; contemporary.The great age of Jewish philosophy, that of Aben Esra, Maimonides,and Kimchi, had been contemporaneous with the later Spanish school ofArabic philosophy. Milman- Con*tem`po*ra"ne*ous*ness, n.
See Cannula, Cannular, and Cannulated.
A public assembly of the Roman people for electing officers orpassing laws.
One who accepts cerebralism.
Of, pertaining to, or derived from, copper; containing copper;-- said of those compounds of copper in which this element is presentin its lowest proportion.
The act of captivating. [R.]The captivation of our understanding. Bp. Hall.

Earth in general, as representing the elementary particles ofthe human body; hence, the human body as formed from such particles.I also am formed out of the clay. Job xxxiii. 6.The earth is covered thick with other clay, Which her own clay shallcover. Byron.Bowlder clay. See under Bowlder.-- Brick clay, the common clay, containing some iron, and thereforeturning red when burned.-- Clay cold, cold as clay or earth; lifeless; inanimate.-- Clay ironstone, an ore of iron consisting of the oxide orcarbonate of iron mixed with clay or sand.-- Clay marl, a whitish, smooth, chalky clay.-- Clay mill, a mill for mixing and tempering clay; a pug mill.-- Clay pit, a pit where clay is dug.-- Clay slate (Min.), argillaceous schist; argillite.-- Fatty clays, clays having a greasy feel; they are chemicalcompounds of water, silica, and aluminia, as halloysite, bole, etc.-- Fire clay , a variety of clay, entirely free from lime, iron, oran alkali, and therefore infusible, and used for fire brick.-- Porcelain clay, a very pure variety, formed directly from thedecomposition of feldspar, and often called kaolin.-- Potter's clay, a tolerably pure kind, free from iron.
Wearing a cowl; hooded; as, a cowled monk. "That cowledchurchman." Emerson.
A measure of length in Italy, varying from six to seven feet.See Cane, 4.
The state of being contracted; narrowness; meannes;selfishness.
Having hollow spines, as some ganoid fishes.
Having a common beginning.
An assessment or tax. [Obs.] Johnson.
In a controversial manner.

To have secretly a joint part or share in an action; to playinto each other's hands; to conspire; to act in concert.If they let things take their course, they will be represented ascolluding with sedition. Burke.
See under Laid.
See Cimbia.
Burdensome; troublesome. [Obs.] Chaucer.
Consisting of, or like, flesh; carnous; fleshy. "Carneousfibers." Ray.
Same as Vetiver oil.
The iron head of a tilting spear.
Tending or having power to consolidate; healing.
To bargain; to buy. [Obs.]
Without a crest or escutcheon; of low birth. "Crestlessyeomen." Shak.
Proved or found guilty; convicted. [Obs.] Shak.Convict by flight, and rebel to all law. Milton.
A gang of negro slaves being driven to market.
That part of the large intestines which extends from the cæcumto the rectum.
To repeat the distillation of, pouring the liquor back upon thematter remaining in the vessel. Arbuthnot.
See Customary. [Obs.]
Having cognizance or knowledge. (of).
Worldly-minded.
The manners of a clown; coarseness or rudeness of behavior.That plainness which the alamode people call clownishness. Locke.
A myriapod of the order Chilognatha.
The cob or axis on which the kernels of Indian corn grow.[U.S.]
A small European woodpecker (Picus minor).
Creatural; characteristic of a creature. [R.] "Creaturelyfaculties." Cheyne.

A rite supplemental to baptism, by which a person is admitted,through the laying on of the hands of a bishop, to the fullprivileges of the church, as in the Roman Catholic, the EpiscopalChurch, etc.This ordinance is called confirmation, because they who duly receiveit are confirmed or strengthened for the fulfillment of theirChristian duties, by the grace therein bestowed upon them. Hook.
A bulkhead on the forecastle and half deck of a ship.
A magnesian variety of dolomite.
The act of crenelating, or the state of being crenelated; anindentation or an embrasure. [Written also crenellation.]
Of no value; rejected; useless.
A peculiar rounded granule of some mineral, usually enstatiteor chrysolite, found imdedded more or less aboundantly in the mass ofmany meteoric stones, which are hence called chondrites.
Of or pertaining to Croatia.-- n.
A duty or tax paid by merchants for the protection of theirconnerce by means of a consul in a foreign place.
One who concludes.
Pertaining to ashes; containing ashes. Cinerary urns, vesselsused by the ancients to preserve the ashes of the dead when burned.
The modes or scales used in ancient church music. SeeGregorian.

A human skull reported, by Prof. J. D. Whitney, as found in1886 in a Tertiary auriferous gravel deposit, lying below a bed ofblack lava, in Calaveras County, California. It is regarded as verydoubtful whether the skull really belonged to the deposit in which itwas found. If it did, it indicates an unprecedented antiquity forhuman beings of an advanced type.
One of the two ecclesiastics allowed to attend a cardinal inthe conclave.
A kind of castanet used by the Corybantes.
In a concentric manner.
Coma with complete insensibility; deep lethargy.
In a creditable manner; reputably; with credit.
A device for recording the amount of cash received, usuallyhaving an automatic adding machine and a money drawer and exhibitingthe amount of the sale.
A contrivance for recording the revolutions of a wheel, as of abicycle.
Pertaining to, or derived from, cresol, creosote, etc. Cresylicacid. (Chem.) See Cresol.
Collected; compact; close. [R.] Bacon.
The range of notes, or tones, within the capacity of a voice orinstument.You would sound me from my lowest note to the top of my compass.Shak.
Resembling a child, or that which belongs to children; becominga child; meek; submissive; dutiful. "Childlike obedience." Hooker.
Having the shape of a horn; horn-shaped.
One who, or that which, cleanses; a detergent. Arbuthnot.
The plain semidome of an apse; sometimes used for the entireapse.
Resembling, or having the form of, bark or rind.
A word or phrase used in conversation; a colloqualism.
Tending to cerulean; light bluish.
The sound made when a cork is forcibly drawn from a bottle."The cloop of a cork wrenched from a bottle." Thackeray.
A kind of drinking cup. [Obs.]
p. p. of Crow. [Obs.]
Pertaining to a chrysalis; resembling a chrysalis.
The matter of which the philosopher's stone was believed to becomposed.

Any plant of the order Cactacæ, as the prickly pear and thenight-blooming cereus. See Cereus. They usually have leafless stemsand branches, often beset with clustered thorns, and are mostlynatives of the warmer parts of America. Cactus wren (Zoöl.), anAmerican wren of the genus Campylorhynchus, of several species.
A coarse umbelliferous weed of the genus Heracleum (H.sphondylium in England, and H. lanatum in America).
Pertaining to the Cimbri, an ancient tribe inhabiting NorthernGermany.-- n.

Having extension of time, space, order of events, exertion ofenergy, etc.; extended; protacted; uninterrupted; also, resumed afterinterruption; extending through a succession of issues, session,etc.; as, a continued story. "Continued woe." Jenyns. "Continuedsuccession." Locke. Continued bass (Mus.), a bass continued throughan entire piece of music, while the other parts of the harmony areindicated by figures beneath the bass; the same as thorough bass orfigured bass; basso continuo. [It.] -- Continued fever (Med.), afever which presents no interruption in its course.-- Continued fraction (Math.), a fraction whose numerator is 1, andwhose denominator is a whole number plus a fraction whose numeratoris 1 and whose denominator is a whole number, plus a fraction, and soon.-- Continued proportion (Math.), a proportion composed of two ormore equal ratios, in which the consequent of each preceding ratio isthe same with the antecedent of the folowing one; as, 4 : 8 : 8 : 16:: 16 : 32.
That carouses; relating to a carouse.
In a chaste manner; with purity.
One recovering from sickness.
Somewhat cool.The nights began to grow a little coolish. Goldsmith.
A movable parapet, serving to support fascines to coverpioneers. [Obs.]
Of or pertaining to the Copepoda.-- n.
Without a church. T. Fuller.
See under Capric.
Having the same bounds; conterminous. [Obs.] B. Jonson.
A national bank not in a reserve city. [Colloq., U. S.]
A marine European fish (Crenilabrus melops); also, the relatedAmerican cunner. See Cunner.
Having all the reefs taken in; -- said of a sail.
Of or pertaining to creation.
A white, bitter, crystallizable substance, obtained fromcoffee. It is identical with the alkaloid theine from tea leaves, andwith guaranine from guarana.
A small South American species of tiger cat (Felis mitis).

An agreement made by the Scottish Parliament in 1638, and bythe English Parliament in 1643, to preserve the reformed religion inScotland, and to extirpate popery and prelacy; -- usually called the"Solemn League and Covenant."He [Wharton] was born in the days of the Covenant, and was the heirof a covenanted house. Macualay.
A clear soup or bouillion boiled down so as to be very rich.

A thin, crimped stuff, made of raw silk gummed and twisted onthe mill. Black crape is much used for mourning garments, also forthe dress of some clergymen.A saint in crape is twice a saint in lawn. Pope.Crape myrtle (Bot.), a very ornamental shrub (Lagerströmia Indica)from the East Indies, often planted in the Southern United States.Its foliage is like that of the myrtle, and the flower has wavycrisped petals.-- Oriental crape. See Canton crape.
The double bassoon, an octave deeper than the bassoon.
One who consigns something to another; -- opposed to consignee.[Written also consigner.]
See Cannel coal.
Making chilly or cold; depressing; discouraging; cold; distant;as, a chilling breeze; a chilling manner.-- Chill"ing"ly, adv.
The state of being cheery.
A king of Lydia who flourished in the 6th century b. c., andwas renowned for his vast wealth; hence, a common appellation for avery rich man; as, he is veritable Croesus.
A genus of mollusks, including the cowries. See Cowrie.
The manners of a cit or citizen.
A traversing base frame, or movable railway, along which thecarriage of a barbette or casemate gum moves backward and forward.[See Gun carriage.]
Having cheliform claws, like a crab.
The act or process of refining gold or silver, etc., in acupel.

A shrub or bush of several species of the genus Ribes (a genusalso including the gooseberry); esp., the Ribes rubrum. Blackcurrant,a shrub or bush (Ribes nigrum and R. floridum) and its black,strong-flavored, tonic fruit.-- Cherry currant, a variety of the red currant, having a strong,symmetrical bush and a very large berry.-- Currant borer (Zoöl.), the larva of an insect that bores into thepith and kills currant bushes; specif., the larvae of a smallclearwing moth (Ægeria tipuliformis) and a longicorn beetle(Psenocerus supernotatus).-- Currant worm (Zoöl.), an insect larva which eats the leaves orfruit of the currant. The most injurious are the currant sawfly(Nematus ventricosus), introduced from Europe, and the spanworm(Eufitchia ribearia). The fruit worms are the larva of a fly (EpochraCanadensis), and a spanworm (Eupithecia).-- Flowering currant, Missouri currant, a species of Ribes (R.aureum), having showy yellow flowers.

Any device for detecting the presence of electric waves. Theinfluence of electric waves on the resistance of a particular kind ofelectric circuit, on the magnetization of steel, on the polarizationof an electrolytic cell, or on the electric condition of a vacuum hasbeen applied in the various cymoscopes.
Convexity.
One who chaffers; a bargainer.
The condition of being tempered; proportionate mixture;temperature. [Obs.]The different contemperature of the elements. SDouth.
The woodbine or honeysuckle. Spenser.

An instrument for the accurate measurement of small differencesof height; esp. of the differences in the height of the uppersurfaces of two columns of mercury or other fluid, or of the samecolumn at different times. It consists of a telescopic levelingapparatus (d), which slides up or down a perpendicular metallicstandard very finely graduated (bb). The telescope is raised ordepressed in order to sight the objects or surfaces, and thedifferences in vertical height are thus shown on the graduatedstandard. [Written also kathetometer.]
One who favors concession.
A cincture, girdle, or belt; -- chiefly used in English as adressmaking term.
To commission [Obs.]
Once in a hundred years.

Alkarsin; a colorless, poisonous, arsenical liquid, As2(CH3)4,spontaneously inflammable and possessing an intensely disagreeableodor. It is the type of a series of compounds analogous to thenitrogen compounds called hydrazines. [Written also cacodyle, andkakodyl.]
The state of being contingent; fortuitousness.
A knife. [Obs.] Bale.
A signal made for a parley by beat of a drum.They beat the chamade, and sent us carte blanche. Addison.
The act or process of changing into ice, or the state of beingconverted to ice; a freezing; congelation; also, a frost. Bacon.
A crooked back; one who has a crooked or deformed back; ahunchback.
Act of confronting.  H. Swinburne.
The bedbug (Cimex lectularius).
An alkaloid resembing physostigmine and occurring with it inthe calabar bean.
The noise of many things falling and breaking at once.There shall be . . . a great crashing from the hills. Zeph. i. 10.
The act or process of codifying or reducing laws to a code.
The green sickness; an anæmic disease of young women,characterized by a greenish or grayish yellow hue of the skin,weakness, palpitation, etc.
The quality of being comprehensible; comprehensibility.
An idiom or peculiarity in the Chaldee dialect.

The essential coloring principle of cochineal, extracted as apurple-red amorphous mass. It is a glucoside and possesses acidproperties; -- hence called also carminic acid. Carmine red (Chem.),a coloring matter obtained from carmine as a purple-red substance,and probably allied to the phthaleïns.
Secret or enigmatical language. Johnson.
Certainly; in truth; verily. [Archaic]Certes it great pity was to see Him his nobility so foul deface.Spenser.
An instrument for showing the optical effects of color.
To collect into clods, or into a thick mass; to coagulate; toclot; as, clodded gore. See Clot.Clodded in lumps of clay. G. Fletcher.
The science which treats of the heart and its functions.
A staff or pole on which a vessel is supported between twopersons. Suckling.
A bearing like a chevron, but of only half its width.
To make chyle of; to be converted into chyle.
A short song, in one or more parts.
One who believes in consubstantiation. Barrow.
A cup. See Calyx.
A rollicking French dance, accompanied by indecorous orextravagant postures and gestures.
like a coxcomb. [Obs.] "You coxcombly ass, you!" Beau & Fl.
Belonging to a chamber or bedroom. [Obs.] Howell.
The act of drinking or tippling together. [R.]The fashion of compotation. Sir W. Scott.
Of or pertaining to the Cestoidea.-- n.
To exhibit mental activity; to have the brain in action.
The relation of a godfather to a person. [Obs.]The relation of gossipred or compaternity by the cannon law is aspiritual affinity. Sir J. Da
Of or pertaining to the hair. [R.] Blount.
A yellow crystalline substance extracted from crude anthracene.
The state or quality of being a churchman; attachment to thechurch.
An order of birds, including the pigeons.

Denudation around or in the neighborhood of an object. Hills ofcircumdenudation, hills which have been produced by surface erosion;the elevations which have been left, after denudation of a mass ofhigh ground. Jukes.
One who is surety with another.
The quality of being cursory; superficial performance; as,cursoriness of view.
State of being a connoisseur.
One versed in crustaceology; a crustalogist.
Clothed with a cassock.
An apparatus for measuring the amount of heat contained inbodies or developed by some mechanical or chemical process, asfriction, chemical combination, combustion, etc.
The process of becoming chitinous.
To copy, as a design or painting, by tracing with a pencil onoiled paper, or other transparent substance.
A kind of warm drink for sick persons, being a mixture of winewith eggs, bread, sugar, and spices.
A person or animal whose ears are cropped.
The quality or state of being clear.
A thin worsted fabric for women's dresses.
Marked by constraint; not free; not voluntary; embarrassed; as,a constrained manner; a constrained tone.
Same as Olibene.
To make or draw a caricature of; to represent with ridiculousexaggeration; to burlesque.He could draw an ill face, or caricature a good one, with a masterlyhand. Lord Lyttelton.
A group of artificial dyes with an affinity for vegetablefibers, so that no mordant is required. Most of them are azocompounds derived from benzidine or tolidine. Called also benzidinedyes.
One who piks or chooses; esp., an inspector who select waressuitable for market.
resembling coral in form.
Any card of the suit of cards having a figure like the trefoilor clover leaf. (pl.) The suit of cards having such figure.
Pertaining to, derived from, or containing, calcium or lime.
See Clarinet.
Crankness. Lowell.
Pertaining to, or resembling, catalepsy; affected withcatalepsy; as, a cataleptic fit.
Gay; cheerful. [Obs.] Shak.
Capable of being caused.
Bloody; cruentate. [Obs.]
A jeweled chain, necklace, or collar. [Also written carkenetand carcant.] Shak.
A variety of andalusite; -- called also macle. The tesselatedapperance of a cross section is due to the symmetrical arrangement ofimpurities in the crystal.
A message of affection or respect; compliments; greeting.[Obs.]Hark you, Margaret; No princely commendations to my king Shak.

The American reindeer, especially the common or woodlandspecies (Rangifer Caribou). Barren Ground caribou. See under Barren.-- Woodland caribou, the common reindeer (Rangifer Caribou) of thenorthern forests of America.

A representation of two of the leg bones or arm bones of askeleton, laid crosswise, often surmounted with a skull, and servingas a symbol of death.Crossbones, scythes, hourglasses, and other lugubrios emblems ofmortality. Hawthorne.
One of the brachyuran Crustacea. They are mostly marine, andusually have a broad, short body, covered with a strong shell orcarapace. The abdomen is small and curled up beneath the body.
Capable of being employed by itself as a term; -- said of aword.
To cover with, or as with, a cloak; hence, to hide or conceal.Now glooming sadly, so to cloak her matter. Spenser.
Formed like a cirrus or tendril; -- said of appendages of bothanimals and plants.
A small sailboat, with a single mast placed as far forward aspossible, carring a sail extended by a graff and long boom. SeeIllustration in Appendix.
The state of being carnal; carnality; sensualism. [R.]
Club-shaped; clavate. Craig.

A rare alkaline metal found in mineral water; -- so called fromthe two characteristic blue lines in its spectrum. It was the firstelement discovered by spectrum analysis, and is the most stronglybasic and electro-positive substance known. Symbol Cs. Atomic weight132.6.
A bird confined in a cage; esp. a young bird. [Poetic]Tennyson.
An instrument (chisel or shears) to cut the ribs and open thethoracic cavity, in post-mortem examinations and dissections. Knight.

The state of being close.Half stifled by the closeness of the room. Swift.We rise not against the piercing judgment of Augustus, nor theextreme caution or closeness of Tiberius. Bacon.An affectation of closeness and covetousness. Addison.

A fossil plant of the coal formation, having the general formof plants of the modern Equiseta (the Horsetail or Scouring Rushfamily) but sometimes attaining the height of trees, and having thestem more or less woody within. See Acrogen, and Asterophyllite.
The office or employment of a commissary. Ayliffe.
The function and rank or office of a counselor. Bacon.
A stone of convex form, highly polished, but not faceted; also,the style of cutting itself. Such stones are said to be cut encabochon.
Having a bottom made of copper, as a tin boiler or othervessel, or sheathed with copper, as a ship.
A genus of marine amphipod crustacea, which bore into andsometimes destroy timber.
pertaining to a feast or to festivity; convivial. [Obs.] "Aconvival dish." Sir T. Browne.
To call, or name. [Obs.]That other son was cleped Cambalo. Chaucer.
Act of concerting; adjustment. [R.] Young.
Rolled or wound together, one part upon another; -- said of theleaves of plants in æstivation.
A winning of all the tricks at the game of piquet. It countsfor forty points. Hoyle.
A female scold. [Obs.]
A medicine that promotes alvine discharges; a purge; apurgative of moderate activity.
The act of applying the chrism, or consecrated oil.Chrismation or cross-signing with ointment, was used in baptism. Jer.Taylor.
One who conforms or complies; esp., one who conforms to theChurch of England, or to the Established Church, as distinguishedfrom a dissenter or nonconformist.
One who works with another; a co

A thin, transparent stuff, the same as, or corresponding to,crape. It was either white or black, the latter being most common,and used for mourning. [Obs.]Lawn as white as driven snow, Cyprus black as e'er was crow. Shak.

A noncommissioned officer, next below a sergeant. In the UnitedStates army he is the lowest noncomissioned officer in a company ofinfantry. He places and relieves sentinels. Corporal's guard, adetachment such as would be in charge of a corporal for guard duty,etc.; hence, derisively, a very small number of persons.-- Lance corporal, an assistant corporal on private's pay. Farrow.-- Ship's corporal (Naut.), a petty officer who assists the masterat arms in his various duties.
See Cæcilian.
A compound formed by the union of cyanogen with an element orradical.

A boat made by covering a wicker frame with leather oroilcloth. It was used by the ancient Britons, and is still used byfisherman in Wales and some parts of Ireland. Also, a similar boatused in Thibet and in Egypt.
Contradictory; inconsistent.-- Con`tra*dict"ive*ly, adv..

A rare element of the vanadium group, first found in a varietyof the mineral columbite occurring in Connecticut, probably atHaddam. Atomic weight 94.2. Symbol Cb or Nb. Now more commonly calledniobium.
Having the form a piece of turf, i. e., many stems from onerootstock or from many entangled rootstocks or roots. [Written alsocæspitose.]
Secretion of abnormally colored perspiration.
The spirit of comradeship; comradeship. [R.]"Certainly", said Dunham, with the comradery of the smoker. W. D.Howells.
See Closure, 5.
Short; as, a cutty knife; a cutty sark. [Scot.]
The chough.
In a covetous manner.
A kind of field spaniel, with short legs and stout body, which,unlike other spaniels, hunts silently.
A heaping together. [R.] Bacon.
One who considers; a man of reflection; a thinker. Milton.
Melodious; musical. "Birds that are most canorous." Sir T.Browne.A long, lound, and canorous peal of laughter. De Quincey.
Of or pertaining to a climax; forming, or of the nature of, aclimax, or ascending series.
The receptacle of the flowers in a composite plant; -- alsocalled clinium.
Of the nature of an onion, as in odor; alliaceous.
A small South American edentate (Chlamyphorus truncatus, and C.retusus) allied to the armadillo. It is covered with a leathery shellor coat of mail, like a cloak, attached along the spine.
A bailiff's assistant.
Same as Chopine, n.
An incubator for sickly infants, esp. those prematurely born.
See Center.
A structure or frame of timber for a foundation, or forsupporting a roof, or for lining a shaft.
Set or covered with cottages.Even humble Harting's cottaged vale. Collins.
An order of ganoid fishes including among living species thebichir (Polypterus). See Brachioganoidei.
The player who stands behind the batsman to catch the ball.
A form of tackle for loading a log sideways on a sled, skidway,etc.
One who remonstrates in opposition or answer to a remonstraint.[R.]They did the synod wrong to make this distinction ofcontraremonstrants and remonstrants. Hales.
A substance, as salt, ammonium chloride, etc., whichcrystallizes with water of crystallization only at low temperatures,or below the freezing point of water. F. Guthrie.

A prefix from the Latin preposition cum, signifying with,together, in conjunction, very, etc. It is used in the form com-before b, m, p, and sometimes f, and by assimilation becomes col-before l, cor- before r, and con- before any consonant except b, h,l, m, p, r, and w. Before a vowel com- becomes co-; also before h, w,and sometimes before other consonants.
See Cony.
Milk curdled so as to become thick.
The formation of chyle. See Chylifaction.
An officer on the bishop, who exercises ecclesiasticaljurisdiction in parts of the diocese at a distance from the residenceof the bishop. Ayliffe.
In a complacent manner.
State of being curly.
Like a citron or lemon; of a lemon color; greenish yellow.Citrine ointment (Med.), a yellowish mercurial ointment, theunquentum hydrargyri nitratis.
The act of thinking; thought; meditation; contemplation. "Fixedin cogitation deep." Milton.
The common gazelle (Gazella dorcas). See Gazelle. [Written alsokorin.]
A thermometer for the measurement of low temperatures, esp.such an instrument containing alcohol or some other liquid of a lowerfreezing point than mercury.
A large roundish variety of the cultivated hazelnut.
A work or artificial watercourse for throwing water on landsthat lie on the slopes of hills; a catchdrain.
A performer upon cymbals.

Any of several acts forbidding the immigration of Chineselaborers into the United States, originally from 1882 to 1892 by actof May 6, 1882, then from 1892 to 1902 by act May 5, 1892. By act ofApril 29, 1902, all existing legislation on the subject was reënactedand continued, and made applicable to the insular possessions of theUnited States.
A little hood or veil, resembling an extinguisher in form andposition, covering each of the small flaskike capsules which containthe spores of mosses; also, any similar covering body.
An organ of female insects, containing a cement to unite theejected ova.

One of the elementary substances, commonly isolated as agreenish yellow gas, two and one half times as heavy as air, of anintensely disagreeable suffocating odor, and exceedingly poisonous.It is abundant in nature, the most important compound being commonsalt. It is powerful oxidizing, bleaching, and disinfecting agent.Symbol Cl. Atomic weight, 35.4. Chlorine family, the elementsfluorine, chlorine, bromine, and iodine, called the halogens, andclassed together from their common peculiariries.
Dexterity in devising and effecting a purpose; cunning;artifice; stratagem.He taketh the wise in their own craftiness. Job. v. 13.
A chromosphere. [R.]
A fixed, semidrying oil extracted from cottonseed. It is paleyellow when pure (sp. gr., .92-.93). and is extensively used in soapmaking, in cookery, and as an adulterant of other oils.
A very fast, unarmored, lightly armed vessel designed tocapture or destroy merchant vessels of an enemy. Not being intendedto fight, they may be improvised from fast passenger steamers.
A priming of size mixed with whiting or white lead, used inhouse painting, etc.; also, a size upon which gold leaf is applied ingilding.
See Coupe. [Obs.] Johnson.
The region or home of cockneys; cockneys, collectively.Thackeray.
Chemical action taking place through an intervening membrane.

A large hemipterous insect of the family Reduviidæ, often foundin houses, esp. in the southern and western United States. It bitesseverely, and is one of the species called kissing bugs. It is alsocalled big bedbug.
Crescent-shaped. "Crescentic lobes." R. Owen.

Consisting of, or containing, cells; of or pertaining to a cellor cells. Cellular plants, Cellular cryptogams (Bot.), thoseflowerless plants which have no ducts or fiber in their tissue, asmosses, fungi, lichens, and algæ.-- Cellular theory, or Cell theory (Biol.), a theory, according towhich the essential element of every tissue, either vegetable oranimal, is a cell; the whole series of cells having been formed fromthe development of the germ cell and by differentiation convertedinto tissues and organs which, both in plants ans animals, are to beconsidered as a mass of minute cells communicating with each other.-- Cellular tissue. (a) (Anat.) See conjunctive tissue underConjunctive. (b) (Bot.) Tissue composed entirely of parenchyma, andhaving no woody fiber or ducts. cellular telephone, a portable radio-telephone transmitting and receiving the radio-telephonic signalsfrom one of a group of transmitter-receiver stations so arranged thatthey provide adequate signal contact for such telephones over acertain geographical area. The area within which one transmitter mayservice such portable telephones is called its "cell.
Unity of action.
A close four-wheeled carriage, with one seat inside, and a seatfor the driver.
In a chalky manner; as chalk.

That change in a disease which indicates whether the result isto be recovery or death; sometimes, also, a striking change ofsymptoms attended by an outward manifestation, as by an eruption orsweat.Till some safe crisis authorize their skill. Dryden.
One who concocts.
A water-tight inclosure, as of piles packed with clay, fromwhich the water is pumped to expose the bottom (of a river, etc.) andpermit the laying of foundations, building of piers, etc.
Capable of being circumscribed or limited by bounds.
Having the same limits; ending at the same time; conterminous.Lamb.
The condition, dignity, of office of a cardinal
The title of the wife of the czarowitz.
The quality of being musical.He chooses his language for its rich canorousness. Lowell.
The cornelian cherry (Cornus Mas), a European shrub withclusters of small, greenish flowers, followed by very acid but edibledrupes resembling cherries.

A poem set to music; a musical composition comprising choruses,solos, interludes, etc., arranged in a somewhat dramatic manner;originally, a composition for a single noise, consisting of bothrecitative and melody.
See under Sergeant.
A plane used for working the upper surface of staircase rails.
Chancellorship. [Obs.] Gower.
The active principle of the water hemlock (Cicuta) extracted asa poisonous gummy substance.
Placed in a caroche. [Obs.]Beggary rides caroched. Massenger.
Without a chape.
See Calash.
One who breeds gamecocks. L'Estrange.
Scientific examination of the cranium.
A woman who competes.
The state of being cloudy.
Granular; pertaining to, or having the granular structurecharacteristic of, the class of meteorites called chondrites.
Relating to a wedge; wedge-shaped.
Having the ribs or the veins of the leaves curved; -- calledalso curvinervate and curve-veined.
The substance of the body of a cell, as distinguished from thekaryoplasma, or substance of the nucleus.-- Cy`to*plas"mic (-pl, a.
The quality of being contradictory; opposition; inconsistency.J. Whitaker.

Of fundamental importance; preëminet; superior; chief;principal.The cardinal intersections of the zodiac. Sir T. Browne.Impudence is now a cardinal virtue. Drayton.But cardinal sins, and hollow hearts, I fear ye. Shak.Cardinal numbers, the numbers one, two, three, etc., in distinctionfrom first, second, third, etc., which are called ordinal numbers.-- Cardinal points (a) (Geol.) The four principal points of thecompass, or intersections of the horizon with the meridian and theprime vertical circle, north, south east, and west. (b) (Astrol.) Therising and setting of the sun, the zenith and nadir.-- Cardinal signs (Astron.) Aries, Lidra, Cancer, and Capricorn.-- Cardinal teeth (Zoöl.), the central teeth of bivalve shell. SeeBivalve.-- Cardinal veins (Anat.), the veins in vertebrate embryos, whichrun each side of the vertebral column and returm the blood to theheart. They remain through life in some fishes.-- Cardinal virtues, preëminent virtues; among the ancients,prudence, justice, temperance, and fortitude.-- Cardinal winds, winds which blow from the cardinal points duenorth, south, east, or west.
Dependent for effect on something that may or may not occur;as, a contingent estate.If a contingent legacy be left to any one when he attains, or if heattains, the age of twenty-one. Blackstone.
The coral or skeleton of a zoöphyte, whether calcareous ofhorny, simple or compound. See Coral.

An instrument, usually resembling a pair of dividers orcompasses with curved legs, for measuring the diameter or thicknessof bodies, as of work shaped in a lathe or planer, timber, masts,shot, etc.; or the bore of firearms, tubes, etc.; -- called alsocaliper compasses, or caliber compasses. Caliper square, adraughtsman's or mechanic's square, having a graduated bar andadjustable jaw or jaws. Knight.-- Vernier calipers. See Vernier.
Greediness of appetite for flesh. [Sportive.] Pope.
Condition of a client; state of being under the protection of apatron. Dryden.

Originally, a part of the palestra, or gymnasium among theGreeks; either the place where sand was stored for use in sprinklingthe wrestlers, or the wrestling ground itself. Hence, a part of theorchestra of the Greek theater.

Of or pertaining to the lowest period of the Devonian age.(Seethe Diagram, under Geology.) The Corniferous period has been socalled from the numerous seams of hornstone which characterize thelater part of the period, as developed in the State of New York.
Producing coral; coraliferous.
Washington -- a nickname. See Chinook, n.
In a convivial manner.
The district to which a constable's power is limited. [Obs.]Sir M. Hale.
Calciferous. Specifically: (Zoöl.) of or pertaining to hteportion of the which forms the eggshell in birds and reptiles.Huxley.
The institution, government, or authority of a church. [R.] Bp.Pearson.
To daub or smear, as with lime; to make or finish in a slipshodway. [Scot.]
Affected with color blindness. See Color blindness, underColor, n.
Cobblestone. [Prov. Eng.]
A South African mole of the genus Chrysochloris; the goldenmole, the fur of which reflects brilliant metallic hues of green andgold.
A neckcloth; a piece of silk, fine muslin, or other cloth, wornby men about the neck.While his wig was combed and his cravat tied. Macualay.
Of or pertaining to, or produced by, a cardiograph.
A loding room; esp., a sleeping place partitioned off from alarge dormitory.
A highly stimulating volatile infammable oil, distilled fromthe leaves of an East Indian tree (Melaleuca cajuputi, etc.) It isgreenish in color and has a camphoraceous odor and pungent taste.

A district on the west coast of Africa. Calabar bean, The of aclimbing legumious plant (Physostigma venenosum), a native oftropical Africa. It is highly poisonous. It is used to producecontraction of the pupil of the eye; also in tetanus, neuralgia, andrheumatic diseases; -- called also ordeal bean, being used by thenegroes in trials for witchcraft.
Love; tender regard. [Obs.] Chaucer.
Of or pertaining to Cilicia in Asia Minor.-- n.
One versed in crustalogy.

Paly, and then divided fesswise, so that each vertical piece iscut into two, having the colors used alternately or counterchanged.Thus the escutcheon in the illustration may also be blazoned paly ofsix per fess counterchanged argent and azure.
An ill-natured person. [Colloq.] "Crosspatch, draw the latch."Mother Goose.
An outer wall. [Obs.] Chambers.
Lying down; recumbent. J. Dyer.
The office, rank, or dignity of a cardinal.
Marking an equality in the tides; having high tide at the sametime. Cotidal lines (Phys. Geog.), lines on a map passing throughplaces that have high tide at the same time.
Brought close together; arched inward so that the points meet;converging; in close contact; as, the connivent petals of a flower,wings of an insect, or folds of membrane in the human system, etc.
One who contends; a contestant.
See Body cavity, under Body.
A strong, liquid, organic base, C3H7.C6H4.NH2, homologous withaniline.

A genus of ganoid fishes, of the order Dipnoi, first known asMesozoic fossil fishes; but recently two living species have beendiscovered in Australian rivers. They have lungs so well developedthat they can leave the water and breathe in air. In Australia theyare called salmon and baramunda. See Dipnoi, and Archipterygium.
A small rodent (Lagamys princeps) inhabiting the summits of theRocky Mountains; -- also called crying hare, calling hare, cony,American pika, and little chief hare.
Tending to form, or to become, a calx or earthlike substance onbeing oxidized or burnt; as magnesium, calcium. etc.

The right of an author or his assignee, under statute, to printand publish his literary or artistic work, exclusively of all otherpersons. This right may be had in maps, charts, engravings, plays,and musical compositions, as well as in books.

Wood-tar oil; an oily antiseptic liquid, of a burning smokytaste, colorless when pure, but usually colored yellow or brown byimpurity or exposure. It is a complex mixture of various phenols andtheir ethers, and is obtained by the distillation of wood tar,especially that of beechwood.
Composed of clumps; massive; shapeless. Leigh Hunt.
Abounding with charms. "His charmful lyre." Cowley.

In the game of casino, to play a card which will take two ormore cards whose aggregate number of pips equals those of the cardplayed. Combining weight (Chem.), that proportional weight, usuallyreferred to hydrogen as a standard, and for each element fixed andexact, by which an element unites with another to form a distinctcompound. The combining weights either are identical with, or aremultiples or multiples of, the atomic weight. See Atomic weight,under Atomic, a.
One who countenances, favors, or supports.
To make a hundredfold; to repeat a hundred times. [R.] Howell.
See Copier.

A colorless, amorphous, nitrogenous substance, tasteless andodorless, formed from cartilaginous tissue by long-continued actionof boiling water. It is similar to gelatin, and is a large ingredientof commercial gelatin.
Cuckold. [Obs.] Chaucer.
Adorned with cabling.
Situated in one plane.
Trick; deception. Bp. Watson.
One who complies, yields, or obeys; one of an easy, yieldytemper. Swift.
Those parts of a picture in which the human body or any part ofit is represented in full color; the flesh tints.The flesh tints in painting are termed carnations. Fairholt.
See Cretan.

Of or pertaining to landed property. Cadastral survey, orCadastral map, a survey, map, or plan on a large scale (Usuallytopographical map, which exaggerates the dimensions of houses and thebreadth of roads and streams, for the sake of distinctness. Brande &C.
An opposite point [Obs.] Sir E. Sandys.
To change into, or use as, a consonant. "The vowel isconsonantized, that is, made closer in position." Peile.
Same as Castellany.
One of a class of anchorites who lived in various parts ofScotland, Ireland, and Wales.The pure Culdees Were Albyn's earliest priests of God. Campbell.
The relationship of cousins; state of being cousins;cousinhood. G. Eliot.
With clashing.
To form into chyme.
Relating to intercourse with men; social; -- opposed tocontemplative.She chose . . . to endue him with the conversative qualities ofyouth. Sir H. Wotton.
Great heat, as of the body in fever.
Like the brain in form or substance.
Same as Cerial. [Obs.] Chaucer.
The gum resin of the hemp plant (Cannabis sativa). Same asChurrus. Balfour.

To put on the other tack by dropping the lee anchor as soon asthe wind is out of the sails (which brings the vessel's head to thewind), and by cutting the cable as soon as she pays off on the othertack. Clubhauling is attempted only in an exigency.
Capable of receiving consolation.

A small marine fish (Mallotus villosus) of the familySalmonidæ, very abundant on the coasts of Greenland, Iceland,Newfoundland, and Alaska. It is used as a bait for the cod. [Writtenalso capelan and caplin.]
A salt of columbic acid; a niobate. See Columbium.
One accustomed to climb rocks or crags; esp., one who makes abusiness of climbing the cliffs overhanging the sea to get the eggsof sea birds or the birds themselves.
The state of being clogged.
Fracture (of a bone) into a number of pieces. Dunglison.
Causing rapid waste or exhaustion; melting; as, collequativesweats.
A neck or cervix. Dunglison.
The ancient Latin name of Scotland; -- still used in poetry.
See Cassava.
One of the Cestoidea.
To prepare or treat with collodion. R. Hunt.
That branch of acoustics which treats of reflested sounds;catacoustics.
Of or pertaining to a dove; dovelike; dove-colored. "Columbineinnocency." Bacon.
A small island or ledge of rock in the water; a key. [Sp. Am.]
A wind instrument, blown by a single reed, of richer and fullertone than the oboe, which has a double reed. It is the leadinginstrument in a military band.

A genus of carnivorous mammals, of the family Canidæ, includingthe dogs and wolves. Canis major Etym: [L., larger dog], aconstellation to the southeast of Orion, containing Sirius or the DogStar.-- Canis minor Etym: [L., smaller dog], a constellation to the eastof Orion, containing Procyon, a star of the first magnitude.

A contractile cell or vesicle containing liquid pigment andcapable of changing its form or size, thus causing changes of colorin the translucent skin of such animals as possess them. They arehighly developed and numerous in the cephalopods.
That which is constructed or formed; an edifice; a fabric.[Obs.]
Lame; disabled; in a crippled condition. [R.] Mrs. Trollope.

Serving or intended to coerce; having power to constrain.-- Co*er"cive*ly, adv.-- Co*er"cive*ness, n.Coercive power can only influence us to outward practice. Bp.Warburton.Coercive or Coercitive force (Magnetism), the power or force which iniron or steel produces a slowness or difficulty in impartingmagnetism to it, and also interposes an obstacle to the return of abar to its natural state when active magnetism has ceased. It plainlydepends on the molecular constitution of the metal. Nichol.The power of resisting magnetization or demagnization is sometimescalled coercive force. S. Thompson.
A genus of plants of the order Scitamineæ, including theturmeric plant (Curcuma longa). Curcuma paper. (Chem.) See Turmericpaper, under Turmeric.
An implement consisting of a broad scythe for cutting grain,with a set of long fingers parallel to the scythe, designed toreceive the grain, and to lay it eventlyin a swath.
Distributed in a curved line, as leaves along a stem.
The act or practice of crimping; money paid to a crimp forshipping or enlisting men.
See Calligraphic.

Disobedience of the rules, orders, or process of a court ofjustice, or of rules or orders of a legislative body; disorderly,contemptuous, or insolent language or behavior in presence of acourt, tending to disturb its proceedings, or impair the respect dueto its authority.
The chief officer of a regiment; an officer ranking next abovea lieutenant colonel and next below a brigadier general.

A very extensive order of Annelida, characterized by thepresence of lateral setæ, or spines, on most or all of the segments.They are divided into two principal groups: Oligochæta, including theearthworms and allied forms, and Polychæta, including most of themarine species.
See Cap-a-pie. Shak.
Caryophyllaceous.
A dwelling or ordinary residence in a place; habitation.Commorancy consists in usually lying there. Blackstone.
See Cockswain.

One of several diseases affecting the digestive and intestinaltract and more or less dangerous to life, esp. the one commonlycalled Asiatic cholera. Asiatic cholera, a malignant and rapidlyfatal disease, originating in Asia and frequently epidemic in themore filthy sections of other lands, to which the germ or specificpoison may have been carried. It is characterized by diarrhea, rice-water evacuations, vomiting, cramps, pinched expression, andlividity, rapidly passing into a state of collapse, followed bydeath, or by a stage of reaction of fever.-- Cholera bacillus. See Comma bacillus.-- Cholera infantum, a dangerous summer disease, of infants, causedby hot weather, bad air, or poor milk, and especially fatal in largecities.-- Cholera morbus, a disease characterized by vomiting and purging,with gripings and cramps, usually caused by imprudence in diet or bygastrointestinal disturbance.-- Chicken cholera. See under Chicken.-- Hog cholera. See under Hog.-- Sporadic cholera, a disease somewhat resembling the Asiaticcholera, but originating where it occurs, and rarely becomingepidemic.
Same as Cross-spale.
One of an ancient religious sect, so called fron Cerinthus, aJew, who attempted to unite the doctrines of Christ with the opinionsof the Jews and Gnostics. Hook.
A sphinx with the head of a ram.
The three days preceding the Feast of the Ascension.
Consisting of clay; abounding with clay; partaking of clay;like clay.
p. p. of Carve. Chaucer.
One who clamors.
To be or become broken down or in, or pressed into a smallercompass, by external weight or force; as, an eggshell crushes easily.
A compound medicinal powder, used by the ancients to sprinkleon ulcers, to absorb perspiration, etc. Dunglison.
Worthiness of consideration; dignity; value; size; amount.
Of or pertaining to a kind of chair appropriated to Romanmagistrates and dignitaries; pertaining to, having, or conferring,the right to sit in the curule chair; hence, official.
The quality or state of being corrosible. Bailey.

Speaking in a whining tone of voice; using technical orreligious terms affectedly; affectedly pious; as, a canting rogue; acanting tone. - Cant"ing*ly, adv.-- Cant"ing*ness, n. Canting arms, Canting heraldry (Her.), bearingsin the nature of a rebus alluding to the name of the bearer. Thus,the Castletons bear three castles, and Pope Adrian IV. (NicholasBreakspeare) bore a broken spear.
Tending to promote the formation of a cicatrix; good forhealing of a wound.
A buskin anciently used by tragic actors on the stage; hence,tragedy in general.The moment had arrived when it was thought that the mask and thecothurn might be assumed with effect. Motley.
One of a set of photographs of a moving object, taken for thepurpose of recording and exhibiting successive phases of the motion.--Chron`o*pho*tog"ra*phy, n.
The art or practice of cozening; artifice; fraud. Shak.

The 12th day of October, on which day in 1492 ChristopherColumbus discovered America, landing on one of the Bahama Islands(probably the one now commonly called Watling Island), and naming it"San Salvador"; -- called also Discovery Day. This day is made alegal holiday in many States of The United States.
See Control.
Aee under Force.
A strolling gamester. [Ireland] Spenser.
Wearing a coif.
To come to an issue; to turn out; to succed; as, to cheve wellin a enterprise. [Prov. or Obs.] Holland.
The Brazilian kite (Polyborus Brasiliensis); -- so called inimitation of its notes.

A name given in the United States to various species ofsiluroid fishes; as, the yellow cat (Amiurus natalis); the bind cat(Gronias nigrilabrus); the mud cat (Pilodictic oilwaris), the stonecat (Noturus flavus); the sea cat (Arius felis), etc. This name isalso sometimes applied to the wolf fish. See Bullhrad.
Formed by consultation; resulting from conference. Consultaryresponse (Law), the opinion of a court on a special case. Wharton.
Of, or like, cord; having cords or cordlike parts.
A reception held at the time of going to bed, as by a sovereignor great prince. [Obs.] Dryden.The duke's levees and couchees were so crowded that the antechamberswere full. Bp. Burnet.
A commander; the commanding officer of a place, or of a body ofmen; as, the commandant of a navy-yard.
Pertaining to convulsion; convulsive. "Convulsionarystruggles." Sir W. Scott.
The act, art, or practice, of riding a cycle, esp. a bicycle ortricycle.
Of or pertaining to cane or canes; abounding with canes.Milton.
The quality of being clusy.The drudging part of life is chiefly owing to clumsiness andignorance. Collier.
Wearing a cockade. Young.
Making complete. [R.] J. Harris.
To create at the same time.If God did concreate grace with Adam. Jer. Taylor.
An outer framework of timber, inclosing something within it; asthe cage of a staircase. Gwilt.
Having that cloudiness or dimness of surface that is called"blooming."
A catch crop planted, esp. in orchards. as a protection to thesoil in winter, as well as for the benefit of the soil when plowedunder in spring.
A part of male dress in front of the breeches, formerly madevery conspicuous. Shak. Fosbroke.
the life estate which a husband has in the lands of hisdeceased wife, which by the common law takes effect where he has hadissue by her, born alive, and capable of inheriting the lands. Mozley& W.
Somewhat like a cavalier.
Concubinary.The married and concubinarian, as well as looser clergy. Milman.
Mass of clouds; cloudiness. [R.]A scudding cloudage of shapes. Coleridge.
A large genus of plants bearing bell-shaped flowers, often ofgreat beauty; -- also called bellflower.
A kind of spiral curve found in certain univalve shells.Agassiz.
A tissue of vegetable cells which are thickend at the anglesand (usually) elongated.
The common burdock; the clotbur. [Obs.] Wyclif.
The office of a canon; a canonry.
In a melodious, flowing style; in a singing style, as opposedto bravura, recitativo, or parlando.
Readiness of belief; a disposition to believe on slightevidence.That implict credulity is the mark of a feeble mind will not bedisputed. Sir W. Hamilton.
A form of scarlet fever characterized by ulcerated or putridsore throat.
Land appendant to a cot or cottage, or held by a cottager orcotter.
To take prisoner; to capture.Their inhabitans slaughtered and captived. Burke.
To call on or summon by a sacred name or in solemn manner; toimplore earnestly; to adjure.I conjure you, let him know, Whate'er was done against him, Cato didit. Addison.
Adapted to eating flesh.-- n.
A counter tally; correspondence (in sound). [Obs.] At thecountretaille, in return. Chaucer.
One who cuts throats; a murderer; an assassin.
Freedom from all that is meretricious, gaundy, or affected; as,chasteness of design.
Like chert; containing chert; flinty.
The quality of being communicable; capability of beingimparted.

Pertaining to, or obtained from, cinnamon. Cinnamic acid(Chem.), a white, crystalline, odorless substance.C6H5.C2H2C2H2.CO2H, formerly obtained from storax and oil ofcinnamon, now made from certain benzene derivatives in largequantities, and used for the artificial production of indigo.
Disposition to willful wrongdoing; malignity; perversity;cantankerousness; obstinacy. [Slang or Colloq., U. S.]
One who opposes baptism, especially of infants. [Obs.] Featley.
A fast of forty days on bread and water. [Obs.]
Having the form of a caulis.
Five; the number five in dice or cards.
(Astron.) A northern constellation near the pole. Its head,which is in the Milky Way, is marked by a triangle formed by threestars of the fourth magnitude. See Cassiopeia.

The movement of the blood in the blood-vascular system, bywhich it is brought into close relations with almost every livingelementary constituent. Also, the movement of the sap in the vesselsand tissues of plants.
The act of killing deer; deer-slaying. [R.]
A somewhat riotous parade, accompanied with the blowing of tinhorus, and other discordant noises; also, a burlesque serenade; acharivari. [U. S.]
Relating to a conjunction.

Under cover; screened; sheltered; not exposed; hidden. Coveredway (Fort.), a corridor or banquette along the top of thecounterscarp and covered by an embankment whose slope forms theglacis. It gives the garrisonn an open line of communication aroundthe works, and a standing place beyond the ditch. See Illust. ofRavelin.
A sculptured basket of flowers; a corbel. [Obs.]
A tropical fish of the Atlantic ocean (Dutes auriga); -- calledalso charioteer. The name refers to a long, lashlike spine of thedorsal fin.

An opinion, or judgment, formed on defective or presumptiveevidence; probable inference; surmise; guess; suspicion.He [Herodotus] would thus have corrected his first loose conjectureby a real study of nature. Whewell.Conjectures, fancies, built on nothing firm. Milton.
Same as Cirrus.
Rendering mutual aid; coadjutant. Feltham.
Connection by birth; natural union. [Obs.] Dr. H. More.

The native church of Egypt or church of Alexandria, which ingeneral organization and doctrines resembles the Roman CatholicChurch, except that it holds to the Monophysitic doctrine which wascondemned (a. d. 451) by the council of Chalcedon, and allows itspriests to marry. The "pope and patriarch" has jurisdiction over theAbyssinian Church. Since the 7th century the Coptic Church has beenso isolated from modifying influences that in many respects it is themost ancient monument of primitive Christian rites and ceremonies.But centuries of subjection to Moslem rule have weakened and degradedit.

A process of transfer or transmission, as of heat orelectricity, by means of currents in liquids or gases, resulting fromchanges of temperature and other causes.Liquids are generally heated by convection -- when heat is appliedfrom bellow. Nichol.
To deceive; to cheat; to play false; to lie; to wheedle; tocajole.For guineas in other men's breeches, Your gamesters will palm andwill cog. Swift.
A cicada. See Cicada. "At eve a dry cicala sung." Tennison.
The act or process of converting the surface of iron intosteel. Ure.
Relating to stone in the bladder.
See Chawdron. [Obs.]
The act of extending equally, or the state of being equallyextended.
A soft, sweet stop, or set of open wood pipes in an organ.
To preach. [Obs.] Lithgow.
An associate in labor, especially in literary or scientificlabor.
The state or quality of being compact; close union of parts;density.
See Congruity.
A knife or instrument used in cystotomy.
A woman who caters. Milton.
Possessing, or characterized by, courage; brave; bold.With this victory, the women became most courageous and proud, andthe men waxed . . . fearful and desperate. Stow.

The official staff or wand of Hermes or Mercury, the messengerof the gods. It was originally said to be a herald's staff of olivewood, but was afterwards fabled to have two serpents coiled about it,and two wings at the top.
Any part of a mathematical instrument that moves or slidesbackward and forward upon another part.
A Small leguminous plant (Cicer arietinum) of Asia, Africa, andthe sounth of Europe; the chick; the dwarf pea; the gram.

Of or pertaining to, or derived from, a plant of the genusCroton, or from croton oil. Crotonic acid (Chem.), a whitecrystalline organic acid, C3H5.CO2H, of the ethylene, or acrylic acidseries. It was so named because formerly supposed to exist in crotonoil. Also, any acid metameric with crotonic acid proper.
A surface of the fourth degree, having certain specialrelations to spherical surfaces. The tore or anchor ring is one ofthe cyclides.
A car; a chariot. [Obs.] Chaucer.
Of or pertaining to cherubs; angelic. "The cherubic host."Milton.
A cohabitant. Hobbes.
Congeniality.
Same as Cribbing, 4.
Pertaining to the Chætopoda.-- n.

An official having charge of a hsien, or administrativedistrict, in China; a district magistrate, responsible for good orderin his hsien (which see), and having jurisdiction in its civil andcriminal cases.
A temporary structure sometimes used in the funeral solemnitiesof eminent persons, for the public exhibition of the remains, ortheir conveyance to the place of burial.
See Crare. [Obs.]
Capable of being cleansed. Sherwood.
A container.
A description of climates.
Long-established practice, considered as unwritten law, andresting for authority on long consent; usage. See Usage, andPrescription.
The science of colors; that part of optics which treats of theproperties of colors.
A circular projecting portion.
A caption or sophistical mode of arguing. [R.]
Same as Monkey-puzzle.
One of a kind of minute, calcareous bodies, probably vegetable,often abundant in deep-sea mud.
One who celebrates; a praiser. Boyle.
A rounded tooth or notch of a crenate leaf, or any part that iscrenate; -- called also crenelle.
Relating to, or composed of, cotton; cottony. [Obs.]Cottomary and woolly pillows. Sir T. Browne.
Participation of the same nature; coexistence in the samesubstance. "His [the Son's] . . . consubstantiality with the Father."Hammend.
A kind of beetle; the cockchafer. The name is also applied toother species; as, the rose chafer.
A crossbowman.[Obs.]
A joint assessor.
A silvered aromatic pill, used to correct the odor of thebreath.

Of or pertaining to a condyle. Condylar foramen (Anat.), aformen in front of each condyle of the occipital bone; -- sometimescalled the anterior condylar foramen when a second, or posterior,foramen is present behind the condyle, as often happens in man.
Having power to captivate or cham; fascinating; as, captivatingsmiles.-- Cap"tiva`ting*ly, adv.

A sunk panel of ceilings or soffits. Pneumatic caisson(Engin.), a caisson, closed at the top but open at the bottom, andresting upon the ground under water. The pressure of air forced intothe caisson keeps the water out. Men and materials are admitted tothe interior through an air lock. See Lock.
Concupiscent. [Obs.]
A small composite plant with cottony or silky stem and leaves,primarily a species of Gnaphalium, but the name is now given to manyplants of different genera, as Filago, Antennaria, etc.; cottonweed.
The dried leaf of a South American shrub (Erythroxylon Coca).In med., called Erythroxylon.
Counterbalance; balance, as of one scale against another.[Obs.] Howell.
The science of the form and characteristics of the skull. [R.]
Contractibility.
A tierce or cask for dried fruits, etc., usually about 700 lbs.Simmonds.
One who, or that which, confirms; a confirmer. Sir T. Browne.
The pincherlike claw of Crustacea and Arachnida.

The act of disclosing sins or faults to a priest in order toobtain sacramental absolution.Auricular confession . . . or the private and special confession ofsins to a priest for the purpose of obtaining his absolution. Hallam.
A chink or cleft; a narrow and deep ravine; as, Shanklin Chinein the Isle of Wight, a quarter of a mile long and 230 feet deep.[Prov. Eng.] "The cottage in a chine." J. Ingelow.
Permissible; done lawfully; as, entry congeable.
Pertaining to Samuel Taylor Coleridge, or to his poetry ormetaphysics.

A ball of thread; a thread or other means of guidance. Same asClew.You have wound a goodly clue. Shak.This clue once found unravels all the rest. Pope.Serve as clues to guide us into further knowledge. Locke.
See Cozy.
To join in praising. [Obs.] Howell.
Following by consequence; consequent; deducible. [R.]"Consectary impieties." Sir T. Browne.
Close union or connection of parts; manner of joining;construction. [Obs.] "With comely compass and compacture strong."Spenser.
One who practices chiromancy. Dryden.
A wind from the northeast. Milton.
One who carries on a controversy; a disputant.He [Johnson] was both intellectually and morally of the stuff ofwhich controversialists are made. Macaulay.

A seal, as of a letter. Lettre de cachet Etym: [F.], a sealedletter, especially a letter or missive emanating from the sovereign;-- much used in France before the Revolution as an arbitrary order ofimprisonment.
A drove or herd. [Obs.] Haliwell.
Consisting of, or similar to, chyle.
A sudden copious rainfall, as the whole cloud had beenprecipitated at once.
Fellowship; association; companionship. [Obs.] Sir T. Browne.
Mixed with copper; containing copper, or made of copper; likecopper.
The quality of being chuffy.
The art of producing photographs in colors.
Proceeding by the smaller intervals (half steps or semitones)of the scale, instead of the regular intervals of the diatonic scale.
One of a body of cavalry.
Minced meat. [Obs.] Bacon.
Culpable. [Obs.]
With concurrence; unitedly.
Heat. [Obs.]
Comatose.
A personcoetaneous with another; a contemporary. [R.]A . . . coetanean of the late earl of SouthamptoAubrey.
Compliments; greetings. [Obs.]Hearty commends and much endeared love to you. Howell.
An herbaceous or woody stem which bears leaves, and may bearflowers.
A remote relation. See Quater-cousin. Shak.

The earth alumina, as found native in a crystalline state,including sapphire, which is the fine blue variety; the orientalruby, or red sapphire; the oriental amethyst, or purple sapphire; andadamantine spar, the hair-brown variety. It is the hardest substancefound native, next to the diamond.
The act of dividing into parts or compartments; division; also,a division or compartment. [Obs.]Their temples . . . needed no compartitions. Sir H. Wotton.
An opposing force.
Capability of being contracted; quality of being contractible;as, the contractibiliy and dilatability of air. Arbuthnot.
Tufted cord, of silk or worsted, for the trimimg of ladies'dresses, for embroidery and fringes, and for the weft of chenillerugs.
To render capable; to enable; to qualify.By thih instruction we may be capaciated to observe those errors.Dryden.
A twisted cord; a tassel. Halliwell.
Worthy to be commemorated.

A method of pronouncing Latin and Greek in which the vowelshave their more familiar Continental values, as in German andItalian, the consonants being pronounced mostly as in English. Thestricter form of this method of pronouncing Latin approaches theRoman, the modified form the English, pronunciation. The Continentalmethod of Greek pronunciation is often called Erasmian.
An instrument for detecting and measuring the amount of carbonwhich is present, or more esp. the amount of carbon dioxide, by itsaction on limewater or by other means.
A heathlike plant of the genus Empetrum, and its fruit, ablack, scarcely edible berry; -- also called crakeberry.
Formed with, or having, a bend or crank; as, a cranked axle.
See Calumba.
See Legislature, Portugal.
a creator of great skill in the manual arts.Syn. -- craftsman.[WordNet 1.5]
One of the Coleoptera.
Was, should be, or would be, able, capable, or susceptible.Used as an auxiliary, in the past tense or in the conditionalpresent.
The state or quality of being compendious.
The act of rolling or revolving round, as a wheel;circumvolution; the state of being whirled round. J. Gregory.
Pertaining to a cyclone.
The system of home study established in connection with thesummer schools assembled at Chautauqua, N. Y., by the MethodistEpiscopal bishop, J. H. Vincent.
Capable of cohesion.
Any bright-colored fish of the genera Chætodon, Pomacentrus,Apogon, and related genera, which live among reef corals.
An artificer who makes carts; a cart maker.

A caterpillar which at night eats off young plants of cabbage,corn, etc., usually at the ground. Some kinds ascend fruit trees andeat off the flower buds. During the day, they conceal themselves inthe earth. The common cutworms are the larvæ of various species ofAgrotis and related genera of noctuid moths.
Calendarial. [Obs.]
The lading or freight of a ship or other vessel; the goods,merchandise, or whatever is conveyed in a vessel or boat; load;freight.Cargoes of food or clothing. E. Everett.
Waxen; like wax. [Obs.] Gayton.
Castrensial. [R.]
An apple-green variety of chalcedony, colored by nickel. It hasa dull flinty luster, and is sometimes used in jewelry.
Capable of being conferred.

To exist at the same time; -- sometimes followed by with.Of substances no one has any clear idea, farther than of certainsimple ideas coexisting together. Locke.So much purity and integrity . . . coexisting with so much decay andso many infirmities. Warburton.
See Courage [Obs.]To Canterbury with full devout corage. Chaucer.
Of pertaining to the skin; existing on, or affecting, the skin;as, a cutaneous disease; cutaneous absorption; cutaneous respiration.
One who pities.
A disdanful manner.
The amphitheater of Vespasian in Rome. [Also written Coliseum.]
The philosophy of Descartes.
The science, art, or practice of healthful exercise of the bodyand limbs, to promote strength and gracefulness; light gymnastics.
Exposing linen to the sun, on the grass, in the process ofbleaching.
To utter reproaches; to raise a clamor; to rail. [Obs.]To conviciate instead of accusing. Laud.
A white, crystalline, poisonous substance, regarded as aglucoside, extracted from the lily of the valley (ConvallariaMajalis). Its taste is first bitter, then sweet.
Mutual; reciprocal; united. [R.]There, with commutual zeal, we both had strove. Pope.
See Cosmopolitan.
Participation of the same nature; natural union or connection.[R.]A congruity and connaturality between them. Sir M. Hale.
An ornamental casing for a flowerpot, of porcelain, metal,paper, etc.

A slender appendage or process, formed like a claw, as the baseof petals of the pink. Gray. Claw hammer, a hammer with one end ofthe metallic head cleft for use in extracting nails, etc.-- Claw hammer coat, a dress coat of the swallowtail pattern.[Slang] -- Claw sickness, foot rot, a disease affecting sheep.
The scarfskin or epidermis. See Skin.
Brain power. [R.]
Possessing the quality of producing heat; heating. Calorificrays, the invisible, heating rays which emanate from the sum, andburning and heated bodies.
The act of telling fortunes with cards.

The amount of degree of bending of a mathematical curve, or thetendency at any point to depart from a tangent drawn to the curve atthat point. Aberrancy of curvature (Geom.), the deviation of a curvefrom a curcular form. -Absolute curvature. See under Absolute.-- Angle of curvature (Geom.), one that expresses the amount ofcurvature of a curve.-- Chord of curvature. See under Chord.-- Circle of curvature. See Osculating circle of a curve, underCircle.-- Curvature of the spine (Med.), an abnormal curving of the spine,especially in a lateral direction.-- Radius of curvature, the radius of the circle of curvature, orosculatory circle, at any point of a curve.
A kind of dress goods, made with a soft and glossy surface likecashmere.
A tool to polish the edge of a sole. Knight.
Formed of a mixture of horny and calcareous materials, as someshells and corals.
Serving, or helping, to form; composing; constituting;constituent.The component parts of natural bodies. Sir I. Newton.
Lead chromate occuring in crystals of a bright hyacinth redcolor; -- called also red lead ore.
To roast, as a cabob. Sir. T. Herbert.
A fruitful field.Libanus shall be turned into charmel, and charmel shall be esteemedas a forest. Isa. xxix. 17 (Douay version).
A little song.These pretty little chansonnettes that he sung. Black.
Shaped like or pertaining to a condyle.
See Caligraphy.
The corporal, or communion cloth. [Obs.] Fuller.
One of the ribs in a groined arch, springing from the cornersin a diagonal direction.
A confessional. [Obs.] Johnson.
Having the shape of a gourd seed; -- said of certain smallworms.
The process of straining; the matter strained; a strainer. [R.]
An engine somewhat resembling a massive crossbow, used by theancient Greeks and Romans for throwing stones, arrows, spears, etc.
One skilled in counterpoint. L. Mason.

A bird of the Parrot family, of the subfamily Cacatuinæ, havinga short, strong, and much curved beak, and the head ornamented with acrest, which can be raised or depressed at will. There are severalgenera and many species; as the broad-crested (Plictolophus, orCacatua, cristatus), the sulphur-crested (P. galeritus), etc. Thepalm or great black cockatoo of Australia is Microglossus aterrimus.Cock"a*trice, n. Etym: [OF. cocatrice crocodile, F. cocatrix,cocatrice. The word is a corruption from the same source as E.crocodile, but was confused with cock the bird, F. coq, whence arosethe fable that the animal was produced from a cock's egg. SeeCrocodile.]
Action of the brain, whether conscious or unconscious.
Catlike; feline Drummond.

A photomechanical print made directly from a hardened film ofgelatin or other colloid; also, the process of making such prints.According to one method, the film is sensitized with potassiumdichromate and exposed to light under a reversed negative. After thedichromate has been washed out, the film is soaked in glycerin andwater. As this treatment causes swelling in those parts of the filmwhich have been acted on by light, a plate results from whichimpressions can be taken with prepared ink. The albertype, phototype,and heliotype are collotypes.

Bearing producing, or containing calcite, or carbonate of lime.Calciferouse epoch (Geol.), and epoch in the American lower Siluriansystem, immediately succeeding the Cambrian period. The name alludesto the peculiar mixture of calcareous and siliceous characteristicsin many of the beds. See the Diagram under Grology.
A wind instrument nearly identical with the bagpipe. Drayton.
A worker in cordwain, or cordovan leather; a shoemaker.[Archaic.]
A heavy, colorless liquid, CCl3.NO2, of a strong pungent odor,obtained by subjecting picric acid to the action of chlorine.[Written also chloropikrin.]
Consisting of clods; full of clods.
A pulley for driving machines, etc., having two or more partsor steps of different diameters; a pulley having a conical shape.
To check (an adversary's king) in such a manner that escape inimpossible; to defeat (an adversary) by putting his king in checkfrom which there is no escape.
A cream-colored limestone for building, found near Caen,France.
Like ashes; ash-colored; cinerous.
A term at omber, signifying that the game is won. Pope.
To administer the rite of confirmation to. See Confirmation, 3.Those which are thus confirmed are thereby supposed to be fit foradmission to the sacrament. Hammond.
Deceitful; collusive; fraudulent; dishonest.
Having the flesh attached closely to the stone, as in somekinds of peaches.-- n.
A chloride. [Obs.]
The neck; also, the necklike portion of any part, as of thewomb. See Illust. of Bird.
Navigation along the coast; the details of coast pilotage.
A constructer.
A protoplasmic granule of some other color than green; -- alsocalled chromoleucite.
Capable of being climbed.
Making a clang, or a ringing metallic sound. [Obs.]
A hawker; specifically, one who travels about selling anddistributing religious tracts and books.
The property of two curves, or surfaces, which meet, and at thepoint of meeting have a common direction.
Composedly; coolly.
Pertaining to, or obtained from, bile; as, choleic acid.
A genus of cruciferous plants, containing the lady's-smock,cuckooflower, bitter cress, meadow cress, etc.
An apparatus in which coal gas, hydrogen, or air is passedthrough or over a volatile hydrocarbon, in order to confer orincrease illuminating power. [Written also carburettor.]
The act or state of growing together, as similar parts; the actof uniting by natural affinity or attraction; the state of beingunited; union; concretion.
Prohibited or excluded by law or treaty; forbidden; as,contraband goods, or trade.The contraband will always keep pace, in some measure, with the fairtrade. Burke.
A zealot. "Simon the Canaanite." Matt. x. 4.
Painless vivisection; -- opposed to sentisection. B. G. Wilder.

A system of prison discipline employing for consecutive periodscellular confinement, associated imprisonment under the mark system,restraint intermediate between imprisonment and freedom, andliberation on ticket of leave.
Consisting of a network of veins, without intermediateparenchyma, as the leaves of certain plant; latticelike.
Censorial. [R.] Bacon.
