Familiar or trifling talk; prattle.
Lowness in price, considering the usual price, or real value.
Having the form of a tube; tubular. [Written also canular.]
Full of little cavities; as, cavernulous metal. Black.
A concave molding; -- used chiefly in classical architecture.See Illust. of Calumn.
In a complex manner; not simply.
Same as Chase gun, esp. in terms bow chaser and stern chaser.See under Bow, Stern.
Relating to chivalry; knightly; chivalrous.
Fellowship; association; the act or fact of keeping companywith any one. Shak.He never seemed to avail himself of my sympathy other than by merecompanionship. W. Irwing
Informal talk or discussion, as about literary matters; lightconversation; chat.
One who causes. [R.] Sir T. Browne.
One who, or that which, connects; as:(a) A flexible tube for connecting the ends of glass tubes inpneumatic experiments.(b) A device for holding two parts of an electrical conductor incontact.
One who labors with another; an associate in labor.
To scratch. [Obs.] Chaucer.
To glitter in flashes; to flash.
A train of attendants; a procession.
A genus of trees of the order Canellaceæ, growing in the WestIndies.

A dog with a docked tail; formerly, the dog of a person notqualified to course, which, by the forest laws, must have its tailcut short, partly as a mark, and partly from a notion that the tailis necessary to a dog in running; hence, a dog not fit for sporting.Hope is a curtail dog in some affairs. Shak.
That part of optics which explants the properties and phenomenaof reflected light, and particularly that which is reflected frommirrors or polished bodies; --- formerly caled anacamptics.

The closing subdivision of the Devonian age in America. Therocks of this period are well developed in the Catskill mountains,and extend south and west under the Carboniferous formation. See theDiagram under Geology.
The state of being cognate.
See Clinanthium.
To deceive with flattery or fair words; to wheedle.I am not about to cajole or flatter you into a reception of my views.F. W. Robertson.
A small species of titmouse, with a black head; the coletit.
The husk covering an ear of Indian corn. [Colloq. U.S.]

A place where money is kept, or where it is deposited and paidout; a money box. [Obs.]This bank is properly a general cash, where every man lodges hismoney. Sir W. Temple.£20,000 are known to be in her cash. Sir R. Winwood.
Growing white, or assuming a color approaching to white.
A liquid measure formerly used in France and Great Britain,varying from half a pint to a wine quart.
Full extent; distance between extreme limits; especially; thedistance between the nearest surfaces of two bodies, or the spacebetween walls; as, a room ten feet square in the clear.
A kind of spore formed in the conceptacles of red algæ.-- Car`po*spor"ic (, a.

To send or address (by bill of lading or otherwise) to an agentor correspondent in another place, to be cared for or sold, or forthe use of such correspondent; as, to cosign a cargo or a ship; toset apart.
The commission or rank of a cornet.
A plant of the Parsley family (Apium graveolens), of which theblanched leafstalks are used as a salad.
To oppose, as another plot, by plotting; to attempt tofrustrate, as a stratagem, by stratagem.Every wile had proved abortive, every plot had been counterplotted.De Quinsey.
Without comfort or comforts; in want or distress; cheerless.Comfortless through turanny or might. Spenser.
A mineral of a black color, submetallic luster, and highspecific specific gravity. It is a niobate (or columbate) of iron andmanganese, containing tantalate of iron; -- first found in NewEngland.
With confirmation.
a box, or vase with a perforated cover to emit perfumes.
In a commensurable manner; so as to be commensurable.
An Algonquin tribe of Indians, inhabiting a large part ofBritish America east of the Rocky Mountains and south of Hudson'sBay.
In a ceremonious way.
A ship's carpenter. [Cant.]
In a clever manner.Never was man so clever absurd. C. Smart.
The presiding judge of the court of exchequer.
The quality of being cogitable; conceivableness.
The interest which one may have in a piece of ground, eventhough it is not inclosed. Bouvier.
In the form of a cup, a little widened at the top.
See Copse. [Obs.]
The quality of being conformable; conformability.
One who checks.
A nonnucleated mass of protoplasm, the supposed simplest formof independent life differing from the amoeba, in which nuclei arepresent.
privately; secretly. [Obs.]
Condescension. [Obs.]
A joint executrix.
Inclosed in a shell.The tender horns of cockled snails. Shak.
Of a consoling or comforting nature.The punishment of tyrants is a noble and awful act of justice; and ithas with truth been said to be consolatory to the human mind. Burke.
Bell-shaped; campanulate; campaniform.
An agreement between two or more persons to defraud a person ofhis rights, by the forms of law, or to obtain an object forbidden bylaw. Bouvier. Abbott.
A circlet. [Obs.] Spenser.
A yellow crystalline substance, C6Cl4.O2, regarded as aderivative of quinone, obtained by the action of chlorine on certainbenzene derivatives, as aniline.
A table stove or small furnace, usually a cylindrical box ofsheet iron, with a grate at the bottem, and an open top.
A cistern in the course, or the termination, of a drain, tocollect sedimentary or superfluous matter; a privy vault; anyreceptace of filth. [Written also sesspool.]

Native tin dioxide; tin stone; a mineral occurring intetragonal crystals of reddish brown color, and brilliant adamantineluster; also massive, sometimes in compact forms with concentricfibrous structure resembling wood (wood tin), also in rolledfragments or pebbly (Stream tin). It is the chief source of metallictin. See Black tin, under Black.
Belonging to, or like, the family of plants of which theprickly pear is a common example.
See Cystic.
A song of joy or devotion; a singing, as of carols. Coleridge.Such heavenly notes and carolings. Spenser.
The doctrine of the Cynics; the quality of being cynical; themental state, opnions, or conduct, of a cynic; morose andcontemptuous views and opinions.
A centrifugal machine.
Worship paid to the world. Cudworth.

A projectile constructed so as to take the grooves of a rifleby means of a soft copper band firmly attached near its base or,formerly, by means of an envelope of soft metal. In small arms themodern projectile, having a soft core and harder jacket, is subjectedto compression throughout the entire cylindrical part.

A French theory of government which holds that commune shouldbe a kind of independent state, and the national government aconfederation of such states, having only limited powers. It isadvocated by advanced French republicans; but it should not beconfounded with communism.

One who shows strangers the curiosities of a place; a guide.Every glib and loquacious hireling who shows strangers about theirpicture galleries, palaces, and ruins, is termed by them [theItalians] a cicerone, or a Cicero. Trench.
An unnatural, violent, and unvoluntary contraction of themuscular parts of an animal body.
In a cordial manner. Dr. H. More.
same as Merlon.
Pertaining to, or measured, by the rising of the Dog Star.Canicular days, the dog days, See Dog days.-- Canicular year, the Egyptian year, computed from one heliacalrising of the Dog Star to another.
Relating to, or consisting of, controversy; disputatious;polemical; as, controversial divinity.Whole libraries of controversial books. Macaulay.
Free from crime; innocent. Shak.
Being in conflict or collision, or in opposition; contending;contradictory; incompatible; contrary; opposing.

The act of chastising; pain inflicted for punishment andcorrection; discipline; punishment.Shall I so much dishonor my fair stars, On equal terms to give himchastesement! Shak.I have borne chastisement; I will not offend any more. Job xxxiv. 31.

A large reptile of the genus Crocodilus, of several species.They grow to the length of sixteen or eighteen feet, and inhabit thelarge rivers of Africa, Asia, and America. The eggs, laid in thesand, are hatched by the sun's heat. The best known species is thatof the Nile (C. vulgaris, or C. Niloticus). The Florida crocodile (C.Americanus) is much less common than the alligator and has longerjaws. The name is also sometimes applied to the species of otherrelated genera, as the gavial and the alligator.

Of or pertaining to Cornwall, in England. Cornish chough. SeeChough.-- Cornish engine, a single-acting pumping engine, used in mines, inCornwall and elsewhere, and for water works. A heavy pump rod orplunger, raised by the steam, forces up the water by its weight, indescending.
Lit., an eggshell; hence, an eggshell filled with confetti tobe thrown during balls, carnivals, etc. [Western U. S.]
Consignificant; jointly significate. [R.]
A form of cloud. See Cloud.
See Kleptomania.
A carbide. [R.]
A double-edged, sharp-pointed dismembering knife. [Spelt alsocatlin.] Crobb.

To make a subject of litigation; to defend, as a suit; todispute or resist; as a claim, by course of law; to controvert. Tocontest an election. (Polit.) (a) To strive to be elected. (b) Todispute the declared result of an election.
The operation of putting down or displacing the opaque lens incataract.

Of or pertaining to the French philosopher René Descartes, orhis philosophy.The Cartesion argument for reality of matter. Sir W. Hamilton.Cartesian coördinates (Geom), distance of a point from lines orplanes; -- used in a system of representing geometric quantities,invented by Descartes.-- Cartesian devil, a small hollow glass figure, used in connectionwith a jar of water having an elastic top, to illustrate the effectof the compression or expansion of air in changing the specificgravity of bodies.-- Cartesion oval (Geom.), a curve such that, for any point of thecurve mr + m'r' = c, where r and r' are the distances of the pointfrom the two foci and m, m' and c are constant; -- used by Descartes.
Subserving the purposes of circulation; as, circulatory organs;of or pertaining to the organs of circulation; as, circulatorydiseases.
One who accumulates; one who collects. [R.]
A white grape, esteemed for the table.
A mark placed under the letter c [thus, ç], to show that it isto be sounded like s, as in façade.
The fillet, listel, or band next to the apophyge at theextremity of the shaft of a column.
Creepy. [Colloq.]
An intermediate shaft; esp., one which receives motion from aline shaft in a factory and transmits it to a machine.
The commercial spirit or method. C. Kingsley.

; sing. Choctaw. (Ethnol.) A tribe of North American Indians(Southern Appalachian), in early times noted for their pursuit ofagriculture, and for living at peace with the white settlers. Theyare now one of the civilized tribes of the Indian Territory.
Continuing; prolonged; sustained; as, a continuant sound.-- n.
A small cyme, or one of very few flowers.
Of, or relating to, Confucius, the great Chinese philosopherand teacher. -- n.
A native or inhabitant of Corfu, an island in the MediterraneanSea.
A narrow chisel adapted for cutting a groove. Knight.
A hawk which is of proper age and training to be carried on thehand; a hawk in its first year. Booth.
A cuirass or breastplate. [Obs.] Spenser.
The transparent part of the coat of the eyeball which coversthe iris and pupil and admits light to the interior. See Eye.
See Catechu.
Choric; choral. [R.]
Serving or tending to concentrate; characterized byconcentration.A discrimination is only possible by a concentrative act, or act ofattention. Sir W. Hamilton.
A genus of leguminous plants; rattlebox.
A cordwainer. [Obs.]

A red, acid berry, much used for making sauce, etc.; also, theplant producing it (several species of Vaccinum or Oxycoccus.) Thehigh cranberry or cranberry tree is a species of Viburnum (V.Opulus), and the other is sometimes called low cranberry or marshcranberry to distinguish it.
To struggle for; to contest. [R.]Carthage shall contend the world with Rome.Dryden.
One who travels a circuit, as a circuit judge. [R.] R.Whitlock.
Having the legs crossed.
One who lives at the same time with another; as, Petrarch andChaucer were contemporaries.
A spider; perhaps from its shape; it being round like a head.
Cancellarean. [R.]
Mean or unfair artifice to perplex a cause and obscure thetruth; stratagem; sharp practice; sophistry.Irritated by perpetual chicanery. Hallam.
Acuteness of discernment; cunningness; shrewdness. [R.]Her eagly-eyed callidity. C. Smart.
One of the tannic acids, extracted from catechu as a white,crystaline substance; -- called also catechuic acid, and catechuin.
Living on fruits; fruit-consuming.

Of or pertaining to dead and putrefying carcasses; feeding oncarrion.A prey for carrion kites. Shak.Carrion beetle (Zoöl.), any beetle that feeds habitually on deadanimals; -- also called sexton beetle and burying beetle. There aremany kinds, belonging mostly to the family Silphidæ.-- Carrion buzzard (Zoöl.), a South American bird of several speciesand genera (as Ibycter, Milvago, and Polyborus), which act asscavengers. See Caracara.-- Carrion crow, the common European crow (Corvus corone) whichfeeds on carrion, insects, fruits, and seeds.
The state of being a citizen; the status of a citizen.
A carving in relief, esp. one on a small scale used as a jewelfor personal adornment, or like.
Of a texture resembling horn; horny; hard. Sir T. Browne.
Mean; base. Shak.
An ancient musical instrument. See 4th Crowd.
A sharp, harsh, ringing sound. Dryden.
Of or pertaining to the cerebrum. Cerebral apoplexy. See underApoplexy.
Rectified oil of turpentine, used for burning in lamps, and asa common solvent in varnishes.
Counterflory.
One of a breed of dogs trained to accompany carriages; theDalmatian dog.
Having the keel arched upwards, but not actually hogged; --said of a ship.
A measure for fresh herrings, -- as many as will fill a barrel.[Scot.] H. Miller.
A bronze-yellow massive mineral with metallic luster; atelluride of gold; -- first found in Calaveras County California.
To move in a circle; to go round; to circulate. [Obs.] J.Philips.
In a compassionate manner; mercifully. Clarendon.

Contested; litigated; litigious; having power to decidecontroversy. Contentious jurisdiction (Eng. Eccl. Law), jurisdictionover matters in controversy between parties, in contradistinction tovoluntary jurisdiction, or that exercised upon matters not opposed orcontroverted.
Brushwood; coppice. Macaulay.
Bonbons; sweetmeats; confections; also, plaster or paperimitations of, or substitutes for, bonbons, often used by carnivalrevelers, at weddings, etc.
A reed instrument, related to the oboe, but deeper in pitch;the English horn.
A yellow crystalline substance, (C6H5.C2H2)2CO, the ketone ofcinnamic acid.
A crude, undigested, or unprepared state; rawness; unripeness;immatureness; unfitness for a destined use or purpose; as, thecrudeness of iron ore; crudeness of theories or plans.
A filament of a stamen. [Obs.]
One who, or that which, holds a candle; also, one who assistsanother, but is otherwise not of importance. Shak.
To temper; to moderate. [Obs.]Moisten and contemperate the air. Sir T. Browne.
The stalk or stem of grain and grasses (including the bamboo),jointed and usually hollow.
The Muse who presided over history.
The state of being crispate.
Sharp-edged and pointed; shaped like a pruning knife, as thebeak of certain birds.
A member of a college, particularly of a literary institutionso called; a student in a college.
See Crowd, a violin.
Cure; healing. [Obs.] Chaucer.
Of or from, or pertaining to, a convent. "Conventical wages."Sterne. Conventical prior. See Prior.
To persuade by gentle, insinuating courtesy, flattering, orfondling; to wheedle; to soothe.

A method of putting an end to debate and securing an immediatevote upon a measure before a legislative body. It is similar ineffect to the previous question. It was first introduced into theBritish House of Commons in 1882. The French word clôture wasoriginally applied to this proceeding.
The science of civil government.
An appendage of the labyrinth of the internal ear, which iselongated and coiled into a spiral in mammals. See Ear.
See Cognizant.
A kind of European carp (Carasius vulgaris), inferior to thecommon carp; -- called also German carp.
Nearly, but not exactly, conical. Lindley.
See Content, n.
The quality of bing curt.
; sing. Catawba. (Ethnol.) An appalachian tribe of Indianswhich originally inhabited the regions near the Catawba river and thehead waters of the Santee.
The science of wealth; the science, or a branch of the science,of political economy.
Growing warmth; increasing heat.
Darkness. [R.] G. Eliot.
In the game of craps, a first throw of the dice in which thetotal is two, three, or twelve, in which case the caster loses.
The chub. Walton.
The office of a controller.
Of or pertaining to crypts.
An instrument or machine for comparing anything to be measuredwith a standard measure; -- applied especially to a machine forcomparing standards of length.
Characterizing a class or classes; relating to classification.
Convalescent. [R.]He found the queen somewhat convalesced. J. Knox.
That which cools, or abates heat or excitement.if acid things were used only as coolers, they would not be so properin this case. Arbuthnot.
The criminal branch of the Court of King's or Queen's Bench,commonly called the crown side of the court, which takes cognizanceof all criminal cases. Burrill.
That which has a common center with something else.Its pecular relations to its concentrics. Coleridge.
Of or pertaining to a chapter; capitulary.From the pope to the member of the capitular body. Milman.
In a careless manner.
A shered; a fragment; a strip of wood. [Obs.] Chaucer.
In a contagious manner.
An instrument for crushing the head of a fetus, to facilitatedelivery in difficult eases.
A small tube of metal, wood, or India rubber, used for variouspurposes, esp. for injecting or withdrawing fluids. It is usuallyassociated with a trocar. [Written also canula.]
To choose; to elect; to coöpt. [Obs.] Cockeram.
Of or pertaining to Catalonia.-- n.
Having clouds resting on the top or head; reaching to theclouds; as, cloud-capped mountains.
The cudweed (Gnaphalium), used to prevent or cure chafing.
A piece of petrified dung; a fossil excrement.

Mildness and suavity of manners; courtesy between equals;friendly equals; friendly civility; as, comity of manners; the comityof States. Comity of nations (International Law), the courtesy bywhich nations recognize within their own territory, or in theircourts, the peculiar institutions of another nation or the rights andprivileges acquired by its citizens in their own land. By someauthorities private international law rests on this comity, but thebetter opinion is that it is part of the common law of the land, andhence is obligatory as law.
Having, or pertaining to, the same language.
The lowest square sail, or the lower yard of the mizzenmast.
Consenting. [Obs.] Chaucer.
A name given to several inconspicuous plants having leaves inwhorls of four, as species of Crucianella, Valantia, etc.

An abstract general conception; a notion; a universal.The words conception, concept, notion, should be limited to thethought of what can not be represented in the imagination; as, thethought suggested by a general term. Sir W. Hamilton.
Belonging to a carbuncle; resembling a carbuncle; red;inflamed.
One who is engaged in chromolithography.
A south American tick of the genus Amblyamma. There are severalspecies, very troublesome to man and beast.
A term or word which is the opposite of, or antithesis to,another; an antonym; -- the opposite of synonym; as, "foe" is thecounterterm of "friend". C. J. Smith.
A narrow-sterned boat formerly much used in the Newfoundlandfisheries; -- called also pinkstern and chebec. Bartlett.
In a cognizable manner.
Commodities sold by a chandler.
A vessel used in calcination.
One who believes in casualism.
One who drives or uses a cart; a teamster; a carter.
Blind and absurd devotion to a fallen leader or an obsoletecause; hence, absurdly vainglorious or exaggerated patriotism.-- Chau"vin*ist, n.-- Chau`vin*is"tic (, a.
A woman chauffeur.
Of the color of cream; light yellow. "Cream-colored horses."Hazlitt.
A gingham woven in plain colors with linen finish.
One who takes and sells cockles.
Of or pertaining to a catapult.
One who curtails.
Belonging to a scale used in measuring cylinders.

A Roman emperor, as being the successor of Augustus Cæsar.Hence, a kaiser, or emperor of Germany, or any emperor or powerfulruler. See Kaiser, Kesar.Malborough anticipated the day when he would be servilely flatteredand courted by Cæsar on one side and by Louis the Great on the other.Macaulay.
A weapon, used in discharging arrows, formed by placing a bowcrosswise on a stock.
Same as Chief.

Synthesis of organic compounds by energy derived from chemicalchanges or reactions. Chemosynthesis of carbohydrates occurs in thenitrite bacteria through the oxidation of ammonia to nitrous acid,and in the nitrate bacteria through the conversion of nitrous intonitric acid. -- Chem`o*syn*thet"ic (#), a.
A small wooden vessel; a pail. [Scot.] Jamieson.
The quality or condition of being consonant, agreeable, orconsistent.
A mate, companion, or associate.And turned my flying comrades to the charge. J. Baillie.I abjure all roofs, and choose . . . To be a comrade with the wolfand owl. Shak.
A company licensed for the purpose of carrying outimprovements, by means of loans and advances upon real securities. ]
The operation of striking out common factora, in both thedividend and divisor.

The use of artful subterfuge, designed to draw away attentionfrom the merits of a case or question; -- specifically applied tolegal proceedings; trickery; chicanery; caviling; sophistry. Prior.To shuffle from them by chicane. Burke.To cut short this, I propound it fairly to your own canscience.Berkeley.
See Gobulin.
Pertaining to, or designating, an acid derived from coal tarand other sources; as, carbolic acid (called also phenic acid, andphenol). See Phenol.
See cap, n., also Paper, n.
See under Crab.
The act of cajoling; the state of being cajoled; cajolery.Coleridge.
One of the orders of Infusoria, characterized by having cilia.In some species the cilia cover the body generally, in others theyform a band around the mouth.
A dwelling in the country, used as a place of retirement fromthe city.
To put into a cask.
About, or near, the meridian.
The lower faceted portion of a brilliant-cut diamond.
A willful contempt of, and disobedience to, any lawful summons,or to the rules and orders of court, as a refusal to appear in courtwhen legally summoned.
Somewhat coy or reserved. Warner.
With credulity.
The manners of a coxcomb; foppishness.
A genus of rodents, including the beaver. See Beaver.

Having the ground engraved or cut out in the parts to beenameled; inlaid in depressions made in the ground; -- said of a kindof enamel work in which depressions made in the surface are filledwith enamel pastes, which are afterward fired; also, designating theprocess  of making such enamel work. --n.
Partaking of the same essence.-- Co`es*sen"tial*ly, adv.We bless and magnify that coessential Spirit, eternally proceedingfrom both [The Father and the Son]. Hooker.
Of, pertaining to, or confined in, a cloister; recluse.[Written also cloisteral.]Best become a cloistral exercise. Daniel.
Resembling Cicero in style or action; eloquent.

The material of repair in fractures of bone; a substance exudedat the site of fracture, which is at first soft or cartilaginous inconsistence, but is ultimately converted into true bone and unitesthe fragments into a single piece.
A numbering of the people, and valuation of their estate, forthe purpose of imposing taxes, etc.; -- usually made once in fiveyears.

The act or process of making seems tight, as in ships, or offurnishing with calks, as a shoe, or copying, as a drawing. Calkingiron, a tool like a chisel, used in calking ships, tightening seamsin ironwork, etc.Their left hand does the calking iron guide. Dryden.
Any operation for the removal of varices by incision.Dunglison.

To draw one's self together as in fear or servility; to bend orcrouch with base humility; to wince; hence; to make court in adegrading manner; to fawn.When they were come up to the place where the lions were, the boysthat went before were glad to cringe behind, for they were afraid ofthe lions. Bunyan.Sly hypocrite, . . . who more than thou Once fawned and cringed, andservilely adored Heaven's awful monarch Milton.Flatterers . . . are always bowing and cringing. Arbuthnot.
The act of forging; forgery. [Obs.] [Written alsocounterfaisance.]
To be commensurate with; to equal. Tennyson.
To apply carbonic acid to; to wash or treat with carbolic acid.
Of a size larger than heroic. See Heroic.
An instrument with a graduated disk by means of which theangles of gems are measured in the process of cutting and polishing.

The rank, post, or commission of a captain. Washington.Captaincy general, the office, power, teritory, or jurisdiction of acaptain general; as, the captaincy general of La Habana (Cuba and itsislands).
One who, or that which, limits or restrains.

Any horizontal, molded or otherwise decorated projection whichcrowns or finishes the part to which it is affixed; as, the corniceof an order, pedestal, door, window, or house. Gwilt. Cornice ring,the ring on a cannon next behind the muzzle ring.

Five English ports, to which peculiar privileges were ancientlyaccorded; -- viz., Hastings, Romney, Hythe, Dover, and Sandwich;afterwards increased by the addition of Winchelsea, Rye, and someminor places. Baron of the Cinque Ports. See under Baron.

The science which treats of measuring time by regular divisionsor periods, and which assigns to events or transactions their properdates.If history without chronology is dark and confused, chronologywithout history is dry and insipid. A. Holmes.
Having a tendril or tendrils.
A pole or beam used in Scottish games for tossing as a trial ofstrength.
One who is born or bred in a city; a citizen. [Obs.] Champan.
A yellow or smoky brown variety of rock crystal, orcrystallized quartz, found esp, in the mountain of Cairngorm, inScotland.
To draw a line around si as to touch at certain points withoutcutting. See Inscribe, 5.
To con (a ship). [Obs.]
The wife of an earl in the British peerage, or of a count inthe Continental nobility; also, a lady possessed of the same dignityin her own right. See the Note under Count.
Having a wavy, floating light; opalescent; chatoyant.
Without limitation or end; boundless. Shak.
In a chromatic manner.
The state of being convex; convexity.
Having (such) a complexion; -- used in composition; as, a dark-complexioned or a ruddy-complexioned person.A flower is the best-complexioned grass, as a pearl is the best-colored clay. Fuller.
Snugly; comfortably.
The Russian variety of bagatelle.
Equal in intensity or degree; as, the relations between 6 and12, and 8 and 16, are cointense. H. Spencer.
Food. [Obs.] See Cates.
Belonging to a chronogram, or containing one.
In a concealed manner.
A trick; a delusive contrivance. [Obs.] Spenser.
Agreeableness to deserts; suitableness.
Compression.

Adapted to its use or purpose, or to wants and necessities;serviceable; spacious and convenient; roomy and comfortable; as, acommodious house. "A commodious drab." Shak. "Commodious gold." Pope.The haven was not commodious to winter in. Acts. xxvii. 12.
To purify spiritually.
Cordiality. Cotgrave.
A duplicate roll (record or account) kept by an officer as acheck upon another officer's roll. Burrill.
To join, unite, or cohere; to have a close relation; as, oneline of railroad connects with another; one argument connect withanother.
See Chica.
Corpuscular. [Obs.]
To move swiftly; -- usually with indefinite it.Straight flies as chek, and clips it down the wind. Dryden.
Two taken together; a pair or couple; especially two lines ofverse that rhyme with each other.A sudden couplet rushes on your mind. Crabbe.
Checking evacutions through astringent or styptic qualities.

A beetle (Lytta, or Cantharis, vesicatoria), having anelongated cylindrical body of a brilliant green color, and a nauseousodor; the blister fly or blister beetle, of the apothecary; -- alsocalled Spanish fly. Many other species of Lytta, used for the samepurpose, take the same name. See Blister beetle, under Blister. Theplural form in usually applied to the dried insects used in medicine.
Covered with wax.
To shape (the brim) into a curve.
Promoting concretion. Sir T. Browne.
See Cardiograph.
In a candid manner.
A soft, earthy, clayey mineral, of whitish or grayish color.
A joint regent or ruler.
A medicated wash for the mouth.
Like the motion of the hands of a clock; -- said of thatdirection of a rotation about an axis, or about a point in a plane,which is ordinarily reckoned negative.
The unit of heat according to the Frensc standard; the amountof heat requires to raise the temperature of one kilogram (sometimes,one gram) of water one degree centigrade, or from 0Foot pound.
A carangoid fish of the Atlantic coast (Caranx hippos): --called also horse crevallé.
See 1st Char.
Pertaining to chivalry or knight-errantry; warlike; heroic;gallant; high-spirited; high-minded; magnanimous.In brave pursuit of chivalrous emprise. Spenser.
One who drinks with another. [R.] Pope.

A venereal sore, resembling a chancre in its seat and someexternal characters, but differing from it in being the startingpoint of a purely local process and never of a systemic disease; --called also soft chancre.
A division of Carnivora, including the dogs, wolves, and foxes.
In single pairs; coupled.
See Pinkboot.
Capable of being confused.
See under Antimony.
A collusive agreement between two or more persons to prejudicea third.

An agreement between parties; a covenant or contract.The law of nations depends on mutual compacts, treaties, leagues,etc. Blackstone.Wedlock is described as the indissoluble compact. Macaulay.The federal constitution has been styled a compact between the Statesby which it was ratified. Wharton.
To make a slight, sharp noise (or a succession of such noises),as by gentle striking; to tick.The varnished clock that clicked behind the door. Goldsmith.
A kind of head covering; a caul. [Obs.] Chaucer.
A figure bounded by a thousand plane surfaces [Spelt alsochiliaëdron.]
An apple seller; a hawker of, or dealer in, any kind of fruitor vegetables; a fruiterer. [Written also costardmonger.]
Art of producing metal decorative work other than statuary, asreliefs, intaglios, engraving, chasing, etc.
A wooden knife with a long thin blade, used in handling creamor ice cream.
A woman who corrupts.Thou studied old corruptress. Beau & Fl.

Having a common measure; capable of being exactly measured bythe same number, quantity, or measure.-- Com*men"su*ra*ble*ness, n. Commensurable numbers or quantities(Math.), those that can be exactly expressed by some common unit;thus a foot and yard are commensurable, since both can be expressedin terms of an inch, one being 12 inches, the other 36 inches.-- Numbers, or Quantities, commensurable in power, those whosesquares are commensurable.
A sycophantic courtier. B. Jonson.
A cliff. [Obs.]That gainst the craggy clifts did loudly roar. Spenser.
Of or pertaining to the carpus, or wrist.-- n.
Radiating to or from the same point. [R.] Coleridge.
One who coaxes.
See Clamp.
An early form of hand gun, variety of the arquebus; originallya gun having a regular size of bore. [Obs.] Shak.
Containing or resembling collagen.

One who comprehends; one who has attained to a full knowledge.[Obs.]When I shall have dispatched this weary pilgrimage, and from atraveler shall come to be a comprehensor, farewell faith and welcomevision. Bp. Hall.
Crinoidal.-- n.
A making ready; provision. [Obs.]
A remedy that purges by alvine discharges.
Consisting of corymbs, or resembling them in form. [Writtenalso corymbous.]
Pertaining to, or becoming, a churchman. Milman.
A south American rodent of the genus Lagotis.
Of or pertaining to the czar or the czarina; czarish.
The charge made by innkeepers for drawing the cork and takingcare of bottles of wine bought elsewhere by a guest.
In a cunning manner; with cunning.
Without any additional weight; without being handicapped; as,to ride catchweight.
An outpost consisting of four men, forming one of a single lineof posts substituted for the more formal line of sentinels and lineof pickets.
Of or pertaining to a cognomen; of the nature of a surname.
A rabbit. See Cony.
See Calipee.
having acquired an unpleasant taste from the cork; as, a bottleof wine is corked.
The leader or director of an orchestra or chorus.
Kicking. Hence: Stubborn; refractory.
The modification, by inflection or otherwise, which theadjective and adverb undergo to denote degrees of quality orquantity; as, little, less, least, are examples of comparison.
The neck or line of junction between the root of a plant andits stem. Gray.

A collection of maritime laws of disputed origin, supposed tohave been first published at Barcelona early in the 14th century. Ithas formed the basis of most of the subsequent collections ofmaritime laws. Kent. Bouvier.

To reduce into another and denser form, as by cold or pressure;as, to condense gas into a liquid form, or steam into water.Condensed milk, milk reduced to the consistence of very thick creamby evaporation (usually with addition of sugar) for preservation andtransportation.-- Condensing engine, a steam engine in which the steam is condensedafter having exerted its force on the piston.
To inspire with courage. [Obs.]Paul writeth unto Timothy . . . to courage him. Tyndale.
Full of chaps; cleft; gaping; open.
One who coshers.
Having stems which bear flowers and fruit year after year, asmost trees and shrubs.
With well-proportioned, unblemished limbs; as, a clean-limbedyoung fellow. Dickens.
Belonging to calculation. Sherwood.
One of the priests of Cybele in Phrygia. The rites of theCorybants were accompanied by wild music, dancing, etc.
In a characteristic manner; in a way that characterizes.
One of a breed of heavy draft horses originally fromClydesdale, Scotland. They are about sixteen hands high and usuallybrown or bay.
To acclimate or become acclimated.
See Cenobite.
To make slight cracks; to make small, sharp, sudden noises,rapidly or frequently repeated; to crepitate; as, burning thornscrackle.The unknown ice that crackles underneath them. Dryden.
An apparent right; as where the defendant in trespass gave tothe plaintiff an appearance of title, by stating his title specially,thus removing the cause from the jury to the court. Blackstone.

Of or pertaining to Cadmus, a fabulous prince of Thebes, whowas said to have introduced into Greece the sixteen simple letters ofthe alphabet -- Cadmean letters. Cadmean victory, a victory thatdamages the victors as much as the vanquished; probably referring tothe battle in which the soldiers who sprang from the dragon's teethsown by Cadmus slew each other.
The bellbird of South America. See Bellbird.
1. Self-originating; uncreated.
Destitute of curd.
To change (one proposition) into another, so that what was thesubject of the first becomes the predicate of the second.
Burdensome. [Obs.]I was chargeous to no man. Wyclif, (2 Cor. xi. 9).
The Scotch shepherd dog. There are two breeds, the rough-hairedand smooth-haired. It is remarkable for its intelligence, displayedespecially in caring for flocks. [Written also colly, colley.]
See Cirsocele.
See Chiaroscuro.
The anterior portion of any one of the Arachnida and higherCrustacea, consisting of the united head and thorax.
Concerned in the formation of chyle; as, the chylopoeticorgans.
A small stone taken from the gizzard of a young swallow.-- anciently worn as a medicinal charm.
Consisting of a series of parallel cones, each made up of manyconcentric cones closely packed together; -- said of a kind ofstructure sometimes observed in sedimentary rocks.
One who uses a canoe; one who travels in a canoe.Cabins and clearing greeted the eye of the passing canoeman. Parkman.
[Chyle + -ferous: cf. F. chylifère.] (Physiol.) Transmitting orconveying chyle; as, chyliferous vessels.
Formed into texture; woven together; arranged; composed. [R.]Carlyle.
Consisting of, or containing calcareous and siliceous earths.
Boastful; defiant; exulting. Also used adverbially.
One who maintains the theory of conceptualism. Stewart.
Same as Cordwain. in England the name is applied to leathermade from horsehide.
The fiery cross, used as a rallying signal in the Highlands ofScotland.
The soft naked sheath at the base of the beak of birds of prey,parrots, and some other birds. See Beak.

A brownish purple pigment, obtained by the action of somecompounds of tin upon certain salts of gold. It is used in paintingand staining porcelain and glass to give a beautiful purple color.Commonly called Purple of Cassius.
One who dwells with another, or with others. "Coinhabitants ofthe same element." Dr. H. More.
The work of a craftsman.
One learned in the classics; an advocate for the classics.
To ascend or creep upward by twining about a support, or byattaching itself by tendrills, rootlets, etc., to a support orupright surface.
A blockhead; a dolt.
The art of measuring circles.
A plant that clings by rootlets, or by tendrils, to the ground,or to trees, etc.; as, the Virginia creeper (Ampelopsisquinquefolia).
Union; combination; a coupling; a pair. [Obs.] Shak.And forth together rode, a goodly couplement. Spenser.
A gluing together; a joining by means of some tenacioussubstance; junction; union.Conglutination of parts separated by a wound. Arbuthnot.

The adjustment of a debt, or avoidance of an obligation, bysome form of compensation agreed on between the parties; also, thesum or amount of compensation agreed upon in the adjustment.Compositions for not taking the order of knighthood. Hallam.Cleared by composition with their creditors. Blackstone.
Made, or consisting, of hair. [Obs.]A Cilicious or sackcloth habit. Sir T. Browne.
In a constitutive manner.
One who describes fruits; one versed in carpology.
A person easily deceived, tricked, or imposed on; a mean dupe;a gull.I have learned that . . . I am not the first cully whom she haspassed upon for a countess. Addison.
Expressing coördination. J. W. Gibbs.
A yellow substance obtained as a by-product in the manufactureof rosaniline. It dyes silk a fine golden-yellow color.

The art or practice of using the manual alphabet or ofcommunicating thoughts by sings made by the hands and fingers; asubstitute for spoken or written language in intercourse with thedeaf and dumb. See Dactylalogy.
A cord. Chorda dorsalis (. Etym: [NL., lit., cord of the back.](Anat.) See Notochord.
Pertaining to the goddess Venus.
A crinoid of the genus Antedon and related genera. When youngthey are fixed by a stem. When adult they become detached and clingto seaweeds, etc., by their dorsal cirri; -- called also featherstars.
Fitted with, or wearing, shoes. Johnson.
An instrument shaped like a lute, but strung with wire andplayed with a quill or plectrum. [Written also cithern.] Shak.
The fertilized egg cell or parent cell, from the development ofwhich the child or other organism is formed. Hæckel.
One who constrains.
A certain possible event that may or may not happen, by which,when happening, some particular title may be affected.
Belonging to the most recent division of geological time,including the tertiary, or Age of mammals, and the Quaternary, or Ageof man. [Written also cænozoic, cainozoic, kainozoic.] See Geology.
Conceding; permissive.
A plant belonging to the Cryptogamia. Henslow.

A series of limestone strata found in Ohio and farther west,presenting bluffs along the rivers and valleys, formerly supposed tobe of one formation, but now known to be partly Silurian and partlyDevonian.
Of or pertaining to, or made at, Cheddar, in England; as,Cheddar cheese.
An embryonic cell which develops into a pigment cell.
, n. (Mus.) Double bass; -- applied to any instrument of thesame deep range as the stringed double bass; as, the contrabassophicleide; the cotrabass tuba or bombardon.
Of the shape of a fig; as, a caricous tumor. Graig.
The privileges, prerogatives, or retinue of a court. [Obs.]Bacon.
A crib for storing corn.
A tax on every plow or plowland.
Bowed in the form of an arch; -- called also arched.
To call, as a hen her chickens. Dryden.
Shaped like a boat; (Bot.) elongated and having the uppersurface decidedly concave, as the glumes of many grasses.
One who, or that which, makes calm.
The Muse that presides over eloquence and heroic poetry; motherof Orpheus, and chief of the nine Muses.
One who comes out or withdraws from a religious or otherorganization; a radical reformer. [Colloq. U. S.]
A shake or fissure between the annual rings of a tree, foundoftenest near the roots.
A gap. [Obs.] Colgrave.
Agreeing in sound; symphonious.
Having a mantle; -- applied to certain gastropods.
One to whom a fine of land was ackowledged. Blackstone.

A thing; personal property. Chose in action, a thing of whichone has not possession or actual enjoyment, but only a right to it,or a right to demand it by action at law, and which does not exist atthe time in specie; a personal right to a thing not reduced topossession, but recoverable by suit at law; as a right to recovermoney due on a contract, or damages for a tort, which can not beenforced against a reluctant party without suit.-- Chose in possession, a thing in possession, as distinguished froma thing in action.-- Chose local, a thing annexed to a place, as a mill.-- Chose transitory, a thing which is movable. Cowell. Blount.
See Coca.
; by force or constraint.
The small apple-shaped or pear-shaped fruit of an Americanshrub (Pyrus arbutifolia) growing in damp thickets; also, the shrub.
A variety of albite, white and lamellar in structure.
Producing cells; -- applied esp. to lymphatic, or adenoid,tissue.
Of or pertaining to a catechism, having the form of questionsand answers; catechical.
United or fastened by a dovetailed joint.

A joint stock company, formed for general banking business, orfor the construction of public works, by means of loans on personalestate, after the manner of the crédit foncier on real estate. Inpractice, however, this distinction has not been strictly observed.
Such as can be, or is liable to be, combated; as, combatablefoes, evils, or arguments.
Measurement of the quantities of heat in bodies.
To make carnal; to debase to carnality.A sensual and carnalized spirit. John Scott.
See Climacteric, n.
To form into clumps or masses. [Obs.]Vapors . . . clumpered in balls of clouds. Dr. H. More.

an organic acid, C3O3N3H3, first obtained by heating uric acidor urea, and called pyrouric acid; afterwards obtained from isocyanicacid. It is a white crystalline substance, odorless and almosttasteless; -- called also tricarbimide.
Cell-like; -- applied to the corpuscles of lymph, blood, chyle,etc.
Imparting knowledge or information.Canonical and communicatory letters. Barrow.
Pertaining to, or derived from, the tannin of coffee.Caffetannic acid, a variety of tannin obtained from coffee berries,regarded as a glucoside.
An instrument signaling the correct time to distant points byelectricity.
One who describes the world or universe, including the heavensand the earth.The name of this island is nowhere found among the old and ancientcosmographers. Robynson (More's Utopia).
The principles or practice of conventionalizing. SeeConventionalize, v. t.
In a continent manner; chastely; moderately; temperately.
A tendril or clasper.
Tending to strengthen; corroborative; as, corroboratory facts.
Traffic in contraband gods; smuggling.
Of pertaining to, or conferring, a commission; conferred by acommission or warrant. [R.]Delegate or commissionary authority. Bp. Hall.
Louisiana; -- a nickname. See Creole, n. & a.
A genus of ground beetles, including numerous species. Theydevour many injurious insects.
The state of being embodied; bodily existence. [Obs.] Dr. H.More.
Pertaining to Canara, a district of British India.
The quality of being cynical.
Coöperating.
An opaque, compact variety of barite, or heavy spar. [Alsowritten cauk.]

An American bird of the genus Cassicus, allied to the starlingsand orioles, remarkable for its skillfully constructed and suspendednest; the crested oriole. The name is also sometimes given to thepiping crow, an Australian bird.
imp. & p.p. of Curse.
Having no couch or bed.
That may be coveted; desirable.
Cultivable.
To fix; to fasten. [Obs.]  Shak.
One who chooses; one who has the power or right of choosing; anelector. Burke.
A stated meeting of preachers and others, invested withauthority to take cognizance of ecclesiastical matters.
Of or pertaining to climatology.

A contrivance for carrying objects from place to place; esp.,one for conveying grain, coal, etc., -- as a spiral or screw turningin a pipe or trough, an endless belt with buckets, or a truck runningalong a rope.
A divination by throwing dice or casting lots.
A rheumatic affection of the muscles of the breast and forelegs of a horse, affecting motion and respiration.
Bread baked in a mold, and scooped out, to serve minces upon.Bishop.
Hundredth.-- n.
An American genus of perennial herbs with delicate blossoms; --sometimes called spring beauty.
Of or pertaining to the cranium and face; as, the craniofacialangle.
Devouring knives; swallowing, or pretending to swallow, knives;-- applied to persons who have swallowed, or have seemed to swallow,knives with impunity. Dunglison.

Relating to, derived from, or like, the Dipterix odorata, atree of Guiana. Coumaric acid (Chem.), one of a series of aromaticacids, related to cinnamic acid, the most important of which is awhite crystalline substance, HO.C6H4.C2H2.CO2H, obtained from thetonka bean, sweet clover, etc., and also produced artifically.

The political morality taught by Confucius and his disciples,which forms the basis of the Chinese jurisprudence and education. Itcan hardly be called a religion, as it does not inculcate the worshipof any god.  S. W. Williams.
An abbreviation of Congius.
A carcanet. Southey.
Tending or intended to commemorate. "A sacrifice commemorativeof Christ's offering up his body for us." Hammond.An inscription commemorative of his victory. Sir G. C. Lewis.
Same as Cystidea.
Cuneiform. "Cuneatic decipherment." Sayce.
A tribute by the head; a capitation tax. [Written also chevageand chivage.] [Obs.]
To make one yield or submit. "If she can not entreat, I can notcompel." Shak.
Wearing, or entitled to wear, a coronet; of noble birth orrank.
See under Calcite.
A genus of aroideous plants, of which some species arecultivated for their immense leaves (which are often curiouslyblotched with white and red), and others (in Polynesia) for food.
Somewhat clever. [R.]
In a confused manner.
Moderately cold; cold and raw or damp so as to cause shivering;causing or feeling a disagreeable sensation of cold, or a shivering.
Choleriform.
One versed in criminal law. [R.]
Account; reckoning; computation. [Obs.] Shak.
Distressing; worrying; perplexing; corroding; as, carkingcares.
An instrument of iron, with sharp prongs, attached to a boot orshoe to enable the wearer to walk securely upon ice; a creeper. Kane.
A person who calenders cloth; a calender.
A light skiff or rowboat used on the Bosporus; also, aLevantine vessel of larger size.
The state or quality of being commensurate. Foster.

The hinder part or buttocks of certain quadrupeds, especiallyof a horse; hence, the place behind the saddle.So light to the croup the fair lady he swung, So light to the saddlebefore her he sprung. Sir W. Scott.
A number of animals or plants living or growing together,beyond their usual range.
One who, or that which, continues; esp., one who continues aseries or a work; a continuer. Sir T. Browne.
See Cross, n. [Obs.]
Usually. [Obs.] Milton.
Pertaining to the top of the palate; cerebral; -- applied tocertain consonants; as, cacuminal (or cerebral) letters.

imp. of Cleave. Cleft. Spenser. Clove hitch (Naut.) See underHitch.-- Clove hook (Naut.), an iron two-part hook, with jaws overlapping,used in bending chain sheets to the clews of sails; -- called alsoclip hook. Knight.
Spars or timbers set up as a support against the side of abuilding.
Folded lengthwise along the midrib, the upper face beingwithin; -- said of leaves or petals in vernation or æstivation.
In a compatible manner.
In a chiding or reproving manner.
Of the nature of cement. [R.] Forsyth.
In a convenient manner, form, or situation; without difficulty.

Formed in columns; having the form of a column or columns; likethe shaft of a column. Columnar epithelium (Anat.), epithelium inwhich the cells are priismatic in form, and set upright on thesurface they cover.-- Columnar structure (Geol.), a structure consisting of more orless regular columns, usually six-sided, but sometimes with eight ormore sides. The columns are often fractured transversely, with a cupjoint, showing a concave surface above. This structure ischaracteristic of certain igneous rocks, as basalt, and is due tocontraction in cooling.
A native or resident of Cambridge; esp. a student or graduateof the university of Cambridge, England.
Befitting a church or a churchman; becoming to a clergyman.Shak.
Bearing or containing chyme.
A partner or associate in some civil or ecclesiastical officeor employment. It is never used of partners in trade or manufactures.
In a curious manner.
A balsam of the Spanish West Indies. See Copaiba.
To thrust oakum into (seams or chinks) with a chisel , thepoint of a knife, or a chinsing iron; to calk slightly. Chinsingiron, a light calking iron.
The top stone of the gable end of a house. Halliwell.

See Coamings. Combing machine (Textile Manuf.), a machine forcombing wool, flax, cotton, etc., and separating the longer and morevaluable fiber from the shorter. See also Carding machine, underCarding.
A soft, whitish, coral-like stone, formed of broken shells andcorals, found in the southern United States, and used for roadbedsand for building material, as in the fort at St. Augustine, Florida.
Encouragement; comfort. [Obs.]Rich bounty and dear cherishment. Spenser.
One who crucifies; one who subjects himself or another to apainful trial.
Of or pertaining to the tribe of ruminants of which the goat,or genus Capra, is the type.
The act or process of taking property or condemning it to betaken, as forfeited to the public use.The confiscations following a subdued rebellion. Hallam.
Pertaining to charcoal, or partaking of its qualities.
A spoonful. Dungleson.
Contentious; quarrelsome. [Obs.] Bailey.

To strike or dash against each other; to come into collision;to clash; as, the vessels collided; their interests collided.Across this space the attraction urges them. They collide, theyrecoil, they oscillate. Tyndall.No longer rocking and swaying, but clashing and colliding. Carlyle.
Of or pertaining to Ceylon.-- n. sing. & pl.
A coarsely granular variety of garnet.
Promoting the discharge of bile from the system.-- n.
Created; composed; begotte. [Obs.]Hearts create of duty and zeal. Shak.
A preparation of fruit in sirup in such a manner as to preserveits form, either whole, halved, or quartered; as, a compote of pears.Littr
A sprightly dance; a coranto; a courant.
Possessing the qualities of a prism, obliquely inclined to arhombic base; monoclinic.
Curved; bent; as, compassing timbers.
By compulsion. [R.]
To attack with heavy artillery; to batter with cannon shot.

The force exerted between the atoms of elementary substancewhereby they unite to form chemical compounds; chemical attaction;affinity; -- sometimes used as a general expression for chemicalactivity or relationship.

Of or pertaining to the central nervous system consisting ofthe brain and spinal cord. Cerebro-spinal fluid (Physiol.), a serousfluid secreted by the membranes covering the brain and spinal cord.-- Cerebro-spinal meningitis, Cerebro-spinal fever (Med.), adangerous epidemic, and endemic, febrile disease, characterized byinflammation of the membranes of the brain and spinal cord, givingrise to severe headaches, tenderness of the back of the neck,paralysis of the ocular muscles, etc. It is sometimes marked by acutaneous eruption, when it is often called spotted fever. It is notcontagious.
The qualiyu of being creative.
A little cloud. R. Browning.Eve's first star through fleecy cloudlet peeping. Coleridge.
Bearing setæ.
A Turkish musical instrument.
Same as Cordelle.
The most westerly branch of the great Slavic family of nations,numbering now more than 6,000,000, and found principally in Bohemiaand Moravia.
A photolithograph printed in colors.
TO equal in weight; to counterpoise; to equiponderate.
To cause to flow together, as water drawn from several streams.[Obs.] Burton.
A dance in which the partners are arranged face to face, or inopposite lines.

A custom, among certain barbarous tribes, that when a womangives birth to a child her husband takes to his bed, as if ill.The world-wide custom of the couvade, where at childbirth the husbandundergoes medical treatment, in many cases being put to bed for days.Tylor.

Marked with the sign of the cross; crouched. Crutched friar(Eccl.), one of a religious order, so called because its members borethe sign of the cross on their staves and habits; -- called alsocrossed friar and crouched friar.
A certain reed stop in the organ, of a quality of toneresembling that of the oboe. [Corruptly written cromona.]
Cheerfulness. [Obs.]There is no Christian duty that is not to be seasoned and set offwith cheerishness. Milton.
Like, or pertaining to the genus Carabus.
In a cursed manner; miserably; in a manner to be detested;enormously. [Low]
A variety of spinel, of a dark color, found at Candy, inCeylon.
Connection of links or union of parts, as in a chain; a regularor connected series. See Concatenation. Sir T. Browne.

To render clean; to free from fith, pollution, infection,guilt, etc.; to clean.If we walk in the light . . . the blood of Jesus Christ his soncleanseth us from all sin. 1 John i. 7.Can'st thou not minister to a mind diseased, And with some sweetoblivious antidote Cleanse the suffed bosom of that perilous stuffWhich weighs upon the heart Shak.

Having the qualities, or exhibiting the characteristics, of acur; snarling; quarrelsome; snappish; churlish; hence, alsomalicious; malignant; brutal.Thy currish spirit Governed a wolf. Shak.Some currish plot, -- some trick. Lockhart.-- Cur"rish*ly, adv.-- Cur"rish*ness, n.
A wading bird of the genus Grus, and allied genera, of variousspecies, having a long, straight bill, and long legs and neck.
The affection of the system with cancer.
See Craunch.
See Quarrel, an arrow.
Delay; procrastination. [R.] Carlyle.
In decorative art, boiled leather, fitted by the process toreceive impressed patterns, like those produced by chasing metal, andto retain the impression permanently.
The small and nearly cubical stone building, toward which allMohammedans must pray. [Written also kaaba.]
United; joined; betrothed. [R.]
One who challenges.
A house or mansion. [Sp. Amer. & Phil. Islands]
A monk of the Greek Church; a cenobite, anchoret, or recluse ofthe rule of St. Basil, especially, one on or near Mt. Athos.
A kind of card or comb having rows of metallic teeth orserrated ridges, used in curryng a horse.

The letting or hiring a vessel by special contract, or thecontract or instrument whereby a vessel is hired or let; as, a shipis offered for sale or charter. See Charter party, below. Charterland (O. Eng. Law), land held by charter, or in socage; bookland.-- Charter member, one of the original members of a society orcorporation, esp. one named in a charter, or taking part in the firstproceedings under it.-- Charter party Etym: [F. chartre partie, or charte partie, adivided charter; from the practice of cutting the instrument ofcontract in two, and giving one part to each of the contractors](Com.), a mercantile lease of a vessel; a specific contract by whichthe owners of a vessel let the entire vessel, or some principal partof the vessel, to another person, to be used by the latter intransportation for his own account, either under their charge or his.-- People's Charter (Eng. Hist.), the document which embodied thedemands made by the Chartists, so called, upon the English governmentin 1838.
That may be confuted.
A spring-blooming plant (Fritillaria imperialis) of the Lilyfamily, having at the top of the stalk a cluster of pendent bell-shaped flowers surmounted with a tuft of green leaves.
A work of more that ordinary heigh, rising from the levelground of a bastion, etc., and overlooking surrounding parts.
That branch of political economy which relates to theproduction of wealth.
Joining subject and predicate; copulative. F. A. March.
To insert in a catalogue; to register; to catalogue. [R.]Coles.
A staff by means of which a burden is borne by two persons ontheir shoulders.
Of the same blood; related by birth; descended from the sameparent or ancestor. Shak.
Construction of, or furnishing with, a canal or canals. [R.]
The state of being a comrade; intimate fellowship.
One bound by a common cath with others. [Obs.]
Of or pertaining to cedar or the cedar tree.
Feeding upon onions. [R.] Sterling.

Merit, acguired by works, which can claim reward on the scoreof general benevolence.Such a worthiness of condignity, and proper merit of the heavenlyglory, cannot be found in any the best, most perfect, and excellentof created beings. Bp. Bull.
See Capriccio.
One who cross-examines or conducts a crosse-examination.
Immediate vicinity; neighborhood.The convicinity and contiguity of the two parishes. T. Warton.
Of, relating to, or mixed with, carmine; as, carminated lake.Tomlinson.
A flat basket or frail for figs, etc.; Hence, a lady's flatworkbasket, reticule, or hand bag; -- often written caba. C. Bronté.
The doctrine that a soul is specially created for each humanbeing as soon as it is formed in the womb; -- opposed totraducianism.
A soft grass (Pennisetum typhoideum) found in all tropicalregions, used as food for men and cattle in Central Africa.

A machine, combining magic lantern and kinetoscope features,for projecting on a screen a series of pictures, moved rapidly (25 to50 a second) and intermittently before an objective lens, andproducing by persistence of vision the illusion of continuous motion;a moving-picture machine; also, any of several other machines ordevices producing moving pictorial effects. Other common names forthe cinematograph are animatograph, biograph, bioscope, electrograph,electroscope, kinematograph, kinetoscope, veriscope, vitagraph,vitascope, zoögyroscope, zoöpraxiscope, etc.
The department of astronomy relating to comets.
One who craves or begs.
Rough, with short, tumultuous waves; as, a choppy sea.
An evergreen leguminous tree (Ceratania Siliqua) found in thecountries bordering the Mediterranean; the St. John's bread; --called also carob tree.

Pertaining to, or derived from, or resembling, chrysophane.Chrysophanic acid (Chem.), a yellow crystalline substance extractedfrom rhubarb, yellow dock, sienna, chrysarobin, etc., and shown to bea derivative of an anthracene. It is used in the treatment of skindiseases; -- called also rhein, rheic acid, rhubarbarin, etc.
A combining form, meaning somewhat resembling a cone; as,conico-cylindrical, resembling a cone and a cylinder; conico-hemispherical; conico-subulate.
A fresh-water herbivorous fish (Cyprinus carpio.). Severalother species of Cyprinus, Catla, and Carassius are called carp. SeeCruclan carp.
A stupid fellow; a dolt. [Written also clodpole.] Shak.
A singer; esp. the leader of a church choir; a precentor.The cantor of the church intones the Te Deum. Milman.

Freodom from motion, agitation, or disturbance; a cessation orabeence of that which causes motion or disturbance, as of winds orwaves; tranquility; stilness; quiet; serenity.The wind ceased, and there was a great calm. Mark. iv. 39.A calm before a storm is commonly a peace of a man's own making.South.
A variety of chalcedony, of a clear, deep red, flesh red, orreddish white color. It is moderately hard, capable of a good polish,and often used for seals.
Set between two cottises, -- said of a bend; or between twobarrulets, -- said of a bar or fess.
One who traffic illegaly; a smuggler.
The female of the hawk; a falcon-gentil.
On the hither side of the river Po with reference to Rome; thatis, on the south side.
A class of Coelenterata, commonly ellipsoidal in shape,swimming by means of eight longitudinal rows of paddles. The separatepaddles somewhat resemble combs.
Of or pertaining to a consociation. [U.S.]
See Cleavers.
Of or pertaining to the shell of a sea urchin. Coronal suture(Anat.), a suture extending across the skull between the parietal andfrontal bones; the frontoparietal suture.
A peninsula; a tract of land nearly surrounded by water, butunited to a larger tract by a neck of land or isthmus; as, theCimbric Chersonese, or Jutland; the Tauric Chersonese, or Crimea.
A regular solid body, with six equal square sides.
Tha act of colonizing, or the state of being colonized; theformation of a colony or colonies.The wide continent of America invited colonization. Bancroft.
Pertaining to, resembling, or hear the heart; as, the cardiacarteries; the cardiac, or left, end of the stomach.
A thousand; the aggregate of a thousand things; especially, aperiod of a thousand years.The world, then in the seventh chiliad, will be assumed up unto God.Sir. T. More.

Pertaining to Cumberland, England, or to a system of rocksfound there. Cumbrian system (Geol.), the slate or graywacke systemof rocks, now included in the Cambrian or Silurian system; -- socalled because most prominent at Cumberland.
Given to contemplation; meditative. [R.] Coleridge.
A roommate, especially in a college or university; an old andintimate friend.
In a curved or crooked manner; in a perverse or untowardmanner.
An order of Crinoidea, mostly fossils of the Paleozoic rocks.They were usually roundish or egg-shaped, and often unsymmetrical;some were sessile, others had short stems.
The rock through which a vein runs. Conclusion to the country.See under Conclusion.-- To put, or throw, one's self upon the country, to appeal to one'sconstituents; to stand trial before a jury.
One who keeps a coffeehouse. Addison.
Existence at the same time; contemporaneousness. Howell.
See Chivachie. [Obs.]

A valuable furniture wood from India and Ceylon, of a hazel-brown color, with black stripes, very hard in texture. It is aspecies of ebony, and is obtained from the Diospyros qusesita. Calledalso Coromandel wood.
A treatise on colors.
A downfall; an humillation. [Colloq.]
A schoolhouse. [Obs.]
See Contingency.
A swelling, like a wen, on the point of the elbow (or the heelof the hock) of a horse, caused probably by bruises in lying dowm.
Mica. [Archaic]
Falsehood; lying; cretism.
Heart-shaped. Gray.
The coloring matter of the blood; the clotted portion ofcoagulated blood, containing the coloring matter; gore.
An associate or companion; a friend; a partner. [Obs.]Misshapen time, copesmate of ugly Night. Shak.
Partaking of the nature of clay, or containing particles of it.
A genus of Dinosauria found in the Jurassic formation, andremarkable for having several birdlike features.

The quality possessed by many crystallized substances ofsplitting readily in one or more definite directions, in which thecohesive attraction is a minimum, affording more or less smoothsurfaces; the direction of the dividing plane; a fragment obtained bycleaving, as of a diamond. See Parting.
Growing immediately on a caulis; of or pertaining to a caulis.
Presiding over, or regulating, climates.
A tool with a cutting edge on one end of a metal blade, used indressing, shaping, or working in timber, stone, metal, etc.; --usually driven by a mallet or hammer. Cold chisel. See under Cold, a.
A clause added to a will.

A fall of water over a precipice, as in a river or brook; awaterfall less than a cataract.The silver brook . . . pours the white cascade. Longjellow.Now murm'ring soft, now roaring in cascade. Cawper.
The wheel in a clock which regulates the number of strokes.
To bring into a square. [R.] Ash.
As much as will fill a cap. A capful of wind (Naut.), a lightpuff of wind.
The quality of being comprehensive; extensiveness of scope.Compare the beauty and comprehensiveness of legends on ancient coins.Addison.
A hole in the ground, or hiding place, for concealing andpreserving provisions which it is inconvenient to carry. Kane.
Same as Center, n., 6. [Written also centring.]
One of a species of aromatic oils, resembling carvacrol.
Caution; crafty management. [N. of Eng. & Scot.]
One who computes.
A variety of vegetable casein, resembling legumin, and found inalmonds, rye, wheat, etc.
A small mine, sometimes formed in the wall or side of anenemy's gallery, to blow in the earth and cut off the retreat of theminers. Farrow.
A way or road for carts.
Full of ashes. [Obs.]
Anything that is very puzzling or difficult to explain. Dr.Sheridan.The perpetual crux of New Testament chronologists. Strauss.
The act of producing or bringing forth children; parturition.Milton. Addison.
The forearm; the ulna, a bone of the arm extending from elbowto wrist. [Obs.]
One who, or that which, corrects; as, a corrector of abuses; acorrector of the press; an alkali is a corrector of acids.

A cap. Specifically: (a) A close-fitting cap covering the sidesof the head, like a small hood without a cape. (b) An officialheaddress, such as that worn by certain judges in England. [Writtingalso quoif.]From point and saucy ermine down To the plain coif and russet gown.H. Brocke.The judges, . . . althout they are not of the first magnitude, norneed be of the degree of the coif, yet are they considerable. Bacon.
Cruelty. [Obs.] Spenser.
To make a rattling noise with.You clatter still your brazen kettle. Swift.
A native of Cathay or China; a foreigner; -- formerly a term ofreproach. Shak.

A scheme of equalizing the social conditions of life;specifically, a scheme which contemplates the abolition ofinequalities in the possession of property, as by distributing allwealth equally to all, or by holding all wealth in common for theequal use and advantage of all.
The act of contravening; opposition; obstruction;transgression; violation.Warrants in contravention of the acts of Parliament. Macaulay.In contravention of all his marriage stipulations. Motley.
The manner characteristic of a child. [Obs.] "Varyingchildness." Shak.
Full of content. [Obs.] Barrow.
The American wood rabbit (Lepus sylvaticus); -- also calledMolly cottontail.
Clearness; splendor. [Obs.] Beau. & Fl.
To connote; to suggest or designate (something) as additional;to include; to imply. Hammond.
The quality of being coy; feigned oWhen the kind nymph would coyness feign, And hides but to be foundagain. Dryden.
Pertaining to Cyrenaica, an ancient country of northern Africa,and to Cyrene, its principal city; also, to a school of philosophyfounded by Aristippus, a native of Cyrene.-- n.
One who coughs.
The cormorant; -- so called from its black color.
Same as Crocoite.

Of or pertaining to the head. See the Note under Anterior.Cephalic index (Anat.), the ratio of the breadth of the cranium tothe length, which is taken as the standard, and equal to 100; thebreadth index.-- Cephalic vein, a large vein running from the back of the headalond the arm; -- so named because the ancients used to open it fordisorders of the head. Dunglison.
See Quitch grass.
That part of acoustics which treats of reflected sounds orechoes See Acoustics. Hutton.
A piece used in the game of chess.
An apparatus for the separation of dry comminuted ore, byexposing it to intermittent puffs of air. Knight.
A Russian copper coin. See Kopeck.
The pursuit or running game with dogs that follow by sightinstead of by scent.In coursing of a deer, or hart, with greyhounds. Bacon
Knowing, or apprehending by the understanding; as, cognitivepower. South.
A bitter, yellow substance forming the essential constituent ofGoa powder, and yielding chrysophanic acid proper; hence formerlycalled also chrysphanic acid.
The giving up or vacating a benefice by accepting anotherwithout a proper dispensation.
A book of directions and receipts for cooking; a cookery book.[U.S.]"Just How": a key to the cookbooks. Mrs. A. D. T. Whitney.
In a chaotic manner.
A transverse drain or waterway of masonry under a road,railroad, canal, etc.; a small bridge.
Brigands in bands, who, about 1793, pillaged, burned, andkilled in parts of France; -- so called because they used to burn thefeet of their victims to extort money.
Affecting like a canker. "Canrerous shackles." Thomson.Misdeem it not a cankerous change. Wordsworth.
Composed of corallines; as, coralline limestone.
To leap or jump about in a sprightly manner; to cut capers; toskip; to spring; to prance; to dance.He capers, he dances, he has eyes of youth. Shak.
A tree or shrub bearing cones; one of the order Coniferae,which includes the pine, cypress, and (according to some) the yew.
Productive of fruit, or causing fruit to be developed.
Consisting of, or containing, calcareous matter or lime salts;calcareous.
A dich or drain along the side of a hill to catch the surfacewater; also, a ditch at the side of a canal to catch the surpluswater.
The principal church in a diocese, so called because in it thebishop has his official chair (Cathedra) or throne.
A fruit like that of the rose, consisting of a cup formed ofthe calyx tube and receptacle, and containing achenes.
A fossil coralline.
Raw sugar; sugar not refined. Mc Elrath.
To counterplead. [Obs.] Chaucer.
The state of being causeless.
Corivalry. [R.]
Same as Cantle, v. t.

One who offers himself, or is put forward by others, as asuitable person or an aspirant or contestant for an office,privilege, or honor; as, a candidate for the office of governor; acandidate for holy orders; a candidate for scholastic honors.

Sailing along or near a coast, or running between ports along acoast. Coasting trade, trade carried on by water between neighboringports of the same country, as distinguished fron foreign trade ortrade involving long voyages.-- Coasting vessel, a vessel employed in coasting; a coaster.

A comparatively rare element related to zinc, and occurring insome zinc ores. It is a white metal, both ductile and malleable.Symbol Cd. Atomic weight 111.8. It was discovered by Stromeyer in1817, who named it from its association with zinc or zinc ore.Cadmium yellow, a compound of cadmium and sulphur, of an intenseyellow color, used as a pigment.
Same as Cartographer, Cartographic, Cartography, etc.
A short coat of coarse cloth. [Obs.]Full threadbare was his overeste courtepy. Chaucer.

To seek the opinion or advice of another; to take consel; todeliberate together; to confer.Let us consult upon to-morrow's business. Shak.All the laws of England have been made by the kings England,consulting with the nobility and commons. Hobbes.
In a congenial manner; as, congenially married or employed.
The shell or bone of cuttlefishes, used for various purposes,as for making polishing powder, etc.
Flint or pebble stone, used in building walls, etc. Haliwell.

The concrete essence of the tonka bean, the fruit of Dipterix(formerly Coumarouna) odorata and consisting essentially of coumarinproper, which is a white crystalline substance, C9H6O2, of vanilla-like odor, regarded as an anhydride of coumaric acid, and used inflavoring. Coumarin in also made artificially.
Any plant of the order Cruciferæ.
In the manner of courts; politely; gracefully; elegantly.They can produce nothing so courtly writ. Dryden
A grand division of birds, including all existing flying birds;-- So called from the carina or keel on the breastbone.
The state or quality of being concurrent; concurrence.
Ralating to a codex, or a code.
See Calculus.
The shotproof pilot house of a war vessel.
To undulate or ripple. Cf. Crisp, v. t.To watch the crisping ripples on the beach. Tennuson.
Coxcombical. [R.]
The texan guan (Ortalis vetula). [written also chiacalaca.]

A minute mineral form like those common in glassy volcanicrocks and some slags, not having a definite crystalline outline andnot referable to any mineral species, but marking the first step inthe crystallization process. According to their form crystallites arecalled trichites, belonites, globulites, etc.
Rogation week, when the cross was borne in processions.
Relating to, or characterized by, catelectrotonus.

One who bears testimony or swears to the veracity or innocenceof another. See Purgation; also Wager of law, under Wager.All they who know me . . . will say they have reason in this matterto be my compurgators. Chillingworth.
The use of concetti or affected conceits. [R.] C. Kingsley.
After the manner of a court; elegant; polite; courtly.
To contravene; to nullify; as, to circumduct acts ofjudicature. [Obs.] Ayliffe.
See Elater.
A man who digs chalk.
See Capybara.
A body consisting of a thousand men. Mitford.
One who calumniates.
One who communicates thoughts by signs made with the hands andfingers.
Companionable; sociable. [Obs.] Bacon.
Pert. [Slang]
A species of European warbler (Sylvia hippolais); -- calledalso chip-chap, and pettychaps.
A plant of Central and Southern Anerica, of the Cactus familly,extensively cultivated for the sake of the cochineal insect, whichlives on it.
Hundredth.

A revolver made according to a system using a patentedrevolving cylinder, holding six cartridges, patented by Samuel Colt,an American inventor, in 1835. With various modifications, it has formany years been the standard for the United States army.
Belonging to the Conirostres.
Having short bends, turns, or wrinkles; wrinkled; wavy; zigzag."The crinkled lightning." Lowell.

False accusation of a crime or offense, maliciously made orreported, to the injury of another; malicious misrepresentation;slander; detraction. "Infamouse calumnies." Motley.Be thou as chaste as ice, as pure as snow, thou shalt not escapecalumny. Shak.
A genus of decapod Crustacea, including some of the most commonshore crabs of Europe and North America, as the rock crab, Jonahcrab, etc. See Crab.
A plant (Anthriscus cerefolium) with pinnately divided aromaticleaves, of which several curled varieties are used in soups andsalads.
To impregnate or wash with camphor; to camphorate. [R.] Tatler.
The office, position, or station of a chaplain. Swift.
The quantitative determination of the depth of color of asubstance.
Advice; warning; instruction. [Obs.] Bailey.
The root of the Oldenlandia umbellata, native in India, whichyieds a durable red dyestuff. [Written also choy root.]

A bureau of the United States government charged with thetopographic and hydrographic survey of the coast and the execution ofbelts of primary triangulation and lines of precise leveling in theinterior. It now belongs to the Department of Commerce and Labor.
See Canteen.
A fabulous being, represented as half man and half horse.
In a correlative relation.
Of or pertaining to the Crossopterygii.-- n.
A contemplator. [R.] I. Taylor.
Of or pertaining to finance and public revenue.
One who belongs to a Congregational church or society; one whoholds to Congregationalism.
A member of a council. [Written also councillor.]
In conjunction or union; together. Sir T. Browne.
Nutritious by force of habit; -- said of certain kinds of food.[Obs.] Crabb.
A French coasting lugger.
The top sheaf of a stack of grain: (fig.) the crowning orfinishing part of a thing.
The art of surveying a region or district.
The Manx shearwater.

Of or pertaining to commerce; carrying on or occupied withcommerce or trade; mercantile; as, commercial advantages; commercialrelations. "Princely commercial houses." Macaulay. Commercialcollege, a school for giving instruction in commercial knowledge andbusiness.-- Commercial law. See under Law.-- Commercial note paper, a small size of writing paper, usuallyabout 5 by 7½ or 8 inches.-- Commercial paper, negotiable paper given in due course ofbusiness. It includes bills of exchange, promissory notes, bankcheks, etc.-- Commercial traveler, an agent of a wholesale house who travelsfrom town to town to solicit orders.
To raise captious and frivolous objections; to find faultwithout good reason.You do not well in obstinacy To cavil in the course of this contract.Shak.
In a curvilinear manner.
To prance ostentatiously; -- said of a horse or his rider.[Local slang U. S.]

The application to another of either physical or moral force.When the force is physical, and cannot be resisted, then the actproduced by it is a nullity, so far as concerns the party coerced.When the force is moral, then the act, though voidable, is imputableto the party doing it, unless he be so paralyzed by terror as to actconvulsively. At the same time coercion is not negatived by the factof submission under force. "Coactus volui" (I consented undercompulsion) is the condition of mind which, when there is volitionforced by coercion, annuls the result of such coercion. Wharton.
See Crupper.
Pertaining to, or of the nature of, colloids.
Cube-shaped, or nearly so; as, the cuboid bone of the foot.-- n. (Anat.)
A filamentous fresh-water alga (Conferva rivularis of Linnaeus,Rhizoclonium rivulare of Kutzing).
An armor-bearer to a knight. [Obs.]
Same as Countertrippant.
One who carps; a caviler. Shak.
An instrument which, when placed in contact with the chest,will register graphically the comparative duration and intensity ofthe heart's movements.
Of, pertaining to, or resembling, the Honeysuckle family ofplants (Caprifoliacæ.
Demonstrable; determinable. [Obs.] Hammond.
A low rhamnaceous shrub (Karwinskia humboldtiana) of thesouthwestern United States and Mexico. Its berries are said to bepoisonous to the coyote.
Of, like, or pertaining to, the Cercariæ.-- n.
The state or quality of being copious; abudance; plenty; also,diffuseness in style.To imitatethe copiousness of Homer. Dryden.

A pictorial view which is extended circularly, so that thespectator is surrounded by the objects represented as by things innature. The realistic effect is increased by putting, in the spacebetween the spectator and the picture, things adapted to the scenerepresented, and in some places only parts of these objects, thecompletion of them being carried out pictorially.
To chant; to recite with musical tones. M. Stuart.
Rendered blue, as the surface of the body, from cyanosis ordeficient a
,n.One of the Cabiri.
A cockfight.
To crush with the teeth; to chew with violence and noise; tocrunch. Swift.
The creed, as sung or read in the Roman Catholic church.He repeated Aves and Credos. Macualay.
A ship keeping company with another.
Peppergrass. Johnson.
Clownishness. L'Estrange.
Power, or command, over a certain district; chieftainship.[Obs.]
In a copulative manner.
Being on an equality in rank or power.-- n.
Weary; mournful. Shak.
A dredging machine for excavating canals, etc.
In a connected manner.
See Crenelle.
The highest class of Mollusca.
To pass through the stages of circumnutation.
The common tissue which unites the various zooids of abryozoan.
An ornament often resembling curved and bent foliage,projecting from the sloping edge of a gable, spire, etc.
Relating to the Ctenoidei.-- n.
Dressed with a shirt over the other garments.
Capable of being condensed; as, vapor is condensable.
A collected state of the mind; self-possession.
A sailor's song.
See Clearstory.
Crepuscular. [Obs.] Sprat.
Sticky and foul; muddy; filthy; dirty. [Prov. Eng.] Halliwell.
Pertaining to a culmen.
The office of a chargé d'affaires.
