A plant of the Brassica or Cabbage genus; esp. that form of B.oleracea called rape and coleseed.
A fishing boat. See Coble.
Affected with strabismus; squint-eyed; squinting.
See Cadre.
The pellicle which forms over a wound or breach of continuityand completes the process of healing in the latter, and whichsubsequently contracts and becomes white, forming the scar.
In Austria-Hungary, one of the provinces, or largestadministrative divisions of the monarchy; as, the crownland of LowerAustria.
To deceive; to cheat; to trick. [Obs.]Take heed, Signor Baptista, lest you be cony-catched in the thisbusiness. Shak.
A pen for animals; esp., an inclosure made with wagons, byemigrants in the vicinity of hostile Indians, as a place of securityfor horses, cattle, etc.
Serving for compensation; making amends. Jer. Taylor.

Of or pertaining to Chaldea.-- n.(a) A native or inhabitant of Chaldea.(b) A learned man, esp. an astrologer; -- so called among the Easternnations, because astrology and the kindred arts were much cultivatedby the Chaldeans.(c) Nestorian.
Pertaining to, or derived from, beeswax or Chinese wax; as,cerotic acid or alcohol.
The place on an ovule, or seed, where its outer coats coherewith each other and the nucleus.
Smartweed (Polygonum Hydropiper).
Shutting; confining; drawing together; as, a claudent muscle.[R.] Jonson
A consolidated annuity (see Consols); -- chiefly in combinationor attributively.
A person versed in chemistry or given to chemicalinvestigation; an analyst; a maker or seller of chemicals or drugs.
A bush of hair; frizzing of the hair. Clarke.
Of or pertaining to the colleterium of insects. R. Owen.
An amphitheatrical circle for sports; a circus. [R.] T. Warton.
An appendage of the vestibular ear sac of fishes. Owen.
By confession; without denial. [Written also confessly.]
See Conine.
A thin lamina of gray matter in each cerebral hemiphere of thebrain of man.-- Claus"tral, a.
A women who plays in comedy.

The creation of the world or universe; a theory or account ofsuch creation; as, the poetical cosmogony of Hesoid; the cosmogoniesof Thales, Anaxagoras, and Plato.The cosmogony or creation of the world has puzzled philosophers ofall ages. Goldsmith.
One of the Conchifera.
The act of strengthening. [Obs.]  Bacon.
Of, pertaining to, or like, saffron; deep reddish yellow. [R.]
The office of a curator.

Contributing to the same stock or purpose; promoting the sameend; bringing assistance to some joint design, or increase to somecommon stock; contributive. Milton.Bonfires of contributory wood. Chapman.Contributory negligence (Law), negligence by an injured party, whichcombines with the negligence of the injurer in producing the injury,and which bars recovery when it is the proximate cause of the injury.Wharton.
The office or functions of a constable.
A temporary structure upon which the materials of a vault orarch are supported in position util the work becomes self-supporting.
A lodging for soldiers in garrison towns, usually near therampart; barracks. Bescherelle.
The coloring matter of the blood in the living animal;hæmoglobin.
A joint sovereign.
Considerate; careful; thoughtful. [Archaic]I love to be considerative. B. Jonson.
Shaped like a round buckler or shield; scutate.
A copier. [Obs.] "A copist after nature." Shaftesbury.
One who clearstarches.
See Contravallation.
Of a pertaining to ancient Carthage, a city of northern Africa.-- n.
The nether part of the beak of a hawk. Clap dish. See Clackdish, under Clack, n.-- Clap net, a net for taking birds, made to close or clap together.
A concussion or shock produced by a blow or other injury, in apart or region opposite to that at which the blow is received, oftencausing rupture or disorganisation of the parts affected.

A lizardlike reptile of the genus Chamæleo, of several species,found in Africa, Asia, and Europe. The skin is covered with finegranmulations; the tail is prehensile, and the body is muchcompressed laterally, giving it a high back.
Of, pertaining to, or resembling, the Corybantes or theirrites; frantic; frenzied; as, a corybantic dance.
Backwards; toward the tail or posterior part.
An apparatus used in beet-sugar factories to heat the juice inorder to aid the diffusion.
A constellation of the northern hemisphere east of, orfollowing, Lyra; the Swan.
See Cayman.
Logwood.
Chylifactive.
An impure, massive, flintlike quartz or hornstone, of a dullcolor.
A colorlees or greenish oil extracted from cajuput.
See Calefactory. [R.]
Relating to conference. [R.] Clarke.
A small castle. Leland.
A series or range of columns placed at regular intervals withall the adjuncts, as entablature, stylobate, roof, etc.
One who chastens.
Fellow member of a fraternity; intimate associate.
Clearness; freedom from ambiguity; lucidity. Of a certainty,certainly.
A contrary method of procedure; opposite course of action.
Relating to a comet.
A surface of ground on which water may be caught and collectedinto a reservoir.
Perforated like a sieve; cribriform.
Food for dogs, made from the refuse of tallow melting.
Like or related to the genus Clupeaster; -- applied to a groupof flattened sea urchins, with a rosette of pores on the upper side.
See Kamsin.
Incapable of being counted; not ascertainable; innumerable.
Running in opposite directions; -- said of animals borne in acoast of arms.
Sticking plaster made by coating taffeta or silk on one sidewith some adhesive substance, commonly a mixture of isinglass andglycerin.
Capable of being changed from a liquid to a solid state. [Obs.]They formed a . . . fixed concrescible oil. Fourcroy (Trans. ).
A chest with holes for keeping fish alive in water. Philips.
To divide into cantons or small districts.
Capable of being conjectured or guessed.
one of the side at the bat posted near first or third base todirect a base runner.
One who conciliates.
Cuboid.

One or more persons elected or appointed, to whom any matter orbussiness is referred, either by a legislative body, or by a court,or by any collective body of men acting together. Commitee of thewhole [house], a committee, embracing all the members present, intowhich a legislative or deliberative body sometimes resolves itself,for the purpose of considering a particular measure under theoperation of different rules from those governing the generallegislative proceedings. The committee of the whole has its ownchairman, and reports its action in the form of recommendations.-- Standing committee. See under Standing.
Cross-shaped; (Bot.) having four parts arranged in the form ofa cross.
The germinating point in the embryo of a seed; the point in theyolk of an egg at which development begins.
See Congé, Conge. [Obs.]
Certainly. [Obs.] Milton.
In the manner of a chevron; as, the field may be dividedchevronwise.
The condition of a consort; fellowship; partnership. Hammond.
The quality of being categorical, positive, or absolute. A.Marvell.
Peevishly; vexatiously; detestably. [Obs.] "Curstfully mad."Marston.
The quality of being communicative. Norris.
Deduction from premises; inference; conclusion. [Obs.] Sir M.Hale.
One who is in the same class with another, as at school orcollege.
Qualified for conversation; disposed to converse; sociable;free in discourse.While young, humane, conversable, and kind. Cowper.
A genus of composite herbaceous plants. One species, Calendulaofficinalis, is the common marigold, and was supposed to blossom onthe calends of every month, whence the name.
Allied to, or resembling, the genus Centriscus, of which thebellows fish is an example.
Of the same kind or nature; having the same substance oressence; coessential.Christ Jesus . . . coeternal and consubstantial with the Father andwith the Holy Ghost. Foxe.
See Cognizance. [Obs.]
At the same time with some other event.
To join luster; to shine with united radiance, or one generallight. [R.]The several things which engage our affections . . . shine forth andconstellate in God. Boule.
A South American bird, of the genus Aramus, allied to therails.
Shaped like a cotyle or a cup.
Cottagelike; suitable for a cottage; rustic. [Obs.] Jer.Taylor.

A body, living or dead; the corporeal substance of a thing.Corpus callosum (k; pl. Corpora callosa (-s Etym: [NL., callous body](Anat.), the great band of commissural fibers uniting the cerebralhemispheries. See Brain.-- Corpus Christi (kr Etym: [L., body of Christ] (R. C. Ch.), afestival in honor of the eucharist, observed on the Thursday afterTrinity Sunday.-- Corpus Christi cloth. Same as Pyx cloth, under Pyx.-- Corpus delicti (d Etym: [L., the body of the crime] (Law), thesubstantial and fundamental fact of the comission of a crime; theproofs essential to establish a crime.-- Corpus luteum (l; pl. Corpora lutea (-. Etym: [NL., luteous body](Anat.), the reddish yellow mass which fills a ruptured Grafianfollicle in the mammalian ovary.-- Corpus striatum (str; pl. Corpora striata (-t. Etym: [NL.,striate body] (Anat.), a ridge in the wall of each lateral ventricleof the brain.
The red, or corn, poppy. [Written also cup-rose.]

One of an ancient race of people, who formerly inhabited agreat part of Central and Western Europe, and whose descendants atthe present day occupy Ireland, Wales, the Highlands of Scotland, andthe northern shores of France. [Written also Kelt. The letter C waspronounced hard in Celtic languages.]
Internal harmony or fitness; mutual adaptation of parts;elegance; -- used chiefly of style of discourse. [R.]An exact concinnity and eveness of fancy. Howell.
A pastil or troche, composed of various aromatic and otheringredients, highly celebrated in India as an antidote, and as astomachic and antispasmodic.
Making choices; fickle. [Obs.]His choiceful sense with every change doth fit. Spenser.
The part inclosed within the walls of an ancient temple, asdistinguished from the open porticoes.
See Cajuput.
A flatterer; a wheedler.
See Chay root.
The power or act which directs or impels to effort of any kind,whether muscular or psychical.Of conation, in other words, of desire and will. J. S. Mill.
A church or parish festival (as in commemoration of thededication of a church), at which much ale was used. Wright. Nares.
A writer of a chronicle; a recorder of events in the order oftime; an historian.Such an honest chronicler as Griffith. Shak.
Partaking of the nature ofcalcite or calcium carbonate;consisting of, or containg, calcium carbonate or carbonate of lime.Clcareous spar. See as Calcite.

A mixture for fertilizing land; esp., a composition of varioussubstances (as muck, mold, lime, and stable manure) thoroughlymingled and decomposed, as in a compost heap.And do not spread the compost on the weeds To make them ranker. Shak.
To appear in court personally or by attorney. [Scot]
To carry burdens in a cart; to follow the business of a carter.
Increase; enlargement. [Obs.]And toward the moon's attractive crescence bend. H. Brooke.
An uneasy sensation as of insects creeping on the skin.She felt a curious, uneasy creepiness. Mrs. Alexander.
To make a calculation; to forecast caonsequences; to estimate;to compute.The strong passions, whether good or bad, never calculate. F. W.Robertson.
Resembling cartilage.
To desire strongly; to feel an insatiable longing; as, acraving appetite.Once one may crave for love. Suckling.
See Choke.
See Crown office.
A hood; especialy, the hood attached to the gown of a monk.
The hundredth part of a franc; a small French copper coin andmoney of account.
See Creese. Tennison.
A kind of case shot for cannon, in which a number of lead oriron balls in layers are inclosed in a case fitting the gun; --called also canister shot,
Cream; a substance resembling cream; yeast; scum.
Without a clank. Byreon.
The state or character of being crotchety, or whimsical.This belief in rightness is a kind of conscientiousness, and when itdegenerates it becomes crotchetiness. J. Grote.
One who confronts.
A machine for adding numbers and making a printed record of thesum.
An unexpected and untoward accident; something inopportune orembarassing; a hitch.In this unhappy contretemps. De Quincey.
Adherence to external rites; fondness for ceremony.
An educating together, as of persons of different sexes orraces. Co*ed`u*ca"tion*al (, a.
An open furnace or forge, in which blooms are heated beforebeing wrought into bars.
Quality of being correlative.

Containing the bodies of the dead. "Charnel vaults." Milton.Charnel house, a tomb, vault, cemetery, or other place where thebones of the dead are deposited; originally, a place for the bonesthrown up when digging new graves in old burial grounds.
An iron block, usually bolted to a ship's deck, for controllingthe running out of a chain cable. The links of the cable tend to dropinto hollows in the block, and thus hold fast until disengaged.

Of or pertaining to conation.This division of mind into the three great classes of the cognitivefaculties, the feelings, . . . and the exertive or conative powers, .. . was first promulgated by Kant. Sir W. Hamilton.
Anancient tenure of land, which obliged the tenant to givenotice of an invasion by blowing a horn.
A warm or spicy condiment or pickle made in India, compoundedof various vegetable substances, sweets, acids, etc.
The quality of being comical; something comical.
A cuplet or little cup, as the acorn; the husk or bur of thefilbert, chestnut, etc.
See Cowhage.
Relating to, or resulting from, or resembling, cholera.
Having a curved or crooked tail.
Compiler. [Obs.]
To cause to coagulate or thicken; to cause to congeal; tocurdle.Does it curd thy blood To say I am thy mother Shak.
In a complex manner.

Of or pertaining to Chios, an island in the Ægean Sea. Chianearth, a dense, compact kind of earth, from Chios, used anciently asan astringent and a cosmetic.-- Chian turpentine, a fragrant, almost transparent turpentine,obtained from the Pistacia Terebinthus.
The beneficiary of a concession or grant.
A name for several species of mushroom, of which one(Cantharellus cibrius) is edible, the others reputed poisonous.
In a convective manner. Hare.
Standing or placed around; surrounding. [R.] "Circumstantbodies." Sir K. Digby.
Same as Coistril.

A creeping plant, and its fruit, of several species of thegenus Cucumis, esp. Cucumis sativus, the unripe fruit of which iseaten either fresh or picked. Also, similar plants or fruits ofseveral other genera. See below. Bitter cucumber (Bot.), theCitrullus or Cucumis Colocynthis. SeeColocynth.-- Cucumber beetle. (Zoöl.) (a) A small, black flea-beetle(Crepidodera cucumeris), which destroys the leaves of cucumber,squash, and melon vines. (b) The squash beetle.-- Cucumber tree.(a) A large ornamental or shade tree of the genusMagnolia (M. acuminata), so called from a slight resemblance of itsyoung fruit to a small cucumber. (b) An East Indian plant (AverrhoaBilimbi) which produces the fruit known as bilimbi.-- Jamaica cucumber, Jerusalem cucumber, the prickly-fruited gherkin(Cucumis Anguria).-- Snake cucumber, a species (Cucumis flexuosus) remarkable for itslong, curiously-shaped fruit.-- Squirting cucumber, a plant (Ecbalium Elaterium) whose small ovalfruit separates from the footstalk when ripe and expels its seeds andjuice with considerable force through the opening thus made. SeeElaterium.-- Star cucumber,a climbing weed (Sicyos angulatus) with pricklyfruit.
Surgically. [Obs.] Shak.
The horizontal projection of a chimney from the wall in whichit is built; -- commonly applied to its projection in the inside of abuilding only.
A cruet or vessel in which chrism is kept.

A milky fluid containing the fatty matter of the food in astate of emulsion, or fine mechanical division; formed from chyme bythe action of the intestinal juices. It is absorbed by the lacteals,and conveyed into the blood by the thoracic duct.
A picture made by any of the processes for reproducingphotographs in colors. --Chro`mo*pho`to*graph"ic (#), a.

A protoplasmic animal cell; esp., such as float free, likeblood, lymph, and pus corpuscles; or such as are imbedded in anintercellular matrix, like connective tissue and cartilagecorpuscles. See Blood.Virchow showed that the corpuscles of bone are homologous with thoseof connective tissue. Quain's Anat.Red blood corpuscles (Physiol.), in man, yellowish, biconcave,circular discs varying from 1/3500 to 1/3200 of an inch in diameterand about 1/12400 of an inch thick. They are composed of a colorlessstroma filled in with semifluid hæmoglobin and other matters. In mostmammals the red corpuscles are circular, but in the camels, birds,reptiles, and the lower vertebrates generally, they are oval, andsometimes more or less spherical in form. In Amphioxus, and mostinvertebrates, the blood corpuscles are all white or colorless.-- White blood corpuscles (Physiol.), rounded, slightly flattened,nucleated cells, mainly protoplasmic in composition, and possessed ofcontractile power. In man, the average size is about 1/2500 of aninch, and they are present in blood in much smaller numbers than thered corpuscles.
A supporter or partisan of chartism. [Eng.]
The quality or state of being comprehensible; capability ofbeing understood.

A species of the Myriapoda; esp. the large, flattened, venomouskinds of the order Chilopoda, found in tropical climates. they aremany-jointed, and have a great number of feet. [Written alsocentipede (
An instrument resembling the astrolabe, formerly used formeasuring the angles between heavenly bodies; -- called alsopantacosm.
A work consisting of two or more bastioned fronts, with theiroutworks, covering an enceinte, a bridgehead, etc., and connected bywings with the main work or the river bank.
The south America alligator. See Alligator. [Sometimes writtencaiman.]
Vehement or urgent desire; longing for; beseeching.A succession of cravings and satiety. L'Estrange.-- Crav"ing*ly, adv.-- Crav"ing*ness, n.
One who believes in the second coming of Christ to reign onearth a thousand years; a milllenarian.
Saturnian; -- applied to the North Polar Sea. [R.] Milton.
One who or that which causes.
A term or expression denoting continuance. [R.]To these may be added continuatives; as, Rome remains to this day;which includes, at least, two propositions, viz., Rome was, and Romeis. I. Watts.
Abounding in, or resembling, chips; dry and tasteless.
A conspicuous wild flower (Centaurea Cyanus), growing ingrainfields.
A custom of the Celts, or an idiom of their language. Warton.

A black, or brownish black, solid, combustible substance, dugfrom beds or veins in the earth to be used for fuel, and consisting,like charcoal, mainly of carbon, but more compact, and oftenaffording, when heated, a large amount of volatile matter.
The act of bringing forth a child; travail; labor. Jer. Taylor.

Reclaimed from savage life and manners; instructed in arts,learning, and civil manners; refined; cultivated.Sale of conscience and duty in open market is not reconcilable withthe present state of civilized society. J. Quincy.
In a crazy manner.
Any small book carried about for sale by chapmen or hawkers.Hence, any small book; a toy book.
A repository for holding things; a hinding place.
State of being clammy or viscous.

A noxious or corroding care; solicitude; worry. [Archaic.]His heavy head, devoid of careful cark. Spenser.Fling cark and care aside. Motherwell.Ereedom from the cares of money and the cark of fashion. R. D.Blackmore.
Native blue vitriol. See Blue vitriol, under Blue.

The upper third part of the field. It is supposed to becomposed of the dexter, sinister, and middle chiefs. In chief. (a) Atthe head; as, a commander in chief. (b) (Eng. Law) From the king, orsovereign; as, tenure in chief, tenure directly from the king.

Of or pertaining to the government of the eleven SouthernStates of the United States which (1860-1865) attempted to establishan independent nation styled the Confederate States of America; as,the Confederate congress; Confederate money.
The state of being a cenobite; the belief or practice of acenobite. Milman.
A salt of cyanic acid. Ammonium cyanate (Chem.), a remarkablewhite crystalline substance, NH4.O.CN, which passes, on standing, tothe organic compound, urea, CO.(NH)2.

According to the flesh, to the world, or to human nature; in amanner to gratify animal appetites and lusts; sensually.For to be carnally minded is death; but to be spiritually minded islife and peace. Rom. viii. 6.

A squirrel-like animal of the genus Tamias, sometimes calledthe striped squirrel, chipping squirrel, ground squirrel, hackee. Thecommon species of the United States is the Tamias striatus. [Writtenalso chipmonk, chipmuck, and chipmuk.]
Desirous to please; courteous; obliging; compliant; as, acomplaisant gentleman.There are to whom my satire seems too bold: Scarce to wise Petercomplaisant enough. Pope.
The state of being chubby.
Of or pertaining to the grasses which are cultivated for theiredible seeds (as wheat, maize, rice, etc.), or to their seeds orgrain.
To cry like a crow, rook, or raven.Rising and cawing at the gun's report. Shak.
The operation of opening the fetal head, in order to effectdelivery.
See Caboose.
An upward convexity of a deck or other surface; as, she has ahigh camber (said of a vessel having an unusual convexity of deck).
Secrecy; privacy. [R.]
Crystal-like; transparent like crystal.
A small bronze mortar mounted on a wooden block with handles,and light enough to be carried short distances by two men.
Capable of being cured; admitting remedy. "Curable diseases."Harvey.-- Cur"a*ble*ness, n.-- Cur`a*bly, adv.
Of or pertaining to a convocation.
State of being champion; leadership; supremancy.

In the United States, a commission appointed by the President,consisting of three members, not more than two of whom may beadherents of the same party, which has the control, throughexaminations, of appointments and promotions in the classified civilservice. It was created by act of Jan, 16, 1883 (22 Stat. 403).
A brittle cake or other crisp pastry.
To render parallel to a certain line or direction; to bringinto the same line, as the axes of telescopes, etc.; to renderparallel, as rays of light.
Leaf tobacco softened, sweetened, and pressed into plugs orcakes. Cut cavendish, the plugs cut into long shreds for smoking.
The upper part of a horse's hoof, where the horn terminates inskin. James White.
A confederate.
Cellular. Caldwell.
Consisting of chyle much diluted with water; -- said of aliquid which forms the circulating fluid of some inferior animals.
Having hair; hairy.
L. pl. of Colon.
A tribe of Indians formerly inhabiting the northern andweastern shores of Lake Superior; -- called also Objibways.
Marked with crow's-feet, or wrinkles, about the eyes. [Poetic]Do I look as if I were crow-trodden Beau. & FL.

The animal that produces civet (Viverra civetta); -- calledalso civet cat. It is carnivorous, from two to three feet long, andof a brownish gray color, with transverse black bands and spots onthe body and tail. It is a native of northern Africa and of Asia. Thename is also applied to other species.
An agreement between belligerents for the exchange ofprisoners. Wilhelm.
A dead human body; a corpse.
A punishment sometimes used by the ancients, consisting in thebesmearing of the criminal with honey, and exposing him to insects.It is still in use among some Oriental nations.
Of pertaining to Canopus in egypt; as, the Canopic vases, usedin embalming.
Possessed of the properties of chyle; consisting of chyle.

The act of seeking, or endevearing to gain, what another isendeavoring to gain at the same time; common strife for the sameobjects; strife for superiority; emulous contest; rivalry, as forapprobation, for a prize, or as where two or more persons are engagedin the same business and each seeking patronage; -- followed by forbefore the object sought, and with before the person or thingcompeted with.Competition to the crown there is none, nor can be. Bacon.A portrait, with which one of Titian's could not come incompetititon. Dryden.There is no competition but for the second place. Dryden.Where competition does not act at all there is complete monopoly. A.T. Hadley.
In the manner of a chorus; adapted to be sung by a choir; inharmony.
The plane in crystals of the monoclinic system which isparallel to the vertical and the inclined lateral (clinidiagonal)axes.
Ornamented with crockets.
One of several signs or sumptoms indicating the same fact; as,a coindication of disease.
To signify or denote in combination with something else.The cipher . . . only serves to connote and consignify, and to changethe value or the figures. Horne Tooke.

Of or pertaining to the Capitol in Rome. "Capitolian Jove."Macaulay. Capitoline games (Antiq.), annual games instituted at Romeby Camillus, in honor of Jupter Capitolinus, on account of thepreservation of the Capitol from the Gauls; when reinstituted byDomitian, arter a period of neglect, they were held every fifth year.
Belonging to the Compositæ; composite. [R.] Darwin.

Of or pertaining to China; peculiar to China. Chinese paper.See India paper, under India.-- Chinese wax, a snowy-wgite, waxlike substance brought from China.It is the bleached secretion of certain insects of the family Coccidæespecially Coccus Sinensis.
To come to one point; to meet in, or converge toward, a commoncenter; to have a common center.God, in whom all perfections concenter. Bp. Beveridge.
The eyelashes.
Resembling, or situated like, a crown or circlet; as, thecoronary arteries and veins of the heart.
The act or process of carrying about. [Obs.]Circumgestation of the eucharist to be adored. Jer. Taylor.
A kind of sexual union; -- applied to a blending of thecontents of two or more cells or individuals in some plants and loweranimals, by which new spores or germs are developed.
Dropping off or disappearing early, as the calyx of a poppy, orthe gills of a tadpole.
Pertaining to the making of commentaries. Whewell.
Alabama; -- a nickname.
In a cordate form.
To celebrate together. [Obs.] Holland.
A secret organization formed at Naples, Italy, early in the19th century, and used partly for political ends and partly forpracticing extortion, violence, etc. -- Ca*mor"rist (#), n.
Chylifactive.
The art of treating diseases of the hands and feet.
Capable of being cheated.
Relating to a cooper; coopered. [Obs.]Coopery vessels made of wood. Holland.
Of or pertaining to carcinoma.

A plant of differend species of the genus Trifolium; as thecommon red clover, T. pratense, the white, T. repens, and the hare'sfoot, T. arvense. Clover weevil (Zoöl.) a small weevil (Apionapricans), that destroys the seeds of clover.-- Clover worm (Zoöl.), the larva of a small moth (Asopia costalis),often very destructive to clover hay.-- In clover, in very pleasant circumstances; fortunate. [Colloq.] -- Sweet clover. See Meliot.
One of the four principal forms of clouds. SeeCloud.
In a churlish manner.
See Kaffir.
See 4th Crowd.
A group of ruminants whose horns are hollow, and planted on abony process of the front, as the ox.
In a changeable manner.
A bitter principle extracted as a white crystalline substancefrom the calumba root. [Written also colombin, and columbin]
Fit; proper; suitable. [Obs.] "A covenable day." Wyclif (Markvi. 21).
Native copper sulphide, called also copper glance, and vitreouscopper; a mineral of a black color and metallic luster. [Formerlywritten chalcosine.]
Of the same age; existing during the same period of time,especially time long and remote; -- usually followed by with.Silence! coeval with eternity! Pope.Oaks coeval spread a mournful shade. Cowper.
An unlawful bargain; traffic in which money is exported asdiscount. [Obs.] Bacon.
The mineral azurite, found in fine crystallization at Chessy,near Lyons; called also chessylite.
Having celebrity; distinguished; renowned.Celebrated for the politeness of his manners. Macaulay.
A monk of the reformed branch of the Benedictine Order, foundedin 912 at Cluny (or Clugny) in France.-- Also used as a.

Expressing a condition or supposition; as, a conditional word,mode, or tense.A conditional proposition is one which asserts the dependence of onecategorical proposition on another. Whately.The words hypothetical and conditional may be . . . usedsynonymously. J. S. Mill.
A stuffed or quilted coverlet for a bed; a comforter; acomfort. [U. S.]
imp. & p. p. of Cling.
A person who appoints another to act for him as attorney infact. Burrill.
In a way tending to or indication consumption. Beddoes.
To sin; esp., to be incontinent. [Obs.]Commit not with man's sworn spouse. Shak.
Clever; sharp; shrewd; ingenious; cunning. [Colloq.]
One of the same religion with another.
In connjunction; jointly.
In a convex form; convexly. Sir T. Browne.

A game played on a chessboard, by two persons, with twodifferently colored sets of men, sixteen in each set. Each player hasa king, a queen, two bishops, two knights, two castles or rooks, andeight pawns.
A contemptible or vicious critic.The rancorous and reptile crew of poeticules, who decompose intocriticasters. Swinburne.
A morbid condition produced by the habitual and excessive useof cocaine. -- Co*ca"in*ist, n.
See Crowberry.
Belonging to a creature; having the qualities of a creature.[R.]
To break into small pieces; to cause to fall in pieces.He with his bare wand can unthread thy joints, And crumble all thysinews. Milton.
A gallery or passageway leading to several apartments of ahouse.
Charging with crime; accusing; criminatory. R. North.
Coalescence of particles; growth; increase by the addition ofparticles. [R.] Sir W. Raleigh.
; sing Cayuga. (Ethnol.) A tribe of Indians formerly inbabitingwestern New-York, forming part of the confederacy called the FiveNations.
See Corm.
A radical, C27H55 supposed to exist in several compoundsobtained from Chinese wax, beeswax, etc.
A fast dyestuff, C20H8O6, made by heating gallein with strongsulphuric acid. It dyes mordanted fabrics green.
The pulpy mass of semi-digested food in the small intestinesjust after its passage from the stomach. It is separated in theintestines into chyle and excrement. See Chyle.
One who capitulates.
The office or employment of a curate.
Any book printed by William Caxton, the first English printer.Hansard.
Haughty; purse-proud. See Cob, n., 2. [Obs.] Withals (1608).
A coniferous tree of the genus Cupressus. The species aremostly evergreen, and have wood remarkable for its durability.
One of the two chief magistrates of the republic.
Spice clove. [Obs.] Chaucer.
A confectioner. [Obs.]He will take your daughters to be confectionaries, and to be cooks. 1Sam. viii. 13.
Faced or covered with copper; as, copper-faced type.
imp. & p. p. of Creep.
Brave; fine; canny. [Prov. Eng.] Grose.
See Cherif.
A room, attached to any place of public resort, where cloaks,overcoats, etc., may be deposited for a time.
A character used in musical notation to determine the positionand pitch of the scale as represented on the staff.
See Clover. Holland.
The highest vocal part; the air or melody in choral music;anciently the tenor, now the soprano. Canto fermo ( Etym: [It.](Mus.), the plain ecclesiastical chant in cathedral service; theplain song.
To draw or bring to a center point; to gather into or about acenter; to bring into one system, or under one control.[To] centralize the power of government. Bancroft.

The inferred proposition of a syllogism; the necessaryconsequence of the conditions asserted in two related propositionscalled premises. See Syllogism.He granted him both the major and minor, but denied him theconclusion. Addison.
A large two-handed sword used formerly by the ScottishHighlanders.
Same as Cabrée.
Having a barklike c
Pertaining to a Presbyterian consistory; -- a contemptuous termof 17th century controversy.You fall next on the consistorian schismatics; for so you callPresbyterians. Milton.
A short, suppressed laugh; the expression of satisfaction,exultation, or derision.
See Courche.
The active principe of the cantharis, or Spanish fly, avolatile, acrid, bitter solid, crystallizing in four-sided prisms.
The office or occupation of a commentator.
A genus of oceanic heteropod Mollusca, having a thin, glassy,bonnet-shaped shell, which covers only the nucleus and gills.
See Chivy, v. t. [Slang, Eng.]One poor fellow was chevied about among the casks in the storm forten minutes. London Times.
To doom to be taken for public use, under the right of eminentdomain.
Deserving a curse; execrable; hateful; detestable; abominable.Let us fly this cursed place. Milton.This cursed quarrel be no more renewed. Dryden.
Having the power of knowing. [Obs.] "An innate cognoscitivepower." Cudworth.
A form of cash carrier in which a small carrier or car travelsupon a kind of track.
The act of croaking. [R] Dr. H. More.
Conchylaceous.

A function involving the coefficients and the variables of aquantic, and such that when the quantic is lineally transformed thesame function of the new variables and coefficients shall be equal tothe old function multiplied by a factor. An invariant is a likefunction involving only the coefficients of the quantic.
To convert, or be converted, into cartilage.
The science which treats of catadioptric phenomena, or of theused of catadioptric instruments.
A jar of vessel, or a division of a compound vessel, forholding the exciting fluid of a battery.
The loose black particles collected from combustion, as on potsand kettles, or in a chimney; soot; smut; also, coloring matter whichrubs off from cloth.
The musical director in royal or ducal chapel; a choirmaster.[Written also kepellmeister.]
A painful erection of the penis, usually with downwardcurvature, occurring in gonorrhea.
Cross; thick; dense; coarse; not elaborated or refined. "Crassand fumid exhalations." Sir. T. Browne. "Crass ignorance" Cudworth.
A poisonous American serpent (Ancistrodon conotortrix), closelyallied to the rattlesnake, but without rattles; -- called alsocopper-belly, and red viper.
Finely ribbed or costated.
The head or uppermost member of a column, pilaster, etc. Itconsists generally of three parts, abacus, bell (or vase), andnecking. See these terms, and Column.
One who, or that which, chops.
Capability of being confused.

To utter in a low, hoarse voice; to announce by croaking; toforebode; as, to croak disaster.The raven himself is hoarse, That croaks the fatal entrance ofDuncan. Shak.Two ravens now began to croak Their nuptial song. Wordsworth.
To make amends; to supply an equivalent; -- followed by for;as, nothing can compensate for the loss of reputation.
A restaurant or café at which the patrons serve themselves withfood kept at a counter, taking the food to small tables to eat. [U.S.]
To feast together; to be convivial. [Obs.] "There, in the full,convive we." Shak.
Confusedly; obscurely. [Obs.]
A wood of small growth; a thicket of brushwood. See Coppice.Near yonder copse where once the garden smiled. Goldsmith.
A fortress in or near a fortified city, commanding the city andfortifications, and intended as a final point of defense. Syn. -Stronghold. See Fortress.
In the manner of a conspirator; by conspiracy. Milton.
A follower of Calvin; a believer in Calvinism.
An order of ganoid fishes, including the sturgeons; -- socalled on account of their cartilaginous skeleton.

To reduce to minute particles, or to a fine powder; topulverize; to triturate; to grind; as, to comminute chalk or bones;to comminute food with the teeth. Pennant. Comminuted fracture. Seeunder Fracture.
One of the sections into which the hold of a ship is divided bywater-tight bulkheads.
The hydroid or naked-eyed medusæ. See Hydroidea.
The name of several different species of the genus Potentilla;-- also called five-finger, because of the resemblance of its leavesto the fingers of the hand.
In a cheery manner.
A banker; a money changer or broker; one who deals in bills ofexchange, or who is skilled in the science of exchange.
Fig.: one who builds castles in the air or forms visionaryschemes.-- Cas"tle*build`ing, n.
Colossal. [R.]

To put faith (in); to repose confidence; to trust; -- usuallyfollowed by in; as, the prince confides in his ministers.By thy command I rise or fall, In thy protection I confide. Byron.Judge before friendships, then confide till death. Young.
Cheerful; lively; gay; bright; pleasant; as, a cheery person.His cheery little study, where the sunshine glimmered so pleasantly.Hawthorne.
An epoch at the close of the Canadian period of the AmericanLower Silurian system; -- so named from a township in Clinton Co.,New York. See the Diagram under Geology.
One of a group of gastropod mollusks, with a shell composed ofeight movable dorsal plates. See Polyplacophora.
(Geol.) See Cenozic.
A Carib.
A European bunting (Emberiza cirlus).
A monster represented as vomiting flames, and as having thehead of a lion, the body of a goat, and the tail of a dragon. "Direchimeras and enchanted isles." Milton.
Certainty.
The science which treats of the head.
A small organ at the upper part of the vulva, homologous to thepenis in the male.
See Confidant. South. Dryden.
The conversion of cell walls into a material which repelswater, as in cork.
The wild service of Europe (Purus torminalis).
Union of parts; structure. [Obs.] Jer. Taylor.
Contumely; reproach. [Obs.] Wyclif.
A method of attaining successively lower temperatures byutilizing the cooling effect of the expansion of one gas incondensing another less easily liquefiable, and so on.
A bargain; a purchase; cheapness. [Obs.]The sack that thou hast drunk me would have bought me lights as goodcheap at the dearest chandler's in Europe. Shak.
The act of carrying anything around, or the state of being socarried.
The cocoanut.
Having cotyles.
Having seeds grooved lengthwise on the inner face, as in sweetcicely.
